IN C O LU M N TW O 
The S.A. hotel rbom 
9 that never was 
By JE S S E CLEMENTS 

San Antonio’s new-hotel boom has gone flat because there was never a real boom. 

Since 1973 som e $1oo million in pro­ jects with 3.834 hotel room s have been announced for downtown San Antonio. 
So far none of the projects have got­ ten beyond the drawing boards. 
Voters reject school bonds 

By LIZ SWEET 
A narrow margin of 498 votes spelled defeat for the San An­ tonio School District s $49 mil­ lion bond issue Saturday. 

In an extremely light voter turnout, the proposed bond p ro gra m ’s received only 8,835 votes while 9,333 votes were cast against the plan. 
A total of 18,168 votes were cast in a district with more than 1oo,ooo eligible voters. 
C h a rlo tte T r a v i s , f o r m e r S A S D board candidate and opponent of the bond issue, said the m a ssiv e air con­ ditioning plan and the huge amount of taxes that would result defeated the program. 
Mrs. T rav is, a m e m b e r of the re ­ cen tly fo rm e r A la r m e d T a x p a y e r s 
SASD. said the result showed the m a ­ turity of voters listened to the points that opponents s t r e s s e d d u rin g the campaign. 
Analyze 
“ We hope now the board will analyze the district’s needs and come up with a new plan that is not quite so large. 
“ We a re not a g a i n s t a bond issue—just this particular p a c k a g e .’ ’ 
Mrs. Travis said. 
Dr. William Elizondo, board p resi­ dent and le a d e r of the b o n d s s u p ­ porters, said he cannot believe r e si­ dents of the San Antonio School D is­ trict actually would vote against the children 
“ It is difficult for me to believe that citizens of this com m unity who have cried over the deterioration of the in­ ner city continually for the last decade would tie against the biggest oppor­ tunity the city h as had in y e a r s to breathe new life into its inner core,” 
Dr. Elizondo said 
Rehabilitation 
The board p resid en t sa id he will continue to work for the rehabilitation of the inner schools. 
“ We won t stop trying. We will con­ tinue to concentrate on the b asics of reading, writing and arithm etic. We will bring quality ed u cation to this district, even if we have to wait a while before our educational plants are im- prov tx!. 

“ And as for our opponents, the en­ em ies of the children, we will m ake sure you know mon* about them by the time we schedule our next bond elec­ tion,’’ Dr. Elizondo said. 

TI** bond program would have called for the c o n s tr u c tio n of e ig h t new schools and renovation and air condi­ tioning of existing facilities. 

D istrict o ffic ia ls had p ro je c te d a property tax increase to finance the bond issue from $1.82 per $1o(1 of as- scsstd valuation to $2.1o per SUMI The rate is based on a 6o per cent ratio of assessm ent. 

Only one hotel a p p e a rs definite at this time, with financing assured and construction schedules planned. 
T h re e other m a jo r p ro je c ts have stalled because of financing problem s, a fourth has been shelved and three m ore have quietly died for v a rio u s reasons. 
In the m e a n t im e lo ca l b u s i n e s s leaders and convention executives are wearying of the situation, which they

Ali’s clan having too much fun? 

CHICAGO — Several fundraising tours by world heavyw eight boxing champion M uham m ad All to Arab na­ tions on behalf of the Nation of Islam failed because of drunken and sexual d eb a u ch e ry by m e m b e rs of his e n ­ tourage, says a com plaint iii federal court. 
C onstantine b an g les, the attorney who filed the suit Friday on behalf of a foreign fundraising corporation, would not say whether Alt himself acted iii the m anner described by the suit. 
The complaint asks $:> million in da­ m ages for Garland M Taylor, of < hi- cago, and his firm, the American Ara­ bian Investment Co. 
Attorneys for the Nation of Islam and 
Ali were unavailable for comment.

Rosalynn’s new jungle dress 

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico - First Lady 
Rosulynn (-arter will receive a specially tailored “ jungle" print long dress from 
Puerto Rico’s first lady Hate Romero at a White House luncheon next Monday. 
The cotton and dacron caftan, with a bold and colorful handsereened print depicting the giant ferns of the island’s El Yunque rain for­ est, was created by the Puerto Hico Design 
Institute. 
Mrs. Komero will make the presentation at a luncheon for the wives of the governors of the 5o states and Puerto Rico, government officials said She is accompanying her husband. Gov. 
Carlos Romero Ban d o , to the winter meeting of the National Governor’s Conference.

Fanne down south for movie try 

BUENOS 
.AIRES. 
Argentina 
- 
Fanne P'oxe, the Argentine-born strip­ per once romantically linked to former 
U.S. Rep. W ilbur M ills, has com e hom e to m a k e a m o v ie, and local newspapers say she is in love with her director. 
The 41-sear-old Miss P’oxe, whose real nam e is Annabel Battistella, a r­ rived late T hursday from New York where she lives, and is scheduled to begin filming next week. 
She told reporters that the movie is a light comedy and musical in which she will do a strip-tease number. Its title is the Spanish equivalent of “ Take Care 
Of What’s Up Front. 
One newspaper quoted Miss P'oxe as saying that she plans to m arry Rafael 
Cohen, the director. 
From pew to politics 

ATLANTA - The Rev. Clennon King, who drew nationwide attention when he tried to integrate President C arter’s church in Plains, has qualified to run for the congressional seat vacated by 
U N. Ambassador Andrew Young. 
The Rev. Mr. King, from Albany, 
(la., said he would establish residency in Young’s district by checking into an 
Atlanta hotel. 
King is the seventh c a n d id a te to qualify for the election March 15. 
A state election supervisor said F ri­ day th e m in is te r q u a lified for the election as a pauper, signing an affi­ davit certify in g he can n o t pay the 
SI..‘IOO registration fee. 

Carter will cam paign to; ratify ERA 

WASHINGTON (A P ) — 
Jim m y 
Carter, who wants to bo rem em bered us a president who helped elim inate sex d iscrim ination, has m ounted a quiet campaign for ratification of the 
FRjual Rights Amendment. 
The command post is a tiny office on the second floor of the White House, w here p resid en tia l as s is ta n t M ark 
Siegel is keeping close w atch over three key states that vote soon on the amendment. 
Thirty-five states have ratified Eli A and three more are needed by March 
22, 1979. for the amendment to become part of the Constitution. 
Rescinded 
Three states — Nebraska, Tennessee and Idaho — have rescinded their ra ­ tification votes, but the legality of that move has not been tested and is not expected to be challenged until the required 38 ratification votes, includ­ ing those three, are collected. 
The Carter forces hope that North 
Carolina, Florida and Oklahoma will put it over the top. 
Before he was nom inated. C urter promised a group of women leaders that he would push for ratification. 
Ju st as Lyndon Johnson is r e m e m ­ bered for his efforts to end racial dis­ crimination. Carter added, he wants to be known for his fight against sex dis­ crimination. 
Siegel, a deputy a s s is ta n t to the 
President for policy planning, co m ­ pares C a rte r’s e n d o rse m en t of the 
ERA to his recent letter of support for 
Russian dissident Andrei Sakharov. 
While the P re s id e n t’s feelings on 
Soviet hu m an rig h ts are now well known, Siegel said in an interview , 
“ it's also not unusual for him to make a s ta te m e n t on h u m a n r ig h ts in 
America. He classifies the ERA as a positive statement on human rights.’’

It is said Idi Amin s

Last week

P re sid e n t ( a r te r told reporters in Washington that events in U ganda

Country aud o rd e red them to a meeting with hun Munday in Kampala, the capital. 
Message

A m erican blacks to vote for him. 
T hro u g h the y e a rs 
Amin. a former Ugandan heavyw eight boxing ch am p io n , has th ru st himself into world head­ lines. 
• 
He has said 
Hi­ tler was "rig h t to burn six million Jews.” 
•He fired 
Princess 
P.lizabetlt

 the Ugandan diplomatic delegation from 
W a­ shington. 
'T h e re a re c e rta in th in g s you ju st c a n ’t tolerate, and having the rep rese n tativ e s of this killer in the United States is one of them .” 
“ All men are both good and bad and presidents are also m en,” Idi Amin once said. “ We must re­ spect our p re s id e n ts , even if they become so bad we have to remove them . We m ad e th em presidents, if they were bad we have ourselves to blame.” 
Sorceress 

Most biographies say 
Amin was born some­ time in 1925— they don’t know exactly when— in the Moslem and Kakvva tribal district of extreme northwest Uganda. The b io g rap h ies say his m o th er, who had a reputation as a sorceress, left the area when Idi was very young and that he had little contact with his lather, a |H*usant farmer. 
But Amin told a differ­ ent story at a meeting in 
1975 of the Organization of 
A frican 
Unity in 
Kampala. 
He said he was horn in 
1928 in a police barracks that once stood ut the site of the m eetin g . 
He claimed his father was a pollee sergeant. 
From the begin n in g o f his rule Amin resorted to outrageous rhetoric and general clowning 

Amin was a v illage tyr­ ant. An U gandan court sentenced Hills to death, and only after the inter­ vention of the British and 
Zaire governm ents, did 
Amin spare the Briton s life. 
Landlocked 
Amin governs a land­ locked nation that is about the size of Oregon. 
Because of its mountains and lakes the East-Central 
A frican n ation s o m e ­ times is culled the Swit­ zerland of Africa. Its ii ti million |M'opie come from various A frican trib e s and they make their living mostly off the land. A chief export is coffee. 
Last year U ganda sold 
2.43 m illion 132-pound bags of coffee abroad. 
But the leadership aud personality of Idi Amin are what has m ade 
U ganda a known word around tile world. 
"A stench comes forth from ev e ry th in g a s ­ sis lated with Rh Amin.” said Dr Thomas Melody, the lust A m erican a m ­ bassador to Uganda, who called on 
P re s id e n t 
(’arte r F rid a y lo expel 

Biographers say he had only a p a rtia l g ra d e school education before joining the 
K i n g s 
African Rifles in 1948. when Uganda was a Bri­ tish protectorate. 
“ I never had any for­ mal education—not even a n u rsery school c e r ­ tificate,” lie once said in an interview. “ True. But sometimes I know more than do cto rs of p h ilo ­ sophy because us a mili­ tary man I know how lo act. I am a m an of a c ­ tion ” 
At ti feet, 4 inches tall and weighing 25o pounds. 
Amin was prime soldier material 
From the beginning OI his rule Amin resorted to outrageous rhetoric and general clowning. 
Lecturing lits propensity for lec­ tor mg world leaders led him to wish President 
R ich ard M 
Nixon “ a speedy recovery” from the W a te rg a te a ffa ir, suggest that P re sid en t 
Gerald R Ford choose a black vice president and advise A rab s la te s to 
“train kamikaze inlets to 

The 3o-year-old Siegel, a former ex­ ecutive director of the Democratic Na­ tional Committee, says he is personally interested in the ERA. 
“ I’m a feminist, and my wife is a feminist,’’ he says. “ I have a son and a daughter, and to me, they’re equal. I want this nation to treat them equal­ l y ” 
White House efforts in N evada on behalf of the ERA were unsuccessful earlier (his month when the a m e n d ­ ment was defeated in the state legisla* ture. The P re sid e n t had sent tele* gram s to all state senators and most of the assembly, he called three senators who were wavering and he spoke tvv iii* with Gov. Mike O’Callaghan. 
Interior Secretary Cecil Andrus con­ tacted several lawmakers, Mrs. Carter called the wife of a legislator, and Judy 
Carter, wife of the Carter’s son. Jack, testified on behalf of the ERA. 
In his message to some Democratic members. Carter expressed sympathy with pressures applied by opponents of the p]RA but added: “ I want you to know just how important it is to me, our party and my adm inistration.” 

To other la w m a k e rs, he sa id r a ­ tification of the ERA is crucial. 

Despite the presidential lobbying, the State Assembly on Feb. 12 rejected the amendment, 24-15. 

The North Carolina Senate will vote on the ERA this week, and Siegel Is assessing what personal lobbying ef­ forts. if any. the P re s id e n t should make. 

S ecre ta ry of C o m m erce J u a n i t a 
Keeps, whose home is in North C a­ rolina. testified on behalf of the ERA before tho state Senate last week, and 
Mrs. Carter has telephoned Gov. Jim 
Hunt, a strong ERA advocate. 
Approved 
The N orth C aro lin a 
House narrow ly ap- jiroved the ERA on Feb. 
9. 
Siegel regards person­ al presidential lobbying as a prec ious resource to be used only when a b ­ solutely necessary. 
“We have to he careful because one of the issues raised by ERA opponents is c riticism of outside in­ tervention in a state,” he says. 
P h y llis Sehlafly, n a ­ tional chairman of an or­ g anization called Stop 
ERA, has accused Ro- salynn Carter of violating states rights by making calls from the W hite 
House to sta te le g is la ­ tors. 
Siegel stresses that the 
President does not coerce or intimidate. The m es­ sage is said to be posi­ tive. 
“The opponents of the amendment are turning its language around to make it extremely threa­ tening to family life and the legal b en e fits of w o m en ,” Siegel says. 
“ The President is saying that the ERA will not de­ trac t in any way from human rights but add to them.” 
Governors 
Siegel has talked with 
Reubin Askew and Dav id 
Boren, the governors of 
Florida and Oklahom a, about ERA’s chances in their states. Both execu­ tives are Democrats and both support the am end­ ment. 
Askew re p o rted ly is 
’’reasonably optim istic” about the vote of the 
Florida legislature, ex- petted in mid-April. 
Oklahoma, which will probably vote soon after­ ward. is “ very c lo se.” 
Siegel says. But if O k­ lahoma proves to be the lust state needed to ratify the am endm ent, ERA's ch a n ce s would be e n ­ hanced. he adds.

Uganda.

Ins ear, killing hts driver and w ounding 37 ( i s ­ landers.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S — Sunday February 27 1977 8 

PAUL 
THOMPSON 

NEW YORK - Percy E llis 
Sutton, one of the sharpest and best, certainly the m ost talked-about black ever born in 
San Antonio, wasn’t run out of his home town as a youth. He simply opted to leave. 

Today he’s president of the Borough of 
Manhattan and the first officially entered candidate for mayor of New York with a real shot at winning. Old S.A. could sure use two or three like him right1 about now1. 

Okay, so why did Sutton shake his native dust back in the late ’3os? 
“ It wasn’t a matter of hate, bitterness or anything analogous. I got out in order to be what a black in the San Antonio area couldn’t be then — a college student,” he said mat­ ter-of-fact ly. 

Percy Sutton’s showing them all 

“Afterwards, tor reasons just as obvious, there was no point in returning.” 

I interviewed Percy Sutton in his down­ town Manhattan office suite. He’s an urbane man of easy warmth and a full, rich, almost hypnotic voice. He can really talk, this man 
The words roll out of his mouth, as someone once said, “ like little helium balloons” — with a vocabulary to match. 
But under the g racio usness and the virtuoso delivery, as Big Apple pols have long since found, lies the cat-quick mind of a tough and unbending pragmatist. 
Sample: I asked Sutton if Alex Haley’s TV epic “ Hoots” hadn’t produced a groundswell of public sympathy for blacks that could help his New York campaign. 
“ Forget it,” he shot back. “ This is a hard town, unsentimental, with a broad diversity of ethnic groups, none commanding more import or pull with voters than the rest. 
“Nothing on TV or in a book can, will or — carrying it a step further — should change that." 

With a wink, he added: “ If elected, it will be on the basis of my well-known capacities 
— a skilled negotiator, good sound adminis­ 

 trator and fiscal expert at a time of great need.” 
Sutton’s memories of his boyhood in San 
Antonio are a mixture of sweet nostalgia and deep devouring revulsion at all the guff a black had to put up with in those days of .lim 
Crow and second rate citizenship in Texas 
“We were known as ‘coloreds’ then, and whites in the Alamo City didn’t want us ar­ ound,” he says. 
“ Looking back, it seem s as though I couldn’t get in anywhere. And that went for public facilities like theaters or concert halls as well as private places of business like ham-and-egg restaurants. 

“ Movie houses had crow’s nests then. small, cramped and crummy lofts with their own concession stands. It was that or no vestige of public entertainment for the ‘co­ loreds.’” 

Fifty-six-year-old Sutton said it would have been near-suicidal for a black to rebel or act up in those days. 
“Thanks to my wonderful father and mother, I became a professional survivor. I decided to take it. that is, in order to make it. 
But you’ve no idea how galling it could be to 

 have some lout, clearly inferior in every important way. tap you on the shoulder on a trolley car or bus, and order, ‘Move out, boy, and make it fast!’ ” 
Sutton said blacks traveling by automobile then had to pack food or suffer hunger pangs en route. 
“ Fating places and rest stops along tilt' road weren’t about to accommodate us. ll s hard for Americans today, even in Texas, to believe how dehumanizing it was. 
“ And for me, it was all the more mystify­ ing because our comfortable family home was in a partly integrated area, at Cherry and Dawson streets, where I was fully ac­ cepted by resident whites and 
Mexican-Americans. 
“But once I left that section of town, I was a pariah, a social leper.” 
Ile reserves a special animus for the San 
Antonio prohibition of that period against black youngsters visiting Brackenridge Park and the zoo there. 
“ We were allowed in once a year — on 
.nineteenth, or June 19, the day in 1865 when slav es in Texas were finally set free. 
“On all other days, we black kids had to watch the enormously captivating zoo ani­ mals from afar. I particularly recall a cuddly 

 little brown bear guarded by a police­ man on un open zoo lot 
“ Lord, how I wanted to get in and play with that bear. I was eight years old, as I re ­ member, and heartbroken over the distance between us. I just knew the delightful little bear, given a chance, would love me as I loved him. 
“But no. I kept hovering... and hovering. 
But it wasn’t to he." 
With a strange, almost mystic gleam in his “ eye, man-of-the-world Percy Sutton harks back to what happened next. 
“ My mind for the very first time turned to thoughts of politics,” he said, and explained 
“ I began spuming a boyhood fantasy, al­ ways the same, a lovely, soul-satisfying daydream iii which I grew up to be mayor of 
San Antonio and then, as my Number One official act. I fired the cop guarding my friend, the little brown b e a r .” Well, of course, that wasn’t to be either. 
The cop was never fired, at least not by 
Sutton, and tin* San Antonio-born descendant of a slave went on to peg his youthful fantasy a whole heap of notches higher — to be mayor of the biggest city of them all 
! 
And when you come right down to it, it’s not really that fantastic any more, is it? 
» 
COPS hits 
The Suttons of San Antonio: plan on gas settlem ent 

By SARA MARTINEZ 
Mayor Lila Cockrell has a responsibility to confront 
Gov. Dolph Briscoe about a ceiling on the cost of gas, the 
Communities Organized for Public Service president said 
Saturday. 

From slavery to leadership 

“Just as we (COPS) confront the mayor, she should confront the governor,” Beatrice Gallego said. “ She has a responsibility to the citizens of San Antonio to do so. 
“The COPS’ position has been not to sign the gas settlem ent until the demands of bringing the governor and the Railroad Commission before the citizens are met so we can get a ceiling on the gas. 
“ Now the mayor is calling a 7:3o a m. meeting Monday to decide on the gas settlement. What is the big rush?” 
Decision deadline 
Mrs. Gallego said San Antonio had until Ju n e 3o to m ake a decision whether to accept the out of court settlement with Coastal States Gas 
Corp. and Lo-Vaca Gathering Co. 
“ We object to any closed-door deci­ sion making," she said. 
“ There should be an open, public meeting so the citizens can see how the decision was reached.” 
The president said she was certain the meeting would not be an informa­ tional one. “There is no such thing as a closed-door informational meeting. 
“ Any decisions concerning major issues in San Antonio have been made behind closed doors,” Mrs. Gallego said. 
Mrs. Gallego said there were pos­ sibilities COPS would be at the meet­ ing. “ At this point in time we are not sure. W'e will wait until Monday before planning counteraction.” 
“ The whole thing smells. It is ob­ vious she is bowing to Oscar Wyatt and all the ‘I owe you s.’ 
“ Money has a bigger influence in the city of San Antonio then the suffering 

Sunday ideas 

'Indoors, 
.outdoors, all around the River City 

T / i c r e should he un open , p u b lic m eetin g so the ci­ tizens can see how the deci­ sion was reached' 

 of the people. The mayor is not think­ ing of the citizens who are on fixed incom es and who have to decide whether to buy food or pay their bills. 
“ The mayor committed herself at the public hearing and again at Mon­ day’s meeting with COPS leaders to bring the governor and the Railroad 
Commission to San Antonio to address the cost of gas before signing the gas settlement. 
“ The mayor asks tor cooperation and w hen we cooperate, this is w hat we get — closed door meetings and closed door decisions. 
“ We protest the way the gas sett­ lement is being handled by the mayor and we demand that she follow up on her promises and committments to the citizens.” 
Percy Sutton 

By JIM MCCRORY 
It’s a lontf way from a small, sun-baked San Antonio farm to a viable candidacy for mayor of 
New York City. 

If the candidate is black, grandson of a slave and raised in an environment where he couldn’t use city parks be­ cause he was black, the way is even longer. 
But Percy Sutton, president of Man- hatten Borough, made the jump, and this year stands for mayor of The Big 
Apple. 
Election to that post, of course, would make Sutton the most powerful black politician in the nation, the one in closest position ever to make a race on down the road for the presidency of the U. S. 
Percy Sutton’s mercurial rise is one of the most remarkable progressions in American history, but it is only a chapter in a saga of upward mobility by a family exceptional by any stan­ dards—the Suttons of San Antonio 
The Manhattan Borough president was the youngest child in a family that

Hoorn of the Convention Center, according to City Mgr. Thomas 
E. Huebner.

April 7, on the required budget modifications for revenue sharin g funds from the eighth entitlement period. 
The Office of Revenue Sharing of the 
U.S. Department of the Treasury has confirmed allocation of $7,683,792 for the city. Huebner said. 
Comments

On March IO, Huebner will present to council his proposed use of revenue sharing funds and a modification plan to the city budget as req u ired by federal law.

Vehicles banned in 
Rom e’s center cityrn 

RONO' (AP) — More than 2,ooo years after Julius Caesar tried it, 
Rome’s Marxist government banned vchicles Saturday from part of the city’s historic and eternally clogged center. 
Congestion and pollution were cited as reasons for closing part of the right bank of the Tiber River to all cars but those of residents and trucks supplying 
Imal stores 
The zone includes the Piazza Far- nest*, site of the French Embassy, and the square of Cam|M> dei Fiori, both 
(topular tourist areas 
Along with areas dosed off some 2<l years ago, alxiut 46o acres of the center city arc now off limits to most traffic. t amar decreed “ no wheeled vehicles whatsoever within the city” in 44 B C, 
Since then, various popes ami even 
Dictator Mussolini have tried it with varying degrees of success, 

 be passed on March 17 setting a public hearing for April 5 on the budget modification which allocates the funds, 
Huebner said. 
The adopted budget calendar then specifies formal council action on 
April 7, enacting the budget modifica­ tion which allocates the revenue shar­ ing funds. 
The final budget as enacted by council will In* available for public in­ 

 spection within 3o days of enactment. 
Federal law specifies senior citizens and their groups be provided an op­ portunity to be heard and present their views on revenue sharing allocations. 
To assist this effort, the Metropoli­ tan San Antonio Nutrition Project will provide transportation for representa­ tives from its 24 congregate sites to and from the public hearing Monday, 
Huebner said. 

San A ntonio's own Roots 

 produced 15 children, all born iii the same family home in the black com­ munity on the East Side of San Anton­ io. 
Achievers 
It was, and rem ains, a family of achievers not only assimilated into the mainstream under adverse conditions, but coming into positions of power based on the tenacity and capabilities of its individual members 
Along the way, education was the key and politics was the door by which members of the family moved ahead. 
The sturdy branch of the Sutton fa­ mily tree was Samuel Johnson Sutton and his wife, Mrs. Lillian Violet Smith 
Sutton. 
Samuel Sutton came to San Antonio from Richmond, Va., son of a former slave and dock worker who vowed his son would never undergo what he went through in his lifetime. 
Lillian Sutton came from a French 
Creole family in New Orleans, and she met Samuel while a student in one of his classes at a small college in 
Seguin. 
Indians 
John Sutton, now 79 and the oldest child born lo the Suttons, said his father came to Texas in search of his roots. The grandfather, .John explains, had heard there were Suttons who moved to Texas and integrated with the Indians. Sam uel’s search, John reports, took him into Mexico before he finally settled in Texas. 
Percy and John Sutton differ on the status of their father. Percy, the youn­ gest child, insists his father was horn a slave. John, a retired biochemist and scientist specializing in agriculture, insists it isn’t so. Records are unclear on the m atter, although one family background report says Samuel Sutton was born in 1863 The same record re­ flects Mrs Lillian Sutton was born in 
•873 
A d au g h ter, Mrs. Lillian Sutton- 
Taylor (she uses the double family lame) tends to agree with John that heir father was lairn a free man 
Mrs. Sutton-Taylor, a widow, is re­ cognized as the family historian and he one child credited most after the 
>arents themselves for the education 
»f her younger brothers and sisters. 
’Couldn't be’ 
“ Father couldn’t have been a slave,” 
>he explains. “ Percy has it wrong lie’s the baby of the family and knows less about it. He came late and left 
*arly.” 
Both 
John 
Sutton and 
Mrs. 
Sutton-Taylor tell a fascinating talc on ane of the founding ancestors, the man 

 who may have been the patriarch of the family. 
John, who now lives in New York and is administrator of the Sutton Fund for 
Educational 
Research. 
Inc . i i i between lecturing and writing, reports his great grandfather, was Pierre Sui ton, an English sea captain who rode a slave ship plying its trade between 
Afriea and Norfolk, Va The captain, 
John says, retirer! and settled iii Nor­ folk. 
“ We’re the Suttons of E ngland,” 
John Sutton laughs. 
He notes that brother Percy’s son is named Pierre after the old sea captain 
Forced 
The children of Captain Sutton, John insists, were pressed into slavery after his death, and remained in sla­ very until the Emancipation Procla­ mation and the Civil War. 
Mrs. Sutton-Taylor generally sub­ stantiates John iii his story of the family antecedents, including Captain 
Sutton and his connection with the slave trade. 
“ Daddy told us as it was told to him," sin* said. 
Here is what John Sutton has to say about Captain Sutton and the woman he claims was his great grandmother: 
“ According to information given us by Samuel Johnson Sutton, our father, our great grandfather was a Captain 
Pierre Sutton, an Englishman, a white, captain on one of the last English slave ships. 
“Our great grandmother was a slave of Pierre Sutton, a beautiful young girl of A frican arid A m erican Indian ancestry. Captain Sutton is said to have died and left his children, a boy and two girls, free, but they were pressed into slavery after his death.” 
Educator 
Samuel and Lillian Sutton came to 
San Antonio in 1893. Ile became tbt* city’s first black high school principal and remained principal for 
3o years Ills wife also was a leacher for a few years until their marriage 
Pupils recall Samuel Sutton’s philo­ sophy was simple, and easily remem­ bered. “ Do right,” he said. To a stu­ dent shining Ins shoes during one of 
Sutton’s classes, Samuel Sutton ad­ vised: “ Son, son. shine your brain al­ so.” 
Samuel and Lillian Sutton became parents of 15 children, all born in the old family home on th** city’s East 
Side Th** location now is the site for th** family-owned mortuary business. 
One of the first blacks in the South to serve on a grand jury the immediate 
Reconstruction era. Samuel Sutton augmented his teaching and adminis­ trative income by becoming Involved iii operating a grocery store, a shoe store, and a skating rink. Al the rink.

JOSKE’S 

A U N IT or ALLIED STOAKS 

BALLET M exico Espana p erfo rm s native dances for Joske’s Festival of the Arts audience 
— Photos bv E lle n S a w y e r 
Artists display talents 

Nearly 1.o(H) artists, exhibitors, and performers displayed their arts, crafts and talents Saturday at the fifth annual Festival of the Arts in .Joske’s downtown store. 
The day-long festival was sponsored by Joske’s of 
Texas and the Arts Council of San Antonio, Inc. 
Among the exhibits display were jewelry, art pastels, photographs, breaddough creations, flower peds, and leather handicrafts. 
Music performances included the San Antonio 
College trombone choir, the Walker-Ford Singers, and the Wheatley High School Eagletones. 
Theater 

The Educational Arts Clearing House presented 
“ The M iracle,’’ the Chicano Arts Theater dram a­ tized “ Birth of the Mestizo,” and The Little People 
Puppet Company presented perform ances of “ The 
Mother Goose Review.” 
Delighting crowds were dance perform ances in the toy departm ent by the Ballet Mexico Espana with Mexican and Spanish folk dances from the regions of Michiocon and Jalisco. 
Stefania’s Dance Gallery presented a dem onstra­ tion of belly dancing and adult tap dancing. 
The San Anotonio City R ecreation D ancers attracted shoppers with lively renditions of jazz, tap, ballet, and folkloric dancing. 
In other areas of Joske’s Alamo Plaza branch, crafts were demonstrated by the Southwest Craft 
Center, the Fiber Designers’ Creative Stitchers, and the city’s Parks and Recreation Department. 
Registration nears end 
San Antonians not yet registered to vote have until Thursday to do so, if they want to cast ballots in the April 2 city elec­ tion. 
City C lerk G arland 
Jackson said citizens who do not already have a valid voter registration certificate may get one at the registration office in the basement of Bexar 
County Courthouse. 
Absentee voting for the 
April 2 election of a mayor and IO city council members begins March 
14 and continues through 
March 2o. 
Sites chosen 
Five sites have been selected for location of absentee polls during that period. They in ­ clude: 
• City Hall, second floor. 
• Northwest C enter, 
3HOO block of Fredericks­ burg Road (behind Sav U at the south end of the mall). 
• Windsor Park Mall, 
Walzem Road and IH35. 
• McCreless Shopping 
C ity, 41oo S. New Braun­ fels Avenue. 
• Fdgewood Square, 
11oo block of S. Gen. 
McMullen Drive. 
Absentee times 
Absentee voting will be held from 7:45 a rn. to 
4:3o p.m ., 
Monday through Friday. Jackson 

 said. 
In addition, the polls will be open to receive absentee ballots from 2 to 
6 p.m ., Saturday and 
Sunday, M arch 26-27, 
Jackson noted. 
A runoff election, if necessary, will be held 
April 16. Absentee voting for a runoff election would be held in the same locations, Jackson said. 
Wednesday is the last day for candidates to file for office. 

Train crash injures four 

CHICAGO (AP) - 
An 
Amtrak passenger (ram collided with a freight train on Chicago’s South 
Side Saturday night, in­ juring at least four per­ sons, authorities said. 
A spokesm an at St. 
Anthony’s Hospital said the condition of the four persons th ere was not immediately known. 
Fire officials said the passenger train collided with a freight tra in , sending some cars off the tracks at 38th and W e s ­ tern Avenue. 
A police spokesm an said neither train was going very last and that one of the injured was an engineer on one of the trains.

Start o f a snowman 

CARL N IC H O LS, 5, starts building a snowman at his Amarillo home after two or more inches hit the Texas Panhandle 
Friday and Saturday. — AP Wirephoto. 
Bickering hurts new agency 

WASHINGTON (A P ) 
— Senate l e a d e rs are promising early action on 
President Carter's plan for a new Department of 
Energy but jurisdictional jealousies in the House may th r e a te n it with delay. 
And while th e re ap* pears to bi* u ide support rn both chambers for the concept of a Cabinet-level energy agency, the m easure's chief Senate backer. Sen. A b ra h a m 
Kibicolf, D-Coiin., says 
Carter must fight hard to get it through Congress. 
“ T h a t 's b ec au s e the bill is so sweeping and f a r-re a ch in g . I'ii q u e s ­ tionably it will shake a lot of the b u r e a u c r a c y and special in te res ts .” 
Kibicolf said in an inter- 
\ iew. adding: 
“ But I’m for the P r e ­ sident's program and 1 11 fight with him." 
Controversial 
One of the more con­ troversial p a r t s of the adm inistration plan is likely to be the proposal to place under a single root p r o g r a m s that regulate energy and ones that promote its develop­ ment, 
Kibicolf acknowledged. 
He said he plans to in­ tr oduce the bill for 
( arter on Tuesday. And lie said his Government 
Affairs 
C o m m itt e e. whose staff members as­ sisted the White House iii drafting the legislation. 

 will begin h ea rings on 
March 7. 
A committee aide said the legislation may be on the Senate floor by early 
April. 
House leaders re­ portedly have not decided yet when to schedule h e a r in g s el­ even what committee or committees will get the bill Three' com m ittees w itll ri\ a1 ju r is d ic tio n over energy matters ap ­ p arently each want a crack at it. 
C a rt e r said Iii' will s u b m it the le gislation early this week, to be followed by a more com­ prehensive energy policy proposal around April 2o. 
The 
White 
House delivered d rafts of the reorganization bill to key m e m b e r s of C o n g res s late last week. 
Replace 
The proposed new 
Cabinet ag en cy would replace tin* p re s e n t 
Federal Energy Admin­ istration. the Energy Ke- seareh and Development 
A d m in is tra tio n . the 
Federal Power Commis­ sion. parts of the Interior 
Department aud about a dozen other energy pro­ g r a m s now s c a t t e r e d throughout the g o v e r n ­ ment. 
Carter plans to nomin­ ate his energy adviser. 
•lames R. Schlesinger. to head the new department once 
C on g res s gets around to creating it. 

Carter hit on new program s 

WASHINGTON (AP) - P resident 
Carter's first federal spending plan reveals increased aid to financially strapped American cities, but an in­ fluential mayors' group says Carter has ignored the need for new social initiatives, such as health insurance or welfare reform. 
C a r t e r ’s budget would i n c r e a s e funds in areas such as public works and c o m m u n ity d e v e l o p m e n t , but 
Carter seeks cutbacks in programs to battle urban crim e and he seeks no increase in job opportunities for teen­ agers in the central cities. 
Many m a y o r s had hoped C a r t e r would seek to put into effect the initial 

 steps of a national health insurance program and a welfare reform pack­ age. However, Carter seeks funds only to conduct studies for such sweeping changes. 
The U.S. Conference of Mayors, iii a budget analysis released Satu rd ay , said: “ In many budget areas, impor­ tant urban program s have been cut below fiscal 1977 levels or their growth restrained to rates of increase well below the inflation rate.” 
City officials say Carter may have deliberately short-changed the domes­ tic p r o g ra m s , b elieving C o n g r e s s would seek higher spending in these areas no matter what levels he set. In 

 fact. Congress is expected to double 
Carter's request for $2 billion in public works jobs aid. 
The mayors conference praised in­ creases in com munity developm ent and anti recession aid. but said the 
Carter budget is inadequate for mass transit and youth employment needs 
Another u r b a n lobby g r o u p , the larger and more conservative National 
League of Cities, expressed dismay at cuts in crime-fighting funds. 
With summer approaching, city of­ ficials are afraid that continued high unemployment among city teen-agers could lead to trouble in the streets. 
Big-city mayors who met with Carter 

 during December came away with the impression “ that he was extre m ely sensitive to the needs of the cities, says John G unther, d irec to r of the 
Conference of Mayors. 
Perhaps we were encouraged beyond reality. 
Follow Ford 
The first budget by a Democratic president in eight years is based lar­ gely on the one s u b m i t t e d by his predecessor, Republican Gerald Ford. 
Gunther called the Ford budget plan 
“ vindictive to the citie s” and c o m ­ plained that Carter built his budget around the 
Ford p ro p o s a l, 
“ a document that contained far too little money for ttit' cities 
JOHN GUNTHER 

Bill is going back where it’s peaceful 

TALLAHASSEE. Fla. (AIM - After a ii I ne-y out­ lay off, Bill White says he is ready to resume his old occupation — being buried alive in a six-foot coffin tor months at a time. 
White announced Saturday that he will go under­ ground next week as a trial run to get ready for an assault on the current world record of 1o1 days 
The trial run, planned a s promotion for a l a b lahassee restaurant, vtill last about three weeks, far shorter than White's personal record of 83 days. 22 hours and 31 minutes, set during a stay in Austin, 
Tex. in WW. 
Health 
White swore off going u n d erg ro u n d al ter the 
Austin stunt because he said his health was broken. 
But White, who has been earning some money as a singer, soul Saturday he is ready to go again, partly as a matter of personal pride to reclaim the world record 
“ I ve already been in t ra i n in g for about two w eeks," White said. “ Eve given up booze, which can get you in trouble underground Eve cut down on my smoking, and Eve been running so much I feel like a road runner." 
White said he needed the Tallahassee trial run to get menially prepared for the record attempt, pos­ sibly in Niagara Falls, Ont., this summer. 
“ When you stay in that box for a long time, you begin to feel like your whole head is mashed flat B’s hard to get yourself mentally prepared to take that again,’’ said White. 42. 

White, a Tallahassee resident, was billed as the 
“ Living Corpse" during his 4H stays underground from 1HH4 to I BBH 
He said lie took up the work, which was used as promotions for everything from shopping centers to mobile homes, as a way to earn a living after serv­ ing a live-yeur prison sentence for forgery 
Ills manager. Ken Frisbee, who is also owner of the restaurant, said arrangements have been made for a local radio station lo do live broadcasts from the coffin, which also would be equipped with telephone and a citizen band radio 

W lute s coffin, which will lie six feel underground, also will Im* equipped with a light, televfson and vents through which food aud oxygen can ive passed to hill).

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS Sunday February 27 1977 

History in the scrapbook 

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sutton are pictured (far left) with their I 2 children who grew to adulthood. 
In the insert is Dr. Carrie Jane Sutton Brooks. Seated from left are G .J., Percy, Lillian, Samuel, A.C. and Lillian Sutton-Taylor. Standing from left are Essie Sutton, Mrs. Smithe Henry, Samual J. Jr., 
John W ., William N., Cora Jackson and Oliver C. Sutton. Everyone in this picture graduated from college. At the farm (above) were, from left, Samuel Sutton, Lillian Sutton-Taylor, Lillian B. Sutton, 
Lura Mae Sutton, A.C. Sutton, G .J. Sutton and Jeffery Dean Sutton 
Greene. The famous Dr. 
Booker T. Washington, third from left in front row (below), was guest of honor at a Sept. 26, 1911 dinner held by Samuel J. Sutton, second from right in back row. Dr. Washington was the second black American to be admitted to the U.S. Hall of Fame. 
They’ve come a long way 

 e ve r. is being co ntested by a disgruntled opponent whom lie defeat­ ed in the election. The opponent claim s election irreg u larities, but the Rev. 
Mr. Sutton pooh-poohs the accusations. 
T h e R e v. Sutton w o rks for B e x a r 
County in juvenile delinquency control. 
Impact 

But the Sutton who stayed and made the biggest impact on Texas and San 
Antonio was (i. .I Sutton, who died in 
197ti. 
(I. J. cracked the color line first in 
194:1. becoming the first black in the 
South since Reconstruction Days to win a metropolitan elective post when he was elected to the San Antonio 
Pinon Ju n io r College Board 
He was tin* first black from Bexar 
County since R eco n stru ctio n to be elected to the Texas House of Repre­ sentatives, a feat he accomplished in 
1972. Once elected, (I. J . was selected by fellow black legislators as chairm an of the Texas Legislative Black Caucus. 
Back in 1957. G. J . was forcibly re­ moved from the gallery of the Texas 
House when he protested the passage of a packet of segregation “ hate” bills. 
The bills were subsequently declared unconstitutional by the courts. 
He was arrested and thrown into 
Bexar County jail in 1972 for p artici­ pating iii a m arch protesting racial d iscrim in atio n , and protested as he was being booked into ja il because there were no black .jail officers. W hen a newspaper ran a picture of him being arrested, he proudly clipped it out. framed it. and gave it prominent dis­ play on a wall of his office 
A long way 

( i . .C's funeral last year reflected how far Texas has come since Texas officials were tossing him out of the 
House g allery and throw ing him i i i jail. 
Texas Gov . Dolph Briscoe delivered a eulogy com m ending Sutton for his service, and Texas political leaders from across Texas, black and white, w ere am ong tin* It.OUI) on hand to m ourn his passing. Texas flag s on state buildings were flown at half staff 

 i i i respect to Ii. .I 
But the beat goes on. 
G .C's widow. M rs Lou Melle Sut­ ton. was elected to replace him in the 
Texas House, the second black to be elected to the legislature from Bexar 
County and the first woman ever. 
She appears a worthy successor to her late husband's causes. 

Court Justice O liver Sutton, all of New 
York; Rev. A. C. Sutton and M rs 
Sutton-Taylor. both of San Antonio, and M rs Cora .Jackson, Mrs. Sm ythe 
H e n ry , and M rs 
E s s ie Sutto n , all teachers or supervisors in the O ak­ land. Calif., school system 
P e rc y Sutton was a tria l la w ye r. 
N A A C P olficial. Freedom R id er and 
New York Assemblyman before being elected Manhatteii Borough president. 
Ile attended Tuskegee. Hampton, and 
Columbia colleges, and Brooklyn Law 
School. 

Jo h n 
Sutton w as a p u p il and assistant of D r. George W ashington 
Carver at Tuskegee* Institute* in Alaba­ ma. When Dr. C arver was invite*el to the* Soviet I lium to elo agricultural re­ search, he declined the offer and sug- gested John go instead. John went and spent seven years in Russia, helping formulate the* Russian five-vear plan. 
The* A fro-A m erican new spaper of 
Ja n . 1H. 194J. carried a letter to the* newspaper from Dr C arver i i i answer to reports he* had bee*n offere*d SI75.(MMI a .year bv the Fdison Foundation and vast sums bv the* Russian government to conduct agricultural experiments i i i 
Russia 
Dr Carve r wrote iii part 
“ The* Russian government did offer me a vast sum. but I could not accept I semi one of my pupils. M r. John Sutton. 

Anti now look al I h o rn 

John Sutton (left), the oldest child of Samuel Sutton, says his great-grandfather was a white English sea captain who transported slaves to Norfolk, Va. A.C. Sutton (below left) was one of the family who elected to remain at home, where he went on to prominence as president of the Texas N A A C P. O liver Sutton 
(below right) went to New York, where he is now a state supreme court justice. He complains there are usually only two black faces in his courtroom 
— his and the defendant's. The late G .J. Sutton 
(right), who was once tossed out of the Texas House visitors' galleries for protesting segregation, went on to win a seat in that same House and serve with distinction. Succeeding G .J. after his death is his wife, Lou Nelle Sutton (far right), who is Bexar County's first woman legislator. 

From slaveship backgrounds to modern frro 

 who has been there about seven years, is doing rem arkably well .” 
Judge O liver Sutton was a m unicipal judge before winning his current New 
York Suprem e Court bench. He is a graduate of Tuskegee Institu te and 
Brooklyn Law School. On a Texas v isit to see a younger brother. G. J . Sutton. sworn iii as a Texas leg islato r, the judge said that far too often in his courtroom he sees only two black faces 
— his and that of the defendant at bar 
M rs Sutton-Taylor graduated from 
Fisk and Columbia universities. A re­ tired school teacher, she is active in civil rights and religious work. Like brother John, she is writing a book. 
M iss Essie Sutton recently took 29 handicapped persons, most of them children, on a 29-day tour of W ashing­ ton. 1). C.. New York City, and other points 
It would be sim plistic to say Percy left San Antonio tor New York solely because he was thrown out of a city park because of his race, but is was a contribuing factor. 
John, too 

John left San Antonio for much tin* same reason 
“ I left San Antonio because I didn't like the place." John says now He is in 
San Antonio on a v lsit. 
He recalled when he wasn't allowed in the city’s public library because he was black, even though his father was a high school principal 
Ironically, as director of the Sutton 
Educational Research Fund, John has channeled funds to the San Antonio public library system, but earm arks it for the C arver branch of the system serving tin* black community. 
Not all of the p o litically inclined 
Suttons elected to wash their hands of 
San Antonio and Texas in the face of blatant d isc rim in a tio n for g reen er pastures up East 
The Rev A C. Sutton (the C. stands for C a rver) stayed, as did Mrs. Sut- ton Tavlor A I 
Sutton also is a Tus­ kegee graduate, and he is president of the Texas N A A C P. Ills election, how- 

( ontinued from Page .JA 

 couples could do fancy skatin g. Gut d an cin g w as taboo. S a m u e l w as a 
God-fearing Baptist. 
T w elve of the la Sutton c h ild re n grew to adulthood , and a ll 
12 graduated from colleg es or u n iv e r­ sities. Ten took post graduate courses, and four obtained m aster's degrees. 
Diverse 

The degrees led indiv idual members of the fam ily into politics, law. m edi­ cine, science, agriculture, education, and social work. 
How did a poor black fam ily educate 
12 children in colleges and universities scattered across the country? The Sut­ ton fa m ily used the s ta irc a s e a p ­ proach. sending the oldest child to col­ lege and expecting him to help educate tin* son or d a u g h te r fo llo w in g . It worked successfully on down the line 
Percy was the luckiest child, perhaps 
He was the last of the la children and had no following brothers and sisters 
Maybe that is why In* is the most af­ fluent member of the fam ily today. 
The fam ily still retains the m ortuary business established by the fath er, some rental properties, and tin* 89-acre farm w here Sam uel Sutton received the injuries which led to his death at age 87. He received a broken pelvis when a calf threw him down. and died of an em bolism i i i a local hospital 
M rs Sutton -T aylor, a lady of quiet d ig n ity , re c a lls his death cam e as neighboring ch u rch bells tolled out 
1959 and rang in 1951. 
T h e widow live d fo r an o th er 29 years, but also was to die tragically 
She succumbed to burns received iii a fire at her home in 1971 
She was 97 years old. 
Eight of the Sutton children survive. 
T h e re ’s P e rc y . Jo h n , and Su p rem e 

. 
,<* V 

In a recent protest of the Texas death penalty , for example, sin* declared; 
"W h e n the first Texan flies in the electric chair, be he black, brown or poor w hite. Jim Crow w ill have his hand on the sw itch.” 
It was a statement that G. J. him self would have been proud to make 
Prov mg tin* fruit never falls far from the tree Ju d g e Sutton s son. O liver 
Jr .. is practicing law in his father’s old home town as an a ss is ta n t B e x a r 
County district attorney 
As tor Sam u el's oldest son, Jo h n . lie s looking forward to a visit from Ins son. Ju a n Jo h n o v ic h Setto n . from 
Russia. Setton? John explains there s no “ i i ” sound in Russian, and thus no 
Sutton. 
Ju a n w as born of Jo h n Sutton s m arriage to a Russian woman who has since died. John subsequently m arried his present wife. Bessie, and both live 

 i i i New Y ork 
And Juan Setton? A Russian citizen, he has children of his own. 
Final irony i i i the Sutton story was the refusal late last year by the go­ vernment of South A frica to grant a v isa to Percy Sutton. 

Nations to study ozone threats 

COMPILED FROM WIRE SERVICES 
WASHINGTON - In the aftermath of new studies released last week in Russia and the 
United States, interna­ tional scientists are meeting here Tuesday to study what humans are doing to the stratosphere. 
Scientists from around the world will meet for nine days to study human activities as diverse as the use of fluorocarbon gases in spray cans, ex­ haust gases from high­ flying aircraft and rock­ ets. and the worldwide escape into the atmos­ phere of nitrogen com­ pounds from fertilizers. 
Of particular interest will be the effect of fluorocarbons on ozone in the atmosphere—the subject of studies in the 
U.S. and Russia. 
U.S. study 

In the 
U.S. study released Saturday, scien­ tists at the Commerce 
Department’s National 
Bureau of Standards an­ nounced they discovered that some of the chemi­ cals thought to damage the atmosphere’s protec­ tive ozone layer appar­ ently break down before causing harm. 
But the amount des­ troyed is too small to greatly reduce the over­ all problem, said the 
-scientists. 
They discovered that two implicated fluor­ ocarbon chemicals and another related one break down when ab­ sorbed by sand and bathed in sunlight. 
Dr. Pierre J. Ausloos said this previously un­ suspected breakdown of fluorocarbons illustrates that there may be other unknown processes in nature that affect the amount of fluorocarbons 
Teaching the upper atmosphere. 
But Ausloos said he aloes not believe the process he and Dr, R i­ chard E . Rebbcrt dis­ covered had more than a minimal effect on the to­ tal amount of fluorocar­ bons dumped into the air. 
In Moscow last week, 
Tass 
News 
Agency reported that 
Soviet scientists had found a 
“ greater than normal’’ concentration of chlorine gas in the earth’s upper atmosphere. 
Igor Karol, a Lenin­ grad earth scientist, de­ termined that freon gas represents the single greatest danger to the ozone band. 
Dr. Karol singled out refrigerators as a serious threat to the atmosphere. 
The meeting iii Wa­ shington 
Tuesday is sponsored by the United 
National Environment 
Program and by the 
United States. 
About five months a major report on fluorocarbons and stratospheric ozone, by the National Academy of 
Sciences, emphasized the need for more know ledge of what effects human activities of all kinds are producing on the stratosphere. 
Need laws

The report said that while more study is needed, all indications are that fluorocarbons arc depicting ozone and that some regulation of 
UM* would almost cer­ tainly bi' necessary. 
Since then, the Food and Drug Adm inistra­ tion. the Environmental 
Protection Agency and the Consumer Product 
Safety Commission have taken steps to ban many fluorocarbon uses within two years. 
Fluorocarbon man­ ufacturers say such ac­ tion is premature and should await further study. Chemical com­ panies say unknown reactions, like the one discovered by Ausloos and 
Kehbert. could reduce the threat. 

Put a member of the 
National Academy of 
Sciences panel who studied the problem and 
|s aware of the new Bu­ reau of Standards study said most new data since the academy report strengthens arguments that there is no unknown factor lessening the problem. 
Worldwide concern about fluorocarbons bas 
Increased since 
1974 when a University of 
California computer study indicated the chemicals used in aerosol spray cans and refriger­ ants reached the upper atmosphere.

Continued from Page I V source, who asked that his name not be used. 
He explained many people in the business world noticed the hotel an­ nouncements. When the projects fail to materialize the city’s reputation for getting things done suffers, he said. 
Another critic of the situation, a prominent businessman who asked his name not be published, complained of a lack of support from city government and “ obstructionists” who were more interested in saving old buildings than

 in progress. 
“ I know of those hotels announced publicly. But I also know of at least fixe more which were planned, but fell through for one reason or another.” lie said. 
The number one stumbling block for many of the would-be developers has been financing. 
Discretion 
The Centro 21 source said reporters should exercise more discretion at press conferences on hotel openings. lh1 said developers announcing hotel 
Mental exam is ordered 

S Y K A L E S E , 
N Y . 
(A P)—A judge 
Sa­ turday ordered a psy­ chiatric examination for an unemployed construc­ tion worker accused til holding a pregnant teen­ ager and her bally hos­ tage alter shooting a man to death in an argument over a pack of cigarettes. 
Leroy Cotton, itll, was held without bail after arraignment before City 
Court .Judge -James .I 
Fahey on one count of second-degree murder. two counts of second-de­ gree kidnaping and two counts of reckless endan­ germent 
An attorney was appointed to repre­ sent Cotton at a hearing 
March 21. 
Cotton was arrested 
Friday alter releasing two hostages he held in his apartment for 13*2 hours. 
Police said Cotton ap­ parently tried to borrow a pack of cigarettes from a neighbor. 
George 
Sparks -Jr.. 24, early 
Friday morning. They said an argument broke out. 

 projects should be asked the following questions. 
• Do they have a management con­ tract signed to assure someone is ready to operate the hotel? 
• Do they have both interim and long-term financing arranged? 
• Are all “ city deals” taken care of, such as land acquisitions and zoning problems? 
“ If all three of these items are not taken care of in advance, then they have nothing to announce.” he said flatly. 
These criteria were used by the Ex- pr ess-News in trying to determine ex­ actly where the proposed hotels stand 
The major hotel project with best chances of construction — the only one with assured financing — is the Wes­ tern International plan. 
Ground breaking 

Western International will hold ground breaking ceremonies after the 
Fiesta observance and before summer. said spokesman Ed Klar. 
The 65o-room complex, to cost ap­ proximately $28 million, will be built over the River Walk extension between 
Market and Commerce streets near 
Marina Parking Garage. 
“ We definitely have our financing arranged and are ready to go. We were going to begin immediately, but were asked to hold off until after Fiesta," 
Klar explained 
Money problems 

The King David Hotel, to be located in the South Texas Building, bt 13 Na­ varro St., is reportedly still a definite proposal but its backers admit to hav­ ing problems with financing arrangements. 
But Jack Yaaler, spokesman for developer 
Efraim 
Abramoff. said the $3.5 m illion, 2oo-room project might begin in a matter of a month or so “ if everything goes as planned.” lie emphasized all tenants have been cleared from tile building except for one restaurant, and the development group has added two additional blue- chip investors. 
When questioned on the project’s viability. Yaaler said: “ I can't tell you the hotel is definite We don’t count on anything until we have the money in our hands but I will say we are opti­ 

 mistic.” 
The Plaza National Hotel is also having financing difficulties although its backers insist it is still a live pro­ ject . 
The planned 25o-room. $8.5 million complex would go on property which the group has already obtained from the city. The property lies along Ar- ciniega Street at the intersection of 
Alamo and Durango streets. 
Developer Jose “ Pepe” Lucero said backers have only this week lined up financing and plan to sign the papers within the next IO days. He refused to name tin' money source but hi' had previously indicated backers were looking in Houston and New York. 
“ We’ve invested many man-hours and dollars in this project and are committed to begin construction with­ in the next four months," lie promised. 
The Hyatt Regency Hotel would be a 
2o-story, 75o-room structure costing 
$32 million, but its money sources have also proven elusive. 
“ I ’m not overly optim istic, but neither am I pessim istic.” (about chances for construction) said Edward 
II. Dennis from his office in Montgo­ mery. Ala. 
6-9 months 

The hotel, which would be located on 
Commerce Street between Navarro and Presa Streets, could become a reality with ground breaking in six to nine months if financing can be ar­ ranged, he said. 
Dennis blamed the new federal tax structure for financing problems, cit­ ing a ( hanged amortization schedule and a tightening of expense account deductions for businessmen. 
“ We’ve been working on this thing for over three years and I think it's safe to say. I would not continue to spend my time and money if I thought it impossible," Dennis insisted. 
The city has already agreed to build a huge parking garage nearby to ac­ comodate hotel guests. 
The Sage Western group originally talked of building a 4oo-room structure on Mulberry Street near the North 
Expressway. Plans were later revised to only JOO rooms. 
But spokesman Bart Palm acknow­ ledged the hotel has never been more than a “ concept* which received pub­ 

 licity during a zoning move. 
“ We aren’t planning to do anything at all until the expressway is complet­ ed.” Palm said. 
Three groups are no longer planning developments. 
ILB. Zachry has attempted several times to expand his Palacio Del Rio 
Hotel. Rebuffed on each occasion, he says he now has no plans at all to add the 384 rooms he once wanted to build onto his Hilton by constructing a wing over Alamo Street 
He criticized the City Water Board. 
City Hall and San Antonio Conserva­ tion Society for blocking his moves. 
The water board earlier had refused to allow Zachry to expand the Hilton onto a piece of property the water board owns. 
Assistance 

“ I just wish City Hall would allow me the same assistance they gave many of these other people.” he said. 
Referring several times to the Con­ servation Society as “ The ladies,” he chuckle “ The ladies always get their way.” 
A group known as the Consortium announced in September, 1975. an am­ bitious project of two hotels involving

1,o5o rooms. The largest was to be near 
HemisFair in the block bounded by 
Commerce, Blum . Bowie and Elm 
Streets. 
“ It's as dead as a door nail,” de­ veloper Eugene Dabney told the Ex­ press-News. 
Dabney explained financiers didn't like his planned site and also blamed the controversy over a city-owned parking garage and its relationship to any new hotel. 
Granada Royale 

The Granada Royale Hotel involved 
15o rooms, costing $7.5 million, for the 
Arciniega Street property which was awarded to the Plaza National Group. 
Spokesman L. Low ry Mayes was not available for comment but another source close to the developing group said there were no present plans to put the proposed hotel on another site. 
While downtown hotel projects have stumbled, meanwhile, suburban con­ struction has proceeded. Only major high-rise hotel to open in here in se­ veral vears is the new 1o-story, 
2oo-room 
San 
Antonio/Airport 
TraveLodge. 
It opened last week along IU 41o on the North Side. 
UGANDA 

 the slaughter’s aftermath 
“ All the heads had been smashed in, and the floor was littered with eyes and teeth,” Mugahi was quoted saying. 
“ During the previous night we did not hear any shots, only some thudding noises from the adjoining rooms. 
“ We heard short cries and then sud­ den silence. I think the victims were strangled and then had their heads smashed.” 
Mugabi. a craftsman who said he had been liv ing in the Kampala suburb of Kisenvi, said he was seized by 
Amin s security forces Feb. 17 and thrown in a cell at the Makindve mili­ tary police headquarters because he once had been a supporter of the party led by former President Milton Obote. the man Amin overthrew in January 
1971. 

He said he was freed three days later. 
Mugabi’s story was the latest in a swelling flow of unconfirmed reports from I ’ganda that thousands of people, primarily members of the northern 
Langi and Acholi tribes, have been slaughtered since Amin claimed he uncovered and crushed a plot to overthrow him two weeks ago. 
According to the Ugandan strong­ man. the plot was masterminded by 
Obote and centered among the predominantly Christian Langts and 
A (.'hobs. 
The reports, and particularly the death of Anglican Archbishop Janani 
Luwutn iii what the government said was an auto accident, have drawn howls of outrage from around the world. 

Se c re ta ry of S ta te C y ru s 
Vance talks w ith reporters 

Amin also wired a long and rambling t able to President Carter, telling him the United States should consider its own violations of human rights before meddling in Ugandan affairs. 
Chambers 
Mugabi told the Daily Nation that all prisoners at Makindyc were divided into separate cells for m ilitary per­ sonnel, political prisoners and 
“ elimination chambers." 
On the night of Feb. 18, he was quoted us saying, all the Langi tribes­ men among the prisoners were herded out of their cells and killed. 
The next morning he and other pri­ soners were taken out of their cells, served tea and led into some rooms, where they found a grisly scene, 
Mugabi said. 

Ex-tycoon 
J sentenced 

NEW YORK (A P) - 
Lowell 
B irre ll, a 
7o-year-old former ty­ coon who admitted swin­ dling stockholders out of 
$14 million, has been or­ dered to serv e a one-year sentence in the Bikers 
Island Hospital.

KATHLEEN VOIGT 

DORA GROSSENBACHER 

Ms Kathleen Voigt Chairman 
Board of Directors of San 
Antonio College of Medical and Dental Assistants. Mem­ ber of Texas Proprietary 
Sch o o l C om m ission and member National Association of Trade and T e ch n ical 
Schools, Washington, D.C. 
Ms. Voigt has a BA from the 
University of Texas, Master of Arts in Government from 
St. Mary’s University, San 
Antonio. 

• ADVISORY DIRECTOR • 

Dr. Dora Grossenbacher Dean of students University of 
Texas at San Antonio. She was Dean of Women at St. 
Mary's University for nine years. Received doctorate in 
Education Psychology from the University of Texas at 
Austin. Dr, Grossenbacher was president of the Texas 
Association of Colleges, Uni­ versity student personnel 
Administrators, and is direc­ tor of United Way,

 the House and Senate delegations to 147. 
No new measures were filed last week by 
Bexar County’s Senate delegation. Sen. Glenn 
Kothmann of San Antonio remains the only Sen­ ate delegation member to not have filed a major piece of legislation. 
Bills on record 
By Friday, the House had 1,295 bills on record and i i i the Senate 732 bills were filed 
The status of the latest local interest legisla­ tion pending before the hath Legislature include; 

Don Cartwright, are aimed at denting, or completely stopping. San Antonio’s 
$37) million annual receipts from mun- ieipally-owned City Public Service. 
If the actual cost to the city for the police and fire fighter’s sick pay benefits are vague. Cartwright’s bills leave little doubt as to the fiscal im­ 

 pact they would have. 
Cartwright wants to put a halt to the city’s collection of 11.5 per cent “ off the top” of CPS annual gross receipts. 
The 11.5 per cent is being collected by the city in lieu of taxes and other income it might receive from a priva­ tely owned utility. 
I IBI IRO and 1161 would first prohibit 
CPS from using the 11.5 per cent as an expense item when calculating utility rates to be charged the Bexar County 
Hospital District and 12 school dis­ tricts on its system. 
HBI 161 would further prohibit CPS from adding in the 11.5 per cent on utility bills of any of its customers. 
Announcement of the Cartwright bills brought an immediate battle cry from city hall, when its liaison man to the 65th Legislature vowed to “ fight to kill these bills at any and every level.” 
Cost city 

Jerry Henckel said adoption of 1161 would cost the city between $55 and $37 million in estimated revenues for this fiscal year 
He warned such a loss could only be passed on by the city to property owners in the form of increased ad valorem taxes. 
Cartwright’s bills were introduced on first reading Monday and sent to the 
House Committee on Energy Re­ sources. 
There, when hearings begin, city hall forces can be expected to use all the ammunition at their disposal to 

EXPRESS-NEWS AUSTIN BUREAU 

AUSTIN — Two bills filed here last week have shifted the attention of San 
Antonio city hall, at least temporarily, from Inc controversial police and fire fighter s sick pay issue. 
The bills, filed by San Antonio Rep. 

Status o f bills 

 blast them under the table. 
Meanwhile, the Senate bill to repeal the con­ troversial sick pay law — as far as San Antonio is concerned — is still awaiting hearings before the 
House Intergovernmental Affairs Committee. 
SB459 by San Antonio's Sen Frank Lombar­ di no was referred there Tuesday after its pas­ sage in the Senate on Feb. 17. 
No hearing date has been set on the bill or on a 
House repeal version introduced early in the session by Rep. Abe Ribak of San Antonio. 
Substitute bill 
San Antonio Rep. Jam es Nowlin has also sent a substitute bill to the committee which would leave the entire issue of sick pay in the hands of the San Antonio City Council 
The fact Sen. Lombardinos resolution calling for a constitutional amendment to legalize bingo in Texas for non-profit, charitable organizations has not had a House hearing is also highly spe­ culative. 
Lombardino s S JR 2 went to the House on Feb. 
4 and was referred to the Committee on Consti­ tutional Amendments 
The committee, chaired bv Rep. Tim Von 
Bolden of Goliad, has yet to hold any hearings so far through the seventh week of this legislative session. 
Question l ins proves there s no discrimination against the Lombardino measure but leaves unanswered the question of what s the hung-up in the Von 
Holden panel 
In other action last week. Bexar County's legislative delegation continued to introduce a steady flow of legislation 
Members of the House delegation filed 17 different measures during the week, bringing the total number of lulls and resolutions filed by 

• ll H1122 by State Rep. Roil Bird proposes to exclude advertising costs by utility companies from being included in figuring customer rates. 
It has been referred to the Committee on State 
Affairs. 
• HB11H2 by Rep Don Cartwright which pro­ poses to add state credit unions under the regu­ latory authority of the state Finance Commis­ sion. 
This bill would expand the membership of the 
Finance Commission to 12 from its present membership of nine. The three new members would be assigned to the credit union section. 
Cartw right's bill has been referred to the 
Committee on Financial Institutions. 
• 
H B I 17o by C a rtw rig h t calls for a moratorium on any new installations of elec­ tronic fund transfer systems by banks, savings and loan institutions and credit unions 
( artwright's bill explains there presently is no regulation of such electronic systems used for transferring funds from depositor accounts. 
The bill was referred to the Committee on 
Financial Institutions 
• H BI 171 bv Cartwright would require state agencies which regulate financial institutions to deposit into the state treasury all funds collected from fines, fees, penalities, charges, grants and donations. 
The purpose of the bill is to insure the collec­ tions are spent by the agencies only for purposes authorized bv present laws

Carter on defense cut 

By DAVID 
MCLEMORE 

Egypt getting 
Arab funding 

CAIRO — Four oil-rich 
Arab countries will pro­ vide E gypt with m ore than $2 billion in funds and deposits to help the country through its econ­ omic difficulties, sources have confirmed. 
A 
Saudi 
Arabian 
Embassy official said the payment would be made within a month and was a huge am o u n t. A high 
Egyptian official said the package from Saudi Ara­ bia. Kuwait, Q atar and the United Arab E m ir ­ ates consists of $1 billion and an equal amount in deposits in the country’s banks to finance invest­ ment projects 

Tower was the featured s p e a k e r at the closing session of the board of the National Federation of Republican Women at the Hilton Palaeio del Rio 
Hotel. 
He urged the women to continue their efforts to stre n g th e n R e p u b lic an positions in the Congress in the upcoming elections in 1978. 
“ I think we ll see that the off-year elections will improve the complexion of C o n g re s s,” he said. 
“ This is the time to pave the way for a return of a 
Republican to the White 
House.”

Sen. Jo h n T ow er said 
Saturday.

G R E E N V IL L E . 
Pa. 
(AP) — A 12-year-old boy was c h a rg e d with m u rd e r and v o lu n tary m a n s la u g h te r i i i the killing of his twin brother and the wounding of a friend. Police said the shooting billowed a squirt gun fight. 

Robert Alexander Jr. was charged Friday after 
Ins brother. Ronald, was shot to death aud a com­ panion, David Christy. 
13, was wounded. 

Police Chief Donald 
Reinhart said the victims were playing curds when 
R obert a rriv e d and began s q u irtin g them with a water pistol. 

When the two youths fired back with squirt guns. R obert went u p ­ stairs, returned with bis fath e r's 3o-31) rifle and pointed it at the others. 
Reinhart said The chief said Robert told the two the gun was not loaded. 

R einhart said Robert then went back upstairs and put two bullets i i i the gun and told the other two boys he would shoot them lf they didn t stop squirting hun.

San Antonio EX P R ESS-N EW S — Sunday February 27 1977 
Cost-of-living pay hike hit by Byrd 

How they voted si ii 

W ASHINGTON (A P ) 
— 
Senate 
M ajority 
Leader Robert C. Byrd said Saturday that Con­ gress would be unwise to accept a cost-of-living pay increase due in Oc­ tober after the law ­ makers received a 
$12,9oo annual raise this month. 
Early estimates are that the cost-of-living raise scheduled for all federal employes in Oc­ tober could amount to between $2,8o(1 and $3,7oo for members of Con­ gress. The hike for sena­ tors and representatives w ill become effective au­ tomatically unless Con­ gress takes some action to disapprove it. 
“ There w ill be no problem in finding a way to knock it out.” the West 
Virginia Democrat told reporters. “ If nobody 

There will be no problem in fin din g a way to knock it out * 

 else does it, I ’ll make the effort.” 
Bills to disapprove the costof-living raise for 
Congress have been in­ troduced in the House. 
A similar cost-of-living raise of 5 per cent was to have been added last Oc­ tober. But Congress took positive action to avoid that raise so close to election day. 
The actual amount of the cost-of-living in­ crease scheduled for congressmen in October will be determined later this year. 
A bill introduced in the 
House by 
Rep. 
Hal 
Sawyer, R-Mich., would exempt Congress from the cost-of-living adjust­ ment law. 

“ The people primarily responsible for inflation ought not to be insulated from its impact,” Sawyer said. 
“ Every time Congress spends more money, causing inflation to get worse and prices to go up, congressmen and senators become eligible for another cost-of-living pay raise.” 
Effective 
Because neither house of Congress voted “ no” on a 28.9 per cent raise suggested by a federal pay commission, that raise became effective 
Feb. 2o, making con­ gressional pay $57,5oo a year. 
Salaries for high-leve 

A MONOFLEX ROOF is being applied to this house, that will not only seal the surface against leaks, but will also insulate it against heat and cold. A Monoflex roof can save you hundreds of dollars by reducing your utility costs over the years. N o matter what type of roof you have, Monoflex con be expertly applied directly over your old roof, whether it’s shingles, gravel, metal, or roll roofing. Monoflex can also be applied on your exterior walls for extra insulation. Stop by Coating Specialists at 
11815 
Warfield or call 3 4 9 -6 2 o 4 for a courteous estimate. 
(Pd. Adv.) 

 executive branch em­ ployes, members of the judiciary and Civil Ser­ vice-ranked policymakers also rose. 
‘‘I am opposed to the cost-of-living increase this October going to any of the employes who benefitted from this justifiable increase,” 
Byrd told reporters. 
Part of the controversy over the 28.9 per cent pay raise centered on the way it became effective. Con­ gress established a com­ mission on government salaries in 1967 to make recommendations on pay scales. This commis­ sion’s recommendations become law if they are not rejected by either the 
House or the Senate within 3o days after they are submitted. 
No vote held 
Neither the House nor 
Senate held an up-or- down vote on the pay raise. But each chamber had technical votes which were interpreted by some as votes for or against the raise. 
Byrd, who repeatedly has said that any pay raise ought to be accom­ panied by a revision in the codes of ethics for 
Congress.

House gets bill on agencies end 

Fight may erupt over nurse bill 

By DICK M ERKEL 
EXPRESS N EW S CAPITOl BUREAU 

AUSTIN - An all-out fight could develop here 
Monday when the Senate 
Human Resources Com­ mittee takes up a bill setting stiffer standards for registering nurses. 
The Texas Nurses As­ sociation has issued a warning that organized hospital administrators are engaging in a cam­ paign of deliberate dis­ tortion in an effort to block the bill. 
SB392 by Sen. ll. Tati 
Santiesteban of El Paso will be heard before the committee at 4 p.m. 
Monday in the Senate 
Chambers. 
TNA President Opal 
Stewart of Kilgore is ex­ pected to head the parade of nursing professionals testifying in favor of the bill. Registered nurse 
Ruth Stewart of San An­ tonio is president-elect. 
“ The revision of the 
53-year-old 
Nursing 
Practice Act, as proposed by our organization, would require strict standards for registered nurses who hold the lives of patients in their hands,” she said. 
“ The revised bill will also “ provide enfor­ cement of those stan­ dards, something the current law does not do. 
“ I can’t understand why there is objection to a revision which would halt dangerous practices endangering the lives of countless Texans every year,” Ms. Stewart said 
Saturday.

Our 5-piece oak bedroom set at a solid $1oo savings. 

Sale *799

 they pay for health ser­ vices. Concerned Texas nurses are trying in this bill to see that this occurs.” 

Continuing the TNA president said, “ AH we are asking is for lawful requirement that those who perform pro” fes- sional nursing functions iii hospitals meet min­ imum requirements set by the state.” 

EX PRESS N E W S CAPITO l BUREAU 
AUSTIN - The 
Senate last week passed and sent to the House “ sunset legislation’ ’ which would phase out state agencies once they have outlived their usefulness. 

Sen. Lloyd Doggett’s 
S.B. 54 won final appro­ val by a 25-4 vote, but not until the bill was amend­ ed twice to exempt the 
Texas Railroad Commis­ sion and Agriculture De­ partment of Texas from its provisions. 
All three local senators opposed the amend­ ments. Votes on the chart are for the bill itself. 
Regents 

The Senate also gave final approval to Dolph 
Briscoe’s appointments of Mrs. Jane Blumberg of Seguin, Dr. Sterling IL 
F ly Jr . of Uvalde, and 
Jess Hay of Dallas to the board of regents of the 
University of Texas Sys­ tem. 
Mrs. Blum berg was 

 approved 26-3. Fly by a 
28-1 vote, and Hay by a margin of 23-5 with one senator marked present and not voting. 
Tax break 
The House voted over­ whelmingly Tuesday to exempt residential utility bills from the 4 per cent state sales tax. 
House B ill I by Joe 
Wyatt of Victoria, as re­ drafted by the House 
Ways and Means Com­ mittee, was approved 
13o-9 and sent to the Sen­ ate. 
Doctors 
Legislation to provide state funds to support medical family practice residency programs in state teaching hospitals 
— including Bexar Coun­ ty Hospital — also won final House approval last week. 

HB 8, authorizing the 
Parks and 
W ildlidfe 
Dept, to commission non-payed deputy game wardens, also passed the 
House. 
The bill, by Rep. Fred 
Head of Athens, was sent to the Senate on an 88-48 vote, but the Bexar Con- unty delegation gave it a 
"thumbs down.” 

Defense 
HB812, by Rep. Roy 
Blake of Nacogdoches, also passed the House by a lopsided 138-1 margin on Tuesday. 
The bill allows the state attorney general to defend a state grand jury commissioner, jury member, or state district judge in any federal court action brought as a result of their perfor­ mance of duty.

We bought all the furniture in a famous furniture factory's warehouse! odded! 

A famous factory sold us the "whole thing" ... all the sofas, chairs, loveseats, ottomans, etc. that were on the premises ... at tremendous savings on the condition that we would take it all. We agreed ...and we got their factory sam­ ples, their original models, their experimental pieces, un-sold merchandise, mar­ ket samples, and much, much more. Nearly all of it is one-of-a-kind merchan­ dise in factory-select covers, in some cases with matching chairs or rockers. It s all here today, at Lack's Coliseum ... and there is so much we have had to dis­ play it on both our warehouse floors. 
While we sold scores of upholstered items in this lot last week there are many left . . . and more have been added from our regular stocks. The response was so tremendous that we are repeating this great event today. We apologize if you were one of those who did not get prompt attention. Hurry in today, for it s a whole new "ball game" . . . and our prices are better than ever!
