2 ,4 o o children lo tour 

Each year in March, the San Antonio Conservation 
Society conducts a series of historical tours for school children called the “ Texas Under Six Flags 
Tours.” 
This year tin* tours will begin Tuesday and continue through March ll). They will be conducted 
Tuesday and Thursday of the first week and Mon­ day. Tuesday and Thursday of the second week 
Society President Mrs. Nancy ii. Negley said 2.4o11 students from 17 schools, representing all school districts in the city, will participate in the tours 
Mrs Sterling S. Smith, tour chairman, said the children will visit the Steves Homestead on King 
William Street and take a driving tour of the King 
William area. There will be a walking tour of La 
Villita and a drive through Main Plaza and Plaza de 
Armas (formerly Military Plaza). 
Preceding the tours, society m em bers will give a slid** presentation at each school describing iii detail the historic background of the various sites featured on the tours. 

M anpower sem inar set 

Image, Inc. and tilt* University of Texas at San 
Antonio's Division of Continuing Education will cosponsor a conference Thursday and Friday at 
Turtle Creek Country Club. 
The conference will cover topics on self-image and 
Department of Labor policy concerning Manpower 
Training Program s. 
The sem inar will provide information useful to agencies which provide services to youth and which adm inister program s under tin* Comprehensive 
Employment and Training Act of 1972 
Featured speakers include Robert Iv Lindberg of 
UTSA and Dr. Vernon Briggs of the University of 
Texas at Austin 
Cost for the conference entitled “ ('ETA Youth and 
Manpower System s" is $25 per person To register, telephone the UTSA Division of Continuing Educa­ tion at 227-9147. 
Driving cou rses slated 

The Greater San Antonio Safety Council will offer the National Safety Council's defensive driving course at two locations Tuesday, Wednesday and 
Thursday. 
('lasses will meet from H 3o to 9:39 p iii. all three nights at MacArthur High School aud Chrysler-Ply- mouth City. 
For information call the council at 225-3o29.

Windsong st

San Antonio psychiatrist Conrad W 
Roars will address the question. “ Is the abortion controversy worth the effort?" at the March meeting of San 
Antonio Right to Life. 
The meeting will be held at 7:3o p.m. Thursday at 
Dor Lady of Grace Parish Hall. 223 E. Summit Ave. 
The public is invited. 

Career Day T uesday 

Mayor Lila Cockrell will address Career Day students at Memorial High School at 1:3o p.iii 
Tuesday. 
Career Day activities begin at 9 a ut with over HO career choices available 
In addition to career representatives from the various areas. Career Day will focus on a numiier of 
Mexican-Amerieans who have established th em ­ selves iii their fields 
Career Day will continue in the afternoon with tile mayor s presentation and two other program s A dog team from Lackland and a fire company will provide demonstrations Narrators will also talk on careers related to the demos! rat ions. 

Health m eetin g Thursday 

A workshop on health care alternatives for senior adults will tic held from 7:3o p.m. to 9 p.m. Thursday at the First Presbyterian Church 
The workshop is sponsorial by the Alamo Area 
Council of Governments. 
Persons from the appropriate state and local a gen cies will be available to answer questions. The workshop is open to the public with no admission charge. 
Topics include when nursing home care is neces­ sary. how to choose a care center, what to do if you have problem s at a center, what services are available to allow senior adults to remain iii their own homes and where to find the services.

Squadron.

It's a p a p er plane 

Members of UCLA’s Triangle Fraternity carry a 13-foot-long B5Z t o the 8th annual paper airplane contest. The event was Friday on the 
UCLA campus in Los Angeles. The model won the Most Appealing 
Award, but nosedived into the ground shortly after takeoff from atop the five-story engineering building. — AP Wirephoto. 
M exico putting sim plicity into tourism effort 

Now you can have a smooth, non-clingy feeling under divided skirts, boot topper pants, or anything that can use a sleeker look. 
Adjust-A-Length divided skirt liner of Antron® III non-cling nylon tricot can take the edge out of denim or unlined, scratchy fabrics. 26" long, with two rows of narrow nylon and spandex stretch lace. You can trim them up to 24". A terrific idea from

Austin. C harge it. 

By MILDRED WHITEAKER 

A m aster plan is under way to sim ­ plify travel to Mexico and make tour­ ism with our ?km Rh bor South of the 
Border even more attractive. 
Several points in the plan were out­ lined in Acapulco last week by Guil­ lermo Rossel de la Lama, new Secre­ tary of Tourism under President Jose 
Lope/ Portillo. 
The secretary was speaking to U.S. press representatives visiting that re­ sort city at the invitation of Miguel 
Aleman, president of the Mexican Na­ tional Tourist Council, and Harding L. 
Lawrence, board chairman and presi­ dent of Braniff International 
“ Any delay in getting a tourist card is being e lim in a te d .” said R ossel. 
“ Within a week, tourist cards will Im1 available in many more places — in­ clu d in g h o tels, a irlin e offices and counters. A tourist will be able to fill out the card at the point of entry. 

“ A toll-free num ber will soon go into effect in the United States, which will offer all types of tourist information — even legal,” he said “ Operators will speak iii English. Spanish and G er­ m an.” 

Patrols increased 

The n um ber of Green Angels who patrol the highways in Mexico giving aid to motorists will In* increased, he noted. 
E a c h tru c k will now be equipped with a CB radio (formerly forbidden) and each will have at least one person who speaks English. 
Already famed for their efficiency in repairing vehicles, the “ Angels” will receive m ore training in helping in­ dividuals. added Rossel 

The discussion of Green Angels was in answer to an inquiry as to what is being done to m ak e m o to rists feel more secure — especially in Northern 
Mexico. 

Obviously optimistic about the tour­ ist picture in Mexico. R oussel said tourism has almost recouped to the point it had reached iii the fall and winter of 1M74-75. That s when the ser­ ious slump began under policies of the prey ions administration. 

Regarding his trip to Washington, 
D C., where he attended the State Din­ ner given by P re s id e n t and M rs. 
Carter for President and Mrs Lopez 
Portillo, Rossel said. 
“ We have ta lk ed w ith P re s id e n t 
Carter about tourists bringing out $4oo or maybe $5oo worth of merchandise tax free, and tin* suggestion met with great sympathy. 
“ We are a ls o talking with U.S. air­ lin es about increasing service to such resort areas as Puerto V allarta. Aca­ pulco. Ixtapan and others.” He did not name the airlines 
Such talk can cause trouble between the communication and air transport secretary and the tourism secreatry, he noted — with a smile. 
“ One wants to protect our national airlin e s and the o th e r w an ts to in ­ crease international travel 
It is my personal opinion that the cake is big enough to slice. We can have a big 
Mexican airline industry and still re­ ceive a g re a t a m o u n t of to u ris ts through other airlines. 
He spoke enthusiastically of the co­ operation between his office (a cabinet post) and the Mexican National Tourist 
Council headed by Aleman, form erly 
P resident of Mexico and a popular man internationally 
P re v io u sly th e re w ere too m any ag e n c ie s c o n c e rn e d w ith to u ris m . 
Roussel said. “ And too much friction.” 
Prices higher 

Prices are no longer as reasonable in 
Mexico as they were shortly after last fa ll’s devaluation of the peso. Salaries of workers have increased, and other internal costs have gone up. 
“ But we are well aw a re that the most important business Mexico has is tourism.” Roussel said. “ And it is the 
Secretary of T ourism ’s responsibility to see that any p ric e c h a n g e s a r e within reason ” 
When someone mentioned that most of the conversation had been directed toward the U.S. and asked w hether 
Mexico was actively courting E u ro ­ peans. he replied: 
“ Eighty-seven percent of tourism to our country com es from the United 
S tate s 
You a re not only o u r best friends, but our best custom ers.”

Boy Scouts put out bags for Goodwill 

Alamo Area o outieil Boy Scouts are on their way to your home to deliver Good Turn Day hags so you can help the handicapped at Goodwill. 
The Boy Scouts will pick up the bags, filled with repairable clothing, sm all appliances and other small items that can be repaired by handicapped people at Goodwill, March 1ft, Good Turn Day 
Ii extra bags are needed, grocery bags may be used 
C om m . A lbert B u sta m a n te . Good Turn Day chairm an, said the event is Goodwill’s single, most important source of raw m aterials for the rehabili­ tation and employment of handicapped individuals in the San Antonio area. 
Serv icemen from loea! military bases have volun­ teered to help load and unload m aterials from trucks donated by local merchants.

WASHINGTON (A P ) 
— The m ore than 1.2 million job losses caused by fuel shortages early this month were down to 
218.ooo last week as plants and b usin esses continued to reopen, the 
C om m erce D epartm ent 

 said Saturday. 
The number of people thrown out of work by shutdowns forced by fuel sh o rtag es could drop below 2oo.ooo early next week if present trends continue, the department said.

1 9 7 7 Dimes W alk will go downtown Saturday 

The 1977 M arch of Dimes Super 
Walk will begin at 8:3o a.m . Saturday at E l Mercado. 
F o r the first time, m archers will be going through downtown, east on 
Houston Street to the Alamo, at the invitation of the San Antonio Down­ towners Assn. 
The walkers will then turn south to 
Mission Parkway to San Juan Mission, 

 through Espada Park and return to 
F a rm e rs' Market. 
This y e a r 's walk ch a irm a n . Ken 
Dushore, said both teenagers or adults can participate in the walk. 
Money raised by the walk will go to the Birth Defects Center at Santa Rosa 
Hospital 
Sponsor form s may bo obtained from schools or any Jaek-in-the-Box.

All wood hickory finish on solid hickory and hickory veneers. Door panels are reversible for extra versatility! Choose hickory veneer or simulated cane door fronts. All units are 25x3ox16". TTI have the rocky road’ 

H ON OLULU - W hen Mr. and M rs. 
R ich ard D u nb ar invited Lew is B e n j a ­ min for d in n er th e o th e r night, they neglected to tell him about one of the h azard s of living on a hillside. 
Ile found out a fte r d e sse rt, when an eight-foot iMiulder cra sh e d through the uphill side of the house. 
The boulder rolled down a hill and crush ed through a wall, d em o lish in g a w ashing m a c h in e , ca b in e ts , a d in ette set and m ost of the plum bing. 
No injuries w ere re p o rted .

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS — Sunday February 27 1977 

/ 

All is not well in soap opera land 

To hare your problem solved or a ques­ tions answered, write Action-Express, P.O. 
Box 2171, San Antonio, TX 78297. 
House numbers 
I personally feel you would be doing the greatest service — not only to the citizens of San Antonio but to the visitors to our great city — if you would initiate a campaign to make it mandatory that all houses, homes and businesses display their ad­ dresses prominently so as to be visible from the street. 
Absolutely, at times when searching for a parti­ cular address, you can waste untold measures of fuel driving back and forth, driving blocks past the number you are searching for before you actually locate it. 
Try it sometime — you will quickly agree with what I am saying. 
I think there is a city ordinance covering this matter, but it is never enforced. There should be a campaign started and pushed until the problem is overcome. 
The convenience and the fuel saved makes it more than just worthwhile. It is a courtesy we owe our citizens and visitors to our city. 
SEE WHAT YOU CAN DO TO GET THE BALL 
ROLLING! 
I don’t think my identity is necessary. The important thing is that this message covers a worthwhile and most important subject. 
E. M. S. 

Did y o u miss your favorite soap opera last week. The Ex press-ISe us presents the highlights o f the previous week's episodes each Sunday exclusively in San 
Antonio. 

ALL MY CHILDREN: 
Nick told Erica she may hate being his sex object, but not enough to stop seeing him. Joe suggest­ ed that Kitty’s illness is not physical and that she consult analyst Dr. Polk. 
Phoebe fumed about 
D onna’s presence in 
Chuck and Little Phil’s lives. Kitty came to Myr­ tle's defense when Poebe threatened to send Myr­ tle back to the streets. 
ANOTHER 
WORLD: 
Willis, Owen and Evan vied for an architectural job with wealthy newcomer Vera Finley. 
Iris’ plans for Brian were stymied when his Tonier lover. Corinne Seton, ar­ rived. Alice hired Jeff. who was peeved to find that Burt had become in terested in Clarice. 
Olive started the rumor that Pat was making ex­ cessive demands in the divorce settlement with* 
John. Jim , Frank and 
Russ halted Liz’s med­ dling. Russ reconciled with Sharlene.

THE

TURNS: John decided to snatch Andrew himself after Pat got cold feet.

Stacy’s baby will be han­ dicapped.

Mike handle her legal affairs. Roger reluctant­ ly admitted that Rita’s defense was more im ­ portant than their secret.

Send your questions about soap op eras to 
“ Tune in Tom orrow .’’ 
P.O. Box 2171, San An­ tonio, Tex., 73297. Ques­ tions cannot be answered personally, but those of general interest will be answered in future co­ lumns. 

There is a city ordin­ ance covering this matter in the city code. 
Chapter 35, section 35-3 says, “It shall be the re­ sponsibility of the ow ner and/or occupant of any house fronting on a pub­ lic street to place house numbers on such houses in so conspicuous a man­ ner that the number may be easily discernible and read from the opposite side of the street.” 
The ordinance further says if a house is too far back from the street or if the view is obstructed and the number cannot be read from the street, it should be placed on a plank on the property in a conspicuous manner. 
The ordinance also dictates the type of ma­ terials and the size of the letters. 
F ailure to com ply could result in a convic­ tion punishable by a fine not to exceed $2N. 
The house numbering division of Building and 
Zoning is responsible for 

 the enforcement of this ordinance. 
A spokesman from the house numbering di­ vision said inspectors patroled different areas of the city every day to enforce this ordinance. 
He said the inspector gives the home or bu­ siness owner a warning. 
If the resident or owner does not com ply, he is fined. 
“ We have a lot of ground to co v er.” the spokesman said. “Some­ times we cover an area and the house numbers are in accordance with the regulations. But by the time we get to that area again, we find the num bers have been knocked down or are in bad shape and they have been that way for a per­ iod of time.’' 
The spokesman asked that all San Antonio citi­ zens comply with the or­ dinance. He said many citizens did not even know the regulation existed. 
Grocery store giveaway 

Enclosed is a game folder a local grocery store is banding out in connection with a sweepstakes contest it is sponsoring. 
The rules say one game piece will be given out per customer per visit. 
There is flits one woman that has been getting game pieces from every checker on each visit at the branch I go to. 
She goes out the door and then turns right around and comes back in for more. She does it several times a day. 
She has been asked to leave the store after calling the checkers names and saying things that upset the customers and the employes. 
Now she is coining back to the store and is allowed to get a piece from the checker and the manager gives her all she wants. 
Why are the rules of the game altered for this troublemaker when the rest of us nice customers are univ allow ed one game piece per visit? lf you need a follow-up, any checker can verify this information. They all seem rather disgusted by the

Juvenile rider 
||iw many warning tickets docs a person have to recrpve before he. or the parents if he is a minor, is finial’ 
A 43-year-old boy has I w n riding a motorcycle in our neighborhood since July. I97B. To date, we know the police have been to his house several tunes and he is still riding his motorcycle without a license. 
Neither the boy nor his parents pay any attention. 
This makes it hard on parents who have children this i*e and who are trying to bring them up to respect and obey the laws 
Aren’t parents responsible for children under age and subject to a fine’’ We know the parents know he is driving without a license.

M A YO R COCKRELL speaks a t YW CA dedication cerem onies 

STAFF P H O TO BY PAT HAM ILTO N 
Las Palmas Y opens 

By MARK 
VILLANUEVA 

The new Las Palm as 
YW CA center will he a facility where society's spiritual values will he upheld, 
M aver 
L ila 
Cockrell said Saturday at the center’s dedication ceremonies. 
The $1 m illio n W est 
Side center was formally opened before an au­ dience of about 'JOO per­ sons, including State Sen. 
Frank Lombardino. City 
Councilmen Henry C is­ neros and Al bolide, and the Rev. Fdm undo Ro­ driguez. 
Mrs. Lu/ Tame/, sister of U .S. Rep. Henry B. 
Gonzalez, represented the congressman at the ceremonies. 
Gonzalez 
She said Gonzalez’ bout with a flu virus prevent­ ed the congressman from attending the dedication. 
M ayor C ockrell said the center will "serve the needs of the young and older persons and will be a place where spiritual values can be upheld." 

Mrs. Tam e/ told the audience Gonzalez was 
“ especially disappoint­ ed" he could not attend the ceremonies. 
She pointed out the 
West Side has access to decent w ater, public health programs and fa­ cilities such as the Las 
Palmas YW CA center. 

"W e have a very long way to go," Mrs Tame/. said "Bu t we have come a long way, too." 
In behalf of Gonzalez, she presented a U.S. flag to the facility. 
An open house and luncheon followed the dedication ceremonies. 
The center will serve 

 males and females but will emphasize activities of young women and girls. 
A gymnasium, indoor sw im m ing pool, cla ss ­ room kitchen, an arts and crafts area, game room and a fine arts area are housed in the struc­ ture. 

Basketball and volley­ ball courts a softball field and tennis courts have been constructed adjacent to the building. 
The Las Palm as Y W ­ 
CA. located at 511o 
Cas­ troville Road, was built by the City of San Anton­ io on land donated by Las 
Palmas, Inc,

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS —Sunday February 27 1977 
Page I -C 
State school funds asked 

It is the state’s respon­ sibility to see children in poor districts get quality education. Jackie Cox of the Intercultural Deve­ lopment Research Assn. said Saturday. 
“ But the state says if the local school district won’t do anything to raise its share of the money, it won’t send it any state funds,” Miss 
Cox said. 
Miss Cox held a dis­ 

 cussion on school fin ­ ances at thi' American 
Federation of Teachers 
Convention at St M ary’s 
University. 
"W ho is the victim ? 
The student." she said. 
"The state must do so­ m ething if the local school district cannot raise enough money." 
M iss 
Cox said 
Edgewood School D is­ trict residents have a higher tax rate than Ala­ 

 mo Heights School Dis­ trict residents, but have less in pupil expendi­ tures. 
"A nd equalization is not in sight All bills be­ fore the Texas Legisla­ ture have upward sloping curves." she said "They w ill provide more money for children in rich dis­ tricts. 
"The more monov put in equalization programs, the better.” 

 she said. 
Debbie 
( a r t w right, 
Texas Speaker of the 
House Bill Clayton’s as­ sistant, said sin' was op­ timistic the House will put "quite a bit of money in equalization pro­ grams." 
"There will be some property tax re lie f.” 
Miss C artw right said. 
"But not enough to make any difference this time around." 

Steel firm pays 

Em ployes of a local steel firm began receiv­ ing $7o.(Kit» iii hack pay a union spokesman said 
Saturday. 
Mosher Steel Co.. B47 
V WAV. White Road, is­ sued checks in that amount to 7H San Antonio em ployes and sent 
SHO,(MKI to 2o other em­ ployes throughout the state in compliance with a ruling by the National 
Labor Relations Board last year. 
The back pay was is­ sued to the employes, all members of the United 
Steelworkers of America. who were denied job reinstatement follow mg a strike in 1o75. accord­ ing to ('. L. Wimberley, 
USW representative. 
The 
N L R B order further directed Moulter not to discourage mein- 
I Reship in unions and to return to the bargaining table with the USW with the intention of reaching i an agreement. Wintber*! ley said. 
M em bers of the, 
Musher union group met 
Saturday to develop bar-! gaining strategies. 

 will be installed 

D r. Ed B. A very of 
Pearsall will be installed as president of the Texas 
V eterin ary 
M edical 
Assn. at the organize* turn's annual convention 
Monday in New Orleans. 
'The Texas association is holding a joint meeting with the Louisiana Ve­ terinary Medical Assn. for the first time. 
Dr. Avery, a general practitioner, was elected to succeed Dr. A.K Hop­ kins Jr . of Dallas as head of the 
IftUO-member 
TVMA. He will become the 75th president of the organization.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S —Sunday February 27 1977 
Heart unit donations drive on 

Some 6,ooo volunteer workers will cover San Antonio Sunday c o llectin g donations for the 
Heart Fund. 

Heart Sunday is the first phase of the fund-raising campaign of the San An­ tonin Chapter of the American Heart 
Assn. 

: Roberta Dot in, chairman of the door-to-door drive, said, “ Over half of all Americans who die each year, from all causes, die from heart and blood 
-vessel diseases. 

“ In addition to collecting much- needed money for research, education and community service programs, the volunteers pass out information that can save lives.” she said. 

“ In a sense, the volunteers are sav­ ing lives with information made possi­ ble by those who gave in the past,” she said. 

The information handed out by the volunteers deals mainly with recogni­ tion of warning signals of heart attack and stroke, emergency action and in­ formation on the risk factors of heart disease. 

Art show, song fete planned for 
Luckenbach Mud Dauber Day 

19TH CENTURY antiques are am ong those offered for purchase at Continental Shows Ltd.'s Antique Show and 
Sale at the Convention Center 
Antiques show set 

Continental Shows Ltd. will stage its 
Antique Show and Sale Friday, Satur­ day and next Sunday at the Convention 
Center. 
The event, known for the quality of its displays, attracts the participation of antique trades people from across the nation. 
Furniture, cut glass, art glass, pot­ tery, bisque, china, paper goods, dolls, stamps and coins. Indian artifacts and 

 jewelry are some of the items to be displayed. 
Books, prim itives. 
Orientals, bronzes. Wedgewood, silver, pewter and many other collectibles will also be offered for purchase. 
The show is open to the public, tine paid admission covers all three days of the event. Show hours an* I to 9 p.m. 
Friday and Saturday and I to H p.m. 
Sunday. 

SPtClAl TO Tnt tXPRtSS NEWS 
LUCKENBACH - Plans for an art exhibit and a song contest on March 19, when the Mud Daubers Come Back to 
Luckenbach Day, were announced Sa­ turday by Gen. Chairman Ja ck 
Harmon. 
Harmon announced the art exhibit would be a retrospective showing of the works of Picasso Mud Dauber, a 
15o-year-old insect who returns to 
Luckenbach each year. 
Picasso Mud Dauber had difficulty in art school, Harmon explains. 
“ He didn t do delicate sculptures like the rest of the Mud Daubers. His were kind of crude. It was because his dauber was on upside down. But he didn’t give up. He decided to make the best of his affliction. 
“ As a result, he has become the most famous sculptor of all and an example to young and old alike.” 
Billv Carter, who has been invited to become Mayor for a Day, will be pre­ sented with a Picasso Mud Dauber sculpture if he comes. No word has yet been received from him. 
“ We hope that Billy will attend and accept our offer of all the beer he can drink,” Harmon said. 
“ We have had an offer from a truck mechanic in Marshall who said he would be happy to take Billy’s place given the same terms. We also had an unsigned telegram from Washington which said. ‘Understand you have 

 invited Billy. Why not the best?” ’ 
Cathy Morgan, first lady of Lucken­ bach, has issued a proclamation ask­ ing all the town's picker friends to write and perform a song honoring the 
Mud Daubers Return on the 19th. 
“ We won’t have any prize for the winner, but the loser will get a one way ticket to Buffalo, N. Y., good only in 
January,” Mrs. Morgan said. 

Four manufacturers who have a 

 surplus of red, white and blue souven­ irs from the Bicentennial have accept­ ed the offer of free space to sell their leftovers in this Non-Bicentennial City. 
The one requirement is that they donate 19 per cent of their proceeds to the Hondo Crouch “ I told you so” 
Memorial Fund to be used to erect a statue of the late humorist mayor who among other things was the inventor of 
When the Mud Daubers Come Back to 
Luckenbach Daw______________ _ _ _

MEXI CO 

Texas hit by winter again 
O 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
Old Man Winter' reminded Texans Saturday that he is still around. 
Temperatures in the northwestern portions of the state dropped into the low 2os and were expected to dip even lower during the night. The rest of the state had generally cloudy skies, some rain and strong winds. 
Early in the day the frost line was near Childress to Lubbock to the southeast corner of New Mexico. 
The cold front was almost out of the state late in the afternoon. Brownsville reported the highest temperature. 71 degrees. 
Early in the morning. Am arillo and Lubbock reported two inches of snow and Dalhart and Chil­ dress reported one inch. 
The Texas Highway Department issued a travel warning for all roads north of Lubbock. It said ice and snow covered most highways and driving con­ ditions were “ very hazardous.’’ 
Winds of up to 4o miles per hour were reported in portions of West Texas and along the Gulf Coast near Brownsville. 
The National Weather Service said the cloud cover over most of the state would clear by Sunday. 

Comptroller Bob Bullock has some letters from confederate soldiers and their fa­ milies that he wants to give to the letter writers' descendants. 

Some of the letter-writers could have San Antonio descendants, according to Leta Baughn, president of the Albert Sidney .Johnston Chapter of the United 
Daughters of the Confederacy 
(UDO. 
The UDO is trying to find descendants of the letter writers. 
“ lf they (descendants) want to pick up the letters instead of letting him throw them away, they can contact him.” Mrs. Baughn said. 

Old letters 

Bullock found some IOO old letters from Confe­ derate pensioners in his office’s warehouse. 
“ These letters now have no value to the state, but they may mean a great deal in sentiment and history to the families.” Bullock said. 
Most of the correspondence was between confe­ derate widows and the state comptroller. 
But. some of the letters were also from the last surviving Confederate soldiers, according to Bul­ lock. 
The letters dealt with confederate pensions. 

S.A. writers 
San Antonio letter writers included Mrs. IV. VV. 
Black, Mrs. Nannie Stone and Mrs. Bessie Palmer. 
The comptroller also has old letters from. Mrs. 
Elizabeth Lusby Kyle of Nixon and from T. F. Har­ well of Kyle. 
Mrs. Baughn said Friday lier organization may ask for the letters that aren't claimed. 
-We feel we should do something about it. I would hate to see those letters thrown away.”

THAT ARE NOTTO KANSSED

State Dairy Queen owners open meet 

Tin' Texas Dairy Queen Trade Assn 
— encompassing the owners of vir- tually all the more than 95o Dairy 
Queen restaurants in Texas — will hold its 1977 convention Sunday through 
Wednesday at the Convention Center. 
The Hilton Palacio Del Rio Hotel is the 1o77 TDQTA conventions’s hotel headquarters. 
The association’s last five conven­ tions were held in Forth Worth, ac­ cording to Ballett M anale, 1978-77 president of TDQTA and owner-opera- tor of Dairy Queens in Benbrook, 
Brownwood (tw o ). Cisco and Co­ manche. 
H ie move of tho annual convention will make it only the second time iii the 
18 year history of the organization that the group has convened for its annual meeting in San Antonio The previous time was iii IHM 

TDQTA is the largest organization of 

U s type in the nation. 
O D ’’Del 
Smalley of Forth Worth. a m em ber of the association’s executive committee and board of d ir­ ectors. is convention chairman. 

Convention manager is Paul (). RUI mgs. president and owner of Paul 
Ridings Public Relations, Inc., of Fort 
Worth and T H Q I'A’s executive secre­ tary. 

“ Help and cooperation from officials of the ll 111 un Palacio Del Rio Hotel; th** 
San Antonio Convention and V isitors 
Bureau and the San Antonio Conven­ tion Center were prune factors in the making of the decision to move the convention from Fort Worth to San 
\ntonio” , said Smalley, who. with 
Ridings, came to the Alamo and Ile- m isFair city last June for tho first planning sessions preparatory to the move 

Fibrosis group to hold Skate-a-thon 

CYSTIC FIBROSIS Poster Child Javier 
G onzales is all smiles preparing for the A ll-C ity Skate-A -Thon 

The Lone Star Chapter of the Cystic 
F’ibrosis Foundation will hold a 12-hour 
All-City Skate-a-Thon starting at 7 p.m. Saturday. 
The Skate-a-Thon is being sponsored by and held at all C’ar-Vel Skatelands in San Antonio. 
Proceeds will be used to support research and educational programs of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, ac­ cording to Mrs. David I L Schoenert, 
Skate-a-Thon Chairman. 
Skaters can participate bv picking up an entry form at any skating rink or by calling 732-o845. 
Skaters skate free by rounding up sponsors before March 5th and bring­ ing th e ir en try form s to the 
Skate-a-Thon. 
According to Mrs. Schoenert, many prizes have been donated by local businesses to be awarded to skaters who collect the greatest amount of pledges. 
Prizes include a portable television, calculators, ro ller skates, savings 

 bonds, a plane ride. and more 
In San Antonio the foundation spon­ sors research at University of Texas 
Medical Center and supports the Cystic 
Fibrosis Center at Santa Rosa Hospi­ tal. 
The most serious of lung diseases, cystic fibrosis causes life threatening lung damage and severe digestive problems. Although there is no cure, cystic fibrosis can be effectively treat­ ed. according to Mrs. Schoenert. 

“ Early diagnosis and treatment of cystic fibrosis and the other children's lung-damaging diseases are very im ­ portant.’’ she said. 
By detecting symptoms, parents can help contribute to tho early recognition of the diseases. 
The signs include: recurrent wheez­ ing. persistent coughing with exces­ sive mucus, recurrent pneumonia, excessive appetite but poor weight gain aiifk clubbing or enlargement of the fingertips.

T h e San A ntonio Ex- pross-News has won two a w a r d s in th e a n n u a l 
T e x a s 
S c h o o l 
Bell 
Awards P r o g r a m of the 
T e x a s S t a t e T e a c h e r s 
Assn. 
In the category of m e ­ tr opoli ta n daily p a p e r s vc it h circulations of more t h a n 
I OO. (IOO, t h e E x ­ press-N ew s re c e i v e d a certificate of m erit for co n tin u o u s o u t s t a n d i n g c o v e r a g e of e d u c a t i o n news. 
In the s a m e category, the paper won a certifi­ c a t e of m e r i t to r o u t ­ sta n d in g c o n tin u in g co ­ lumn. 
That column was “ On 
C a m p u s ” by Vickie D a­ v i d s o n . It r a n in t h e 
Monday Express. 
The Express-News was nominated for the aw ard s by t h e 
S a n 
A n to n io 
T e a c h e r s ’ Cou ncil and the L a c k la n d T e a c h e r s 
Assn.

1975 coverage.

1975 and most of 1976. Liz 
Sweet has a ss u m e d that position.

CADIL LAC,

Minolta SR-T 2o1. 
It makes fine photography easy. 
And easy to afford. 

The Minolta SR T 2o1 is loaded with features, quality md value. Try one and see why Minoltas are the best selling 35mm single lens reflex cameras in America. 
• Fast, easy handling ... information viewfinder lets you compose, focus and adjust exposure without ever looking away from your subject. 
• Patented through-the-lens "CLC” metering... pro­ vides proper exposure even in high-contrast lighting 
• Hot shoe for cordless flash operation. 
• Convenient memo holder so you always know what film you’re using. 
• Shutter speeds to 1/1ooo second. 
• Accepts the complete Minolta system of lenses and 
SR-T accessories for unlimited photographic versatility. 
• Full 2-year Minolta U.S.A. warranty.

HIGHLIGHTING: Several repeater pocket watches including a Ferret ond 
Berthoud, railroad and hunters watches Lucian Picard ond Rolex watches. 
Dozens of solitaires ond clusters of mounted precious stones 
|ewelry in­ cluding a lot of 8o carats bag diamonds 18S4 Kelloqg ond Co $2o goldpiece, silver coins by the bag. 8 oz man s chainlink Cold cords Religious metals, you nome it11 You will bedazzled by the variety and quality of the aesthetic beauty of this collection 

HISTORY: this auction represents the lifelong investment of o Laredo businessman who for SO years, shrewdly invested his funds in the world's most stable market — Gold, Silver and precious stones Inspired by a recent 
U S. Customs Gold Auction in Laredo, and serious heolth problems, he has commissioned our frm to liquidate his possessions. Although the owner wonts his nome withheld, his story is fascinating It began in 1929 in Cuba, going door to door buying precious items. Storting with only S2S ond parlay­ ing it into o pirates chest* Before moving to Laredo he spent 2o years in the him and cities of Mexico, living in recluse but buying gold"

Meadow Oaks patio homes opening today 

This weekend 
Homecraft 
Corp. will hold its grand opening for the building-developing firm's innovative patio homes in 
Meadow Oaks, an established community serenely situated in northeastern Bexar County. 
The dram atic debut of these patio homes in Meadow Oaks m eans the long awaited arrival of the utmost in care­ free modern living in a setting so serene yet so convenient to so many different destination points. 
Privacy reigns 
Although “ carefree" is a good word to describ e the lifestyles for which these patio hom es are m ost suited, another key feature they present is privacy, a kind of intimacy so many seek in this kind of residence. 
Standards among Meadow Oaks pa­ tio hom es would be considered “ ex­ tras" at sim ilar projects in the vicini­ ty. Each has a private courtyard and patio; roomy storage and utility rooms; and two-car covered carports with rear en tries that m ean front y ard s look good at all times. 
Most surprising about these patios homes, perhaps, is their price range, s ta r t in g as low as $28,95o to only 
$36,95o They now a re offered with eased conventional financing te rm s requiring only 5 per cent of the ad- lusted purchase price as a down pay­ ment. Some are offered even with a 

 total move-in cost of only $45o by con­ ventional financing. 
As well, these patio hom es boast fe a tu re s th at ex e m p lify the real m eaning behind H o m ecraft’s recent housing concept, the “ Snug Home." 
“ Snug Home" is a term Homecraft chose to briefly describe the solid con­ struction of its IOO per cent masonry homes. Although it sounds simple en­ ough. there is much to it, especially when the need for modern families lo save as m uch energy as possible is considered. The Snug hom e a c c o m ­ plishes that with ease. 
E n erg y -sav in g fe a tu re s in H o m e­ craft houses actually result in “ tight" insulation — not just am ple insulation. 
Item s included in the Snug Home concept are double paned, solar gray and light-resistant windows; foil-faced sheathing added to wall insulation to reflect both heat and light; and steel- encased doors with m ag n etic, refri- gerator-typc weat herstripping. 

B esid e s its new s e rie s of p atio homes, a total of six model homes will be showcased in Meadow O aks this weekend. These fully furnished, pro­ fessionally d e c o ra te d m o d els have c a u g h t the in te re st of m an y hom e shoppers looking for a fine house nes­ tled am ong trees of a neighborhood near all the city conveniences. 
This is because Meadow Oaks fits that description to the fullest. Its ser­ enity, combined with convenience, has m ade it the choice of m any families 

 since its opening. 
The m arket-tested floor plans and designs Homecraft offers in this com ­ munity make up ev en more reasons for its surge in popularity. 
It is in Meadow Oaks that Homecraft proudly presents not only its new patio hom es but also its two recent Snug 
Home m o d els and its original four m o d els to fully r e p r e s e n t m o d e rn housing available in the neighborhood. 
Just some of the Homecraft features are all-electric, decorator kitchens; fine c a rp e tin g ; h a n d c ra fte d , wood- b u rn in g fire p la c e s w ith g a s log lighters; and, of course, optimal insu­ lation. 
The choice location of Meadow Oaks is still another reason for so many fa­ milies' moving there. 
The c o m m u n ity is co n v en ie n t to 
Randolph AFB v ia N.E. EM 16o4. It is also near the shopping and entertain­ ment facilities of both Universal City and northeastern San Antonio. 
Also, an am enity area aptly called 
“ The Oaks” Swim and Tennis Club is exclusively for the enjoyment of Mea­ dow Oaks residents. 
Com plete city services, of course, are in Meadow Oaks, actually outside 
San Antonio City L im its. T he c o m ­ munity is in the progressive Judson 
School District. 
Meadow Oaks is reached most easily by exiting from N E. HI 35 to N E. EM 
1694 and proceeding east to the com­ munity’s grand entranceway. 

LAKESIDE hom es b y Schaefer featu re the kind o f standards, e x tra s fam ilies seek 
S ch aefer’s ‘ph ilosoph y’ put to work in Lakeside 

Schaefer has a definite philo­ sophy of building: a quality home affordably priced in a proven neighborhood. 
What does this m ean to the home buyer? 
Ideal community 
Well, for those prospective buyers looking for a home in a com m unity ideally centered on families and family life in the rolling hills of southeastern 
B exar County, it m ean s a S chaefer home in Lakeside. 
While more and more builders have cut down their building program s and stripped down their products. Schaefer is building quality homes with hidden values, luxurious extras and energy- saving features, all at an affordable price and special financing. 
At Lakeside. Schaefer offers homes in country setting quite unlike anyth­ ing you’ve ever seen. These homes are built with the care and craftsm anship 

M EA D O W O A K S patio hom es can be seen during grand opening w eeken d o ffere d b y H om ecraft Corp. 

Schaefer is known for. 
Schaefer quality starts with the fin­ est construction m aterials like solid copper wiring, top quality plumbing, beautifully painted woodwork, hand- laid tile baths and top-of-the-line (IE appliances. All features make Schaefer homes look better and last longer. 
But the quality doesn t stop there. 
Schaefer is out to prove that luxury fe a tu re s need not be lim ite d to luxury-priced homes. You can still find quality built homes with luxury fea­ tures at prices yAu can afford. Home with glamorous kitchens, space-saving bonus rooms, formal liv ing and dining areas and even separate gam e rooms with fireplaces or a study for the kids. 
As well, there is more energy-sav­ ing features Each home has a custom engineered, high-efficiency central air and heating system; special duct work for optimal air flow; 3t*>-inch insula­ tion between walls; and eight-inch in­ sulation in attic. In fact, there is extra attic ventilation, and all windows are designed to minimize air ingittration and maximize light and views. 
All of this adds up to the Schaefer concept: “ We're building homes you'll want to come to.” Quality built, afford­ ably priced homes show an astound­ ing amount of imagination and foreth­ ought on the part of the builder. 
But S c h a e fer also b eliev e s the neighborhood is just as important as the home you live in. Schaefer neigh­ borhoods a re p lan n ed and built to feature a variety of homes with many d iffe ren t d e s ig n s and e le v a tio n s . 
Neighborhoods like Lakeside are d e ­ veloped with consistency and sound e n g in e e rin g , a re n e a r sch o o ls and 

 shopping centers and assure buyers of a sound investment 
(.’entered on families and family life, 
Lakeside also boasts recreational faci­ lities that can ’t be found in any other 
San Antonio com munity. Picnic a m is , p la y g ro u n d s an d a n e ig h b o rh o o d swimming pool — plus lighted tennis courts, a path for biking, hiking and jogging and an 11-acre recre atio n al lake — are just a few of the am enities 

 iii the HUO acres of wooded park land surrounding Lakeside. 
Yet the convenience of this south­ eastern com munity will astound you. 
Located a short mile from S E. Loop 
41o, Lakeside is m inutes from down­ town. convenient to excellent shopping areas and just a short ride away from 
Fort Sam Houston, as well as Brooks. 
Lackland, Kelly and Randolph AFBs 
The East C e n tral School D istrict provides an o u ts ta n d in g a c a d e m ic program and an opportunity for chil­ dren to lie part of cham pionship athle­ tic teams, a superior hand and music p ro g ram and one of th e to p -ran k ed agricultural departm ents iii the state. 
Bus service is provided to all schools. 

Residents of Lakeside also enjoy the advantage of a RI per cent savings on their monthly home payments, which actually run an average of $35 less |>er month for a quality built home com ­ parable to homes found in other San 
Antonio communities. 

S chaefer m odels iii L ak esid e are open from lh a.m. until dusk Prices range from $3ti.<MHI to $5o,ooo. Ask al the Information ('enter, 26o2 Lake Al­ tair. about special financing term s that postpone paym ents until June.

 oversized lids with' many trees. All lots front on paved streets with con­ crete curbs. Undergroun utility lines elim inate unsightly poles and lines that would mar the na­ tural beauty of the ser­ enity anil rolling terrain.

Homecraft houses. 
Twin Creek 
Professional planning 
In Homecraft Corp. has made Twin Creek one of the fastest growing com­ munities iii the San An­ tonio area. 
The northwestern 
Bexar County develop­ ment offers the kind of homes modern families are looking for today and c an afford. 
Twin Creek, now con­ sidered one lo the* estab­ lished neighborhoods by 
San Antonians, has ac­ quired a good popuI us since it opened. 
Streets in the neigh­ borhood necessitate slow traffic, and house exter­ iors along each create an 
Impressive blending of both colors and styles. It was all planned that way. 
The community also features its own private clubhouse It offers green, fenced tennis courts lighted at nights. Other recreational facilities in­ clude a swimming pool, wading pool, clubhouse with equipped kitchen 
~~ M W W WPUT---- 

Located in the pre­ ferred Northside School 
District. Twin Creek is also close to 
CTSA.

Lackland 
AF'Bs. 
Twin Creek homes, priced from as low as

 and a playground for youngsters. 
.Although surrounded by nature. Twin Creek also has a location of ut­ most convenience. Here deer are seen running or feeding and city noises never are heard, even though the thoroughfare 
Bandera Road is just a mile away; NAV. Loop 
41o. one mile more. 
Of course, no city taxes apply to home payments made by Twin Creek re­ sidents. 

Charm and grace of 
Mediterranean styling are reflected by patio homes in Royal Ridge. 
Equally important, however, are the features behind all this beauty that create a home of ex­ ceptional value. 
Two-story 

The distinct advan­ tages of living in a two- story home also comprise an important feature of these patio homes. 
This weekend it is possible to purchase one of these two-story models at prices asked for dur­ ing 1978. The next con­ struction phase for these patio homes w ill de­ mands prices some 81,o9o to $2,ooo higher. 
Among the advantages 

 gained by selecting a two-story model would bt* more square footage for relatively little extra cost. The additional liv­ ing area could be between 2oo and 5oo sq. ft. at $7 to $8 for each. 
This contrasts with one- story models in that each square foot would aver­ age some $3o in cost. 
Overall, the two-story model would cost about 
$25 per square foot. 
Costs of operating uti­ lities actually are histor­ ically less in two-story models. That really pre­ sents a bargain to I m * en­ joyed in one of these 
“ Energy-Crafted” patio homes.

EXPRESS-NEWS —Sunday February 27 1977 
San Antonio 
Camelot community has it all ‘cooking’ 

The Litton Micromatic double oven in microwave range is standard equipment in some Camelot homes, and kitchen buffs who have seen it in action understand why the Litton is called “ the ultimate cooking center.’’ 

The Litton solid state Vari-Cook oven control permits variation of the mi­ crowave cooking speed, enabling the kitchen artist to cook, reheat, roast, simmer, warm and even defrost. 
Speed-cooking on top with the mi­ crowave oven and baking or broiling in the conventional oven are great ways to prepare lavish, special meals the cook usually dreads but the family loves to feast on. The self-cleaning oven makes clean-up chores fast and 

The Camelot lifestyle offers a lot of things, including a baked potato in IO minutes; a fried egg in 45 seconds; and a couple of ham burgers for a couple of hungry kids in 3o seconds. 
What’s that got to do with a Hay E l­ lison home in Camelot? 
Important feature 
Everything, if a person happens to believe that the kitchen is one of the most important features in a home. 
Whether the homeowner is a harried housewife in a hurry or someone who just plain loves to cook, cooking in 
Camelot is super because kitchens in 
Camelot are super, too. 

 easy. 
But the Litton is only part of the 
Camelot kitchen story. There’s the stainless steel double sink, rich hand­ crafted wood cabinets, built-in dish­ washer, disposer plus easy viewing through the lovely French door leading from the kitchen into the backyard. 

Ray Ellison homes in Camelot offer more than just a super kitchen, of course. Every room in a Camelot home features the Ellison attention to detail that means a balanced combination of convenience, practicality and down­ right luxury. 
Thanks to its location in the north­ eastern quadrant of the city. Camelot is served by excellent schools at all 

 nearby and within easy driving distance of either Randolph AFB or Fort Sam Houston. 
Camelot by Ray Ellison Homes offers homes such as this one in a choice north­ eastern location, with Windsor Park Mall

San Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S — Sunday Februar> 
\ 
1977 

Morton/SW found ‘favorite’ 

San 
A n tonian s stro n g ly favored the two different hous­ ing series Morton / Southwest featured last year. In fact, they put the building - developing firm on top. 
Morton / Southwest still features 
Freedom Homes and Success Homes in three outstanding communities: Lake­ side, in southeastern Bexar County off 
U.S. Hwy. 87 outside S .E . Loop 41o; 
V alley Forge, off O ’Connor Road between Nacogdoches Road and N E. 
Ill 35; and Cimarron, found just south of V E . EM I HCM east of Kitty Hawk 
Drive. 
Series well named 

The two series are aptly named, too. 
Freedom Homes are called that be­ cause they literally set buyers “ free from rent” into a new world of home ownership. Success Hom es are so named for the series’ unique features 

 that would make the purchase of any a sure success. 
‘‘A ffordability” is a key word for each series. 
Fredom 
Homes are priced from as low as $28,5oo; Success, 
$34,ooo. No com parable homes are built for those kind of prices these days; so, Morton / Southwest has a valid claim to leadership in San An­ tonio area housing. 
Morton / Southwest has drawn de­ signs from ingenious floor plans which have revolutionized the market for new homes by making them more afforda­ ble and more useful, square foot by square foot. Traffic patterns are ideal. 
This is the way those who have had to rent actually sacrifice nothing at all when they buy and move into a new 
Freedom or Success home by Morton / 
Southwest. In fact, they gain all they’ve ever wanted. 
Freedom Homes go far beyond the basics, too. They feature frill modern families have come to expect in a new home. This indeed, is just one of the 

CLASNFKD DISMAY 
CLASSIFIED D IS PLA Y 

 many reasons Freedom Homes have gained such widely spread popularity. 
Their three- and four-bedroom plans include two complete baths generally sought by home buyers today. All this is figured into an attractively afforda­ ble package in a price range families today can afford. A Freedom home is no “ pearl of great price.” 
Pan try kitchens feature the right kind of appliances to lessen the work­ load for today’s homemaker. D ish­ washer, disposers, ranges, vent hoods and abundant cabinetry are provided in Freedom Homes. All appliances carry the reliable Magic Chef brand name. 
Other extras Morton / Southwest has made available in Freedom Homes are wall-to-wall closets with storage space extending all the way to the ceiling and sliding doors of panel designs, finished two-car garages, utility and work ar­ eas, patios with sliding glass doors, clever blends of masonry and wood for striking exteriors, carpeting of the 

 buyers’ choices of colors and kinds. 
Friedrich central air and heat systems and. in most, woodburning fireplaces. 
Success Homes vividly reveal that an enjoyable home remains the “ great 
American dream " and one that can be realized without great sacrifice. 
The large amounts of total square footage in the Success plans can be seen in spacious family rooms, separ­ ate dining areas, large family rooms and sizeable living rooms. In fact, even the patios for Success Homes are fa­ mily sized. 
Also encompassed are the large, de­ corative all-electric kitchens. They boast space-saving built-ins like Magic 
Chef ranges, ovens, vent hoods, dish­ washers and stainless steel Waste King disposers. 
But the scope of Success Homes, of 
L'Ourse, goes beyond their “ furnisha- ble” and useful space. The luxury ap­ pointments add much to how they pre­ sent more than the money’s worth. 
They include shag carpeting in Iiv-

Buyer can choose the colors and pat­ terns for carpets and wallcoverings.

W IND DRAFT. 

Northcliffe, a major part of a new $15o million single-family residential 
/ golf course community off N.E. Ill 35 just north­ east of Hubertus Road 
(FM 11o3), presents at­ tractive financing terms this weekend for its new homes. 

Homes in the North­ cliffe community have received widespread at­ tention because of their innovative, energy-sav­ ing program which fea­ tures Snug Homes. 
Fine features 
H om ecraft’s 
Snug 
Home Program includes gray tint solar glass win­ dows, precis ion-fit ted steel doors which are in­ sulated and have a refri­ gerator -1 y p e rn a g n e t i e weatherstrip, insulated foil-back sheathing and an all-electric air condi­ tioning and heating sys­ tem. 

In addition to Home­ craft’s exclusive Snug 
Home 
Program , the 
Northcliffe homes have a one-vear w arranty on construction and all ser- vicable products. 

Northcliffe. priced from $37,25o to $44,95o, offers three- and four-be­ droom models with a choice of variety of ex­ terior designs — Tradi­ tional M editerranean, 
French and the like. 
Floor plans vary, too. 

Each home features a woodburning fireplace, all-brick exterior and spacious kitchen with built-in cabinets and an­ electric appliances. In addition, there is a prac­ tical pantry and washer- drycr area with overhead built-in cabinets adjacent to the two-car garage. 
Four professionally de­ 

 corated models are open here. 

Northcliffe is located is the Schertz-Cibolo-Uni- versa 
City 
School 
District. All schools have bus service a short eight-minute drive away. 
Emergency services to the entire community in­ clude police protection from the county and a volunteer service provid­ ed by the Schertz com­ munity nearby. 

YA financing, with a $1 total move-in, and con- ventiona loans, with only 
5 lier cent of the purchase price as down payment and low closing cost, are available to buyers in 
Northcliffe. 

Construction on the $2 million recreational faci­ lity program is well under way. It includes three lighted, standard play tennis courts and a professional centre court surrounded by tourna­ ment bleachers. 

An 18-hole golf course, swimming pool, wading pool and diving pool are to be included as well. 
Completion on the mul- ti-storv. 6,ooo-sq. ft clubhouse is scheduled for early April to coin­ cide with play on tin' golf course. 

Northcliffe is located 22 miles from downtown 
San Antonio via N E. Ill 
35; eight from 
New 
Braunfels. Walnut Shop­ ping Center, Gateway 
Shopping Center and 
Windsor Park Mall are all within a 15-minuti drive from the commun­ ity. 

To reach Northcliff^ take N .E. III 35 to the 
Cibolo-Hubertus Road exit and follow the signs to the community.

Tanglewood Realty has announced the recent ac­ quisition of 
Regnier 
Realty Inc. 

The purchase of Reg­ nier, which had been in business around San An­ tonio for some 25 years, moved the Tanglewood offices to the Windcrest area at 5o15 Sherri Ann. 

Tanglewood Realty is a full-service firm dealing with residential, new homes and pre-owned; farm and ranee property; commercial real estate; and property manage­ ment. It is co-owned by 
Chuck DeLaney, who has been in real estate for some 25 years, and Bill 
Neighbors. 

As a full-service realty, 
Tanglewood has mem­ berships in 
Multiple lasting Service, San An­ tonio Board of Realtors, 
National Association of 
Realtors and Texas As­ sociation of Realtors 

Sales associates, also acquired with the Reg­ nier purchase, include 
Magdalena Maseorro, 
Marjie Doyell, Bud Dyer, 
Charles Malloy, Fmorey 
Zimmerman and Othell 
Bain.

W h il e m a n y S an A n ­ tonio b u i l d e r s a d d r e s s t h e m s e l v e s to t h e e n ­ ergy-efficient h o m e now that they’re in the face til' s p i r a l i n g u t i li ty c o s t s , the B u rn s Co. be gan d e ­ sig n in g energ y-effi cient h o m e s to s e r i o u s l y r e ­ duce en ergy waste within h o m es as m a n y as four years ago. 

A n d . w h i l e m a n y builders are adding extra i n s u l a t i o n a n d d o u b l e glass windows. Burns set out to tackle the biggest e n e r g y - w a s t e r of all — air infiltration 

‘Unnecessary’ 

Air in filtratio n is th e u n n e c e s s a r y m o i om en ! ol air into or out of your h o m e . W h il e s o m e ait movement occurs in d a i­ ly activities, such as e n ­ tering or leaving through a door, the ove rw he lm ing p e r c e n t a g e e s c a p e s or e n te r s d u e to loose c o n ­ struction techniques. 

Tests have proven that up to 41 per cent of your cooling and heating costs can be att rib u te d to the effects of air infiltration 
As new a i r m o v e s into y o u r h o m e , it m u s t be r e c o o l e d o r r e h e a t e d . 
Eventually, all the air in th e r o o m will b e r e ­ placed. 

\\ hile one chan ge of air p e r r o o m e a c h h o u r is r e a s o n a b l e ( s o m e o ld er homes have a rate of four ch anges of air per hour), the av era ge Burns home c h a n g e s a i r o n ly o n c e every two hours. 

T h i s r e m a r k a b l e ' d e ­ crease in infiltration rate1 is brought about by the extra time and effort that goes into the* construction of a B u r n s Co. “ P o w e r 
Saver" home. Each step of co nst ru ction include s e n e r g y - c o n s e r v i n g t e c h ­ niques to seal out air in­ filtratio n. E x t r a in s u l a ­ tion a n d d o u b l e g l a s s windows are st an dard, as are power ventilators. 

Although WI per cent of the added energy-saving techniques a re invisible 

 iii a completed home, the difference they make will be clearly visible on your monthly utility bill. 

F r o m top to b o t t o m a n d f r o m i n s i d e o u t. 

 e v e r y B u r n s h o m e is built to m e e t s t r i c t en- e r g y - e f f i c i e n c y s t a n ­ dards. And. while this is a m a i o r c o n c e r n of th e 

B u rn s Co., it n e v e r n e g ­ lects the styling or liva­ bility of the home 

T h e “ P o w e r S a v e r ’’ homes collection features e x c it in g o p tio ns to suit any lifestyle. H a n d so m e living a r e a s w ith de ep- pile carp etin g and furni­ t u r e - f i n i s h e d p a n e l i n g a re planned arou nd su n ­ ken conversation pits or m o r e tr a d it io n a l p la ns. 
All include vvoodburning f i r e p l a c e s a n d b u il t- in bookcases. Some models feature a roll-out TV c a ­ binet. co m p lete ly a n t e n ­ na-wired. u nder the st air landing. 
S p a c i o u s m a s t e r b e ­ droom s include s e p a r a te d r e s s i n g a r e a s a n d walk-in closets. Built-in alcov ed b e d s w ith m a t ­ t r e s s e s . d r a w e r s p a c e an d toy s t o r a g e a r e o p ­ tional iii s o m e u p s t a i r s ch il dren’s bedrooms. 

E x t r a f e a t u r e s a r e found in the “ wife s a v e r " kitchen areas, too. Many b e c o m e f a m i l y a c ti v it y c e n t e r s , s o m e w ith u p ­ d a t e d v e r s i o n s of th e breakfast nook popular in the 192os. 9214 DARTBROOR DR. 696-o1 46 

A new day is coming to 
Briarw iek in northeas­ tern Bexar County. 
All-new homes, a new and wider selection of floor plans and new fur­ nished models are center stage in Briarwiek. 
Price range 
New homes in Briar- wick are priced from 
$28,5oo to $43,ooo. They boast the latest energy- saving features: the fin­ est luxuries and most up-to-date conveniences. 
Each Briarwiek home has all the luxuries you look for in a new home. 
Central air and heat, ex­ quisite carpeting, profes­ sionally decorated inter­ iors and kitchens with dishwashers, disposers, ranges and vent hoods 
Many have fireplaces, indoor utility rooms, sunken living areas, beamed and vaulted ceilings and garden kit­ chens. 
Briarwiek is served by the North East District. 
The children attend its preferred schools: R e­ gency Elementary. Ma­ dison Middle and M a­ cArthur High 
Away from the noise and congestion of the ci­ ty. Briarwiek is like liv­ ing in the country. It is nestled atop a lovely hill overlooking Northern 
Hills Country Club. 
Less than two minutes away, numerous shop­ ping centers provide every convenience. Re­ creational facilities and community parks are also nearby. 
No city taxes in Briar- wick means lower monthly payments than for a comparable home in another area. 
VA financing can be arranged with no down payment and no closing costs. Other types of fin­ ancing are also available. 
To reach Briarw iek, drive north of Loop 41(1 on 
Wetmore 
Road. 

GREAT AM ERICA hom es found in seven prestige communities 
Great America homes emphasize all quality with custom touches 

Quality built elegance and dynamic styling add up to the personality-plus 
Great Am erica homes creating so much excite­ ment among home buyers in San Antonio 
Every turn of the cor­ ridor and every room of the home surprises the visitor with refreshing and exciting features 

Enter a Great America 

CLASSIFIED D ISM A Y 
CLASSIFIC) D ISM A Y 

Great bathroom, 
Carol McClannahan! 

D on't be surprised it someone tells you how great your Great America nome looks. Because at 
Great America, we believe you can see the difference quality makes. 
In our garden kitchens, with handffnished cabinets and top quality appliances. In our roomy living areas, with vaulted cathedral ceilings, built-in bookcases and woodburn- ing fireplaces. In our lavish ceramic tile baths, with marble vanities and decorator appointments. 
Even in our generous mas­ ter suites, with private baths and walk-in closets. 
Everywhere you look, there is careful attention to design, styling, practicality and encrgy-cfficiency. 

 home tn the breathtak­ ing. panoramic view of a spacious living area with brick-crafted fireplaces and soaring ceilings which may extend beyond second-story liv­ ing areas or indoor bal­ conies. Generous panels a} glass merge the envir­ onment and the home in­ to one airy, open living concept. 
Panoramic 

Natural utilization of space by the 
Great 
America home designers elim inates the four- walled. dosod-in feeling of conventional housing. 
Instead, a Great America home may center life ar­ ound an enormous family living area adjacent to the breakfast nook and kitchen and with easy access to outdoor patios, pools and garden lands­ caping. 
Formal living and din­ ing areas, many va ith bu ilt-in buffets, cabinets and glass-doored upper cabinets for display lie to the opposite side of the kitchen, creating a com­ plete walk-through serv­ ing area perfect for home entertaining. 
This unstructured feeling of extended living space is found among the bedrooms and master suite, all tucked away from traffic areas for privacy and many with sloped ceilings, glass- paneled walls and indoor or outdoor balconies overlooking great views or living areas below. 
Master suite plans exa­ mine the alternatives to 

 design, styling, practicality ana energy-ei 
But that's only the inside story. Outside,

America homes are strikingly individualistic. Each home is designed for its particular homesite. Some are traditional, others reflect the informality of California styling. Some have soaring rooflines, cedar trim and 

 second-story balconies. 
Others are simple, yet ele­ gant. But all are equally suited to entertaining and day-to-day family living. 
You'll find these really great homes in San 
Antonio's finest com­ munities. In Northwest 
San Antonio, we have new homes in Park Forest, 
Hidden Creek, Forest Oak 
Estates, and now, 
Elm Creek. In North 
San Antonio, we have new homes in Thousand 
Oaks, The Oaks in 
San Pedro Hills, and 
Hidden Forest. Each community is minutes from excellent schools, near major shopping and employment centers. 
Prices range from the upper-4o's to $1oo,ooo 
Visit these fine communities today and look for our new red, white and blue signs. For additional informa­ tion on a particular community, call 69o-o3oo. The really great homes in San Antonio are Great America homes, lust ask any of our homeowners.

San Antonio EXPRESS-N E W S j—Sunday February 27 1977 

Briarwiek opens series 

Trailwood houses suit Hill Country 

The family looking for peaceful country living north of San Antonio will find that Trailwood fills all qualifications. 
Trailwood is an exclu­ sive area of prime wood­ ed properties varying in size from I’-2* to 3-acre hom esites priced from 
$7,15o. 
----------- ciA isT m b bisSUr---------- 

The seren ity of the cou n trysid e has been maintained in Trailwood through careful planning of the tract locations. The b enefits of ow ning acreage in this beautiful area of h illtops and sw eep in g v a lley s are many. 
The tracts in Trailwood 
C L A SSI TflbbKPLAY----------------- 

 leave plenty of space for gardens or orchards, as well as room for a horse or two. Bikers and hikers will find hours of plea­ sure on the wide, winding drives through the area.

The home designs have been chosen to blend with the country environment, yet contain all the luxury features hoped for in homes priced from 
IBI .HOO to $92,5oo. Much thought has boon given in the p lacem ent of the homes to gain the best advantage of prevailing sum m er breezes. Addi­ tional insulation in Don 
Smith hom es includes subfloor insulation, in­ suring econom ical e n ­ ergy use. 

The home at 289oo Bent 
Trail is a good example of Don Smith C o.’s in­ genuity. The home has three generously sized bedrooms, master bath with sunken bathtub and guest bath The 15 by 22 foot living room features a corner rock fireplace and sliding glass doors to an outside patio that has a view of the surrounding woods. The star feature of this large home of 
2,o22 sq ft. is a unique 15 by IB foot library loft, overlooking the living room and accessible via a circular, wrought iron stairway. An all-electric kitchen, breakfast room, formal dining room, full utility room and two-car garage with large stor­ age area com p lete the floor plan.

Co.. Hon Macon, Boerne 
Community Builders and 
Homes by Vicki (Vicki 
Schleyer).

Telephone Co. and a se­ lection of either the 
Northside or the Boerne 
School District. City-tvpe utilities are available in

Another Denton Development 

A convenient location, invigorating country- fresh atm osphere and handsome designer in­ teriors m ake Woodhill 
Apartments popular. 
Some recent residents at the apartment community, 49o9 Wood- stone Dr. off the Huebner 
Road exit from NAV. Ill 
IO, moved there because i f s only m inutes from the South Texas Medical 
(e n te r and the new 
USAA complex. Others, including some military personnel, chose Wood­ hill purely for its esthetic value. 
Hilltop 

 cheery interiors give the com m unity a most ap­ pealing appearance. 
Woodhill's thoughtful planning includes ample room for full-size washers and dryers with connections provided in some floor plans. Wood- burning fireplaces, pri­ vate patios and balconies, private dress­ ing areas and separate dining areas and, in som e units, breakfast nooks. 
An ideal spot for en ­ tertaining or being en ­ tertained is Woodhill's elegant clubhouse, pool and sun patio. The faci­ lities include a formal 

 clubroom with fireplace, game room with card ta­ bles and separate lounge with fireplace. 
W oodhill’s spacious one- and two-bedroom studios and one-, two- and three-bedroom apartm ent hom es are now leasing. Furnished model apartments are on display and the Leasing 
Information center open daily until 9 p m 
Woodhill is a develop­ ment most easily reached by taking NAV. Ill IO north to the Huebner 
Road exit and continuing on the a cc e ss road to 
Woodsville Drive and the entrance to Woodhill. 

A truly graciou s ad­ dress. Woodhill is situat­ ed at the top and side of a quiet, wooded hill with a beautiful, unspoiled view of genuine rolling h ill­ sides. The rustic, con­ temporary redwood e x ­ terior and bright and

Schwarz heads realty 

A long-standing friend of the 
San 
Antonio builder-dev eloper com ­ munity has joined Mor­ ton / Southwest. 

Norris Schwarz of San 
Antonio recently was nam ed m anager of 
Morton 
/ 
Southwest 
Realty, with offices at 
I IHI J Perrm-Beitel Rd. 

Well known 
Schwarz is well known in and has been closely related to the building* development and real es­ tate business in San An­ tonio for more than IO years. 

Before coming to San 
Antonio, Schwarz was a partner in A dcraft, one of the largest advertising agencies in Little Rock. 
Ark With other related experience in wire ser­ vice, newspapers, radio and TV work, he has a total of m ore than 2o years experience in mass media and advertising. 

Prior to assuming his position with Morton / 
Southwest 
Realty. 
Schwarz was classified advertising director of the Express / News Corp 
Schwarz is a Phi Theta 
Kappa graduate of Little 
Rock Junior College, an extension of the Univer­ sity of Arkansas. He is serving on the Publicity and Public* Relations and 
Builder - Realtor Com­ m ittees of San Antonio 
Bourd of Realtors Inc. 
(SABORI, Schwarz is also on the Sales and 
Marketing and Program 
C om m ittees of the 
G reater San 
Antonio 
Builders 
A ssociation 
(OSABA) and a member of the San Antonio Mort­ gage Bankers A ssocia­ tion.

San Antonio E X P R E S S -N E W S — Sunday February 27 1977 

Davis wins escrow post 

San Antonio EXPRES5-N EW S—Sunday February 27 1977 
Page I I D 

R A Y W ILEY, left, and Frank M an u p e lli 
Ray Wiley wins special blazer 

Mission Title Co. Pre­ sident Roger Bowden has announced that John Da­ vis has joined the com­ pany as escrow officer. 
Davis is in the company's main offices in the Alamo 
Savings Tower. 
Davis has 17 years of experience in the real estate, construction and title business. He has re­ cently been involved in teaching real estate for new' brokers and agents. 
In making the an­ nouncement, 
Bowden 

Ray W ile y received his Royal 
Purple Spike Club Blazer from 
Prank Manupelli, president of 
Greater San Antonio Builders 
Association, for having brought 
15o new members into the asso­ ciation. 
Wiley joins a select group of only 6o wearers of the blazer — out of the Na­ tional Association of Home Builders' 
82,ooo-plus members. 
Highly respected 

The Royal Purple Blazer is a highly respected symbol among 
Spike 
Clubers for outstanding achievement in the membership field. W iley achieved this highest Spike pinnacle in 

 a three-year period. He joins builder- developer Jim Uptmore as the only other member of the local association to achieve this level of recognition. 
Wiley, during his tenure as mem­ bership chairman, created the famous 
Rusty Spike Award for "unmeritorious non-achievement.” 
Wiley said, “ Look, fella. Member­ ship work requires a degree of persis­ tence and perspicacity unmatched by an other committee work. After all, you’re asking a guy to put his money on the line, and we needed to find a way to put some humor into the thing. 
Hence, the Rusty Spike Award.” 
It is a sought-after and a cherished insiders award presented usually at 
Wiley's discretion. Manupelli is one of the awardees. 

 said. “ John will be very much of an asset to this company. He has an ex­ cellent background, and ho is deeply committed to professionalism in the real estate and title in­ dustries.'' 
He added that the ad­ dition of Davis to the 
Mission Title staff is an­ other part of the com­ pany's policy of provid­ ing the best possible title service to attorneys, builders and real estate agents.

^ it 
& I 

Mortgage money available 

Three years ago, when mort­ gage money was scarce, most home buyers were happy just to get through a lenders’ front door. In many parts of the country, what money was avai­ lable carried interest rates of IO per cent or even higher. 

‘‘Happily, today mortgage money is readily available, and most rates of interest have dropped to about 9 per cent.” reports Larry Rosow of Rosow & 
Kline, Realtors. "Many mortgage in­ stitutions are again competing for homes to finance, and the buyer is an excellent position to shop for lower rates of interest and fewer service charges." 
What lenders look for 

“ In shopping for a mortgage, the home buyer should realize that a lend­ ing institution is looking for property that justifies financing and a buyer with established credit.” states Resow . 
“ The size of the down payment is im­ portant. Generally, the larger the cash investments by the buyer, the more favorable terms from the lender.” 
Most buyers are adv ised to put up at least 2o per cent of the home’s selling price, although various mortgage in­ surance programs can reduce down payment requirements to IO or even 5 per cent. Lower down payments, though, generally carry extra costs, higher interest rates and additional service charges. 
“ Of course, most real estate firms such as ours maintain close contacts with local mortgage lenders,” Rosow concludes, “ and a part of our service is helping buyers secure the most favor­ able home loans available.” 
Beyond the size of the down pay­ ment, a shopper for a home mortgage will make a good first impression on lending officers by having facts and figures organized, suggests Rosow. 
“ This is particularly important for people moving into San Antonio from other parts of the country because the gutiiiwio 

Chandler to Lakeside 

BO B O W E N S, right, and Terry W ie g e l 
Jefferson office starts 

Schaefer, the build­ ing-marketing division for houses by Schaefer 
Cos., has announced the recent appointment of a new salt's manager for 
Lakeside. 
Don Chandler, who joined Schaefer about a year ago. is the sales manager for the firm s homes iii the southeast­ ern Bexar County devel­ opment 
Chandler, who holds a 
Bachelor of Arts degree awarded by Texas AAM 
University with a major m economics and minor in real estate, pre\ mush managed sales in two northern 
San 
Antonio communities. Northern 
Hills and 
Live 
Oak 
Estates. 
He is a Dallas native who says lie's found real estate sales iii the San 
Antonio area a “ chal tonging career.” 
Chandler was cited bv 

I , * * J s .’-V * ' ' 
J ’ A * > . ' h *. > 

D O N C H A N D L E R 

Schaefer for selling more than $2 million i ii real estate last year. 

 ciAisimo oTmiir 

 home purchase and mortgage loan are among their first business dealings in our community.” 
Rosow A Kline, Realtors, is a member of RELO. the nation's largest not-for-profit relocation service and suggests that mortgage loan shoppers: 
•Provide the lending officer with a copy of the sales agreement which in­ cludes the purchase price and address of the new home. 
•Keep in mind the cash investment you are able to make, recognizing that the lender will determine the amount of the mortgage loan on an official ap­ praisal report of the home's market value. If the home is priced higher than the appraiser determines it is worth, you may have to make up the difference with a higher down pay­ ment. 
•List the family's current income and its sources — salaries and invest­ ments. 
•List the fam ily’s current assets, including savings account balances, life insurance policies, equity in other property, market value of stocks and other investments, including auto­ mobiles. home furnishings, art work and jewelry. 
•List family's credit references — banks, department stores, credit un­ ions. institutions granting previous mortgages. 
•List the family’s financial obliga­ tions — bank loan and revolving credit balances, ongoing medical expenses such as nursing home care for tduei 1> relatives, educational bills such as college expenses. 
“ By putting this information to­ gether before you shop for your home kum. you’ll be able to support your requests in an efficient and business­ like manner, Rosow points out. “ Alao, as you will want to talk with several lending institutions, you’ll have the information each needs ready to transfer to their individual application forms.”

JO H N D A V IS, right, and R oge r Bow den 

Close door 

CtAMimO WJBIAY 

If the doors to those rooms are kept open, they defeat their purpose because the heat from the other rooms flows in­ to the cool areas, so the units in the warm rooms keep working overtime as the heat flows out. 

CtAMiniD WWUT 

Homeowners with elec­ tric baseboard are trying to reduce their bills by drastically reducing the temperature in some rooms when they arc not being used, reports the 
Better Heating-Cooling 
Council. 

Robert E. Owens Sr., president of 
Beanie 
Owens Co., Realtors, has announced the opening of a new office at 341 St 
Cloud in the Jefferson area. 

Its owner-manager is 
Terry Wiegel 
Although operational for several weeks, the business was officially launched with an open house last week. 

Participating in the festivities were business neighbors; associates in the real estate, title and mortgage industries; 
Deanie Owens officers 

 and staff; and communi­ ty leaders. 
The opening of the of- fiee marks the introduc­ tion of localized real es­ tate services into the 
Jefferson area "We saw a need iii this neighbor­ hood and fulfilled i t " said Wiegel “ This is an area of older, larger homes, and there is a specific market for these homes.” 
Wiegel added that the office would be open se­ ven days a week, and hi* extended an un italian to customers and neighbors to come iii and get ac­ quainted. 

Thermostats 

Saves cost 

It’s possible to save from HI to 15 per cent on tilt' cost of home re­ modeling bv doing some of the work yourself. Pp to date building pro­ 

 ducts. such as Ander­ sen’s Perma-Shicld win­ dows and gliding doors, enable many a competent do-it-yourselfer to handle the carpentry. 

If you must constantly raise the setting on your room thermostat to stay comfortable iii cold weather, the chances are you have a Ime-voltage thermostat. These usual­ ly are installed with electric baseboard heaters and have the un-

C L A S S IF IE D D IS M A Y 
C l A S S IH fD D IS M A Y 
C L A S S IflC D D IS M A Y 

 fortunate characteristic of “ droop.” 
That s a problem in­ herent in some of these thermostats, and the best remedy is to install a lovv-voltage thermostat instead, advises the Bet­ ter 
Heating-Cooling 
Council.

YOUR GOVERNMENT MUST PUBLISH 
THIS REPORT ADVISING YOU HOW THESE FUNDS HAVE BEEN USED OR OBLIGATED DURING THE YEAR FROM JULY I. 1978, THRU DECEMBER 31, 
1976. THIS IS TO INFORM YOU OF YOUR GOVERNMENT'S PRIORITIES ANO TO ENCOURAGE YOUR PARTICIPATION IN DECISIONS ON HOW FUTURE 
FUNDS SHOULD BE SPENT

The individual selected will possess in-depth quality assurance supervisory experience within the production area of a manufacturing company. A degree is required, preferably in the science or engineering field. Must be people- oriented.

SWEARINGEN 

A s / t A k T i r y r s t o o f y f » o 
« a t / o i n 
/ 

Continued growth of Swearingen Aviation Corporation has created a demand for additional employees desiring careers in aircraft manufacturing. 

Swearingen has immediate requirements for: 

PRODUCTION: it Sheet metal mechanics minimum of I year experience sheetmetal assembly 

ADMINISTRATIVE: it Accounts Payable Bookkeeper • minimum of 2-3-4- years general bookkeeping experience, preferably in accounts payable area, in ad­ dition, typing in 1o-key adding machine, skills required. it Technical Typist • Minimum 7o-8o wpm typing, must have experience using IBM Selective Composing machine. 

TECHNICAL: it Technical Writer - Required extensive background in technical publica­ tions for aircraft. Must have experience with illustrative parts catalog maintenance manuals and related aircraft publications. 

COMPANY BENEFITS INCLUDE: 

6D6 ADMINISTRATIVE 
FIMANCIAl 
6o6 ADMINISTRATE 

FINANCIAL 

• Retirement Program 
• Insured Sick Pay 
• 9 Holidays 
• Tuition Assistance 
• Bereavement Pay 

• Compony Sponsored Employee Activities 
• Reserved Pay Differential 

• Job Stability 

• Group life Insurance 
• Group Medico! Insurance 
• liberal Vocation Benefits 
• Disability Benefits 
• Job Posting 
• Jury Duty Pay 

Swearingen is o growth oriented aircraft manufacturer competing in the general aviation industry. We ore committed to a policy of promotion from within and offering employees opportunities for advancement based on their individual ability and performance. 

 lf you are interested in knowing more about these openings ond a possible future with 
Swearingen, telephone Paul Granato, Personnel Administrator, at 824-9421, Ext. 319. You may oho apply in person at the employment oHice, Swearingen Aviation Corporation, In­ ternational Airport, San Antonio, Tx. (come East on Bitters Road past Blossom Athletic 
Center, turn right on NE entrance rood.)
