C O N S T R U C T I O N M 
A N A G E M 
E N T T R A I N 
E E 

H O M ECRAFT C O R P O R A T IO N is an ag gressive fast p a ce d residential construction firm, ded ica ted to sound prin cip als o f m an a g e ria l develo p ­ ment. W e are seeking self-starter, who is interested in a ll phases o f residential construction a n d m anagem ent. This Superintendent-Trainee position will be filled b y an intelligent, g o a l-o rie n ted in d ivid u al who is w illing to work long hours, 6 days a week an d who needs a growth position, where income is directly re la te d to his contribution to m eeting com pany objectives. A college degree is not necessaiy, but an y college is a plus. Construction experience is not req uired, but we p re fe r 5 years business a n d / o r m ilitary background.

Sambo’s is looking for Manager Partners. 

One of the nation’s leading chains of family restaurants 

 offers talented, hard-working people 

 a tremendous opportunity to earn what they’re worth. 

 ou’re the person w e’re looking for if: 

You have management experience and are up to the challenge of running a 
$ 5 o o ,o o o a year rest­ aurant. 

You're willing to go through a six-month training program so thorough and practical it’s a model for the restaurant industry. 

You want to do more than manage a restaurant — you want to invest as a partner and share in the profits. 

You’re looking for more than a job, but a real career with a company that offers some of the best fringe benefits in the restaurant in­ dustry.

DRIVERS

G re y ­ hound drivers en|oy ex cedent woges, liberal benefits; including paid pension pion, paid holidays, poid vacation a fte r one year, cost-of-living a llo w a n ­ ce, free travel benefits, group m edical pion, etc.

More 
Classified 
On 

Hill IP ll I I W i l l 

Three beautiful 
^ 

 evenings to remember 

Swam:' 
I 

/ he I nit rd States and my country share a 

3ooo-kilometer border, said Guillermo Rossel de La 

Lama, Mexico's nae Minister of Tourism. 
It con­ 

 nects and unites us — not dirides us. 
This a as the 

 spirit of 
Three Evenings to Remember in Acapulco 

— a gala journey for press and world socialites 

 hosted by the Mexican National t ourist donned and 

Rra niff Internationa I. 

MILDRED 
WHITEAKER 

EXPRESS NEWS WOMEN S [D U O * 

The engraved invitation read: 

Mig uel -Heman, preside!! Ie- 
(.on se jo A a d o n a i de I aristae 

 d e Me. K U O , a n d H a r d i n g I.. 
La ie re ti ce, c h a i r m a n o f the hoard a n d president, It rn ti iff 
I n t e r n a t i o n a l C o r p o r a t i o n , request the h o n o u r o f your presence for th r ee Lceilings to R e m e m b e r in A c a p u lc o . 
February, 1o77. 

Inside the creme-colored folder. 
Hie evenings with hosts and hos­ tesses were listed i i i order. 
I glanced at my calendar. Then phoned an acceptance lo the closest of the five RSVP designations rang­ ing from New York to Dallas to 
Mexico City to Acapulco. 
OneTiundred and fifty members ot the international set accepted the same invitation — the globe trotters generally known as the ‘"Beautiful 
People.” 
Also some 5o members of the press including our own syndicated 
Washington. D. C., columnist Betty 
Beale; former San Antonian Nancy 
Holmes, a staff member of Town and Country Magazine who travels the world as a freelance writer and photographer; and a contingent from Women’s Wear Daily. All B P ’s read WWD.

There’s a chicken You can cook it. You can order in. Or we can go out. I’m not doing anything.” 
Ile applauded ( "Thank God you’re not playing m artyr again!” ) and took mc out lo dinner 

Furthermore. I found that once I said “ I don’t want to do that” to my husband. I could say “ I can't take care of the dog while you’re on vacation” to my stepmother and ” 1 want x-v-z provision in the con­ tract” to my agent. 

Andrew Salter, a leading 
New York psychologist who is considered the father of mo­ dern behavior therapy, prefers the word “ excitation” to assertiveness ( ’’Assertive­ ness has aggressive connota­ tions” ). 
Ile contrasts “ inhibitory” people with “ excitatory” tro­ pic. “ Tho inhibitory try to be everything lo everybody, and end up by being nothing to themselves 
“ They are chameleons try­ ing to please the people they are with. They express every­ thing but what they feel. 
They find it difficult to say no. 
They an* always doing things they don’t want to do.” 
Assertion 

In contrast, the excitatory person “ is direct. He re­ sponds outwardly to his en­ vironment When he is con­ fronted with a problem, he takes immediate constructive action 
“ Ile sincerely likes people, but he does not care what they may think. He makes rapid decisions and likes responsi­ bility. Above all. the excita­ tory person is free of anxie 

^ 
I FEEL PINE - 
D inner ? you 
’/by COo< IT I 

One of my mother's dictums stressed the ne­ cessity of giving your husband a good dinner. 

And I always did, even though I g«»t up at six. worked all day at a very demanding jol), and usually came home wanting a little French maid to bring me dinner i i i bed. 
The only French maid available was named Jean 
(me), and she felt she had to serve her husband the gour­ met food Mama had brought her up to feel was proper fare for a hardworking man at the end of a long day. 
No hamburgers for me. 
One Friday I came home after a particularly taxing day, took one look al that mangy chicken in the refri­ gerator. went upstairs, took a bubble bath arui retired to bed with a highball and a good spy story. 
' 
My husband, Herb, arrived some time later, took a look at me, and inquired with con­ cern, “ Are you sick?” 

I answered, “ I feel fine. I just don’t want to cook ton­ ight. You have a choice. 

HER COM PU I E SPRING & SUMMER COLLECTION 
W ILL BE MODELED INFORMALLY TOMORROW, 
DOWNTOWN: TUESDAY AT NORA Ii STAR M ALL. AND 
HER FASHION ENVOY WILL BE HERE TO 
ASSIST YOU WITH SELECTIONS. 
COUTURIER SALON. 

Far too many people con­ fuse assertion with aggres­ sion. Nonassertiveness is self-denying, inhibited beha­ vior where you allow others to choose for you 
Assertiveness is making your ow n choices, standing up for yourself appropriately. 

See ASSERTIVE, Rage 2-E 

F 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS —Sunday February 27 I 97/ 

Assertive but never aggressive 

Continued from Pago I-Ii 

 and having an active orientation to life. 
You stand up for your legitimate rights in such a way that the rights of others are not violated. 
Aggressiveness is an act against others that minimizes their worth as people, where you enhance vourself at the expense of another person, stand up for your rights in such a way that the rights of others are violated, and achieved by in­ flicting deliberate hurt. 

\ oil attack the person rather than his/her behavior. Frequently aggressive behavior may take the form of an outburst that stems from past pent-up anger. Letting someone else know your angry feelings at the time they occur can be assertive behavior. 
As Salter says. "Excitation (or assertiveness) is a two-way street. 

Aggressiveness is a one-way street which pays no attention to the wishes of the other person. It is nonadaptive." 
Because they have beett socia­ lized to be submissive, women particularly get confused when they want to speak up. They set* the alternative to keeping quiet as aggressiveness — and that s 
"unfeminine.” But the Assertive­ ness Training (AT) goal is to be effective iii an appropriate way. 
Let s take some situations com­ mon to women and show what possible nonassertive, aggressive, and assertive responses might be. 

SITUATION ONE: Recently you met a new man at a ski resort. He volunteered to drive you back home and en route you stopped for dinner. When the check came he discovered he had little cash and no credit curd. 
Nim volunteered to lend him the 

 money and forked over $25. That was a month ago and you haven't heard from him since. You want vour money back. 

SITUATION TWO: 
You’re in line at the supermarket eounter with a shopping cart full of gro­ ceries The quick checkout counter is closed. 
You’ve already been Nice Nellie and let one woman with a few items go ahead of you. Now, a second woman asks. ‘"Can I go through?” 

SITUATION TH REE: You have a very dependent and talkative friend whb c alls every day at six o'clock just w hen you’re preparing dinner. You can never get her off 
Hie phone. 
Here are the answers: 
SITUATION ONE: The man who owes you money. 

Unassertive: 
You do nothing. wait for him to call, and hope 

 someday you’ll find the $25 check in the mail. 

Aggressive: 
You call him and say, “ Listen, what kind of person are you? You owe me money and you don't even have the decency to pay it back — or even to get in touch with me. I have the feeling you'll never pay it back.” 

Assertive: You call and explain, 
“ I’m calling about the money si­ tuation. Perhaps you’ve forgotten the $25 you owe me. Can you send me a check for it?” 
And if he says. "I don’t have it now,” you counter with, "What do you think we should do about it? I need the money.” 

SITUATION TWO: In line at the supermarket counter. 

Unassertive: You let the second woman get ahead of you and inside you seethe ut your own passivity. 
That night you take yoni anger out on yourself or your family. 

Aggressive: You berate the wo­ man with some crack like “ Don’t be so pushy.” 

Assertive: 
You say, “ Sorry. I was here first” and start getting 
\ our money ready for the clerk. 

SITU A TIO N T H R E E : 
The friend who is a compulsive tele­ phone talker. 

Unassertive: Day after day you continue to listen, following your familiar pattern of putting her needs ahead of yours. 

Aggressive: "Listen, other peo­ ple have problems too. only you never seem to think so. I ’m getting pretty tired of listening to you say the same things over and over.” 

Assertive: 
“ Look, I ’m glad to talk to you but this is always a bad time for me. Let me call you back after dinner w hen my mind will be clear to concentrate.” 

Monday in the Express: The rights of women.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS —Sunday February 27 1977 

Teens touting a touch o f Braille 

Braille T-shirts may be­ come the newest fashion fad! 

Louis Braille, in 1824, de­ vised the system of raised dots for touch reading and writing by the blind. He never dreamed then that his evolutionary method would appear on American bo­ soms. 

A Washington firm. Daze!, will place quarter-inch raised dots on 

 custom ordered shirts to spell out the name of a school, organization—whatever. Imagine the impact of a T-shirt which re­ quires “ touch” in order to read the lettering! 

T-shirts have already had a tremendous impact on society. 
Every individual can be a walk­ ing signboard with his lettered cotton knit proclaiming “ Keep 
America Clean,” “ Property of 
San Quentin” or “ Champion Beer 
Drinker.” 

No longer is a T-shirt meant to be worn as an undergarment. 
Youngsters who used to take 

 pride in a T-shirt boosting Texas 
University or the YMCA now in­ sist on screen prints of heroes ranging from King Kong to Tony the Tiger. 

Every shopping center has its own T-shirt printer-painter with designs ranging from CB buddies to Beethoven. 

Every cereal box and cookie sack offers a coupon for ordering a T-shirt. My school teacher friend wears with pride her cotton knit which reminds her English student! — “ Don’t Use No Con­ tractions.” 

T-shirts can be ordered today in pairs. One set has become especially popular. “ I ’m with 
Stupid.” says one of the shirts. 
The other, intended to walk be­ side the first, says “ Stupid.” 

Another popular dun is 
‘lie s the Boss” on one shirt and “ Boss” on the second. 

I'm so impressed with the money-making possibilities of the 
Braille shirt, I wish I had thought of it myself. 

It struck me as so clever that I immediately wrote to a friend to share my find. “ Can you ima­ 

 gine today's generation wearing shirts that invite fondling?” I asked her. 

Yesterday she answered my letter. She enclosed a T-shirt advertisement of her own from a 
Michigan newspaper, lier T-shirt find topped mine—by far. 

The ad told of a New York firm who sells a T-shirt that could affect the moral tones of Ameri­ ca's T-shirt trade. 

“ I AM A V IR G IN !” the shirt announces in bold black letters 
Then, just below tin1 phrase, it says in smaller print, “ (This is an old shirt) ”

Mood of spring fashion 
Toastmistresses plan meeting of Council 8 is colorful and feminine 

Council 8. Texoma Re­ gion International Toast­ mistress Clubs, will have 
Us third quarterly meet­ ing Saturday in Oak Hills 
Motor Inn. 

 wardrobe, 

 takes you 

 daytime into 

ADELE SIMPSON'S spring collection includes these A z­ tec prints, both in fe a th e ry -p rin te d geo rg ette 

 dimension 

 to a basic 

 in this “ realities collec­ tion" include the shawl with long fringes or flowered borders to match the border print of the dress. 
Waists 
Mrs Simpson s clothes this season are waist­ line-conscious, although not always with clearly defined waists 
Little laced bodices ap­ pear on evening dresses with miniscule waists. 
Tilt1 same fabric or color combination may appear again in a slim-wrapped column or one-shoulder dress. 
There are four major groups of her latest col­ lection. First is the com­ posed dressing for the realities of busy business and civic lives — soft suits with eased jackets, skirts and blouses, and versatile coats and dresses Second is the group of day dresses iii border patterns and bright colors. Third is her disco-dressing de­ signs — fluid, graceful dresses for restaurant dining and disco dancing. 
Fourth is for the indivi­ dual, personality dress­ ing, for the woman who wants to be remembered and noticed at her best.

The spring “ realities" of fashion from one of 
Am erica s leading de­ signers. Adele Simpson of New York. come to San 
Antonio this week. 
The collection will be informally modeliMl all day Monday in Frost's 
Downtown designer salon and Tuesday in North 
Star Mall 
Mrs. Simpson's envoy. 
Alfred Klauber, will be on hand to chat fashion and to assist with selec­ tions. 
The New York de­ signer’s collection fol­ lows the month long whirlwind of F ro st’s 
“ California 
Fashion 
Rush" — a salute to the 

Golden State’s many ta­ lent iv! designers. Among those featured were Bob 
Mack ie of Cole, Belga and Paul Scott, president of Ernst Strauss and 
Schnell Sports. 
The California fashions will remain til all Frost’s stores. 
Now the focus switches to the East Coast and 
Adele Simpson's forecast for spring. 
Design 

The purpose, the per­ son, the taste and the intelligence-of American women today are what 
Mrs Simpson and her daughter and associate, 
.loan Raines, term the 

“ R ealities” on which their spring designs are hast'd. 
“ Nothing derived or contrived," says the pe­ tite designer. "These are clothes with the ring of truth in softness, gentle­ ness, appropriateness and quality." 
The collection features vivid color — clear reds, greens and navy, fresh raspberry and blue and the naturals like bamboo 
Color is linked with pure silks and cottons, jacquard weaves, ultra- fine woolens, wool and matte jersey, Ultrasuede, faeonne satin crepe, silk georgette and chiffon.

Love designed Valdez home 

THE FRANK M. VALDEZES, Omar, Lance, Janina and Frank 

PHOTO BV H M DEAN JR 
Dieting on Jiber 

A 
Lovely w rites: 
“ P lease explain what 
“ high-fiber” m eans in relation to dieting. 
Friends of mine have ta­ ken up with high-fiber diets. 
They say it means eat­ 

 ing a great deal of roughage. 
Does this cause a loss of weight? Is roughage good for you?” 
The answer: High-fiber foods include whole grains, oatm eal, brown rice, beans, soybeans. 

B v ------------------- 
Mary Sue Miller 

TRAVIS PARK 
JEWELERS 

428 N. St. M a ry's St. 
N ext to Slue Bonnot Hotel 

SALE 
DIAMOND EAR STUD MKT 

AU HME QUAUTY FUU CUT DIAMONDS 

Pork fro * Up to I Hr. with Pwrchato 
At San Antonio Bonk A Trull O arage. 

C ath , Budget, Layaway, BankAmericard 
Matter Charge, American Kiprew 

T ra v is P a rk J e w e le rs 

N e x t to the B lu e Bonnet H o te l Lobby 

4 2 8 N . St. M a r y ’ s 

 cabbage, peas and bran. 
All approved reducing diets recommend those foods in balanced amounts 
The foods are not only nutritious but help to prevent constipation, a disorder of modern life. 
Various renowned me­ dical men have studied the use of fibers in the diet and recom m end increased amounts as a way of preventing nu­ merous abdominal and other ills. 
On the other hand, re­ searchers have found that an excessive intake can result in the loss of es­ sential vitam in s and minerals; that increasing fiber intake should be a slow process. 
Otherwise, the stomach may react with m um ­ blings and grumblings — hardly a peaceful condi­ tion. 
If, for exam ple, you take in a portion of w hole grain cereal, a slice of whole grain bread and a raw vegetable, you will be with a healthful diet. 
Before taking up with any diet, however, you should consult your doctor. 

This is an absolute ne­ cessity before tying into a bushel of fiber. Thus far, balance is the secret of a diet. 

E ver have the feeling that everything is so perfect, and going so smoothly that you hold your breath thinking — some­ thing's bound to happen. 
M agdalena Valdez laughs saying, 
“ We are so happy. We love our home and think we have the greatest chil­ dren. We are so lucky — I hope we stay that way.” 
Frank and Magdalena Valdez m ar­ ried 15 years ago in California. She didn’t change her name, not because of woman’s lib. her name already was 
Valdez. (This simplified their honey­ moon trip to Hawaii, Japan and Hong 
Kong. Her passport was ready with 
“ Valdez” on it.) 
Frank had worked on designs for a bowling alley and a IO story apartment building in the F ar E ast and they visited the buildings. 

Frank 

Frank is a native of our tow n and his degree is from University of Texas in 
Austin. After working for an architec­ tural firm for a year and a partnership for four, he opened his own firm. 
He taught courses at UT in Austin in the architectural field. He is now tak­ ing courses in it at UTSA. His firm does schools, churches and buildings with a home or two a year. He likes variety. 
He had planned on commercial art 

"When I'm grown, I'm going to be a millionaire, an d I like to sketch my m an sion; g u a rd s an d grounds.' — Omar Val- dez 

 butv architecture won his heart. Res­ toration work is also a favorite. 
He belongs to American and Texas 
Institute of Architects and Task Force of the Chamber of Commerce for the 
Trade Fair. He is a past president of 
Sembradors de Amistad. past director of Cham ber of Com m erce, form er 
Symphony board member, member of 
Urban Renewal and city planning commissions, past national president of LULAC and was a member of Pan 
American Optimists. 
He enjoys fishing and hunting with his family. Tennis and golf also inter­ est him. The whole fam ily enjoys evening walks. 
Oils and watercolors of his can be seen around their home. 
“ I really like to cook, as long as I don't have to do the clean u p ,” he

IN THE 
FAMILY

Magdalena 

Weight 

To diet or exercise? In­ dependently, both will work wonders on your fi­ gure. But together it will make you a head-turner. 
Mv new booklet, WHY 
WEIGHT?, offers a sen­ sible two-week program for trim m in g those edges.

Magdalena grew up at Laguna Beach where they m et through m utual friends. 
Living in San Antonio since their marriage, the last five years have been in their present home. The house was ail old three story home with an acre of land curving down to Olmos Creek. 
Combining their architectural and ar­ tistic talents they have changed it into a showplace. They’ve added spacious rooms to the lower level. The yard has been terraced and beautifully land­ scaped with a patio on one level, a gazebo on another and a picnic table area on another. 
“ We are a tight little family group,” 
Magdalena says and take on projects together.” 
The family belongs to St. Peter’s 
Prince of the Apostles Catholic Church. 
Her mother still has a bridal shop, 
‘‘Gowns by Valdez,” in Santa Anna. 
Magdalena studied dress designing in 
Los Angeles and likes to design clothes for herself and her daughter. “ Of 
Souffle 
I recipe contest 
Souffles will be the category for the next San 
Antonio News recipe con­ test. 
Five dollars will go to the person entering the best souffle recipe by mailing it to Food Editor, 
The News, Box 2171, San 
Antonio, Tex. 78297 be­ fore March 3. 
Write your recipe on one side of a sheet of paper, tell why it is your favorite and sign your nam e, giving your ad ­ dress and daytime tele­ phone number. 
Only tested recipes are eligible, and only one entry from each contes­ tant will be considered. 
The winning souffle re­ cipe will be published 
March 17. Watch for the winning recipe using cauliflower on March 3 and the winning recipe using English peas on 
March IO.

The Day of Recollection of Our Lady of G race 
A ltar Society will br

Grace Catholic Church.

O M I., will conduct the service. Registration will be at 9:3o a.m ., followed by mass at 11:15 a.m.

 course with the jeans craze — Janina isn’t too interested in dresses.” Maybe when she reaches prom stage, Magda­ lena will get her chance to create beautiful gowns. And then there’s al­ ways the bridal gown! 
She has used her love of art and fabrics to create large applique hang­ ings. She has joined the Needlepoint 
Guild to learn new methods. 
Magdalena has served on the boards of Witte Museum. YWCA, Texas Al­ liance of the Arts and is a juist presi­ dent of Sembradores de Amistad. The first organization she joined when she moved here was the Women’s Com­ mittee of the San Antonio Symphony. 
Magdalena and Frank both love to entertain and to cook “ fancy” dishes. 
“ Magdalena makes beautiful desserts such as baked A laska and cheese cakes.” Frank says. 
“ I’ve given cheese cakes to friends for Christmas for years,” Magdalena laughs, “ and this year I decided they would like something different. I guess 
ITI go back to cheese cakes — they were all disappointed.” 
“ We take family vacations to th*' coast or to Mexico and also short trips for just the two of us,” she adds. "We like to visit my mother in California. 
We’re planning a winter trip to Colora­ do now.” 
“ We enjoy the children’s fun at places like Disneyland, Six Flags over 
Texas, or Lion s Country. We plan to visit relatives in Spain when the chil­ dren are a little older.” 
M agdalena and Frank have four children: Frank, almost 14. Lance 12; 
Janina ll and Omar 9. 
Frank is a eighth grader at Alamo 
Heights Junior High School. His fa­ vorite course is history. 
He plays on the tennis team, both

 singles and doubles. He also enjoys football, bike riding, jogging after­ noons and hiking on Alamo Heights nature trails. 
Hunting and fish ing are other hobbies he enjoys. “ Once, on Bob Hall pier we ran into a school of golden croakers. We caught about tit) and filled our ice chests. Now fishing is pretty slow.” 
Frank plays piano, enjoys skating, pool, ping pong, reading fiction and enjoys doing his homework listening to his stereo. He collects stamps and used to play golf. 
He would like to he an architect and will get “ inside” tips working sum­ mers for his father. He will choose 
Princeton or UT in Ausin. 
Lance is a seventh grafter at AH 
Junior School. Ile also plays tennis and is on the Student Council. 
He collects coins and has many old 

 ones from his grandmother. He also has some Canadian and Chinese coins. 
He enjoys the outdoors and likes to fish and hunt and play ping pong He has taken up golf, but is now concen­ trating on tennis. 
Tennis is important and in fact he may be a tennis pro and a lawy er. He’s picked Princeton for his college choice. 
Port Aransas is his favorite coast spot. Frank and Lance both played 
Little League for a number of years 
His chores include w atering the many house plants.

“ My friends are starting to have parties — you know — dancing and stuff like that,” he says 
Janina is a sixth grader at St Mary’s 
Hall. She likes art and music and has taken piano lessons 
Gymnastics is top on her list of in­ terest. She won a blue ribbon for vaulting. 
Very sportsminded, she has taken tennis lessons, played hockey and won a trophy in track. She s been swim­ ming since she was three. “ She swims and dives like a duck," her Mom says 
She does m acram e and beaded jewelry and gave both for ('hristmas. 

Her Siamese cat. Jack. Is her pal. 
Slum ber p artie s are still going strong and 15 girls giggled and talked through lier birthday slumber party. 
She’s learning to cook desserts be- 
• cause that’s her favorite and to sew. 
Omar is a fourth grader at Cam ­ bridge. Math and art are his favorites with art as No. I. He loves to draw constantly, especially Army pictures. 
His parents say he is very good at draw mg. 
“ When I’m grown. I’m going to he a millionaire,” he says seriously, "and I like lo sketch my mansion, guards and grounds.’’ 
He plays violin in the string orches­ tra at school and wants to continue with violin lessons 
He builds model airplanes and rock­ ets and decorates his room with them 
IU1 also likes to catch minnows and frogs and bring them home. He has a goldfish named Alfred and a guppy named Guppy. 
He likes to ride bikes and play bas­ ketball 
Tin* Valdez home was featured on a city pilgrimage and their kitchen was featured in the October issue of Kitchen and Bath Ideas by Better Homes and 
Gardens. The charming yellow tiled island work center was made by all of the family. 
“ We try to give th*' children a moral and religious upbringing,” the Vakle- zes say 
“ And we believe that our togetherness is what makes our happi­ ness.’’

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS —-Sunday Feb 
27 1977 Page • 9-E 
W atercolorists set reception 

M arch m ay com e in like a lamb, but the social lions will keep calendars churning with activity. 

The San Antonio Watercolor 
Group will have a champagne reception at 7:3o p.m. Friday in Trinity University's Chap­ man Graduate Center Library. 
Bill Bristow, chairman of the 
Department of Fine Arts, will gi\e a half-hour slide presen­ tation on watercolor. 

The party will show off the 
5o paintings in the traveling exhibition of th e A m e ric a n 
Watercolor Society, which will h a n g in the li b r a r y until 
March 16. 

Assisting; 

The library will be open for viewing from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. weekdays, from 9 a.m . to 5 p m. Saturdays and from 1:3o to 5 p.m. Sundays. Beth Ei- delberg and Tom Pressly are co-chairman of the exhibition. 

Committee chairmen assist­ ing include Louise Beckham, 

EVE LYNN 
SAWYER 

 reception; Betty Gene Haile and Ivan McDougal, in v it a ­ tions; M a r g a r e t J o n e s , d o ­ cents; and Barry Scott, student tours. 
The San Antonio Watercolor 
Group was organized iii the summ er of 1974 and has some 
25o watercolorists ut all levels of achievement. 

Activities include 
“ paint* outs'' held at scenic sites in the area, four demonstration- seminars a year conducted by* nationally acclaimed guest in­ structors. and lecture-presen­ tations by professionals in the arts and related fields. 
Members also have the op­ portunity to compete in one major group-sponsored, juried exhibition a year. P artic ipa­ tion is also encouraged in spe­ cial events jointly sponsored with watercolor organizations in six o t h e r s o u t h w e s t e r n cities.

Announcing yerw'ii 
Headliners of 1977 

Women in Communications, 
Inc. ha named five outstand­ ing professional women as its 
1977 Matrix Headliners. 
These top career women will share the spotlight with Mar­ lene Sanders, ABC News vice president and director of tele­ vision docum entaries at the 
‘joth annual Matrix Table on 
M arch 18 in the Anacardic 
Room, St. Anthony Hotel. 

Honorees are Leis G. Park- house, life insurance agent with M assach u setts M utual 
Life Insurance Co.; Carolyn H. 
S pears, p re sid in g judge of 
County Court at Law No. I; 
V irginia Stone, first grade teacher at Woodridge Elemen­ tary School; Vivian M. Kiel bossa, office m anager, Kioh bossa Provisioning Co., anc 
Thelma Ledger, information director and assistant eoordin at or of Volunteer Services at 
San Antonio State Hospital. 
The public is Invited to meet the honorees at the cocktail re­ ception at 7 p.m. preceding the 
Matrix banquet. 
The Headliners were selected by members of the San Antonio 
Professional Chapter, Women in Communications, Inc. (WI­ 
C H . from nominations submit­ ted by local organizations and individuals. M rs. Betsy M. 
Welch served as H eadliner chairman. 
Nominees 
To be eligible for nomination, a woman must have been active in her profession for at least two years, have demonstrated herself an expert in her profes­ sion and made noteworthy ac­ com plishm ents iii lier field. 
Additional consideration was 

 given to community involve­ ment . 
Mrs. Parkhouse is recognized for her achievements as a pro­ fessional financial counselor. 
She is an active member of the 
Board of Directors of the San 
Antonio Association of Life Cn- derwriters (SAALU) and the only female committee chair­ man and board member. 
She has qualified for the 
Texas Leaders Round Table, double qualified for the Nation­ al Women’s Leaders Round Ta­ ble, and is the only woman agent to qualify for the Mass 
Mutual South Texas Agency’s 
Wildcatters Club. 
Judge Spears, mem’uet of the 
Quota Club board of directors, is recognized for the programs she has promoted to help reha­ bilitate defendants in criminal cases and to increase docket efficiency in civil and criminal m atters. She is licensed to practice law in the State ol 

 his Natural 
Autumn 
Haze"' nu11* stroller i 
HOW 

She regularly writes and re­ cites her own limericks in the 
Ad-Ribs Show, the annual spoof of the industry sponsored by 
American Women in Radio and 
Television. She holds th*' dis­ tinction of turning down a job u uh the Johnny Carson Tonight 
Show.

San Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S —Sunday February 27 1977 

Sridenschiiur-Biiie 

Miss Madelyn Louise Seidenschnur became the bride of Michael Lee Buie of Jacksonville, Fla., Saturday in St. 
Francis Di Paulo Catholic Church. The 
Rev. George Stump officiated. 
The bride is the daughter of Mary 
Lou Seidenschnur of Austin and Max 
H Seidenschnur. The groom’s parents are Mr. and Mrs. Chester Buie 
Matron of honor was Suzanne Wilson of Fort Worth. Maid of honor was 
Kathy Evans. Bridesmaids were Judy 
White. Annette Collins, Beverly Beh­ rens, and Debbie Buie, sister of the 

 groom. 
Serving as flower girl was Elizabeth 
Crumpton and ringbearer was Brett 
Wosnig. 
Best man was David An­ derson. Groomsmen were Joe Cooper. 
Mike Van DenBerghe, and Terry Buie, 
Jerry Buie, and Bobby Buie, brothers of the groom. Ushers were John Toed and Billy King. 
A reception was held in the Turtle 
Creek Country Club. 
After a wedding trip to Disneyland and Orlando. Fla , the couple will re­ side in Jacksonville. 
Learn to 
Super Sew. 
After 8 easy, inexpensive lessons you will have made at least: 
One T-shirt 
One pair of perfect-fit pants 
Three fashion tops 
One skirt 
One sweater 
One suit jacket 
One swimsuit 

Using Ann Person's unique sewing methods, you sew in a fraction of the time of ordinary sewing. You’ll learn to fit and to design. 
And its so simple. The classes are fun— like a special club meeting You learn. But you love it. 

You can make it. W e w ill show you how. 
Stretch & Sew 
America’s Fabric and Sewing Center 

Carl Hall III, 
Miss Richstatter solemnize vows 

Miss J o Anne Richstatter and Carl L. 
Hall III. both of Dallas, exchanged marriage vows Saturday in Chapel One of Randolph AFB. The Rev. Bernard 
Popp officiated at the ceremony. 
The bride is the daughter of Lt. Col. 
(ret.) and Mrs. Joseph Edward Rich* statter. The groom is the son of Mrs. 
Rose M. Hall of Dublin. Tex. and the late Carl L. Hall 
Maid of honor was Betty Jean Tubbs. 
Bridesmaids were Mary Sepko, Lyn 
Woods, Kathy Doneghy and Jeannie 
Richstatter. Flower girl was Beth Sep­ ko. Ringbearers were Jeffery Hall and 
Steve Sepko. 
Serving as best man was Jeff Senter. 
Groomsmen were Robert Z. Hall. Mike 
Reaves, Larry Cowan and Bob Hensly. 
Ushers were Bitchy Woods Jr., Eddy 
Morin and Larry Sehrank. 
A reception was held in the main ballroom of Randolph A FB Officer’s 
Club. 
After a wedding trip to Lake Tahoe, the couple will reside in Dallas.

Adoption favored 

DEAR ABBY: Our son is 13 y ears old and a freshm an in high school. A 12-year-old junior high girl will have a baby next 
June, and our son will be that baby’s father. 
Thank God he had the courage to bring the little girl to us and tell us. 
The girl’s parents both work, drink and run around while the child stays home days (and many nights) alone, with no supervision whatsoever. 
We went to the girl's parents, and they told us they would have our boy jailed for statutory rape if we didn’t give them $1,ooo in cash. 
My husband said he wouldn’t get in­ volved with blackmail. Then they sug­ gested the kids get married in a state that allows kids their age to m arry with parental consent. We refused. 
We think it better for all concerned if the girl had her baby and gave it up for adoption. Are we doing right in refus­ ing to consent to this m arriage? — 
OHIO PARENTS 
DEAR PARENTS: 
In my opinion, yes. The baby will be much better off 

 i i i an adoptive home with parents who really want a child You need a lawyer to acquaint you ult Ii your son’s rights and obligations. 
It may be a bit late to tell you that your son’s education on "the birds and bees” must have been sadly neglected. 
But perhaps this will serve to warn other parents that this CAN and DOES occur. 
Critic 

DEAR ABBY: 
I am a 32-year-old man who is self-supporting, and alth­ ough I didn’t graduate from college, I did go for two years. I know that my spelling and g ra m m a r is far from perfect, but I’m not exactly illiterate. 
My problem is my m other. She taught school before she was married, and now lives in a distant state. When I write to her, she returns my letters with all the errors iii spelling and grammar “ corrected” with a red pen­ cil! 
At first I just ignored it. but I have had enough. Should I write to her and ask her to please quit correcting my letters? Or should I just quit writing? 

Divorce triggers depression 

Everyone has a problem. What’s yours? For a personal reply, write to 
ABBY: Express-News, Box 2171, San 
Antonio, T ex., 78297. Enclose a stam ped, self-addressed envelope, please. 

My wife says, “ Skip it. Your mother is probably getting senile.” 
Senile at 58. - BUGGED 

DEAR BUGGED: I f s doubtful Why not look at it this way: Your mother is really doing you a favor by pointing out your mistakes. But if you’re all that with her. (Old school die. they just lose their bugged, level teachers never class.) 

 ll c i r s 

Dear Dr. Menninger: Recent­ ly, I read your article about di­ vorce and husbands and wives cheating on each other. I ani a victim of this very situation, for the second time. 
The first time, I divorced my hus­ band Later, for our sake and our son, we re m a rrie d . Then it w asn ’t two years until he was going out with a young woman who was alm ost the same age as our son 
We’ve been separated now for almost a year, and my husband has not yet indicated that he has any love for us or that he desires to reunite his family. 
Needless to say, this has been difficult for my son and me to accept. 
It appears that some men, atter they have had the best years of a w ife’s life, have to search for greener pastures. 
By then, the wife has reached the point in her life when she needs her husband more than when she was young. 

DEAR ABBY: 
My grandmother is the sweetest woman who ever lived 
She had a stroke a couple of years ago and is quite old now. She is always talking about dying. 
When I am with her she tells me to he sure that Aunt G gets this and Uncle B doesn’t get anything. 

And she has told mc repeatedly that she wants me to have her diamond brooch, her good dishes aud her silver, and she wants my husband to r'randpa’s gold watch. 

Helj 

I’m finding this situation getting worse and much harder to bear as time goes by. I am now seeing a psychiatrist which I cannot afford financially. 
But I needed help, and I’m trying to find a way to go on living a happy and decent life without the man who was my husband for 26 years. ll you could advise mc in any way. it 

 would be greatly appreciated. I feel that our son needs help, too, from someone or somewhere. I believe that my husband also needs help, maybe more so than we do. — Thank you — 
Mrs. A L. 
Dear Mrs. A.L.: As long as you are now seeing a psychiatrist, you should look to him for advice. He should also be best able to get your son any help he might need. 
However, your letter did prompt several thoughts. About the time I received it, I came across a study of the relationship of psychiatric illness and divorce, made by some psychiatrists at the Washington University School of 
Medicine in St. Louis. 
Your anguish is experienced by many women and men who have been divorced. The St. Louis study found over three-fourths (7o per cent) of divorced women had some emotional illness, as did two-thirds (68 per cent) of the divorced men. 
The most common problem for both women and men was depression. 
Findings 

To put their findings in perspective, the St. Louis group studied a compara­ ble group of never divorced, married persons. They found that group also had more mental illness than many people might suspect — one-third (34 per cent)of the men and one-sixth (18 per cent) of the women.

 lave 

I know that I am her favorite grand­ daughter, and she has told me repea­ tedly what she wants me to have. 

Since her dying is inevitable, do I continue to tell her not to talk about it?

T h e r e ’s nothing “grabby” in suggesting that she “ write it down.” That’s the only way she can be sure that her wishes will be carried out after she is.

Arthur McCall 
LaMar Roxbury 

Times were tough for me after I was divorced. 
My husband skipped the state and I had to get work in a hurry to feed myself and my children. 
A neighbor woman w ho looked like a cross between the Mona Lisa and an ad for complexion soap told me she became a call girl when her hus­ band’s disability ran out. 
She was in desperate need of money and this was something she could do without a diploma or references. I nearly died of the shock 
When I recovered, I said I’d like to try it. She made a few phone calls and I was in business. 
(Somehow it seem ed more respectable and a lot less complicated than going on welfare.) 
My “ c a r e e r ” lasted four m onths, until I landed a selling job with a cosmetic firm. 
I d be m ortified to death if anyone ever told on me. God bless all them i i i the world who keep their mouths shut. 
They are beautiful peo­ ple. Been There For $1oo

Lonely

“ Daddy, my bike doesn’t shift like it should. Could you fix it?” lf I speak to her, she says, “ Daddy, J c a n ’t concentrate on what I’m reading and listen to you at the same time.” 
Or, “ Daddy, I’m really not interested in that subject." After being re­ buffed a few hundred tunes, I stopped trying to share my thoughts with her. 
Recently, I’ve noticed that when I enter the room and my wife and daughter are talking, a

Dear Lonely: Your w ife is partly responsible for placing you in the 
“ isolation chamber.” A mother sometimes pun­ ishes her husband for real or imagined “ sins” by turning ihc children against “ the old man.” 
(A father can play the same game.) 
This situation d id n’t develop overnight. Too bad you didn’t write 16 years ago. I would have told you to take your wife and go together for counseling. 
Often children develop a sense of appreciation for their parents (or a parent) when they them­ selves have children. I hope you don’t have to wait THAT long, hut don’t be surprised if vou do.

Dr. Menninger invites your com­ ments and questions. Write to him in care of the San Antonio Express, P.O. 
Box 2171, San Antonio, Tex., 78297. 
Because of the volume of mail, he cannot answer each individually hut will handle questions of general inter­ est in his column. 

Clearly, the mental illness is signifi­ cantly greater in the divorced group' than in the married group — twice as great for divorced men. four times greater for divorced women. 

What does this mean? It is unclear whether the emotional illness is the cause or the effect of the divorce. 
Balance your diet 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: 
You mention that we should have a 
“ balanced diet.” Just what does this mean? It seems everybody has his or her own idea of what a balanced diet means. — ILF. 
I think the confusion is iii the term 
“ balanced.’’ lf you substitute “ ade­ quate” for “ balanced,” you will be on firmer ground 
An adequate diet is one that supplies significant amounts of the important nutrients. 
For this purpose foods are grouped into the basic four: (I) milk and milk products; (2) meat, fish and poultry, with nuts and legumes (pod foods such as peas and beans) as alternates; (3) fruits and vegetables; (4) breads and cereals. 
Any reasonable selection from all four of these groups will provide an adequate dict. 
Actually, even the word “ diet" is misused by many. Generally speaking, the word “ nutrition” would be better. 
Diets can vary but nutritional needs are pretty constant. 
Meals follow a recurring pattern in various societies, and that pattern represents the diet of a particular so­ ciety. 
Thus, the North American diet is heavily oriented toward excess fats and carbohydrates, leading to a high inci­ dence of arterial diseases. 
For Americans, balanced nutrition would eliminate much of the vascular disease from which we suffer. 
Nails 

However, the St. Louis study did find a significant number of divorced peo­ ple reported a history of earlier emo­ tional illness which may have con­ tributed to the marital breakup. 
Anger 

One additional thought: when you are involved in an angry conflict in a m ar­ riage, it s normal to blame the partner for the problems. Indeed, if your psy­ chological “ defenses” are working well, you blind yourself to your own shortcomings. 

Rarely, however, is the situation totally one-sided in reality. Each partner has some responsibility for the breakdown of the relationship, some­ times wittingly, som etim es unw it­ tingly. As one of my former teachers used to repeatedly observe, “ It takes two to tango.”

JEANE DIXON 

Dear Dr. Thosteson. Eve always had attractive fingernails 
Recently, 
I have been plagued with some white sores right where the base of the nail joins the skin. 
It is tender, and if I squeeze the nail some pus runs out. The rest of the nail is fine I suppose this is some kind of infection. Have you any information on it? - Mrs R T. 
Impossible to tell ut this distance, but from your description it sounds like paronychia (par-uh)NK K ee-ah). It will require treatment to d e a r it up 
Boor manicuring technique is usual­ ly at lault. Occasionally a hangnail produces a break in the skin fold that allows invasion by either bacteria or a fungus. 
The organism must be identified so that appropriate antibiotic or antifun­ gal applications can be selected. This and hot compresses to promote drain­ age is the usual treatment for parony­ chia. 
In severe infection an incision mav 
I — 

Dr. 
Thosteson w elcom es reader mail but regrets that, due to the trem endous volume received daily, he is unable to answer individual letters. 
Readers’ questions are incor­ porated in his column whenever possible. 

 have to be made to release a pocket of the pus you speak of. The condition is discussed in my booklet on nail health. 
F’or a copy, send 35 cents care of this newspaper with a stamped, self-ad­ dressed envelope. 
Cause 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: Please advise me on the “ gentleman’s disease” — prostate trouble. I am 55. 

There seem to be two schools of thought, and each can cite cases to back up its point of view. Is it lack of sexual intercourse in older men? Or is it sexual intercourse that brings on prostate trouble? 

May I have the benefit of your thoughts? I am married and am wor­ ried because the problem has arisen in my own family as well as in friends’ families. — O.M. 

I like your genteel term , “ gentle­ man’s disease.’’ 
The cause of prostatism (gland en­ largement) is not known. Intercourse has nothing to do with it. 

Some congestion may occur briefly if a sexually active male suddenly stops activity, but this will not cause the changes in fibrous and muscular tissue which are features of chronic prostate enlargement. 

There are other causes — infection, cancer, stone formation, etc. That’s the bad news. The good news is that the gland is so readily accessible that treatment is almost always available. 

NOTE TO MRS. CLN. - Tampons, especially the smaller sizes, are occa­ sionally “ lost." However that would soon cause a malodorous discharge which would force your 14-year-old girl to seek help. Ask lier about that aspect of the matter. 

It is not unusual for a 14-year-old girl to have an interrupted menstrual cycle, and that should be checked. If she balks at seeing a male doctor, perhaps you can find a woman physi­ cian who will put her at ease.

About your wedding 

Are you getting m a r ­ ried soon? Here are gui­ delines and deadlines for sending inform ation to the Express and News. 
A picture of the bride will be p u b lis h ed in thum bnail size free of charge. Engraving fees for larger pictures (en ­ g a g e m e n t or wedding—you may have both) will be determined by size of picture desired. 
There, is no charge tor stories without photos. 
Wedding pictures and copy m u st be in the 
Express-N ew s office at least one week before the wedding date. A black and white glossy photo is required. 
Wedding form s m ust be signed and must con­ tain a daytime telephone num ber for the person submitting the story. 
E n g a g e m e n t a n ­ n o u n c e m e n ts m u st be p u b lish ed at le ast six 

 weeks before the wedding date, therefore they must lie submitted at least se­ ven weeks ahead of the wedding date 
Wedding stories are not accepted after the wed­ ding.

Time For Children To Take Stock 
OD could not be everyw here, and 
\ J J therefore he m ade m others 
A very fit­ ting retort to children who neglect or find fault with mothers might be ' Child heal yourself.'* It is time to turn your gaze inw ard an d ask if you are fulfilling your obligation. Certainly, your accounts receivable from her, although well over-paid, continues to bring interest and dividends. Your accounts payable to her may be long past due 
A recent incident has suddenly refreshed my memories and should encourage all children to-set aside quiet time to take stock 
As president of a local civic organization, I noticed that one dedicated m em ber repeatedly arrived late to each evening m eeting 
Her reason "You see, she said, 
First I feed my ail­ ing mother her dinner, and this takes priority to all my other wants or needs." 
This com passionate daughter knows that one cannot live in a hurry. She knows too that love requires three terms, not only the lover and the beloved, but also that m ysterious bond that unites both, which is love Few children ever see all that a mother has m eant to them until it is too late to let them know that they do see it. 
Mother's Unlimited Love 
At the very outset, let us realize how early and to what extent a m other's influence begins to act effectively Her very first act of m inister­ ing care is to enter the valley of the shadow of death (at time of delivery) to win her child's life at the very danger of losing her own. Tell me, if you can, do you know of any other love so ex­ tended with full knowledge of such peril? 
Each Child Has Two Fathers 
Every newly born babe has two fathers, his father on earth, without whom the child could not possibly have life, and his heavenly father, without whom he could not own a soul, distinctive personal character. The mother is the main-sprmg, the living partner and motivat­ ing force through whom both fathers work 
A father may turn his back on his child, brothers and sisters mav becom e confirmee enem ies to each other, husbands may abandon wives and wives may forsake husbands, But through this all, a m other's love endures, pray ing and everlastingly hoping that each may re­ pent and return to receive her welcoming arm s with full pardon 
Thank GOD for mothers, to you who still have them. To each of you who has lost his, let us thank HIM for such a mother to rem em ber 
To you young mothers who are blessed with children, may your own rem em brance and respect tor your mother be their beacon of light 
Thus you will give them such love and memories and homes 
Doctor Housekeeper! You Can Cure Sick Carpet 
C arpets are like humans, both need con­ stant care Perhaps tile most popular question given me each day is 
Will this carpet stain"? 
Yes, every carpet will accept stains but some carpet fibers release them more readily 
Remember! There is one solvent that can dissolve any riddle — and that is knowledge. 
Never before in the history of our carpet in dustry have our products been so produced and prepared for ease of m aintenance; never before has so much information been available for the housekeeper's convenience There are 
Believe It O r Not" answ ers to comfort w orried housekeepers. You are deserving of them, the reliable, know ledgeable and co-operative carpet expert can fill your every need and answ er every call. 
Through him, you can doctor and cure your carpets needs. 
Next Week 
We will discuss; “Choosing the right carpet to fill your particular needs " Until then, think this over . . . We Am erican a re strange people 
We devote only one day out of the year to our mothers and an entire week to straw berries."

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW5 —Sunday February Iii 1977 
Page I -G 
Pour oil on troubled waters? 

By DICK M h R K tX 
CHIEF, EXPRESS N EW S AUSTIN BUREAU 
AUSTIN — Last week legisla­ tion was laid out here its authors say will literally spread oil on the troubled waters of ad valor­ em taxation in Texas. 
The legislative doubleheader calls for elimination of the ad valorem tax for maintenance and operations cur­ rently being levied on property owners by school districts state-wide. 
Abolition of this tax would represent a saving of some $1.3 billion for school district property owners over the next two years. 
To replace this revenue on the school districts’ books, a second bill calls for imposing a five per cent tax on all crude oil and distillate input into Tex­ as’ refineries. 
This tax would produce an estimated 
SI.7 billion over the same two-year period, with three-fourths earmarked for the school districts and the balance to the state highway program 
Immediate “ on the street’’ reaction to the news was predictably good. 
Anything that would reduce an ad valorem tax has to be good. 
Anything that would eliminate such a tax completely has to be nothing short of unbelievable. 
However, as the week wore on. there 

 was another predictable reaction — this from the state's oil industry and it was anything but good. 
Even as proponents of the legislation were mustering support for their bills, the* industry was rallying its forces to battle against them 
One of the major rallying points for the opposition is the Austin head- 

W ILLIAM ABINGTON 
Tax reform act a windfall for some 

N EW VORK TIMES SERVICE 

N EW YORK - The Tax Re­ form Aet of 197H was full of major provisions but the biggest thing it provided early on was burgeoning business for lawyers, accountants, brokers and publishers. 
Not since the enactment of the In­ ternal Revenue (ode of 1954 was this world of financial legerdemain, so ex­ quisitely calculating, so painfully con­ trived, burdened with such blessings, as lawyers searched for loopholes lost and loopholes gained, accountants be­ gan unlearning the old and mastering the new and publishers scrambled to disseminate and analyze the new law. 
“ Hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent — some would say wasted — as a result of this Act.” said 
Prof. Bernard Wolf man. an enthusias­ tic tax reformer who teaches tax law at 
Harvard. “ This gigantic side effect had nothing to do with whether the act makes for good or bad tax law.” 

Law has provided jobs for law yers, accou ntants an d brokers 

Iii tile winter's worst snowstorm more than HIM) lawyers found Bedford. 
N ll., and paid $5o each to attend a session on the new law sponsored by bar association. 
When the Federal Tax Institute of 
New England announced a two-day session on the act, Boston's John Han­ cock Hall was filled with 1,ooo lawyers paying $75 each. 
‘Sadism ’ 
Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith of 
Harvard University suggested that the act was a device whereby legislators provided impetus for the CNP. 
‘ There s no question that it's quite an industry.” he said, then summarized the industry as “ economic sadism” which takes pleasure and profit from the fresh sorrows of the taxpayer. 
“ There s no way of avoiding it,” he 
See REFORM. Page >G 

 quarters of the Texas Mid-Continent 
Oil And Gas Assn. 
Almost as soon as word of the pro­ posed legislation got around. Mid-Con­ tinent issued a press release predicting some very dire consequences if the tax bill finally becomes law. 
The tax, it pointed out. would further jeopardize construction of Sea-Doek facilities for foreign oil to Texas for refining. 
It would also make less likely the possibility of refining Alaskan crude here in Texas. 
The tax would also give a big boost to rapid expansion of refineries of the 
Middle East and North Africa. 
And finally, it also hinted broadly at further intervention by the federal government in the form of stranger controls over oil and gas prices. 
Ready and willing 
By week’s end, Mid-Continent's Ex­ ec. Dir. William Abington was ready, and more than willing, to expand on these points which will surely be the main line of the industry's attack on the legislation. 
Sea Dock, invisioned as a huge off­ shore terminal off the Texas Gulf 
Coast, is now a shaky concept at best, la* says. 
“ Sea Dock has been in the mill now for some five years.” Abington sa vs 
“ Originally, there were some 12 ma­ jor oil companies considering partici­ pation in its construction. 
“ However, under restrictions an­ nounced by the federal government to be placed on Sea Dock tin* number of participants has dropped off to eight 
“ Just last December, EXXON an­ nounced it was pulling out. 
"There are so many contingencies on Sea Dock now it wouldn’t take much to make the remaining participants pull out.” Abington says, leaving little doubt the tax might just bo the “ final straw.” 
On the question of Alaskan oil, 
Abington moved quickly to counter the statement of Sen. Peyton McKnight of 
Tyler, one of the bill's co-sponsors. 
McKnight has already warned the oil industry would threaten the tax could affect the flow of Alaskan oil to Texas refineries. 
The Tyler senator told a press con­ ference not to believe this threat since the pipeline to carry the oil into Texas was already there “ right into Mid­ land.” 
Wrong direction 

The pipeline is there. Abington con­ cedes, but it s pointing in the wrong direction. 
It is currently carrying natural gas from Texas to California. 
"In order to obtain this pipeline to ship oil to Texas, you’re going to have to assure California of a continued gas supply." 

Proposed bills would eliminate ad va­ lorem taxes, but impost* a fire per cent tax on all crude oil and distillates refined in Texas 

That’s only part of it. Abington says 
“ The mood in California righi now isn’t all that good on the Alaskan oil situation. They’re already opposing plans for the construction of an off­ shore terminal near Long Beach from an environmental standpoint 
"In addition, if the pipeline is se­ cured for shipping Alaskan oil into 
Texas some new lines will have to be constructed for about 83-miles as well as pump stations. 
“ All of these factors, when added up, represent a major investment by the oil industry, and when added tit the present situation in California, cer­ tainly don’t make tin* Alaskan crude plan a certainty,” 
The 48 oil refineries in Texas repre­ sent 28 per cent of the nation's refining capacity. Abington continues 
According to industry figures. Tex­ as' refineries produce some 3 f) million barrels of oil daily One third of all this oil refined in Texas last year was for­ 

 eign crude. 
The industry paid over $4o billion iii 
1977 for this crude, Abington points out 
Increasing the price to the point where Texas' refineries would no longer be competitive would release enough capital to the oil producing nations of the Middle East and North 
Africa “ that they could build their own refineries and chemical plants 
“ They would then refine their own products and export them to the U.S. instead of having it done here,” 
Abington warns 
“ Highly discriminated 
According to Abington, “ Texas' re­ fineries employ some 38.1)1)1) people with an average payroll of $812 7 mil­ lion annually 
The proposed tax would produce about $82H million the first year 
“ That’s 135 per cent of our total pas roll," he says 

\bington charges the proposed tax is highly discriminatory. 
“ Texas’ refinery industry accounts for eight per cent of the total manu­ facturing of the state Repeal of the ad valorem tax would amount to a tre­ mendous break for all mdustrv iii the state Certainly the oil industry would share iii that But. bv the same token, we would be made to pick up the tab on the other end for everyone 
Concluding, \bington posed a ques­ tion 
“ Assuming the refinerv tax is used to replace the ad v anicut tax. what would happen it there was another oil embargo” 
“ The answer is obvious Since Texas refines HO per cent ol all the foreign oil brought into the United Stales, you would immmodiatelv lose H4 per cent of your state's public school finance revenue 
“ If some new source of financing must be found for such an important thing as public education. I don’t think ll should be tied to the whims of so­ mething as uncertain as foreign oil 
( oncluding. \bmgton calls the pro­ posed tax “ a very dangerous thing to say the least 
“ It will ultimately be damaging to the entire economy of Texas and lo an mdustrv which is an integral ol ilia) eeonomv 
Tesoro is planning to reduce Corco holdings 

Tesoro Petroleum Corp. is considering reducing its invest­ ment in tis troubled affiliate, the 
Commonwealth Oil Refining 
Company, Inc. (Coml). 
During the first quarter of Tesoro’s 
1977 fiscal year, the company lost $1 2 million, or 29 cents per diluted share, compared with net earnings, before preferred dividends, of $4 8 million, or 
44 cents per share and H9 cents per diluted share, for the-year earlier per­ iod 
Dr. Robert V West Jr., Tesoro's chairman of the board and chief exe­ cutive officer, said that Tesoro \ result are attributable to the company's 
“ equity in the losses of it s 37.8 per cent-owned Corco affiliate.” 
Com ps losses 
He said Tesoro's interest in Corco s 
* losses amounted to $19 I million, or HH cents a share, for the quarter 
Dr. West said that as a result of 
Corco's cont nilling losses ut the last 

 several months and recent writedowns, the company is “ is evaluating the 

DR. ROBERT V. WEST

Last m onth’s price jump worries som e analysts 

N EW YORK — Wall Street, already suf­ fering from a ease of inflationary jitters, was aggravated last week even more by the 
o.8 per cent jump in consumer prices in 
January. 
For those determined to achieve maximum anx­ iety, ll 9 per cent eau be multiplied by 12 months to give an annual rate of inflation of 9 H per cent. 

But, jitters may be temporary because o f increased profits anti dividends, some say. 

Mso. inflationary fears can be compounded bv expectations of a tighter 
Federal Reserv e moue tan policy, sharply ris­ ing interest rates and — despite 
President 
Caner s reassurances to the contrary — price controls. 
Iii the most ot all this pessimism, however, there is a serious cast* for optimism. 
It starts by discounting heavily for the impact of the unusually severe winter. This has given consumer prices a hard upward shove The bitter cold has also created en­ ergy shortages iii some areas, forced plant clos­ ings and la y o ffs and 

By 
I CONARD SICK! 
NEW YORF TIMES SERVICE 

 caused Hie labor force to shrink, as hundreds of thousands ol frustrated lob seekers stopped look­ ing for work iii the cold 
A great many shoppers no doubt staved home, partly as a result of the dent made iii family budgets by rising fuel and electric* bills 
However. Prof Solo­ mon Fabneant, the dis­ tinguished productivity and growth expert of the 
National 
Bureau of 
Economic Research, be­ lieves there is no reason to expert that the severe winier will put a lasting 

 crimp in the economic expansion. 
The Carter Adminis­ tration reached the same conclusion iii deciding not to increase its stimu­ lus package to make tip for the unusual w inter weather 
Indeed, the spring thaw, when it comes, is likely to release a spurt of catch-up buying and an industrial rebound. 
The case for optimism rests on much more the a reverse seasonal affect. 
Most fundamentally, if is based on the outlook for continuing economic growth and expanding business profits 
After-tax corporate profits increased last year by 28 8 per cent. 
And div idcud (layouts, fi­ 

 gured from the final quarter of 1975 to the fin­ al quarter of 1978, in­ creased 17 per cent 
Since 1977 began, cor­ porations have been in­ creasing their dividends even more. Standard & 
Poor’s has calculated that more companies have increased their di­ vidends than in any prior 
January since the mid-195os, when S & I* began recording such data. 
The ease for optimism includes the expectation that the economy is on solid ground and will go on expanding for at least two more years. 
This expectation rests partly on the ( arter Ad- ministrulton s two-year stimulus package But it 

 also rests on belief that the underlying growth trend is stronger than many observers realize 

GNI* slowdown 
On the surface, last week's report of the 
Commerce Department that the gross national product had slowed to an annual rate of increase of only 2.4 lier cent was ta­ ken as bearish news. 
However, the slowdown to 2.4 per cent (rather than the original esti­ mate of 3 per cent) was caused by less inventory accumulation that than the Commerce Depart­ ment originally estimat­ ed

I ii his fireside chat earlier this month President Carter promised “ a very simple tax return,” so that 75 per 

FROM IG

Bv HOBART ROWEN 
W A SH IN G TO N 
- 
.Jiminy 
Carter, running for the presi­ dency, promised he would dras­ tically cut the unemployment rate, balance the budget, and introduce a new range of social programs — all within his first term. 
Although many observers wrote this off as merely campaign rhetoric. 
Carter’s closest economic adv isers arc sticking to the general outline of the economic goals. But they now concede ifs going to be tough. 
In the handsome White House office in the West Wing once occupied by 
John Ehrliehman. 34-year old Stuart 
Eizenstat — Carter's No. I adv iser on domestic issues — puts it this way; 
” 1 think what has become painfully obvious is something we knew — but you have to see it to believe it. That is, the fact is the budget numbers are very tight, and having to add the sti­ mulus (package) on top of ail already existing $Bll billion deficit, gives you even less latitude.” 
What it comes down to, Eizenstat admits, is that “ every few of the things that we’d like to do are attainable un­ less we can get economic growth back to a 5.5 per cent track.” 
Not by 198o 
Coincidentally, Alice Rivlin ’s Con gressional Budget Office also reported to Congress last week that goals as ambitious as Carter’s could not bo achieved by 198o unless the growth rate turns unusually high. 
But while there is a surface similar­ ity iii Rivlm’s and Eizenstat’s assess­ ment. there is a subtle and important difference. Rivlm suggests that if past performance is any guide, the privatt sector won’t produce anything like a 
5.5 per cent growth rate, without sub­ stantial government deficits 

And if I understood Eizenstat, he was saying that if we got a 5.5 per cent growth rate, we can eliminate defi­ cits and move toward a balanced bud­ get One or the other must be wrong 

For the moment, the reality is red ink — lots of it — $7o billion in fiscal 
1977. and something approaching $61) billion iii the amended fiscal 1978 bud­ get Carter is about to send to Congress 
Zero-base bud^eiin^ 

With some justification. Carter's aides say it isn t their baby — it's still a Ford budget. Tile country won't get a real look at the Carter administration, they say, until it introduces “ zero- base” budgeting for fiscal 1979. Wa­ shington veterans will believe “ zero- base" budgeting when they see it work the idea is to force a justification of all federal spending every year —■ 

 including programs started in a prior year. 
The skeptics tend to think that the persistence of high unemployment and a sluggish recovery are likely to force 
Carter to give up one or more of his goals — either the fiscal 1981 balanced budget, full employment, or a mean­ ingful start on such ambitious pro­ grams as national health insurance. 
The Week 
In Business 

Eizenstat. among the half-dozen or so most influential Carter advisers who continue a direct, personal relation­ ship. insists that isn t so. 
The campaign promises were “ judi­ cious.” he points out. allowing for 
“ phasing in” the liming of various new programs. 
Meanwhile, the impact of back-to- back budget deficits in fiscal 1977 and 
1978 that total some $ JBO billion is clearly worrying financial markets. 

Wall Street’s perceptions may be wrong but its expectation of trouble is a fact that must be dealt with. Eizen­ stat argues that there will be plenty of 
“ liquidity" — lenders with cash — to finance the deficits. 
But many financial men wonder. A high growth rate will feed competing demands for money from business and the housing industry. The drive to get the economy rolling, plus outside price pressures arising from drought and energy shortages could re-tilt the scales toward inflation. 

There is clearly enough slack in the economy now so that the deficit this year ought to he absorbed fairly well. 
But looking down the road to 1978, a strong program to stablize wages and prices may be necessary. 

Nobody likes the word controls. But maybe ihey'ro inevitable. The real economic trade-off of this era may not he, as conventional wisdom has it, between full employment and infla­ tion. ll may, instead be between full employment and controls. To get the one, we may need to accept a degree of the other 
Production up for December 

Industrial production in Texas climbed in December at nearly a ‘JO per cent annual rate. 
Preliminary figures, supplied bv the 
Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, show total output 2.1 per cent above a year earlier, seasonally adjusted 
The increase resulted from a rise iii manufacturing output that more than offset a drop in mining. 
Durable goods manufacturing led the gain iii total factory output, with biggest gains occuring in stone, clay. and glass; fabricated metals, non­ electrical machinery; and transporta­ tion equipment 
Reduced crude 
In nondurable goods area, textiles, apparel, food and allied products, along w itll printing and publishing were largely responsible for the rise. 

Biggest gains came in building goods and ma­ chinery. 

Chemical and petroleum refining output were also up. while paper was the only industry lo suffer a decline 
Reduced crude oil output production accounted for tho decreased in mining activity. Drilling posted its first de­ cline iii seven months, according to the report 
Reflecting the strong gain in factory output, the manufacturing capacity utilization index rose iii December tit 
97 ti per cent of the 1972 base — the highest level since December 1974

Workshop provides training to mentally re­ tarded adults by con­ tracting with local busin­ essmen for such jobs us repairing pallets, mak­ ing candles and bows, assembly line work. food

Thus the trend of final sales through the four quarters of 197H was as follows: 3.7 per cent, 4.2 per cent. 4 2 per cent and 
» .i per cent

GNT* this year vv ill in­ crease by 5 75 per cent to ii per cent, from the fourth quarter of 1976 to the fourth quarter of 
1977 
Such a rise is likely to strengthen business pro­ fits as 1977 wears on 
Profits are iii part a function of rising operat­ ing rates 
En en more basically. however, busi­ ness has improved lls profit margins iii the last couple of years as a re­ sult of a very aggressive corporate pricing stra- 

FROM IG 

 tegy. Since 1974. corpor­ ate profit margins have broken a 12-year declin­ ing trend Profit margins unproved iii 1975 and 
1976 
As operating rates move up this year, pro­ fits should continue to increase. The standard forecasts is for a rise iii profits in 1977 of ll) to 12 per cent. but the com­ bination of better mar­ gins and higher utiliza­ tion of capacity could increase profits even more than that 
Gaining 

The ease for optimism is not so bearish as the general view oil inflation. 
Productivity appears to be gaining by 2 to 3 per cent So there is no rea­ son to believe that infla­ tion must accelerate appreciably from the 4 8 per cent rate of the past year 
As for sharply rising interest rates, the Feder­ al Reserve, like the Su­ preme Court, has a way of following the election returns.

San Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S —Sunday February 27 1977 
AT & T study: Bell wasn’t all that candid 

W A SH IN G TO N 
— 
An independent 
3V2-year study of American Telephone & 
Telegraph Co., says the huge telecommun­ ications firm is becoming a greater risk for investors than perhaps it ever has been. 
Tho study, which a has boon published in tho form of a 45o-page book soiling for $75o, oasts doubt on 
Boll System accounting, tho quality of its internal information and says that tho company has boon giving an unjustifiably rosy picture of its technolo­ gical expertise over tho past quarter century. 
In fact, using largely 

M e 'r e not out a it h a h a tch e t f o r a a vboilx . . .' 

 internal Boll System do euments which have boon placed in public files — principally in connection with a Federal Commun­ ications Commission in­ vestigation of the finan­ cial structure of AT&T — the report im plies that the com pany has no' been completely cand with its investors. 
It points, out, for exam­ ple, that while AT&T an­ nual reports — the com­ pany's most widely road publications for investors 
— were reporting the de­ velopm ent of A T & T ’s electronic switching sys­ tem as one long string of trium psh, internal papers were decrying the continuing problem s with the new switching system and the millions of dollars these problems were costing. 
Further, although the discovery of the transis­ tor is properly credited to two scientists at Bidi 
Telephone Laboratories, internal 
A T & T docu­ ments complain that the 
Bell System fell far be­ hind several major man­ ufacturers in the deve­ lopment of transistorized circu its and further technological advances in solid-state circuitry. 
Future 

The report, en titled . 
The Future of AT&T, is the product of V ictor 
Schnee, a law yer and financial analyst and 
Walter J. Gorkiewicz. an engineer, who is now also a financial analyst 
The two say they spent 
3l a man-years p rep ar­ ing the document which draws on thousands of pages of A T & T m ater­ ials. They say the Book was not sponsored bv ali­ ene with anyone with an interest in AT & T — neither the company nor 

By 
STEPHEN M. AEG 

W A S H IN G T O N STAP 

 its portents. 
In an interview recent­ ly, Schnee said the $7511 price for the soft-cover book isn’t unreasonable. 

“ I think you’ll find that a lot of consulting work that is sold at about $5(1(1 to $7oo a copy has got far less meaty information in it than this ” 
Schnee concedes the book — several hundred copies have been printed 
— is unlikely to be a best seller. 
But he says copies al­ ready have been sold to the FCC, some industrial firm s with interests in teleeommunicat ions se­ veral independent telephone com panies, some telephone systems 

 outside the United States, institutional investors, and one copy to AT&T. 
Schnee point out that the prevailing opinion of 
AT&T and its Bell Sys­ tem subsidiaries within the investment commun­ ity is of a firm providing an absolutely safe in­ vestm ent. 

“ W e're not out with a hatchet for anybody . . . we’re only interested in reporting the facts and setting them straight,” 
Schnee says. 
A spokesman at AT&T 

STERLING SM ITH , left, and Steven Lee unveil Stanley 
Sm ith Security sign at Conroy Square 
Security agency goes to new headquarters 

Conroy 
Square has been selected as the new national corporate head­ q uarters for 
Stanley 
Smith Security Inc. 
Founded in San Anton­ io in 1928, Smith is one of 
America’s top IO security com panies providing guard, patrol, burglar and fire alarms, armored car and in vestig ative services. 
It employs over 1.8oo 

 people in 23 North Amer­ ican branches to residen­ tial, commercial, institu­ tional and governmental agencies. 
Also iii San Antonio is its Olmos Drive branch office providing local service. 
Conroy Square. Loop 
41o and HUO, is over 95 per cent leased, accord­ ing to Steven Q. Lee. vice president of Quincy Lee 

Co. 
The garden office building includes en­ closed tennis courts and separate health club fa­ cilities for men and wo­ men, including sauna and whirlpool. 
Location and office de­ sign played a major role in the selection of Conroy 
Square, said Sterling 
Smith, president of Stan­ ley Smith Security Inc. 

 said the company had no comment about the book, although he added that so far as he knew it con­ tained nothing but what was already on public file. 
Schnee and Gorkiewicz conclude that a good part of the risk facing AT&T investors is the poor quality in information — riot only what the com­ pany publishes, but even its internal information. 
If known 

For example, if an in­ vestor had known of the major problems facing 
A T & T’s first electronic sw itching system 
— problems that took about lh years to overcome — as well as the rising rate of customer trouble re­ ports beginning in 19B3, and the slow rate of in­ stallation of equipment designed to cut conges­ tion in large metropoli­ tan areas, an investor might have had a differ­ ent perception of the long-term risks in own­ ing AT&T securities. 

They also point out — as did an FCC adminis­ trative law judge several months ago — that there are serious questions about some of A T & T ’s accounting policies, in­ cluding depreciation practices which leave substantial costs to be recovered iii com ing years. 
Conclusion 
T h eir m ajor conclu­ sion, Schnee and Gor* kievvicz say. is that “ fun­ damental risks for AT&T are rising. 
There is abundant evidence that the risks of the late 197os and early 198os are likely to be far higher than those laced in the late 
19Hos . . . the financial vulnerability of the com­ pany in facing these risks, will, we believe, be considerably greater in the late 197os and early 
198os than it was in the late 198os.” 
Compounding these risks, the two say, is the 
“ overriding problem of poor quality of informa­ tion, and this. they say. could result in a decline in confidence in the com­ pany’s financial reports. 

SA guide to appear 

SUZY DREW -MARTIN 

The San Antonio Guide, a twicely yearly guide to apartments, will appear this week. 
. ‘ 
The free publication will detail the city, places to visit, em ergency numbers and a listing of over 7o apartment com­ plexes, according to Suzi 
Drew-Martin, editor/ publisher. 
The first edition will be distributed at various re­ tail outlets. Chambers of 
Commerces and mailed 

 to prospective residents by the SA Guide staff. 
Ms. Drew-Martin is a graduate of 
Alam o 
Heights; and attended 
Trinity and the Universi­ ty of Houston. 
Drew 
En terp rise s, which publishes the guide, is a member of the 
National Association of 
Apartment Guide Pu b ­ lishers, the San Antonio 
Apartment Association. 
National and 
Texas 
Apartment Associations. 
THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS 
OF 

 and trust in banian main 

 is pleased to announce the election of 

BYRO N E. MILLS, JR. 
PRESIDENT A N D CHIEF-EXECUTIVE OFFICER 

Mr. Mills comes to Main Bank from the Cullen Center Bank and Trust in Houston. For the past five years, he has been the executive vice-presid­ ent and chief operating officer at Cullen Bank, responsible for all lending functions, operations and administration. He was elected a director of 
Cullen Bank in 1971. Earlier, he had been a senior loan officer at Moody 
National Bank in Galveston. 

Mr. Mills is active in the Air Force Reserves and presently is director of intelligence at Tenth Air Force (Reserve) at Bergstrom Air Force Base in 
Austin. 

Main Bank and Trust is a member of First International Bancshares, 
Inc., the $7.2 billion Texas based multi-bank holding company.
