Mouseketeers meant morality 

Th*> Mickey Mouse Club didn't just iiff/teal to M iddle A m erica during the I OoOs. ll leas Mi fid Ie A m erica tit the kids o f the oos. 

. To Continue in the News 

By JER R Y BOWLES 
More than eight million peo­ ple live in the Los Angeles ba­ sin, which covers all of Los 
Angeles and about half of 
Orange County. It is second only to New York in population, second to none in sprawl. 
The valley is the personification of the dream of middle-elasshood, alth­ ough it does have its small contradic­ tions. Walt Disney lived there and chose to move his studio to Burbank in the early fifties Universal Pictures is in the valley, as are most of Hit' other movie companies and television dream factories. 
Perhaps, this is not really a con­ tradiction at all. The dream of becom­ ing a film or telev ision star is a middle 
— or working-class ambition after all. 
And despite his affectation of polo. 
Walt Disney remained tin' dour son of a Missouri fanner with no patience for either intellectualism or status arran­ gement. Disney simply chose to live among the people who most revered his vision of the American dream In a sense, he was simply living over the store. The valley was his spiritual home. 
How inviting thi-> valley must have seemed to those thousands of settlers who came west in those giddy, heroic, brave new world days following World 
War II. Tract homes. No down. G I. 
B ill. 
They settled in places with exotic names: Van Nays. Studio City. Sher­ man Oaks. Burbank. The new pilgrims brought with them the security of a world finally at peace with tile cer­ tainty of prosperity to come. 
For these survivors ol the Great De­ pression and tin' Big War, life would bo different under the golden sun. Their 

February 27 1977 

♦ 
Page I H 
V 
............................ 
J 

 fish She, more than any ot the others, had some comprehension of what was going on around her Cubby and Karen were babies really. Karen more than 
Cubby. 

Doreen was a natural clown, radiant with her saucer-shaped eyes and bud ding sexiness Tommy was too nice to be believed Lonnie w as cocky and* professional, a sharp dresser, and a smart knl 
W hen Cilery I louted the group a year later, slit1 was something ol a mystery girl lier father had been a general iii the Army, a tact that put her into a slightly different ( lass 

For the most part. they were inst average kids "Don't got me those kind with the tightly curled hairdos — tap dancers — get me children who look like they're having fun Then later we can teach them to tap dance or sui:' or whatever,” Walt Disney reportedly told Walsh 

The club was a bittersweet blend of innocence and commercial hyperbole aud it had an enormous influence oil what the kids who watched it thought or. at least, believed they should tlmik 

Simpler 

Part ol the show s impact had to tin with its really not being a children s show at all but. rather, a show that featured children playing the roles ol little adults. All of the values the show taught — reliability, reverence, bravery, loyally, good behavior, the ickky-sticky grown-up concept til romantic love — are tilings that adults think kids should be taught 

Unlike Us newfangled successors — 
"Sesame Street” and the “ Electric 
Company" — the mouse club did not attempt to leach mechanical skills like reading, writing and spelling. 

The educational emphasis of the 
MMC was morality, as Wall Disney aud those who worked for him. per­ ceived it What the club wanted lo iii still was nothing less than a philosophy of life, a picture ol the ideal world 
And. at the time — incredibly only 2(1 years ago — that philosophy seemed reasonable and v table enough X on can be whatever you want to be ii only you have faith aud work hard toward (hid goal \ on can truly know what is right aud w hat is w mug 

 l o l l m illion children d a ily , the clu b prom ised a belter and b rig h ter world 

 iii the future.

■Forever hold y© banner high!9 

 kids would have the advantages they had missed. They had a shot at the silver screen. Certainly , they would never know hunger or fear. They would hav e dance lessons. 
Tile new fantasy was television which, although still in its infancy in 

 the early limits, was already beginning to reshape the entertainment business 
The state of television programming for children was rather poor in I MAT. although perhaps no worse than the 
Saturday morning fare of today There was a horse series called " F u r y ” which starred Bobby Diamond, now a lawyer in Los Angeles. There was 
"Pinky Lee " ("Yon Boo, its me. My name is Pinky Lee.") 
There were a bunch of "Honiper 

Booms" across the nation and they all seemed to presume that kids were idiots. There was "Captain Corbett" and "Sky King” with Kirby Grant 
And. of course, there was the venera­ ble "Howdy Boody" with Buffalo Bob, which had been in regular production since UHT. It was simplistic stuff, to be sure But then, the Blahs was a rather simple decade, at least on the surface 
The nation was firmly on the road to the Great Society. The working men. 

 the people of the valley, would finally have the life they deserved. It seems only natural, in retrospect, that when 
Walt Disney reluctantly agreed to produce the "Mickey Mouse Club" for 
ABC. he would look no farther than his own back yard for the talent The San 
Fernando Valley represented the triumph of the working class. It was a microcosm of blue collar America and out of this microcosm a few would be chosen to be stars 
In the early months of I!)’>;>, the word went out. Walt Disney is looking for kids lo appear on a new TX' series lie wants inst normal, average everyday kids The auditions are open Anybody can come. 
The concept of the show, which evolved from the creative team that planned it (mainly Bill Walsh. Bal 
AdelquisL Dick Barley, .litnmie Dodd, and Boy W illiam s), was relatively simple The heart of the series was the tremendous backlog of Disney car­ toons The group divided the show into four segments of fifteen minutes each 
Undoubtedly, this division had com­ mercial as well as artistic reasons since sponsor time was sold iii fifteen minute blocks The first segment was 
"Boll Call" followed by newsreels or 
Jiminy Cricket; segment two was the major Mouseketeer segment and its format varied from day to day. Seg­ ment three was the hve-action serials like "Spin & Marty.' and segment four featured a cartoon of the-day from Hie 
Disney library. Iii addition to their own segment, the Mousketeers introduced each quarter hour and served to bind the show together 

Frantic 

Things started to get frantic around the studio iii the early summer of 195Y 
With the targeted air date only a few months off. there were still many things to be resolved What, for exam­ ple. should the kids wear? Spaceman outfits'.’ Cowboy outfits? Boy Williams, an illustrator who later appeared on the show as the big Mouseketeer. had come up with an idea they liked 

W illiams remembered a gag from a 
I HJO cartoon w here Mickey Mouse tipped Ins hat to Minnie as lie passed but instead of a hat. it was the top of his head 
He designed a set ol 
"mouse" ears based on the gag 

There was an avalanche of kids 
Every stage mother within fifty miles of Burbank had responded to the open audition call 
The planning team looked at, and listened to. over three thousand kids before settling on the original 24 

T h e g a n g * * a l l h e r e 

Now scattered all over the country, the Mouseketeers were a varied bunch but they kept smiling, smiling and smiling for this group picture (left.) Darlene (below left) was older and somewhat aloof, while Annette (below right) gained unusual prominence among Mouseketeers. 

With the exception of Bobby B u r­ gess, who was from Long Beach, they were all valley kids Their fathers were laborers, meatcutters. filling- station operators, truck drivers and carpenters Their common bond was that they had all had dance or music lessons That s how they had been found. 

The word went out Disney looking tor kids who eau sing and dance and have nice personality. And the kids they found did have personalities 

Sunny 

Annette and Sharon Baird were sunny, easygoing, and cooperative 
Bobby Burgess smiled so much that the other kids suspected he was a phony. Darlene Gillespie, older than the other girls, was aloof and standof- 
Space’s gift to man: 
Microwave energy 

By ISAAC ASIMOV 
S 

Human beings have always had to travel to satisfy their needs. 
As hunters and gatherers, they scoured the tribal area for food. 
When they settled down to farm, they sent some members afar to trade what they had iii excess for what they lacked. 
The Uhoenieians. in HUO 
B C., traveled the length of the Mediterranean, out into the At holt ie and to the British Isles iii Iheir search for the tin needed to make bronze 
But now the Earth s physical frontiers have vanished.'almost all its surface has been ripped and plundered of its re­ sources — and we need more. 
XX hat we need most direly is energy. XX itll energy all our other needs would Im* reduced, for it would enable us to recycle almost everyth­ ing. remove pollution, reuse the used sub­ stance's. 
But our easy-energy days are over here on 
Earth. The Industrial 
Revolution began in 
England and spread elsewhere I hanks to the energy of easily mined coal. The great advances of the 2oth century were achieved thanks to en­ ergy’ of the still cheaper and more convenient oil 
Now the oil is running out and. by the year 2ooo, ti 

ASIMOV 

With the passing of the era of easy energy, 

 our scientists are now perfecting a way lo beam limitless amounts ai solar energy irom power satellites circling the Earth. The rub. says science author Dr. Isaac Asimov, is in the billions of dollars it will cost, t an we afford It? 

In this first of a four-part series, he 

 explains why we can’t afford NOT lo look beyond Earth's ecology — not if civilization is to survive. And he shows how an inter­ planetary approach to the energy crisis could yield the most welcome of all results, un end to war. 

XVhat de we de then? 
We can switch back to coal or move on to shale, possibly with drastic cf- lefts on the environment. 
We can use windpower and waterpower and ti­ dal power and the energy ot Earth's inner heat, but those won t he enough. 
We eun use nuclear fission, hut it is danger­ ous, We eau switch to nuclear fusion, but that has not yet been worked out and we don't know when it will be, We can switch to the direct list* of solar energy; but solar energy is spread out thinly, is interfered with by mist, smoke, fog and clouds, and is stopped entirely ut night. 
A mixture of all these things may work and keep us going; perhaps, on the other hand. we will have to do as the Phoeni­ cians did and travel far 

 to get what we need, since the Earth has al­ ready been ransacked, that means traveling out into space. 
Why not? We have reached the moon six times and returned w it li­ eut a man lost. Three men al a time have been in Hie space station. Sky­ lab; they have remained as long as three months and then returned in reasonably good condi­ tion. 
Expensive 
To do all this has seemed expensive to most people and perhaps 
"not worth it " but, so far, there has only been an initial flexing of mus­ cles, 
Now the space shuttle will be put into use. a reusable spaceship that will cut costs tre­ mendously. What we need is a task fur the shuttle to perform 

Suppose we choose a task that, however ex­ pensive, will bring incal­ culable benefits to hu­ man beings generally •— to every one of us In ­ stead of coating thou­ sands of square miles of desert surface on Earth with solar batteries de­ signed to convert the en­ ergy of sunlight into electricity, suppose we use the shuttle to build and maintain structures in space on which those same solar butteries can be placed 
Such structures would be placed about 22.IHM! miles abu* c 
Fa rib a equator. At that height, they would revolve about the Earth in 24 hours, just the time ll takes 
Earth to rotate on Us ax­ is. so that each would re­ main over some particu­ lar equatorial spot on 
Earth 
These solar power sta­ 

 tions would have to pre­ sent large surfaces to the 
Sun. but not so large as the areas we would have lo coal on tilt* Earth s surface. In space, the 
Sun s radiation is more energetic than it is on the surface of the Earth, for none of it is weakened or stopped by un atmos­ phere 
There is never any in­ terference ut ait by clouds or by other at­ mospheric phenomena, and each power station will Im* in Earth's shadow for only two hours out ol the day. With as leu as two power stations on opposite sides of the 
Earth, we may he sure that one will always Im* in sunshine. 
The energy absorbed by the solar power stations can In* converted into the shortwave radio waves called microwaves which, in turn, are beamed down to Earth 
The microwaves will Im* more concentrated than ordinary sunlight, so that receiving them on Earth and converting them to electricity is a more effi­ cient procedure than re­ ceiving and converting sunlight. 
Furthermore. m i­ crowaves can penetrate clouds, mist, fog and smoke w it flout trouble; thus, the tie;.rn from any I particular station need) stop only for the two hours a day that the sia-i 
(ion is passing through I

Ethan Allen Winter Sale 

Sale prices on the Winter 
Salt* selection w ill he extended 
Nationally through March 5th. 

Because of the hardships of shopping in the north, east and mid-west during this country’s most in­ clement weather, and because Ethan Allen is national in scope, an extra few days are being allotted to the 
Winter Sale. The ending date is Saturday, March 5th, rather than Monday as previously announced.

 big cam paign plum 

By JAM ES MCCRORY 
U. S. Sen. John Tower, up for the third defense of the senator­ ial title he won back in 1961, is positioning him self well for his 
1978 run. 

The positioning is p articu larly a t­ tractive to Texas and San Antonio. 
The senior senator from Texas, first 
Republican elected to the Senate since 
1877, is now ranking minority m em ber of the Senate A rm ed Services Com- puttee. 

The committee is considered one of the four major committees in the Sen­ ate. and Tower has served on it since 
19H5. 

Iii years aiel years of Bexar County politicking, datin g back to the late 
195os and early 19Bos, candidates for the Senate and the C S. House used possible appointm ents to Armed Ser­ vices as a prime campaign carrot. 

Potpourri 

P eople a m i Politics 

The late C ongressm an and Ju d g e 
Paul Kilday, who resigned as Bexar 
County's U.S. Representative in 19o1 to take a bench on the U.S. Court of Mi­ litary Appeals, was v irtually sa cro ­ sanct politically as a m em ber of the committee. 
He knows 

Tow er, known in som e circ les as 
“ The Little H aw k," recognizes inst what the ranking com m ittee assig n ­ ment tran slates into in the political realities of things. 
At a tim e the new ( arter adm inis­ 

 tration is advocating heavy budget cuts from P resident F o rd ’s proposed de­ fense budget, Tower cites the im por­ tance of the military to Texas. 
Last year. Tower notes, $2.5 billion was spent by the Defense Department 

 iii T ex a s on m ilita ry and c iv ilia n payrolls. 
Compensation to 93,ooo m ilitary re­ tirees and part-tim e earnings of N a­ tional Guardsm en and Reserve Units brought the total federal expenditure for defense m a n p o w e r in T ex a s to more than $3.2 billion. 
Added to that, of course, Texas bu­ 

 sinesses held contracts with the De­ partment of Defense for m ore than $2.1 billion, making the defense outlays in 
Texas more than $5.3 billion. 
It s a bunch 
T h at fig u re , T o w er p o in ts out, represents 4o per cent of all federal taxes collected in Texas. 
San Antonio, with its huge defense facilities and payrolls, is a recipient of a large am ount of the defense dollars. 
In accepting the minority leadership role on Armed Services, Tower had to s u r re n d e r a n o th e r choice m in o rity lead er role on the S en ate B an k in g 
Committee. 
Senate rules don't allow a senator to 
( hold more than one ranking committee 
' position. 
In his new’ Armed Services position, 
Tower, one of the most articulate Re­ publicans in public office, will m anage legislation and budget reco m m en d a­ tions reported by the com mittee to the 
Senate floor.

Like a Christmas catalog 

 s n CIM to tm t i n o i n i w s 
W ASH ING TO N 
- 
J im m y 
Carter, who m ay be* the first 
President rn history to com pile his ca m p a ig n p rom ises after election day, has released a 
111-page collection of his public com m itm ents. 

Hut Hie document, which the White 
House had been reluctant to release, contained a disclaimer which suggest­ ed that the promises should Im* viewed historically rather than taken literally. 
The pledges covered alm ost every area of domestic and foreign concern. 
Some, such us the pardon for Vietnam d raft vio lato rs, have alre a d y been kept, iii whole or in part. 
And at least one — the vow to cut the defen se budget by $5 billion to $7 billion — seems certain to be broken. 
But probably more significant than any of the specific pledges in the book, unofficially dubbed “ P ro m ises, P ro ­ mises.” were the reasons underlying their compilation and the belated de­ cision to release them. 
In the early stages of Ins presidential candidacy, Curter sought to avoid the sort of specific prom ises which had contributed to widespread public dis^ illusionment with the political process 
Gigged him 
Indeed, C a rte r ut first was often criticized by his rivals for the Demo­ cratic nomination for being vague and fuzzy on the issues. 
But as the campaign progressed, the candidate found himself making more and more specific com m itm ents to win the support of various interest groups, and by November in* was drawing in­ creasing criticism for “ over-prom is­ ing ” 
After bls v let or >, ev ideiitly as part of an effort to establish ins credibility, the I‘resident directed his staff to col* 

‘N o w w h at did I p ro m ise ?' Carter had better rem em ber 

 lect the co m m itm en ts he had m ade publicly in his long drive for the White 
I louse, 
The work was done by the campaign issued staff, using speeches, press re­ leases, letters, newspaper stories and other material. 
It was completed Nov. 3U and sub­ mitted to the President along with a memo from Stuart Eizenstat, head of the issues stuff aud now head of the 
White House Domestic Council. 
There’re more 
Eizenstat cautioned the then-Presi- dent-elect that the list was “ certainly not exh au stiv e," but added: “ T here are not likely to in* very many addi­ tional p r o m is e s " iii th e C u rte r 

 speeches and statem ents he had not yet been able to examine. 
“ The stren g th of the various pro ­ m ises n atu ra lly v a r ie s ," E izen stat wrote. Some w ere prom ises just to 
“ consider” action, others to “ support” action, while still others were definite pledges to take action. 
But Eizenstat added: “ In many in­ stances. the full context of your speech or statement must bi* reviewed to de­ te rm in e the exact s tre n g th of your promise.” 
When word of the existence of “ P ro­ m ises, P ro m is e s " leaked out before 
Inauguration Day, reporters asked for copies 
C arter's staff at first refused, p er­ haps because some of the pledges are 

 either so broad or so specific that it would ap p ear to be difficult for the 
P re s id e n t to keep faith w ith all of them. 
Whew 
Among many other things, the P re ­ sident is on record, according to his staff, as promising to disapprove “ any actions which would im pair the auton­ omy of the arts,” to make possible “ a more efficient use of containerization” to revitalize the railroads, to give Is­ rael "whatever military and economic aid . . . is necessary." to support “ the repair of existing 9-foot-deep lock and 
Dam 2B on the Mississippi River, but o p p o sin g re p la c e m e n t w ith a new larger 12-fwd lock." 
And so on and so forth. 
On page B4 the book lists the Presi­ dent’s pledge to pardon Vietnam draft dodgers which he fulfilled, as he said he would, in his first week in office. 
On page 1o8, Hie book lists am ong the prom ises “ reducing present d e ­ fense expenditures by about $5 billion I to $7 billion annually.” 
The statement was made last June, during fiscal 197B when the total d e­ fense obligational authority was $97.5 billion. The com parable figure for the current fiscal years is $11o.2 billion. 
Recently the President said he ex­ a c t e d his proposals for the next fiscal y ear to be " s u b s ta n t ia l ly " h ig h er, though below President Ford’s request for $123.1 billion. 
Lust week. after interm ittent prod­ ding by reporters, White House Press 
Secretary Judy Powell disclosed that the promise ImmiW would Im* released. 
He said the White House felt earlier that since all of the promises were on the public record, there was no reason to release the list. 
“ But it did not seem worth getting into a tiff over,” Powell said “ Ma>be lf >ou have it, there will be much less interest in it."

Anybody seen an electrical plug around here anywhere? 
Seems che City Hall wizards of planning who masterminded the flagstone paving of Alam o Plaza forgot something. Lights. 
The W ise Ones decided to light up the plaza at night to keep the weirdos away but first they have to rip up chunks of that carefully laid flagstone to find outlets. City workers Pete 
Gonzales, left, and Richard Santana were conducting the search. — Staff Photo by Charles Barksdale 

But the senator is keeping his bund in the Senate Banking Committee deck, although he won’t be at the minority helm. 
He rem ains a m em ber of the Bank­ ing C o m m itte e , and is ra n k in g mem ber of the com m ittee's Financial 
In stitu tio n s S u b c o m m itte e d ealin g with legislation affecting banks, sav­ ings and loan associations and credit unions. 
For all those Democrats lining up to take the senator on in 1978. Tower may be sitting but he isn t a sitting duck. 
An indefatigable fund raiser, it will be rem em bered that Tower raised and spent $2.3 million in his 1972 bid for re-election, the highest expenditure at the time in any U. S. Senate campaign. 
At the start of the year, Tower was sitting on a $75,7o7 nest egg in his 
Tower Senate Club fund. 
That nest egg should hatch out to a full-sized financial chicken by the time the senator gets rolling on his re-elec­ tion campaign later this year.

Manson girl still having nightm ares 

LOS ANGELES TIMES 
LOS ANGELES — Form er 
Charles Manson follower Leslie 
Van (tauten says she still has nightmares about the gruesome murders of Leno and Rosemary 
LaBianca, for which she was once condemned to death and for which she will be retried next month. 

Iii a wide ranging interview at Sybil 
Brand Institute, Miss Yan Boutell said: 
“ I know that I did som eth in g horrible . . . I don’t expect people to forgive me but I hope eventually they will give me a chance.” 
She freely admitted her past domin­ ation by Manson but said, “That's over and has been completely over for about three years. 
“ I'm embarrassed to say it now. but back then I really believed in Charlie’s 
‘Belter Skelter’ plan to start a race war. Now. the hardest thing is to rea­ lize the killings were so senseless.” 
Perspective 
She believes she is now completely capable of putting Manson into proper perspective, saying: 
“ I really don't think he has much power. Bis power was in us women and without that he isn t much of anything 
. . . Since he has been in prison, I don’t know of anyone p roclaim ing him anything other than a man who is do­ ing time.” 
During the hour and 15 minute in­ terview. she talked about falling under the influence of Manson, her heavy use of LSI). Lynne (Squeaky) Bromine s attempt to assassinate President Ford, her close family ties and what she hopes will be a future as a writer. 
By agreem ent with her attorney. 
Maxwell Keith, no questions were asked about the LaBianca killings. The two were fatally stabbed in their Los 
Angeles home in the early morning hours of Aug. IO. 19H9. 
Miss Yan Bouton was granted a new trial when the state Court of Appeal ruled that her case should have been severed from Manson and the other co-defendants when her attorney dis­ appeared in the middle of the trial. 
Remain 

Instead. Superior Court .Judge 
Charles Older let her remain in the trial after appointing Keith to take over lier defense. 
In her testimony at the first trial. 
Leslie said. “ I took one of the knives and Patricia (Krenwinkel) had a knife and we started stabbing and cutting the lady up.” An autopsy showed Mrs. 
LaBianca was stabbed more than 4(1 times. 
Ber husband, the owner of grocery chain, was slashed to death in an ad­ joining room by Charles (Tex) Watson. 
The attackers left a fork protruding from LaBianca's chest as they fled the scene. 
The 27-year-old former high school homecoming princess from Monrovia. 
Calif., expressed her feelings about what happened that night. 
“ I still have nightmares about it." she said “ It is something I live with. 
There were lunes when I wondered if I could make it through the nights at the prison without my psychiatrist." 
Contrast lier demeanor during the interview was in dramatic contrast to her testi­ mony at the first trial when Keith asked her if she had any sorrow or remorse and she coldly replied. “ Sorry is a five letter word." 
She said she is not necessarily opti­ m istic about tilt1 upcom ing trial, scheduled for March 2K before Super­ ior Court Judge F.dward Bin/ Jr.. but she added: 
“ I'm looking forward lo the chance to go on till’ stand and really tell the truth. Before my testimony was what 
Charlie wanted — to try to get him out.” 
During the penalty phase of the first trial. 
Miss Yan Boutell and co-defendants Susan 
Atkins aud P atricia 
Krenwinkel all testified that the motive for the 
LaBianca murders had nothing to do with Munson’s efforts to trigger a ra­ cial revolution. 
Sharon Tate and four others were killed the night liefnre (In* LaBiancas were slain. Miss Yan Boutell was not charged in the Tate killings. 
They said instead that the killings were committed in an attempt to free another Manson follow er. Robert 
Beausoleil. who had Iwen jailed for the murder of Malibu. Calif . musician 
Cary Binman 
Wrong man 
They testified that by committing a sim ilar type m urder, with bloody writing on the walls, they could con­ vince authorities they had arrested tin* wrong man. 
Discussing that testimony iii the first trial. M is s Yan Boutell said 
“That was all made up lieeauae we thought we could say that there would 
In* |»oor Charlie sitting over there iii his innocent seat while alt these people were calling him all these terrible things That was the whole thing on that.” she said Manson decided on this strategy “ about the middle oi tin* trial or may be a little earlier than that 
\t the conclusion of the penally phase, the jury came back with death penalty verdicts for Manson and the three young women, Did she ever think she was going lo die Iii the gas chamber? 
••Oh. when the judge read it. sn- met lung was clicking down deep inside

 of me amidst all of these crazy little things.” she said. “ Yeah, it was pretty heavy. But. of course, right away we giggled about it . . ." 
Shelter 
She said that at the tim e of the killings “ life and death didn’t matter that m u ch ” because she hand the others were convinced they were pro­ tected by Munson's plan calling for them to find a hole in the desert where they would stay until the race war was over. 
Manson cited the Bible and the Bea­ tles to support his predictions. Miss 
Yan Boutell said. 
“ Be pointed out a bunch of stuff iii the Book of Revelations that supported what he was telling us. including the thing about the hole in the earth. 
“ And he would have us listen to a 
Beatles record over and over. saying 
‘Can you hear it? Can you hear it? They are speaking to m e.’ We got so we thought we really did hear it.” 
Bow did Manson achieve such do­ m ination over her and his other followers? She admits to being a little at a loss to explain it now but she says that LSI) had a lot do with it. 
Acid 

"By the time I went to the “ family” at S|>ahn Ranch. I was really into acid . 
. . and for eight hours solid Charlie would do things on acid. I didn t know at the time what he was doing to my mind but it was really a trip to watch him. 
“ Be used to Im* good with cards, you know, play tricks with cards. And when you take acid, your eyes will sort of hallucinate. Charlie would put so­ mething in our mind and because he was quick with his hands and wit. we would sort of think we had seen a miracle. I did believe he was a special person brought here." 
One of the most vivid scenes she re­ calls of Manson during an LSI) session was “Charlie going through the eruci- ficion. with contortions of pain and everything.” 
Ber return to her “own self.” as she puts it. came about iii several ways. 
“ First, we were isolated from him. then much of what he predicted just wasn't happening, and I got a lot of help from another woman who was on 
Death Row with us and from a really nice psychiatrist at the prison. Some­ where iii all of this. I grew up quite a bit.” 
Danger? 
Is there any danger to her or the general public from the Manson “ fa­ mily" at this time? 
“Well. first I’ll tell you the Manson family was never as big as the news media made it. There really were only about ll) girls and three guys although peo|)le came and went. 
“ Now. I think Squeaky and Sandy 
((ioode) are the only two he has left and they are locked up. I’m not wor­ ried and I don’t think hysteria should 
A i i r i d m em ory: ''Charlie g o in g through the cruci­ fixion. , with contortions o f 
Imin and everything' 

 trial.” 
What was her reaction when she heard 4hat Squeaky had tried to shoot 
Ford? 
“ When it happened. I just figured. 
Well. that figures.’ I don t think it was any accident the gun didn t go off. 
“ I think on her part. Nile wanted to do something that Charlie would be proud of. but she never really wanted to take that chance of having to live with her conscience . 
Deciphering 

Miss Yan Boutell said that during the month prior to the assassination attempt, prison authorities had conn to her asking for help iii deciphering letters written by Squeaky and Sandy 
"All of a sudden the administration was getting all of these weird letters that indicated Lynne and Sandy were going to do something 
“ It surprised me to lie questioned bv tin* authorities because all of us at 
Frontcra had stopped writing to them or accepting their letters, 
“ We had cut off contact at least a couple of years before. Their letters weren’t making any sense,” 

Leslie thinks that Front me and 
(ioode remained Manson followers tor so long hecuusc they became addicted to the publicity they got

Editor o f the Editorial Page 

C artw right’s double-tax bill 

State Rep. Don Cartwright hasn't learned a thing from the 
Lombardino law. 

The Bexar r e p r e s e n t a t iv e from District 57-H to tin* Legis­ lature has introduced two bills that would, if his colleagues ap­ proved, tamper materially with the budget of the City of San 
Antonio. 

In e ffec t, 
C a r tw rig h t is proposing lo double property taxes on San Antonians. 

One of his bills would prohibit the city from taking any money from City Public Serv ice 
Board. Approximately one-third of the city 's G en era l Fund r e v en u e s c o m e from 
CPS payments to tin* city. Last year’s figures show ( FLS payments ap­ proximately equal to property taxes. 

Thus, if CPS paym ents are denied, tilt1 only other readily-available source of funds is taxes on property, lf the load tell equally upon property, tin* lax payment would double for every taxpayer 

So Cartwright is proposing to reduce utility b ills by a maximum of 11.5 per cent (the city's share (from CPS) in e x ­ ch a n g e for doubled property taxes. 

H ouseholders and other property owners can com pu te the effects of that quite readily 

 by estim a ting a v er a g e utility e x p e n se and c o m p a r in g that with doubling the tax bill on their house or business property. 

On a m id d le -in c o m e house with an average utility bill of $6(1 a month (that is high for many households and low for those where cost is no problem), the annual savings under 
Cart­ w r ig h t's proposal would be about $84. 

Doubled property ta x e s would cost far more than that. 

A dditionally, C a r t w r i g h t ’s sc h e m e would give su bu rb an users of CPS services their dis­ count without ANY com pensat­ ing help with the city budget. 

C a r tw r ig h t’s p ro p o sa l is more irresponsible than he may realize, and we anticipate other 
Bexar legislators will shortly persuade him so. 

But the sad part of the proposal is that C artw righ t hasn’t caught on that local c i­ tizens sh ould n ’t have their 
I ova I Iv-financed s e r v i c e s m eddled with in A u stin . San 
A ntonians are as c a p a b le ut electing officials to stall ( tty 
Hall as they are of electing those who help staff the Legislature. 

Cartwright would do himself a favor by withdrawing the bills and burning them. That would show, at least, that he can learn. 
City’s planning goals under pressure 

Tin* next few months will be the toughest tor the City Plan­ ning 
C o m m is s io n and 
City 
Council. 
The P la n n in g C o m m iss io n h a s e st im a te d city growth in terms of population and geogra­ phic lo cation s. It e s t im a t e s growth over the next two d e ­ cades will be about 4o per cent iii population that will require about 41.9oo a c r e s fur new houses and other development. 
It s e e m s in e v ita b le that growth will continue northward. 
Precedent has broken resistance against urban d e v e lo p m e n t within the so-called hot zone of the Edwards aquifer's recharge area. 
The definitive study of tlie* zone, ordered by City Council, remains perhaps two years dis- taut. That study (by Metcalf & 
Eddy. one of the nation’s fore­ most fir m s for that kind o| work) is supposed to tell council what will be the results of deve­ lopment in the zone. Pressure to hold off substantial change over the recharge zone until results are known is b ein g m et by pressure to proceed with pro­ tects already planned. 

T I? HP T 17 D C 

W ho thinks of the kids during school warfare? 

Council is being responsible in the face of hard pressure and is unfairly taking criticism dir­ ected at it for inaction by prior councils 

Demand for water, sewer and other services grows stronger almost daily. Council should be careful to identify problems and pressures as they arise and in­ sist, as a m i n i m u m r e q u i r e ­ ment, the standards already de­ signe d iii the e n g in e e r in g studies made for the proposed 
San Antonio Ranch New Town. 

The planners’ growth sketch has been presented to council, which h a s put it on public exa­ mination for at least two weeks. 
Major g o a ls are renewal of the center citv and adequate pro­ tection <n tin* city’s water sup­ ply 

The sketch is the first c o m ­ prehensive look at goals in many years. Those most-direct Iv con­ cerned with development should commit to improve the sketch to meet fundamental goals. P lan­ ning is essential if we are to get best results from available re­ sources and avoid costly correc­ tive work later. 

Although the results are in, the dust probably will not settle for some time in the San Antonio 
School D i s t r i c t ’s $49 m illio n bond issue. 

VV hat began as a sim p le black or white issue, through the process of the cam paign eventually grayed so that the original intent becam e losi 

Buried som ew here underneath the rubble of the campaign is the original question of whether ttit* bond issue would be beneficial to the children of the San Antonio School District. 

And that question drew accusations and counter charges from opponents and proponents of the bond issue like honey draws bees 

Many of the concerns regarding the value of the bond proposal were valid arid deserved consideration 

Worries over increased utility rates stem m ing from new schools and air conditioning of old structures certainly were relevant in a time of limited en- ergv supplv 

‘Overindulgent' 

Some who argued against the bond issue believed funds were designated for im provem ents which w ere unne­ cessary and overindulgent. And older citizens of the district who must pay their lulls from fixed incomes worried about the in c r e a s e iii ta x e s w hich would result from the bond issu e's passage. 

Proponents, on the other hand, also had their selling points. 

(h e r half of Hit* district's schools are more than 2*> years old and it) need of renovation They house so m e 68,ooo students 

Liz 
Sweet 

Education 

In tin' years that the district has 
I icon in operation, the needs and con­ cepts of education have changed, the proponents pointed out 

Keeping up with modern concepts of open area c la ssr o o m s and learn in g centers used in other school districts, supporters said, necessitated new and improved buildings 

Revitalization 

Im p roved e d u c a tio n a l fa c ilit ie s winch would allow the district to offer a superior educational environm ent, they noted, would attract m ore resi­ dents into the inter-city area and thus help in the city's goal toward revitali­ zation. 

Kilter polities and politicians. 

The lines began to reorganize around different issues and personalities, 

P assage of the bond issue perhaps would indicate a com m unity support for the new majority taction which has sat in the board's driver’s seat since last April’s election. Or that's what the faction hoped 

Charges 

That new faction is led by Dr. Wil­ liam Elizondo who, in the midst of the campaign, had been accused of politi­ cal am bitions above and beyond the 

 extent of the school board. 

To further those ambitions, his cri­ tics said, he used pressure tactics a g a in s t d is tr ic t p r in c ip a ls and teachers to ensure the passage of the bond issue and thus strengthen his own political power base. 

In the process, critics said. Elizondo and “ Ills board" have taken credit for im provem en ts in the d istrict which were thought of and instigated manx years ago under a different board. 

In r e sp o n s e . E lizo n d o and other su p p o r te r s of the bond is s u e sa id charges of pressure tactics were just sour grapes from those who had not gotten over the results of the last board election. 

T hese ch arges. Dr. Elizondo said. were a tactic in them selves to cause a loss (if support for the bond election and to make Elizondo look like a table without legs. 

Vendettas 

Encouraging the defeat of the bond issue, supporters stressed, was a way to wage political vendettas 

Probably both sides have degrees of v a lid ity to th eir a r g u m e n t s . 
Accusations of political coercion ce r­ tainly should not be ignored or taken lightly. If the board m em bers and ad­ m in is tr a tiv e o ff ic ia ls w ere not in ­ volved. as they insist, they have noth­ ing to lose and everything to gain by a thorough investigation. 

T he point su n k in all the m u d , though, is that a bond election where children are trapped in the line of fire is not the place to wage political w ar­ fare. 

 rishis i m u rn ; schools cities, su bu rbs. 
Local GOF chewing on its own tail 

The view from the Hilton Ba­ lat in del Ru» was a great tine for 
Republicans last week. But it may hast* been a mirage. 
Meeting ut the Hilton were m em bers of ibe board of the National Federation of Republican Women 
From the moment of the curb arn* va! of National President Pat Hutar, the mood vvas upbeat. 

Atter all. a Republican congressional candidate had just staged a big upset victory in a special election in a liberal 
Minnesota district 

F ro m now on, M rs 
H utar noted gleefully, the Democrats cannot blame what happens in Washington on a Re­ publican president, much less a HOP congress 
Not only that, she said, but party organizations like the federation are alrcadv mobilizing to find and support candidates for Pt?tv In fact, til ii’ sta* 
11 st iv gins and com puters have a ln adv pin pointed 82 congressional districts and hundreds of state legislative d is­ tricts in which the part) can hest start its com eback 

Kemper 
Diehl 

Politics c 

S ta te R ep u b lica n C h airm an Hay 
Hutchison was just as optim istic fol­ lowing a fruitful meeting of the state committee last weekend in Dallas 
The c o m m itte e drew up plans to build GGP strength iii the legislature 

 i i i 1978 and Ihhu in anticipation ut the redistricting of con gressional boun­ daries following the next conins 
So harmonious were the state's Re. publican lead ers Ihaf the situation drew awed comments from no less than Rav Barnhart, the Mute Ronald 
Reagan chieftain 
And Mrs Hutar suggested that on a national level the painful wounds of the great f ord Reagan nomination strug­ 

 gle were almost miraculously healed 
Well. perhaps a great GOF love-in is 

 really just around the corner 
But there are ominous rum blings right here in Bexar County that fac ­ tional feuding is still the name of the game 
I hairm an H utchison has m ade a realistic appraisal of what Republicans in Texas should be doing: working at electing legislators and congressmen. 
After ail there is little point in hav­ ing Republican presidents if the rest of the government is in the hands of De­ m on ,tu 
When Hutchison's list of Republican c a m p a ig n o p p o r tu n itie s in 1978 is drawn, Bexar County should be near ttie tup 
( onservativf 
It seem s a good bn that t S 
Re p 
Bob Krueger will seek promotion to the 
I x. senate, leaving tho li s t District w ole open rh is i s , of course, a con servative bailiwick which could Im* won by the right Republican 
Mid at b a st one B exar legislative 

 district in addition to that of GGP State 
Rep Jim Nowlin could easily go Re­ publican. 
But if party harmony is necessary to make these gam es, Chairman Hutch* son might well forget it 
“ In Bexar C oun ty,” exp la in s one battered survivor, “factional hatreds are stronger than party loyalty. 
“ The te s t,” he con tinu es, “ is not whether you are a R ep u b lican, it's what faction you belong to.” 
Factional splits, for example, clearly contributed to John O’Connell’s close loss last November to State Rep Abe 
Ribak. 
Spreading 
Now the i ultra-party strife is spread­ ing into a new arena in which Repub­ licans have a chance to dev elop leaders 
— the city council districts 
Take the race ut District « between 
( agnel Inurn Fbi! Pyndus, the Reagan 
Republican, and ( ouncitman Ford 
Nielsen a liberal Democrat. 

It would Im expected that Republi can s iii t h i s area of GGP stren g th would supt mu t Pyndus. 

But the truth is that his factional foes within the party are charmed by the 
IHissibility of a Pyndus defeat. 

Nielsen strategists realize the very well Ralph Langley and Cliff Morton have l>een working to obtain open sup­ port for the D em ocratic councilm an from well-known Republicans. 
They’ll succeed 
Nowlin, for example, would make a strong GOF c a n d id a te in the giant district which extend s from A lam o 
Heights to Pecos and Alpine 
But Nowlin was an outspoken backer of President Ford last year. In consi­ dering a race he would have to face the very real prospect that stubborn Rea- g a n ite s m ig h t p refer to vo te for a 
Jim m y Curter campaigner like Nelson 
Wolff before backing a Ford man 

There is little doubt but that they will succeed in a number of cases. 
It is this sort of elephantine memory of old feuds whit h will make it hard for party-builders tike Hutchison to find can d id ates even when there are op- jMtrtunihes like an open rate in Dim, 

This n e w s p a p e r w e lco m es le tte r s (ro m its r e a d e rs . 
They should b e sh o rt, n o t o v e r 3 o o w o rd s, an d th e y m ust b e sig n ed . H o w ev er, only re a d e rs ' initials will b e u sed if th e re q u e s t is m o d e. Politicians7 

Sir: Everyone knows. I’m sure, that mem bers of Congress have received a pay raise from $44.HOO to $57,5oo an­ nually. The huge increase was secured through a deceitful dev ice of Congress which allowed a recommendation of a commission proposing the increase to become law without additional affir­ mative action by Congress. 
A lth ou g h th e r e w e r e h o n est mem bers of the House of Representa­ tives anxious to have the House have a roll call vote on the raise proposal, their efforts were thwarted by House 
Speaker Thomas P. “T ip” O’Neill of 
Massachusetts and a complacent m a­ jority of the House. 
O’Neill has defended the pay raises as necessary to keep salaries com peti­ tive with industry and on CBS' “ Face the Nation” program , he said that if 
Congress had voted on the issue, the raise would have been defeated be­ cause of public opposition, are in­ stances where it is in the best interests of the nation not to vote the will of the people". 
Such conceit, such assumption of omnipotence, by this powerful man to whom we are supposed to look for leadership in the hope for a resurgence of ethical conduct in a Congress rid­ dled with evidences of lack of integri­ ty, destroys one’s faith in the future of our Republic. 
Roy M. Mueller 
"Thin-skinned’ 

Sir: I ain not usually one to write this kind of letter, hut that Sunday tirade of 
Stephen Marinaro deserves comment. 
Either Marinaro is so thin-skinned that he can't take a d ifference of opinion by three letter-w riters, in which case he has no business working for a newspaper. 
I think that the letter mention­ ing the co m m en tator for the New 
Yorker Magazine shows the caliber of 
Don Stefuno. 
I am surprised that the Express- 
Nevvs would waste newsprint letting this fellow bellyache like this for no more than three dissenting letters, 
A further razzberry to Marinaro, just on general principles. 
Ford Green 
Double jeopardy 

Sir: There is something about this 
Hayes-Morales case that bothers me. 
Isn t it a well established principle of law that no man shall twice be plac­ ed in jeopardy for the sam e offense? What is it that the feds are claiming here? Are they saying that this is not lint1 offense but two? That would seem to be a neat piece of end running. After all this man was in­ dicted and tried, how ever ineptly, before a jury of his peers. If there was a miscarriage of justice it wasn't his fault. 
The double jeopardy safeguard, one might surm ise, was never intended to be limited in its application. In fact it was intended for use precisely in those cases where courts become capricious. 
If they never erred there would be no need for it. 
It looks to m e like Big Nanny is getting ready to trample on som ething more important than either Hayes or 
Morales. 
William o . Dysard 

Wizard o f Ogg 

 sir While enroute to Houston to visit friends I couldn’t help but feel that HI 
IO became the yellow brick road and I was on the way to the Land of Ogg. 
The Wizard of Ogg, State Sen. Jack 
Ogg of Houston, like the Wizard of Oz. can bestow extraordinary favors on certain people and manipulate events in distant realms. 
The Wizard of Ogg gave the tin soldiers of San Antonio new heart with his “ grandfather clause" added to the bill to repeal the Lombardino unlimit­ ed sick-pay bill that guarantees such favors to current tin soldiers, or in the case of Lt. Al Peeler, cowardly lions. 
Dorothy complained that she didn’t have her act together when the Wicked 
Warlock of the West, Frank Lombar­ dino, tricked her out of her govern­ mental slipper. Lt’s hope that the 
Wizard of Ogg will bestow the gifts of courage and leadership on Dorothy 
Cockrell. 
Hubert Franklin 

T r y r e a d i n * - 

Sir: We have been assailed with horror stories about nuclear power plants and radiological waste. Yet, I have found in financial journal that 
Sweden's ASEA is developing a m eth­ od of air cooling reactors without heating local water sources and have found out how to solidify nuclear waste into inert ingots. Why have not the TY n e ws m edia reported on this? Not sensational en ou gh o about obscene corporate profits. Yet, in another fin­ ancial journal I have learned that return on equity for major corpora­ tions is down from 1H per cent two decades ago to 8 per cent today inhi­ biting modernization, expansion and employment. Why have not the TV news media reported on this? 
We have I Teen assailed by the m e­ dia's demands for freedom of the press. 
Yet, I have learned that over Wtu news items pass over the wires each day, of which no more than l f are selected for 
TV airing 
Who determines which items I will learn of and which I will not? Could this not be a case of free­ dom for the press but m assive thought control for the viewers? 
The TV new s media have audited the presidency and the corporate system and are now auditing the C ongress. 
Has riot the time com e for a revealing audit of the news media, especially 
TV? 

Edward J, ( nsiellu 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS — Sunday February 27 1977 
 arming o f the presidency 

War Powers Act clouds the issue 

By STUART DARLING and CRAIG MENSE 

 w a s h i n g t o n p o s t 
Three years have passed since 
C ongress enacted the 
War 
Powers Resolution over Presi­ dent Nixon’s veto. 
Since then there has been relatively little discussion about this law that p u rp o rts to e n s u re that the United 
States will never again become in­ volved in another unpopular war like that in Vietnam. 
In essence the law seeks to ensure that American armed forces w ill not be committed to hostilities by tin* Presi­ dent without prior congressional auth­ orization except in “ e m e rg en c y ” si­ tuations. In the event that such an emergency does arise, the President can. on his own, com m it forces to combat, but they must be withdrawn after HO days unless Congress has en­ acted a measure specifically endorsing his action. 
The sta tu te g ra n ts the P re sid en t authority to extend this 6o-day period for an additional 3o days if, in his opinion, “ unavoidable military neces­ sity” so requires. Thus, the President can wage war on his own for OO days before Congress really enters the pic­ ture. 
The current act has seemingly been forgotten since the resignation of P re ­ sident Nixon. But w h e th e r , as is claimed, the law will compel future 
Presidents to allow for congressional participation in any decisions to com­ mit U.S. troops lo hostilities overseas is questionable. 
As we enter a new era, there is a clear need to analyze tin* law’s practical effects on the nation’s foreign policy. 
Crisis 
It is not diffic ult to envision, drawing from the current world situation, a crisis that might precipitate the intro­ duction of U S. troops overseas to pro­ tect our real or imagined interests. 
The death of Marshal Tito, now 85, could te m pt the Soviets to g rab for power in strategic Yugoslavia, proba­ bly by a variety of subtle means, con­ ceivably by overt military action. 
Should that occur. President Carter would not necessarily be bound by the comment of candidate Carter dismiss­ ing a military response. The potentia­ lities for trouble in the Middle East are not limited to the Arab-lsraeli conflict but cover as well the volatile Persian 
Gulf. into which has flowed iii recent years large quantities of American weapons and thousands of American military instructors. 

One can go on identifying potential trouble spots, evoking Cassandra-like images of the future in southern Africa or Korea. 
Tile question that must be asked is this: Would an American President, laced with what he saw as an unavoi­ dable conflict and aware of the mili­ tary advantages of quick action, be restricted by the current war-powers law from initiating U.S. military ac­ tions until he could acquire congres­ sional approval? 
Problems 
Probably not. In fact, the existing statute creates more problems than it solves As Yale Law Professor Charles 
L. Black characterized it “ Presented as a limitation on presidential power, 
(it) can hardly be read as other than a very nearly explicit authorization of any presidential action whatever, with 
C o n g res s e x e r c is i n g s u p e r v i s o r y power later along, after tile com m it­ ment has been made.” rile failure of the law stems from a decision made in 1973 in a conference com m ittee form ed to reconcile the differences between the bill s House and Senate versions. 
The Senate had acknowledged the necessity of the P r e s i d e n t ’s acting without prior congressional approval in certain em ergency situations but spelled out what those “ emergencies” were: 
(1) responding to or preempting un attack on the United States itself 
(2) responding to or preempting an attack on U.S. armed forces stationed abroad and 
(3) Kescuing American citizens abroad from c ircu m sta n ces which endangered their lives. 
The House, on the other hand, had allowed the P r e s i d e n t u n ila te ra l emergency power without specifying what would constitute an emergency. 
The conference committee placed the 
Senate codifications of em ergencies under the “ Purpose and Policy” sec­ tion of the compromise bill." 
Language 
The conference report explained that tile “ Purpose and Policy" section was 
“ a statement of the authority of the commander-in-chief respecting the in­ troduction of armed forces into hosti­ litie s and went on to say “ subsequent sections . . . are not dependent upon the language of this subsection, as was the case with a similar provision of the 
Senate bill." 
By delaying the congressional im ­ primatur for 9H days, one of the bill s main goals was co m p ro m ised . The authors of the Senate bill felt it cru­ cially important that Congress share in 

 the decision to use force before an ac­ tual commitment had been made. 
Otherwise, Congress would have to make the difficult choice of compelling a withdrawal or evacuation of forces already engaged in hostilities. For these reasons. Sen. Thomas Eagleton 
(D-Mo.) voted against adoption of the co n fe re n c e re p o r t, though he had helped draft and guide the legislation through the Senate. 
Most other supporters of the Senate bill, even though they shared many of 
Eagleton’! reservations, chose to ac ­ cept the conference version. They did so to a significant and unfortunate degree because of unrelated political events. 
R e m e m b er the atm osphe re at the time: President Nixon, under m ount­ ing criticism from all sides because of 
Watergate, had recently fired special p r o s e c u to r A rc h ib a ld Cox in the 
"Saturday Night Massacre." 
Vetoed 
Nixon vetoed the conference bill, claiming that it was both unconstitu­ tional and an unwise inhibition on the 
Presidents conduct of foreign policy. 
By this tim e , however. C ongress seemed to have tired of arguments for or against the bill itself. Nixon's veto tended to transfer the issue from the bill’s provisions to a question of con­ gressional capability to stand up to an increasingly discredited President. In its 1o-month existence, the 93rd Con­ gress had not overridden any of Nix­ on's vetoes. 
In the House, the vote to override was very close. Eight House liberals 

 who had formerly opposed the confer­ ence bill switched sides to make the override possible. The margin was on­ ly 4 votes above the necessary two- th irds m ajo rity . In the Senate the override margin was 13, and on Nov. 7. 
1973, in Public Law 92-14K, the country at last had a war powers act 
But is this law worth having? Does it do more harm than good? 
It is difficult for d e m o c r a c ie s to compete in world politics against tot - litarian states. Democracies are su­ spicious of secrecy and not very good at it. 
Secrecy 
Yet successful foreign policies so­ metimes require secrecy, as well as intimidation, threats, alignments with undemocratic states and. too often, the application of force to obtain desired ends. 
When a democracy must resort to violence, however, it is im p e rativ e both for the success of the foreign po­ licy leading to the use of force, and for the military operation itself, that the people understand why they are fight­ ing and accept tin1 sacrifices necessary for victory Without this element of consent and a willingness to bear the burdens of war, a democracy is wise to keep out of combat situations. 
In effect, by deciding not to require prior congressional consent for p r e si­ dential war-making in other than de­ signated em e rg en c y situations, the conference c o m m itt e e aw ard e d the 
President carte blanche to undertake any sort of military operation subject only to ex post facto Congressional re- 

 v lew. 
A situation in which Congress felt compelled to force a w ith drawal of forces already engaged in hostilities would be a n i g h t m a r e for all c o n ­ cerned, not least to the military p e r­ sonnel doing the actual fighting. The effects on service morale would bi1 la­ mentable and frightening. 
More likely, however. C o n g res s would never steel itself to make such a decision unless a military venture had proved utterly calamitous, either on the battlefield or at home, or both. 
Dunkirks 
Additionally, if for some reason (al­ beit an unlikely one) Congress became too zealous iii compelling withdrawals after HH days, the world could bear witness to a succession of American 
Dunkirks that would be unredeemable. 
Sen Barry Coldwater (R-Ariz.) and others have expressed the view that the 
President must not be deprived of his ability to defend and protect U.S. lives and interests throughout the world 
True It is the price we pay for living iii a world where force, and not law, is oftentimes the arbiter of the future. It would be a foolish mistake to deprive the President of the ability to wage a defensive war. 
However, th en4 remains the problem of determining what a defensive wai­ ls Nearly all belligerents call their half of any war “ defensive;” it is the other side who’s waging an aggressive. 
“offensive" war. 
The Senate lull presented as worka­ ble a definition of defensive war as can likely be written. In that section, the 
President was empowered to “ fores­ tall," or preempt, the “ direct and im ­ m inent t h r e a t , ” of a t t a c k s on tin1 
United States itself and on American armed forces abroad without a declar­ ation of war. 
Retaliation 
In the event of attacks on the United 
States, he could take “ retaliatory” ac­ tion as well Ile could use the armed forces to rescue \ m e r i c a n citizens abroad, but with provisions that pre­ vent such ail operation from, being used as a guise to cloak ulterior mo­ tives. In any other situation the Presi­ dent would first have had to secure the approval of Congress before resorting to the use of armed forces 
The present law, however, took one step forward and two steps backward 
Certainly this War Powers Resolution is not without some valuable ideas. It m akes clear, for exam ple, that our treaty com mitm ents are not self-exe­ cuting. Apparently, this surprised se­ veral of our allies and caused them to worry aloud about 
A m e r i c a n credibility as a world power. 
I ii reality, however, the m ere fact that a given nation s signature appears on a treaty proclaiming a military al­ liance is not what matters. Alliances are based on a shared perception of a common threat 
Alliances are little m ore than verbal ex p re s s io n s of a common v iew of potential danger. 

The NATO treaty will become only a scrap of paper if, for whatever reason, the United States, or the West Euro­ peans, come to feel that Sov iet domin­ ation of Europe is not something worth fighting to prevent. 
The congressional record in foreign affairs since the adoption of the pre­ sent war-powers law has not been im ­ pressive. The failure of tin4 bill to in­ volve Congress in the decision-making processes surrounding the evacuation from Vietnam or the Mayaguez affair illustrates both the weaknesses of the statute and congressional reservations about accepting the constitutional re­ sponsibility that some cla im e d the 
President has usurped. lf Congress continues to evoke its constitutional authority in as h ap h a­ zard a manner as it has in the last two years, becoming involved in the Ango­ lan and Cypriot situation, but not in the e v a cu a tio n from V ie t n a m or th e 
Mayaguez affair. Congress will justi­ fiably be subject to charges of m e d ­ dling in presidential concerns and tin* formula for democratic participation in decisions to use force will remain cloudy. 
The current period of relative do most ic and international tranquility offers tin4 opportunity to reopen the issue for further consideration. Now is a good time for a reasoned and dis passionate analysis of tin* existing law 
The fact is that a 
President isn't re­ stricted from he- g i ii n i i i # wa r f a re despite this law 

A better opportunity may not be forth­ coming 
It is bitter to contemplate the effects of a renewed war-powers debate insti­ gated by a future military conflict in­ volving i s troops Common sense should beckon the Congress to settle the issue beforehand 
A return to the original Senate bill would clarity tin4 situations iii which the President’s emergency powers do allow him to act unilaterally aud would specify the situations i ii which the 
P r e s i d e n t can act only w ith p r i o r authorization 
Some flexibility would be lost to tin4 
President in his conduct of diplomacy. 
This weakness is inherent in our de­ mocracy. and we would be better off recognizing our limitations 
H ow ever, th a t loss of flexibility would be more than compensated by the gain of a truly democratic dialogue on the issues of foreign policy. 
The President, too often shielded from adversary politics, would be ob­ liged to engage in public debate — to state his proposal and to p e rs u a d e 
Congress and the American people to accept it. 
Carter is building world hope 

WASHINGTON 
- 
When 
Jimmy Carter was running for 
P resident, he lam ented that 
America had been disgraced by government policies unworthy of her people. He would change these policies, he promised; and he would never do anything that would shame us. 

He hadn’t been in the White House long before he began taking several small steps to place morality above convenience, above hypocrisy. Ile con­ demned the abuse of human rights a r­ ound the world from Rhodesia to South 
Korea. 
He pro tested rep e ate d ly the s u p ­ pression of basic freedoms in the So- v iet Union — the unmentionable corpse in the closet during the Nixon-Kis- singer-Ford era And lest these pro­ tests h*4 thought empty formalities, he dramatized them by going out of his way to show resp e c t for the g r e a t 
Russian spokesmen for freedom and decency. 
A personal letter was sent to Andrei 
S ak h a ro v ; the word w ent out that 
Alexsandr Solzhenitsyn and Vladimir 
Bukovsky will be welcome at .Jimmy 
Carter s White House. 
From these simple acts, a ripple of hope has started to spread the world over among o p pressed people who 

Jock 
Anderson 

W ashington 
C 

 keep aliv e a yearning for freedom. It is a hope that springs not from any ex­ pectation that we will liberate them. but from the knowledge that we are aware they exist, that we honor their struggle and that the great human tide is with them. 
Determined 
C onsistent with this. P r e s i d e n t 
Carter seems determined lo keep the 
FBI within the law and to keep the CIA away from covert activities. Murder, burglary, bribery, extortion, election rigging — all are out. Any oilier covert activity will require a written authori­ zation with his signature on it where it can be read by history and the special prosecutor. 
Byproduct 

It is bad enough that we stood mute l>efore foreign despotism; it is intoler­ able that from refusing to see evil in 

 front of our noses, we went on to prac­ tice it ourselves We have m ade no p erm a n en t gains, and we have lost what was once our greatest strength. 
Our reputation for decency, once the beacon of the world, is now everywhere in tatters, and we are looked ut as little better than the communists 
And an inevitable by-product haunts us. One by one, the schem es we de­ signed for others, in competition with the Soviet KOB, have been tu rn ed against our own people and in stitu­ tions. 
This insidious, corrosive process can be seen in em bryo in the testimony given by the incomparable E. Howard 
Hunt as a prosecution witness in the, trial of the White House plumbers for breaking into the office of Daniel EUs- berg’s psychiatrist. 
The P r e s i d e n t ’s b u ria l s hoped to steal discrediting information about 
Ellsberg which the White House could, in turn, leak to the press 
Hunt was asked what type of work he did during his long career with the 
Central Intelligence Agency. “ Oh,” he replied with bored nonchalance, “ sub­ version of prominent figures abroad, the overthrow of governments — that sort of thing.” Judging from his tes­ timony, it seemed to Hunt a logical progression to go from subverting for­ eign leaders to discrediting by illegal means an American public figure 
Then he recruited under false pre­ 

 tenses a group of Uuban-Americans who followed him, out iii trust, into the | burglary of they knew not what; and then, in the final scene, he turned state’s evidence and testified against his recruits in order to avoid having additional time added to his Watergate sentence. 
That Hunt at one stage thought this sort of esc a p ad e served A m e r ic a 's cause is the final argument against it 
Boomerang 

The CIA program of bribing politi­ cians in other countries in order that they might support American interests has produced a sim ilar boomerang. 
Over the years, we have chronicled how the CIA has corrupted foreign of. fie aals with wine. women and under- the-table cash. 
Now Americans are up in arm s over the South Korean CIA’s efforts to bribe 
American congre ssm e n. The KITA, like Iran's SAYAK and other foreign intelligence operations, was modeled after our own These agencies learned ulwtut bribery from the ( IA 
Conclusion: The ClA” s d e t e r m in a ­ tion to get down in the g u tte r and operate at the same level with the So­ viet KOB has not paid off. The direct result is that the United States has lost, not g a i n e d , in flu en ce, a ro u n d the world. There comes a time when. ti we cannot be guided by principle, at least we ought to bi* deterred by shame

The Henry Kissinger Show 

WASHINGTON - NBG has just signed on Henry Kissinger as a "news consultant," a per­ former on news specials, an occasional guest on the Today show, and an adviser to John 
Chancellor and David Brinkley on foreign affairs. 

I haven t seen the contract so I'm not certain what other m atters Mr. Kis­ singer will handle with the network. 

I suppose my biggest concern is us­ ing Henry as a foreign affairs adviser to Chancellor and Brinkley. 
Since he has a vested interest in 
American policy that he initiated he c a n ’t be considered an unbiased ob­ server. 
I take you now lo the NBC Evening 
News studio a few months from today. 
Story? 

“ Hello, Henry, this is John Chancel­ lor. Brinkley is on the other extension. 
A dispatch just came over the wires that Dick Helms, the former director of the CIA, said you instructed hun to lie to C o n g re s s about our role in 
Chile.”

Buchwold

“ That's all?”

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S — Sunday February 27 1977 

S.A. group aids m oral grow th 

EL 
By LIZ SWEET 
The responsibility of provid­ i n g a moral education for chil- 
*;tlren has long been a tug-of-war 
•b etw een parents and teachers — 
- with the children landing in the 
Timid. m 
In a recent Gallop Poll, 79 per cent of 
* the participants believed teachers and 
■ schools should carry the burden of 
J moral education. 
* 
Schools, however, have been reluc- 
1 £ant t° wade into issues where they anight be forced to play umpire, ac­ cording to Dr. David Jacobson, head of 
J *4he American Institute for Character 
ESBducation in San Antonio. mw* Slowly and with much foot-dragging, 
J "however, schools have begun to sub- 
* merge their toes in the icy water of 
£ character education, according to Dr. 
* Jacobson. 
Z 
From that tentative awareness that 
Z something must be done, the American 
Institute for Character Education was established in 197o with financial help from the Department of Health, Edu- 
* cation and Welfare and the Bracken* 
* ridge Stone Foundation. 
Not religious 
% 
The institute, the first of its kind in 
2 the United States, is a non-profit or- 
* ganization which has poured thousands 
2 of dollars and years of research into 
«- the development of education program 
$ models for instructors to use in teaeh- 

Dr. David Jacobson ing basic character traits to students. 
Dr. Jacobson, who recently retired as Rabbi of the Temple Beth El after 38 years, was quick to point out that the models do not preach religious doc­ trine. 
What they do encourage is a concern for moral questions and issues. 
‘‘The thrust of the models is to get kids in an open and relaxed situation 

 and allow them to consider true-to-life dilemas,” Dr. Jacobson said. 
The methods developed include kits containing stories detailing problems or situations which occur in real life and which have no prepared solutions. 
Kits also contain filmstrips, records and posters. 
The institute hopes the classroom teacher will use these props to stimu­ late discussion and to aid children in solving the problems on their own. 
Some models draw from theories of psychologists who believe people fol­ low an evolutionary process towards ultimate understanding. 
Stimulate 
"The trick is to help the child keep moving toward a higher understanding so that he or she inevitably makes the good choice,’? Dr. Jacobson said. 
The highest state, he said, accepts a u n iv e rs a lis ts view and is not self seeking. To reach this step, the child must have help. 
Dr. Jacobson is enthusiastic about the m aterials and is convinced they work. 
"The programs are as specific for developing moral character as quinine is for malaria," Dr. Jacobson said. 
And many teachers and administra­ tors all over the country where the 
AICE programs have been used agree. 
In a letter to Dr. Jacobson, M G. 
Bowden, director of elementary edu­ cation for Austin Independent School 
District, said: 

“ I have known about the .MCP] cur­ riculum materials in character educa­ tion from their beginnings in San An­ tonio. These m a te ria ls have been painstakingly developed, tried out with children, and have, under the guidance of effective teachers, produced great results.” 
Dr. Ivan Fitzwater, superintendent of North East School District w here the materials also have been used, wrote: delighted’ 

“ We are delighted with the results 
(of the character education materials.) independent research and the over­ whelming thrust of teacher opinion convinces us the program is effective in building positive character traits in 
Children. 
Dr. Jacobson attributes the institute’s success in an area where others have failed to the practicality of its doctrines. "Where character edu­ cation has been tried, schools usually presented such rigid doctrines that kids were turned off. The presenters tended to lose credibility," he said. 
Dr. Jacobson stressed that the indi- 
• victual must make the proper moral choices from within himself. 
“ We are concerned with helping teachers help the kids get started making proper choices,” he said. 
The need for such direction, Dr. Ja ­ cobson added, is inherent in the times. 
“ Young people today are increas­ ingly aware that more options and opportunities confront them every day 

 of their lives. There is a new permis­ siveness. And the increasing wealth and leisure time provided by today’s society affords chances to fulfill these choices," Dr. Jacobson said. 
Although the institute itself has had a relatively short life span, the idea which gave it birth was spawned many years ago. 
Russell Hill, a San Antonian con­ cerned with what he believed to be a breakdown in traditional values, drew up his own concept of a “ Freedom 
Code” more than 5o years ago. 
Iii the code. Hill formulated stan­ dards for a "good” person which he eventually had printed on posters and 

 showed to friends in the school busi­ ness. 
One friend. Tom Fort wood, then with the San Antonio School District, was impressed and requested more copies for distribution. 
The posters detailing the Freedom 
Code were such a success that Hill eventually printed more than two mil­ lion copies at his own expense 
Hill’s materials attracted other San 
Antonians interested in providing a set of values for children and in 1943 the 
Children’s Fund — which later would become the institute — was established with a $1 million grant from the Eli 
Lilly endowment fund. 

CPA Leal made his own life 

By VERONICA SALAZAR 
Frank J. Leal grew up not knowing the value of an educa­ tion . He had no concept of what college would mean to him in the future. There were no role models he could follow. 
His father was just a provider. As an immigrant from Mexico he lacked fa­ miliarity with this country. Leal’s only brother, a laborer for a steel company, used to tell young Frank that “ drafts­ men worked u p sta irs, wore white shirts, and worked in air-conditioned offices." 
He recalls his brother often telling him to take care of his hands because one day he was going to be a drafts­ man. 
T hat was tin* only thing L eal’s brother could identify with so Frank went into vocational training when he entered Fox Tech. 
Dedicating three years of high school to draftsman training he was obligated 

DEDICATION REWARDED 

Frank J. Leal 

 to enter college on a GED test. Leal was an all "A ” student but that didn’t helped. He lacked the required courses to qualify him as a freshman in col­ lege. 
Because of his previous training he started in engineering. He was hit with courses he was not prepared for. He realized that if he continued in this field he wouldn’t be doing justice to himself so he changed careers. 
Frank remembered his mother al­ ways talking about her father in Mexi­ co who was an in d u stra list and a writer. “ She would tell us that she hoped that one day one of her children would follow our grandfather’s steps, go into the business world and better ourselves,” said Leal. 
Accounting 
So Leal went into business. He had heard that accounting was in demand at the time. He also recalled a teacher at Fox Tech telling him that he was a bright student and should pursue a college education. "He told me that he saw me in a position of leadership, running a business with a lot of peo­ ple” , he recalls. 
Now Leal, just 29 years old. owns his accounting firm. He is m anager of 
Frank J. Leal and Associates, Inc., certified public accoun tants, and manages a staff of 13. 
A native San Antonian, Leal was born to Jose S. and Consuelo A. Leal on 
Sept. 19, 1947. He was born on Comal 
Street, at an aunt's house, shortly after his p aren ts had im m ig ra te d from 
Mexico. He comes from a family of three girls and two boys, 
His first job was selling crocheted baby booties on Salado Street for his m other when he was eight. “ My m other would crochet them and I would sell them for $1 a pair and I would accept whatever she would give 

 me in return for my efforts,” he re­ calls. 
Since he was not able to rely on his parents for school money, he worked at different jobs while attending school. 
In the summer there were times when he would hold two jobs. 
After graduating from Fox Tech he enrolled at San Antonio College. Two years later he transferred to St. Mary’s 
University where he graduated cum laude in 197o, obtaining a bachelor’s degree in business administration.- 

Exxon 
Towards the end of his senior year 
Leal was interviewed by recruiters and was offered a job with Humble Oil 
(Exxon) in Houston. He didn’t want to leave San Antonio but the glamour of a big company pushed him to go. 
Leal graduated on a Sunday and started working at 8 a.m. next day as an accountant in the exploration and production departm ent. He was the only Mexican-American in the depart­ ment at the time. He worked there 13 months. 
In June of 1971 he returned to San 
Antonio and started working with a local public accountant firm. In 1973 
Leal went to work for himself. 
Leal believes the Mexican-American 

 will continue to demonstrate improve­ ment with respect to social, education and economic standards. 
“ This involvement has generated increased responsiveness within our society to improve conditions for the 
Mexican-American,” he says. 
Examples 
He cites examples such as bilingual education, business assistance to small businesses, availability of more col­ lege scholarships and loans, and the affirmative action program s in em ­ ployment. He adds that the Mexican- 
American has as a result achieved certain levels that have never before been attained in our society. 
Leal’s advice for today’s youth is to seek counseling and carefully plan an education; become involved politically at all levels; and obtain self confidence and a positive attitude about one’s ca­ pacity to excel and to fully recognize and respect one’s identity. 
Me is a mem ber of the American 
Institute of CPAs; American Associa­ tion of Spanish Speaking CPAs; Texas 
Society of CPAs; A rchbishop’s Ad­ visory Council of the Roman Catholic 
Archdiocese of San Antonio; serves on the board of the San Antonio Business 
Resource Center, and on the adm is­ sions and allocations com m ittee of 
United Way. 
Leal is married to the former Norma 
De Los Santos and they have four chil* 
‘ dren. 
ENERGY

Earth’s shadow . 
N aturally , th e re is some question as to the possible d an g ers of beam s of concentrated m icrow aves passing 

 but it doesn’t seem to be too extravagant a hope to suppose that such danger can be m inim ized and made endurable. 
It is not likely to be a more serious danger than
