 through the atmosphere the air pollution that re­ sults from burning coal and oil, or the radioactive pollution that threatens us in our use of nuclear fission. 
Advantages 
There are three main advantages arising out of such energy from space: 
First, a great deal of energy can be obtained this way. If we build en­ ough stations, there will be ample energy to sup­ ply ail our reasonable needs. Naturally, forms of earthbound energy sources will continue to be used where these are locally convenient. 
Second, for the first time in history, there will be a source of energy that is not bound to geo­ graphy. It will come from beyond Earth and will therefore belong to the entire planet. 
Since all nations will have an equal interest in maintaining and reaping this energy source, and since all nations will want a proportionate claim to it and will therefore labor to coo­ perate in its construe* tion, the stations may represent a common goal of utm ost im portance that may help to unite ail hum ankind. It may do more than anything else to end the tragedy of war. 
Third, it will eliminate other energy sources which are polluting in one form or another and will replace it with an energy source that pos­ sesses zero chemical pol­ lution. 
The microwaves them­ selves are a form of ra­ diation pollution, but they cannot possibly be us dangerous as that which might arise from nuclear fission, for in* sl atlee, 
There will Ik* a certain amount of thermal (heat) pollution, since the Earth will receive energy over and above what it re- 

18.99 

OUR STOOLS ARE ON SALI, TOO! 

M icrowave ««• lei Ii ten ct} ult! replace nuclear power plants 

 ceives naturally from the sun. Still such thermal 
E llution is very likely to 
1 less than that pro ­ duced by burning coal and oil or by conducting nuclear reactions. 
Of course, there is no question but that the ex­ pense of building the space power station! will run into tens of billions of dollars, Can we afford this? 
Can we afford NOT to do it when the stations may offer us the best chance of an energy source large enough and safe enough to make it possible for civilization to continue? 
Besides, the expense may not be as great as it sounds. If the space power stations are pro­ duced by all nations in cooperation, that expense wili be spread out and the 
United States may not need to contribute more than half 
If that should come to pass and if the danger of war were consequently to recede, the possibility of gradu al d isa rm a m e n t would become g reater. 
At present, the E a rth ’s nations spend a total of 
13oo billion a y ear on their military machines. 
A small part of this in te rm s of money, m a n ­ power and m aterial re- sources would suffice to build the power stations, and a rm a m e n t cuts 
Im*yond that could supply am ple resources for a variety of humanitarian goals, 
Earth s resources can further be saved if the moon itself is used as a source for construction materials. 
In short, far from be­ ing an expensf. spat e is likely to offer the grea­ test profits humanity has e v e r. experienced.

N 1892 banks were prohibited by law from having Trust 
Departments. Thus, these progressive San Antonians, 

, many of whom were associated with their own banks, established the San Antonio Loan 6? Trust 
Co. to serve the Trust needs of South Texans. 
Today, the San Antonio Bank 6? Trust still has the most experienced Trust Department in South 
Texas. In addition, San Antonio Bank & Trust offers complete banking services for all of your financial needs. 
As in the past, you can continue to bank on us!

It m a y lo o k v e ry little like it, but this is a skull id en tified a s “ B o d o m an,'” a p re -N e a n d e rth a ll sp e cie s of m an. 
Af* WIREPHOTO 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - 
Bodo Man isn't much to look at 
— a lump of fossilized human skull, low-browed, with two gaping dark holes as eye sock­ ets. But he is about hail a m il­ lion to three quarters of a m il­ lion years old. 

To Jon Kalb, a 35-year-old Dallas geologist who heads a research team digging up fossils in a remote and in­ hospitable area of Ethiopia, his d is ­ covery last October is of major s i g ­ nificance in the slow process of piecing together the evolutionary history of early man 
Unique 
The owner of the skull, who belonged to the species homo erectus — the im ­ mediate ancestor of modern m an, is not the oldest specimen of his type to be discovered. More ancient but less com plete skulls have been found in n eig h b o rin g Kenya and in Tanzania further south in East Africa. 
Bodo man is unique, accord in g to 
Kalb, “ because although Louis Leakey 

Modo Man was a tool maker, and that's what is important 

 of Kenya found older hominid fossils, this is the first tim e this particular type of hum an has been found in association with abundant stone tools.” 
T his says Kalb, should allow his team of researchers, com posed of 16 scientists from six different American universities and graduate students from Addis Ababa University, to piece together something of “ Bodo Man’s ” lifestyle as he ambled around all those hundreds of thousands of years ago. 
“ He m a d e his c a m p n ex t to the water’s edge and killed anim als in the water like hippos and those that went down to the w a te r ’s e d g e , lik e a n ­ telope," says Kalb. “ He made his tools from nearby volcanic rock." 
Kalb also believes that the work his team is doing, using fossil rem ains to uncover the origins of man, will rival the discoveries of the late Dr Louis 
Leakey and his wife Mary in Olduvai 
Gorge northern Tanzania and those of their son Richard Leakey on the ea s­ 

 tern shore of Kenya’s Lake Turkana 
Kalb and 'his team have uncovered what he enthusiastically says “ is going to becom e without doubt one of the most important sites in the world in terms of early man and fossil tools.’’ 
Important 
It is in Ethiopia’s northeast Harrar province in the Bodo area — hen ce 
Bodo Man — inhabited by Afar tribes­ men who follow a precarious existence alternately battered by raging winds, torrential rains and appallingly high temperatures. 
Kalb sa y s that b e c a u s e of the geological structure of the area it con­ tains within one basin a sequence of fossil beds stretching back six million years — a historical period more than sp an n in g m a n ’s en tire to o lm a k in g culture. As far as is known this culture stretches back 2.5 million years. 
The team which has only been oper­ ating for the past 3U months, had col­ 

 lected an abundance of fossil tools, in addition to sections of fossilized e le ­ phants, hippos, horses, rhinos, gir- affes> pigs, rodents, reptiles and fish — all of them of types long extin ct — before Dodo Man. the prize of the col­ lection was spotted. 
Molar 
Alemayehu Asfar, from E th iop ia’s 
Ministry of Culture, Sports and Youth. who is the g o v e r n m e n t ’s o ffic ia l representative working with the m is­ sion, had previously made a significant contribution on the day of Bodo M an’s discovery, by picking up a fossilized baboon molar from the ground. 
He handed it to paleontologist Dr. 
Charles Smart, of Princeton Universi­ ty. 
As Smart was inspecting it only a few ya rd s from the b a s e c a m p . 
Alemayehu turned round to spot the lower section of Bodo Man’s skull lying on the ground, partly hidden by som e grass. 
Ile bent down, picked up the skull section and handing it to Smart, said 
“ Oh. what’s this.'' 

'3o off.

Ellery Administration, it is part of a p ack age of em erg en cy cont ingeney p la n s that co u ld he implement**] i i i the fate of a new Arab oil boycott

Ford gas plan sent 
Congress 

 w a s h i n g t o n p o s t se rvice 

WASHINGTON — A detailed contingency plan for establishing a national g a s ration­ ing s y s t e m w a s sent to C o n g r e s s by the 
Ford A dm inistration the day before P re s i­ dent C arter took office.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS —Sunday February 27 1977 

M oscow’s defenses are nearly invisible 

ASSOCIATED p r is s 
MOSCOW - The 
Soviet Union has a vast civil defen se program, at least on paper, but to the naked eye of the outsider there are no apparent signs that this country is hea­ vily preparing its people against a nu­ clear attack. 
Some western military and intelligence sources recently have claim ed that Russia has a m as­ sive civil defense pro­ gram — costing as much 

Could a nation, even one as se­ cretive as the Soviet Union, hide a civil defense program entailing large-scale construction and thor­ ough public indoctrination? An AP 

 a* $B billion a year — in­ cluding bomb sheller construction, re in fo r­ cement of bunkers and buildings, buried utility lines, underground food reserves and stepped-up public drills 
Support for these claim s presum ably comes mostly from reconnaisanee satellites. 
Western m ilitary a t ­ taches here can point to 

 little evidence of either construction or public awareness about large- scale civil defense in 
Moscow and other major cities open to them. 
A growing debate in the West, particularly tin' 
United States, about the extent of Soviet civil defense preparations has fostered an ominous theory that heightened defense is really the 

M B R 
' 
TU r f ! 
Moscow citizens often soy th e y w ould use this subw ay corridor and others like it fo r shelter in case o f nuclear atta c k . But th e re a re fe w real signs o f civil defense preparation in the Soviet cap ital.

 eat bank heist: 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S — Sunday february 27 1977 

France's biggest bank robbery came on a quiet weekend last summer in Nice as a gang worked methodically through a city sewer. The alleged ringleader and others have been caught and the 

 case partially broken. New infor­ mation made available to re­ porters shows that, ironically, the police knew a big robbery was coming but couldn t do anything about it. 

ASSO CIATED p r e s s 
NICE, France — It came as no surprise to 
French police when a gang of 
“ sewer rats” tunneled into the sa­ fety deposit vault of a 
Nice bank last July and got away with an estimated $1o million in jewelry, cash and gold bars. 
The police had known for more than a month that something big like that would happen. 
“ U nfortunately we couldn't find out where and when it would come,” said Police Com­ m issioner 
Albert 
Mourey. 
.Six men and two* women are in jail in con­ 

 nection with what police have described as the biggest bank robbery in 
French history. They in­ clude the confessed mas­ term ind, 
45-year-old one-time paratroop ser­ geant Albert Spaggiari. 
At least 15 members of the gang are still on the run. Three alleged minor participants arc free on bail, pending the trial, not expected to begin before 1979. 
So close 
If Spaggiari, a rig ht­ wing activist and former m em ber of the illegal 

Secret 
Army 
Organization, had known how close the police came to his tracks during the two-month, pre-oper- ational stage of the rob­ bery, he would probably have given up the whole idea. 
It was not the planning that was at fault, it was the execution. Spaggiar- i’s attorney, Jacques 
Peyrat, described him as 
“a great general who put too much faith in poorly disciplined troops.” 
Peyrat said Spaggiari accepts full responsibili­ 

 ty for conceiving, plan­ ning and leading the break-in and is prepared to pay the penalty. 
No one has yet located any part of his huge share of the loot. Peyrat said Spaggiari handed over “every last cent” to a previously unheard-of rightwing underground movement named “ La 
C atena” (The Chain). 
Police 
Com m issioner 
Mourey said he is con­ vinced Spaggiari stashed away millions of dollars in secret bank accounts or safe deposits a n y ­ 

 where between the Ba­ hamas and Hung Kong. 

Spaggiari faces a max­ imum sentence of 2o years in prison — sub­ stantially less if Peyrat can influence the jury with his plea of “ political idealism.” Spaggiari can expect to be released for good conduct after serv­ ing one third of his sen­ tence. 
Audacity 
The robbery was c a r­ ried out with what Mour­ ey called "the most ex­ traordinary audacity and m ilitary precisio n .” 
From the sewer system, w here they moved about in cross-country vehicles and rubber boats, the thieves tunneled 3o feet through earth, rock, con- 
See GOLDEN, next page 

A lbert Sp aggiari, 45, center, is escorted by Nice, France, police into police headquarters last O ctob e r afte r the form e r p aratroop se rge an t w a s arrested as the suspected m asterm ind of the “ se w e r ra ts’1 w h o tunneled into a Nice bank and go t a w a y w ith ab o u t $ 1 o m illion in jew els, cash and go ld bars. 

 anim als 

A SSO CIATED PRESS 
This winter’s crazy weather actually has been kind to some birds and beasts, while cruel to many others. 

What with warmth and drought in the Pacific 
Northwest, hitter cold in the Midwest, and ice and snow in the Middle At­ lantic states, wildlife over most of the country has had to cope with ex­ tremes. Vet some experts are not so pessim istic about long-term p ro­ spects as laymen who pick up dead birds, or see flocks of starving water­ fowl. 
Fish and Wildlife Ser­ vice biologists agree in general that the unusual weather will have an im ­ pact on next year’s hunt­ ing, fishing and bird watching, but they aren't ready to predict just how, or label the w inter 
"good” or “ bad." 
Ducks 
D isaster is most ob­ vious am ong storm - stricken ducks and gees** barred from normal fond supplies by ice. The sick, the weak and the slow adjusters fall first, leav­ ing the fittest to survive 
Many bird s and a n ­ imals are well adapted to cold, others have re ­ treated farth e r south than usual. Even hard-hit species may rebound next su m m er because there will bt* less compe­ tition on the breeding grounds. 
A mild season in Alas­ ka is believed to have in­ sured a higher survival rate for elk and caribou calves, which iii turn means a likely increase in the number of wolves. 
Robert C, Boardman of the National Audubon 
Society says that the ex­ tra waterfowl deploying on southern m arshes doubtless found that others got there first, creating competition for available food. 
"But a good breeding season will restore their numbers.” he says. 
Grain- 
The grain and bread that kind-hearted people spread for hungry ducks and geese may be a mixed blessing. If a bird is emaciated. Boardman says, mouldy bread or even good grain not on its usual menu may do it harm. Or if it has lead shot in Us gullet, a mix of lead and corn can be fa­ tal. 
Even before the winter started, a small goose, the brant, was in trouble because the eel g r a s s that its staff of life has been disease stricken in recent years. Even if it learns to take handouts, it may not thrive on an artificial diet.

Redecorating? Let Wards help with our attractive modern sofa group. Lively zigzag pat­ tern olefin upholstery. Reversi­ ble seat cushions add to chang­ ing convenience plus long durability. Easy care fabric gives quality and comfort.

REGULAR 349.99 

Deer must fear deep snow , Ice and farm dogs 

There isn t much peo­ ple can do to help the hungry. Boardman adds, except cont mue to put out food for small birds if they have been doing that right along. The Fish and 
Wildlife Service agrees that man should not try to help except in rases of extreme need. As an or­ nithologist once wrote. 
"Wildlife faces an en­ ergy crisis every winter, yet manages to cope. The strong survive and the species adapts." 
Hawks 
An ornithologist at the 
American Museum of 
Natural History, Boger 
Pasquier, reports that many hawks hav e been flying farther south than usual because of scarci­ ties of ra b b its anti rodents on which they feed. 
They say that bears in 
Alaska, awakened early from hibernation, are on the prowl for scarce food 
Wet snows anti avalanches have driven moose to the lowlands where they fatten on am ­ ple browse. Rainbow trout are m igrating farther inland than ever before, with unknown re­ sults 
Drought is hampering 
Hie spawning of salmon and steelhead trout, as will lie evident when this year’s meager hatch re­ turns from the sea. Game fish in the Great Lakes and midwestern rivers are smothering beneath the ice, but fish in deep 
New England lakes are not affected, 
Hard frosts that kill dormant insects may hurt songbirds in the spring. Deer herds are being dimtnis cd by belly-deep snow, sharp crust ice and farm dogs, but then the limiting of deer populations is a problem in some locali­ ties. How drought and changing wind patterns will affect waterfowl and shore bird breeding in the Midwest and in the 
Arctic rem ains to be seen.

N ice’s fashionable 
California d istric t o b ­ served two men carrying heavy suitcases through the streets shortly after midnight.

5 men 
On July 9, residents iii 
Plan du Var, a Village in the hills ‘JO miles north of 
Nice, te lephoned the local police station to report that a g ro u p of strangers seemed to have occupied a n e i g h b o r's villa.

Dominique Poggi, a Cor­ sican m e m b e r of the 
Marseille u n d e rw o rld , v\ as quoted as saying 
“ We’re expecting some girls for a sex p a r t y . ”

 police said, and the gen­ darmes went home. The next morning, tile house was empty.

Dallas South Oak Cliff won the 
( lass AAAA State C ham pion­ ship with a 79-65 victory over 
Clemens. 
Tho loss not only kepi Clemens from duplicating the feats of Churchill's 
^ridders and Jay cross-country champ 
Mark Anderson, but also deprived it of a perfect season after 
34 straight victories.

Gregory Gym h a r d ­ woods where five years ago the Jeffer­ son boys lost to a n ­ other Dallas team . 
Roosevelt, in another 
Class AAAA state title game. 
South Oak C liff’s 
Hines overpowering height proved too much for Clemens' quick­ ness in the overall analysis.

Steve Gamboa hit 12 of 13 fourth-quarter free throws, including four crucial freebies in the gam e’s last 25 seconds, to lead 
Burbank to a tense 611-57 win over Sam 
Houston Saturday night at Alamo Gym. 
The victory handed the Bulldogs the 31-AAAA title and its third straight district crown. Burbank earns the right to meet 32-AAAA champion Lee iii b id i* - trict play. Officials from Burbank and Lee will meet at IO a.in Sunday to decide the time and site of the post-season clash " 
Gamboa. Burbank’s high scorer with 2o points, hit both ends of a one-and-one with 24 seconds left to give Burbank a 58-55 lead Follow­ ing two free throws by Houston’s 
Charles Bean. G am boa put the game on ice with two more charity tosses on a one-and-one situation with six seconds remaining. 
Burbank, the loop s first-half winner, snapped a throe-game bis- mg streak in hiking its record to 
*

The Baylor Bears produced the only surprise in the first round of the Southwest 
Conference tournament Saturday with a thrilling 72-7o victory over the Texas 
Longhorns in Gregory Gym. 
In other opening round • clashes. Tech ripped 
Rice, 93-74. Texas AAM run by SMU, 89-79 and the 
Houston Cougars paddled TCU, 111-67, 
The second round of the tourney will be played 
Thursday, with the Aggies meeting Houston and the 
Red Raiders taking on Baylor. SWC champ Arkan- b o x scout:*, u s 

 sas will meet the winner of this four-team skirmish 
Saturday All of the remaining games in the tourney will be played at the Summit in Houston. 
Baylor’s Sherm an Patton earned the expert marksman status when he swished a jumper with two seconds left in the gam e to elim inate the 
Longhorns. 

 knew they were a good shooting club 
(led the Lone Star Conference in foul shooting) but they were outstanding.” 
HPU hit 13 of 19 first-half field goal tries and IO of ll at the free throw line, but still trailed. 37-36, at intermission when Larry Gooding hit a juniper as the clock expired. 
“ I thought we had our momentum going at halftime,” said Messbarger. 
“ We understood what we wanted to do. 
Then we got out front early and it really picked us up. 
St. M ary’s scored the first eight points the second half. Howard Payne got the next seven. St. M ary’s then answered the next six and the romp was on. 
Bobby Reid led a balanced Rattler attack with 12 points while Brian 
Schroeder had ll and Mark Pawzun and Leon Walls had IO each. Larry 
Gooding, had nine and Mike Cun­ ningham added eight. 
Just bout everybody was a star as St. 
Mary’s moved its season record to 23-5, with its 13th win in a row. 
Reid sat out the middle 18 minutes of the game with foul trouble, but Paw­ zun came off the bench, his had back and all. and helped pulverize the 
Jackets from outside.

By JEFF GROSSMAN 
O f THE I XRM SS N I W S STAf f 
ATLANTA — San Antonio was the tortoise and Atlanta was the hare. 

Only in this story, the hare had bet­ ter staying power 
San Antonio was never able to over­ come a slovenly start as the Spurs dropped their second straigh t gam e, 
119-111, to the Hawks 
Saturday night at the 
Omni. li f t' ‘‘ 
'•.% 
The Cleveland Ca- l l 
& callers lost to Chica- B L - M M K go, however, so the 
Spurs remain tied for third in the Central 
Division.The Spurs journey to New O r­ leans Sunday for a matinee with the Jazz. 
It was the Spurs’ third loss in as 
Grossman 

 m any gam es against A tlanta, and broke a rare San Antonio two-game road winning streak. 
The Spurs, throughly disorganized in the first half, trailed by as many as 17 points in the second quarter 
But San Antonio started to play with some direction in the second half, and an Allan Bristow layup with 6:43 left in the game brought the Spurs to within two, 97-95 
And then the Hawks ran off eight straight points, and the Spurs never got closer than six again 
"We weren’t ready to play," said 
Spurs’ Coach Dong Moo He has made it a well worn statement. But it was painfully true. 
"The offense stood around in the first half and just held the ball But then we started to play good defense and get gf>od shots in the second half. 
“ At the end, all the breaks went against us. But we did some pretty dumb things with the hall. And we 

 missed a lot of easy shots " 
"Everyone has got to be thinking about the game before h and," said 
Spurs’ forward Mark Olberdiug. " I ’m not sure we’re doing that.” 
The Hawks were obviously thinking about rebounding because they grabbed 2o more carom s than tin1 
Spurs, leonard “Truck” Robinson se­ cured 2o bounds, and scored a c a r ­ eer-high 34 (Hunts. 
John Drew had 28 points for the 
Hawks, 21 of them iii the first half be fore encountering serious foul trouble. 
He was one of six players to finish with five fouls. 
The Spurs* Coby Diet ric k and 
(ieorge Gervin along with A tlanta’s 
Arround Hill all departed early with six fouls. 
San Antonio center Billy I'uultz had four fouls by halftime, but was never any factor even before his foul diffi-

Continued from Page IS in the half when Mike drew his third foul. 
He not only added the key points, but put the collar on .James Hall, who wound up as HPU’s top scorer with 211 points. Hall had just four in the second half. 
“ Hall was hurting u s ," said 
Schroeder. “We didn’t realize he could go as well to his left. I just tried to keep him from getting to his spot.” 
Gooding had six rebounds and played “ probably the best game he’s played since he’s been here,” ’ said 
Messbarger. 
Roy Leggett and Leon Walls put de­ termining pressure on HPU’s guards and when Walls got in foul trouble, 
Darrell Brogdon came off the bench to hit six points. Bobby Jaklich had four free throws in the last minute. 
St. Mary’s went into a delay with IO minutes to play “ in order to bring them out of their zone.” 

“ We really w eren’t interested in stalling,” said Messbarger. “ We just wanted to bring them out of their zone. 

"They switched to a zone trap in the middle of play and we picked it up immediately,” he added. “ That was a key because we could have had prob­ lems when they made the change, but we responded and adjusted and actually made a couple of key buckets off it.”

CORPUS CHRISTI - T rinity won the number one singles and doubles, but won little else as the SMU Mustangs upset the 
T igers, 6-3, in the fin als of the Corpus 
Christi Invitational Tennis Tournament. 

It was the first dual match loss of the year for the 
Tigers, who journey to the West Coast next week to take on CSC, UCLA and Pepperdine. The defeat also ends TU’s two-year reign at this meet. 
Ironically, it was SMU which last won here before the Trinity grabbed the crown. 
Larry Gottfried lost his first dual match of the year, dropping a number two singles match to Chris 
Delaney, 7-6, tj-4. Tony G iam m alva edged Jai 
DiLouie in the featured singles match, 6-2. 6-7, 7-6.

DURHAM, NC. (AP) 
— Phil P’ord scored 23 points and Walter Davis added 
IB to lead ninth-ranked North Ca­ rolina to an 84-71 victory- over Duke in an Atlantic 
Coast Conference basket­ ball game Saturday. 
Duke never got closer than six during the last eight minutes. splits 

The San Antonio Col­ lege baseball team dropped its first game of a doubleheader to Hill 
.Junior College. 5-2, but came back to win night­ cap, 12-9, with a 1o-run sixth inning. 
Mike Lynn had two doubles and four RBI’s, 
Rito Garcia had one dou­ ble and 2 RBI’s and Bill 
Keiffer slapped a single for 2 RBI’s to lead SAC in their 1o-run burst. 
SAC’ is now 1-3 for the year and Hill is 13-5.

Uincv wins 

JACKSONVILLE. Fla 
(AAP) — Fourteenth- ranked Cincinnati, paced by Brian William?*’ 19 points, stalled iii the first half and rail in the second Saturday to win a 
78-61 college basketball game over Jacksonville. 

Once, when a kid fresh out of high school signed himself up for a four- year athletic scholarship he had the free ride all the way, even if he decided to quit playing sports. No, that wasn’t fair. The boy made a deal, offering his best athletic efforts in exchange for four years of free college work. 
Nevertheless, some gung-ho 17 and 
18-year-old kids discover that college sports really aren’t their bags. Some­ times such discoveries are made by- fleet halfbacks shortly after 28o-pound tackles poke their helmets about four inches through a rib cage. Wowie, who needs that four days a week in practice with double licks on Saturday? The kid quits football. But, under the oid rules, he could remain on scholarship. For four years. But not anymore. 

In recent weeks you’ve heard and read about all the flashy high school stars of yesteryear signing with the various c o lle g e s. F olk s, those are one-year a g reem en ts that th e y ’re signing if they sign with an NCAA col­ lege. Just one year at a time, no more than that. Some will be dropped after one year. 
.After each year a school’s coaches will review their football program and some scholarships will be renewed while others will be canceled. Some of the cancelations are going to lie diffi­ cult to accept and some, in all proba­ bility. will wind up in a courtroom. 
One-year wait 

And why a courtroom? Well, since the kid can only Im? offered a one-year pact there shouldn’t bo much debate if he can’t cut it and contribute to the team. But the raw rub comes when the athlete is reminded that In1 must lay out of sports for a whole year before becoming eligible as a transfer at an­ other school. 

In other words, he can’t make the team that recruited and landed him. 
But before he can take his athletic talents—whatever they might be—to another NCAA school, lie must sit out a whole year. Some attorney somewhere is almost a cinch to decide that at least a few of the young man’s rights have been violated. 

Of the nine coaches we met with last week in Kansas City only one. Boston 
College’s Joe Yukica. made the flat statement that he will “ never cancel a hoy’s scholarship because of his inabi­ lity to contribute to the team.” 

As Joe put it. “ if the boy gives his hest effort and it’s still not enough then 

BO SCHEMBECHLER 
. . . not me 

 we, the coaches, made the mistake in recruiting him. We should pay for our m istakes, not the youngsters.” Then he continued, “ the unfavorable publi­ city that I, as the head coach, and our school would get for taking a boy off scholarship, would be too much to come close to balancing whatever little strength we might add to our team 's quality.” 

Won't be first 
M ichigan’s Bo Schembechler, an ­ other of the* nine who met with us in 
KC. agreed that the rules will be hard to live with and he made it clear thai he won t be the first in the Big Ten to cancel a kid s scholarship. 

“ Yes. I’m sure that, sooner or later, we’l have to pick up some scholarships to make room for younger, brighter prospects but I II tell you this for a fact, I won’t be the first in the Big Ten to do it. Somebody else will have to be first.” Bo said. 
Bo didn’t name any names but I got the strong im pression that he was thinking about his old rival, Ohio 
State’s Woody Hayes, when he kept talking about “ somebody else” mak­ ing the move before him. 
Georgia's Vince Dooley and Johnny 
Majors, everybody’s coach of the year last season at Pittsburgh and now the new boss at Tennessee, made no bones about their intentions to cut and keep as they see fit 

“ We’ll have 95 on scholarship just as the ru les say but I w on't keep a youngster who can’t make the team .” 
Majors said. “ It will he tough, cutting some junior or senior who has tried hard but, for one reason or another, can't make the travel squad. It will he tough, hut I'll do it. I don't make the rules but I certainly intend to live by them," Johnny said. 

And in juries? Suppose a player breaks a leg and is no longer able to compete? 
Houston’s Bill Yeoman answered that one. “ What do you think we coaches are, m onsters? I think all schools would keep such a player on full sc holarship and hi' wouldn’t count against your 95 since he would be through as a player.” 
Well, the new deal still has some heart for the players but not nearly as much as in the past. 
T rinity shocked 

Dan Cook 

3o-95 rules have coaches sweating 

Once upon a tim e, not too many years ago, NCAA-governed colleges were a bit too fair to young athletes. But it’s not that way anymore. To the contrary, rulesm akers seem to have leaned a mite heavily in the other direction while over-correcting. 
Unless you’ve been paying close attention the 3o-95 rule probably doesn’t mean much to you. But to many college coaches—and many more college athletes—it’s a rather alarming matter. As a matter of fact, it was the main topic for the three days that 4o of us sportswriters spent visiting with NCz\A officials and nine out­ standing coaches in Kansas City. 
In a nutshell, the1 rules say that no more than 3o football scholarships can be offered each year to high school grads and junior college transfers. Al­ so, at no time can more than 95 football players be on scholarship for any 
NCAA college. 

Now you don’t have to be loaded with figure-juggling sm arts to understand that if 3ft new hands are signed each year it won't take but a few years be­ fore a coach will have to start with­ draw ing sch o la rsh ip s from som e sophs, juniors and sen iors to stay within the 95-scholarship limit.

Parting Shots 

B v 'B o f f { p r e s s m a n 
S p u r s fall 

S an Antonio EX P R E S S - N E W S — Sunday February 27 1977 
H 

 iv * mn i—hint 

Pistol P ete’s idea o f sports reporting off target 

NEW ORLEANS — In this city known primarily for its flesh, fun and music, Pete Maravich is unique. He is the city’s only superstar athlete. And they love him here because he can do as many things with a basketball as Al flirt can do with a trum­ pet. 

But as a purveyor of opinion, a newspaper columnist. Pistol Pete 
M aravich has a long way to go. 
Woodward and Bernstein can rest ea­ sily. 
The .Jazz’ eminent guard recently made his newspaper debut in the New 
Orleans Times-Pieayune. The subject? 
Negativism in sports reporting. Some excerpts: 
“ Fans want to see a game in a happy frame of mind. Expressing and writing negative attitudes will turn off good, solid intelligent sports fans — fans who are knowledgeable, and who love their professional sports, teams and indivi­ dual members. 
“ They attend the game. They sit and enjoy. They do not boo. They are proud of their teams and the city they repre­ sent. It seems everything written is negative. 

“ We must return to the basics where violence seldom showed its ugly face in sports, booing was good natured, and playing the game and watching indivi­ dual expression wast great Iv appre­ ciated. . . 
* 

“ We live in an unbalanced world, and sports should be one dimension that leaveSxthe fans happy and car­ efree. The media, I believe, must search for a new approach towards sports in New Orleans. Fans want to see a game in a happy frame of mind. 

Criticism destructive 

“ It is my belief that continued criti­ cism will eventually destroy the pro­ fessional atmosphere in New Orleans. I have openly witnessed this destruction in the city of Atlanta.” 

At best, Maravich’s presentation is naive. Does he really think the fan wants to wallow in ignorant bliss? The intelligent fan not only wants to know who won and lost, but he or she also wants to know why. What went into that victory or that defeat. 

Is the coach interfering with the front office? Why did they trade that player? Why can't they meet their payroll? These are questions that begged to be answered. 

But for Maravich, like some other news figures, it is easier to blame the messenger than the source. “ Why do you bring us bad news “ Maravich seems to be saying. “ If you can’t say something good, say nothing at all.” 

Who is violent? 

Maravich's suggestion to cleanse sport of violence is a worthwhile one. 
Who wants unneceesary violence in a world that already has too much of it? 
Think back, however, to earlier this season. One Pistol Pete jmaravich. perturbed by the pesty defense 
Portland’s Dave Twardzik was using on him. turned around and slugged the 
Blazer guard, knocking out two teeth. 
What should have bothered Mara­ vich most about that incident was the fact he lost control and hurt someone. 
Instead, he was probably peeved by the reporting of that event. Someone in 
New Orleans probably even criticized him for it. Heavens. 
Yes, we do live in an unbalanced world. And any adult,who looses sleep over the performance of their favorite team is not acting rationally. Sports should be for enjoyment. It never was, and should never be, a life-and-death proposition. 
The irony of Maravich's column was heightened this week when he said he might leave the Jazz after this season so he can be a part of a championship team. And he realizes the Jazz is a long way from being even a contender. 
How negative can you be, Pete? Here you are playing for a team, and right in the middle of the season you say you may leave because you hate losing. 
Maybe the fans feel the same way. 
Only the residents of New Orleans can't play out their option. 

Odds and ends 

The Milwaukee Bucks, one of the sorrier entities in this year’s NBA. have a pretty bright future. They have three strong forwards in Dave Meyers, 
Junior Bridgeman and Bobby Dan­ dridge. And the Bucks have three first-round draft picks in the upcoming college draft. They also have a pro­ mising playmaker in Quinn Buckner and an outstanding shooter in Brian 
Winters. 
And to the Spurs, who have lost twice to the Bucks at home this season, it is anything but a sorry team already. . . 
The NBA made a wise decision when it kept the schedule format the same for next season. It may dilute certain rivalries, as the Northeast clubs con­ tended, but it assures that the Ervings and Jabbars will get equal exposure. 
And, too, how often would you pay to see the New York Nets? 

Continued from Page IS culty. He was shut out in the scoring department and had but two rebounds in 25 minutes of inglorious futility. 
Gervin led the Spurs with 26 points, while Dietriek had 21. He missed his first field goal attempt, hit nine straight and then missed eight straight. 
Olberding had 17 points and ll re­ bounds despite hurting his back early in the second half, while James Silas saw his most extensive action since returning a second time from knee surgery. 
He had 19 points in 25 minutes. 
“ It felt good,” said Silas. “ I think I am ready to play more than I have been.” 
Atlanta Coach Hubie Brown em­ ployed much the same illegal zone de­ fense he used at Kentucky the last two seasons. At first, Moe complained about it. Then he said no more about it. 
“ I really wanted them to stay in it,” said Moe. “ Once we started to move the ball, it was fairly easy to get a good 

 shot. But they weren’t going in. I don’t know how many easy shots Mike 
(Gale) missed.” 
After trailing, 61-5o, at the half. San 
Antonio stayed within eight most of the second half. But that 8-o streak which included four points by Robinson and two each by Claude Terry and Ken 
Charles proved to lie fatal 
The Spurs, it appears, are the 
Hawks’ favorite charitable organiza­ tion.

NEW YORK (A P) - Reserves Don­ nie Shelton and Butch Beard led a 
39-point second period that helped the 
New York Knicks beat the Indiana 
Pacers 129-115 in a National Basketball 
Association game Saturday night. 

Shelton sank two free throws with 
5:17 to play in the second quarter to snap a 42-42 tie and start a 2o-9 burst that staked the Knicks to a 62-51 half­ time lead Shelton scored Kl points in the quarter while Beard added eight and keyed the New York attack with his penetration to the basket

LA N D O VER, 
Md. 
(AP) — Mitch Kupchak came off the bench to score 13 of his 15 points in the fourth quarter Satur­ day night, sparking the 
Washington Bullets to 
1o5-1o2 National Basket­ ball Association victory over the 
Milwaukee 
Bucks. 

Kupchak, a 6-foot-1o rookie from North Ca­ rolina, sank five of eight shots and grabbed six rebounds in the fourth period. 

El vin Hayes tossed in 
25 points and Phil Chen­ ier added 22 as the Bul­ lets strengthened their hold on first place in the 
Central Division with their 22nd victory in their last 29 games. 

Milwaukee led throughout the first half and was on top 64-59 midway through the third period when the 
Bullets made their move. 

The Bucks last lead was 82-81 early in the fourth quarter, before 
Kupchak took charge. 

Brian Winters led Mil­ waukee with 28 points. 
Swen Natcr contributed 
14 points, 16 rebounds and seven assists.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sunday february 27 1 9 7 7 
Curt Elliott selected Bowler o f the Year 

Tho Southeast Classic Bowling 
Association honored Curt Elliott has its Bowler of the Year for 
1976. 
E lliott was p resen ted the award last weekend at North­ west Bowl in Houston. 

“ I was very pleased,” said the 
23-year old right hander. ‘‘I haven’t received anything that nice before. It really gives the bowlers something to bowl for in each SEC’BA monthly tour­ nament.” 
Elliott out-pointed runnerup Kirk 
Harper and third place Hick Loeb both of Houston, for the honor. The 
Bowler of the Year is based on tour­ nament points accumulated through­ out the season.

HFBC A meets this year.” 
The (list annual 
T exas Tenpin 
Bowling Tournament gets under way 
Saturday at the Highland Park Social 
Club. The event features 435 teams from San Antonio, Houston, Seguin, La 
Grange. Rosenberg-Richmond, Austin, 
Brenham, New Braunfels. Sealy, 
Texas City, Schulenburg and Galves­ ton. The event concludes .lune 2B. 
Mary 
Falconer captured the monthly Ladies Amateur Tournament 
Association event at Southside. Sell 
Kecroft finished second and 
Linda 
Fox was third. Falconer’s victory was worth $115. 
Entry deadline for the 41st annual 
San Antonio Bowling A ssociation tournament is midnight March 13. 
Entry fee is $7 per event with an addi­ tional $2 all events fee. The meet starts 
April 23 with the team event at Wonder 
Bowl, and the singles and doubles at 
Sports Palace. Entries should be mailed to ll.II. "R ed” Holland at 
2811-A E. Southcross, San Antonio, 
78223. The meet ends May 8.

Hermann Sons ... Doug Moe Jr., the son of the San Antonio Spurs’ coach, had a 256 game and a 672 series at Oak 
Hills ... Gall Cantu had a 269 at Oak 
Hills ...

■tv H a r r y l* a g r 

Not tan howled 1o5 pins over his 65 average with 119-3oo series at San Pe­ dro ... 
Evelyn Herrera bowled 117 pins over her average wit!) a 269 game. 
Robert Barber had a 167 triplicate. 
Thelma Tijerina had a 257, and Bob 
Harris 258 at Southside. 

Moving right along.. 

Jimmie Rivera had a 278 game and a 73o series, Rudy Baerwald had a 279 and a 7o1, Jerry Colson (A JBC ) had a 
234 game for 111 pins over his average, and Jan Williamson rolled her first 
6oo (OOI) all at Wonder Bowl ... Mary 
Moore picked up the big 7-1o split at 
All Star ... Jennifer Carter rolled an 

8o triplicate, Michael Burt rolled a 117 pins over his average with a 254-567, and eight-year old 
Charlie Green rolled 133 pins over his average with a 
2o3 game at Goliad ... Andv Eli/,undo, a kindergarten student, had a 3 — yes three — triplicate at Oak Hills ... The 
12th annual Texas “ HOO” Club Tourna­ ment will be rolled at Eastridgc Lanes in Amarillo. March 19-June 12; entry fee is $5 per person and they should he mailed to Pauline Thompson, 14o1 N. 
Marrs, Amarillo, 791o7; entry blanks can he obtained by calling 828-5746 lo­ cally. 
“ The American Bowling Congress wants to provide nuetral conditions for everybody,” said Roger Tessman to a 

 gathering of 56 people at Wonder Bowl this week. 
Tessman, the director of A BC ’s 
Rules Department, was in town to ex­ plain ABC’s new rules, listen to con­ structed criticisms, answer questions, and to note some local suggestions from proprietors, lane mechanics, and the like. 
“ We don’t want the conditions where: (A) You have a certain lane condition for the competitive and high average bowlers, and (B ) another for the social bowler.” Tessman ex­ plained. "Proficiency is what ABC wants under the same conditions. 
“ We love to give awards — as long as they are made on conditions that arc acceptable. It’s not a ease of how many awards are given. 
“ No one said the rules were Utopian or final, hut they’re what we’re going by now.” said 
Tessman.” 
ABC wouldn’t have any respect if it took a mild attitude towards its rules. The last thing is not to have hassles — hassles hurt the industry. We want to work collectively for the progress of the industry.” 
Deadline for entry into the Martha 
Washington tournament is May I 
Entries can he obtained at the Oak 
Hills Bow ling Center,

By JOHN HINES 
Of THt express n e w s stAff 
Will “expansion" bring about a new order in San Antonio high school baseball? 
That answer and a lot of others will be forthcoming “ in the weeks ahead as San Antonio starts the 1977 high school baseball season Tuesday. 
Despite losing some of their players to the new West Campus High School, 
South San Antonio's Bobcats are a harrow favorite to pull down a fourth consecutive city championship. 
The ‘Cats received the votes of nine coaches across the city, just one more than the Marshall team they defeated in the second round of the playoffs last year. Churchill was third with four votes, while nobody else had more than one. 
The Class AA AA bidistrict matchups are expected to be South San vs. Mar­ shall or Eagle Pass and Jefferson vs. 
Churchill. 
In the other districts, F red erick s­ burg and New Braunfels are favored to

LAUDERDALE, Fla. 
(A P ) — Jack Niek- laus shot a three- under-par 69 Satur­ day but saw his lead in the $25o,ooo Jackie 
Gleason Inverrary 
Golf Classic drop to one stroke over steaking Gil Morgan. 

Morgan, a licensed op­ tometrist in Florida and 
Oklahoma who has never practiced his profession, shot a seven-under-par Ko to co lh under liar for the tournament. 
Xicklaus, who had a four-shot advantage over defending 
Masters champion Ray Floyd, 
Je rry McGee and Don 
Pooley entering the round, stood at ll under 
2o5 after 54 holes on the 
7,127-yard Inverrary Golf and Country Club course. 
Two shots behind him was first-round leader 
Gary Player, who had a six-under 66. The next nearest challenger for the $5o,ooo top prize was 
F'u/zy Zoeller at seven- under 2o9 after a round on 68. 
Tom Weiskopf and Bob 
Murphy were at 211 
Xicklaus started out his round with a bogey five and playing partner 
Floyd scored a birdie on the first hole to move within two shots of the lead. But Xicklaus had no more bogeys and F'loyd had three of them to come in at 73 and drop to

7-pound black bass 

Wilma Buster of San Anton­ io caught this trophy bass at 
Calaveras Lake. She caught the 7-pound 4-ounce black on a plastic worm. 

6-pound black bass 

Don Ely of San Antonio caught this 6-pound 4-ounce black bass at Lake Corpus 
Christi during a tournament of the Helotes Bass Club, 
The bass hit a floating-diving lure called the Beaujack.

Pedernales drownings 

 wtciAi to the express news 

AUSTIN — Eight drownings on the 
Pedernales River in Pedernales Falls 
State Park have prom pted Texas 
Parks and Wildlife Commissioners to ask Blanco County officials to close portions of the river to swimming. 
According to park operations official 
Johnny Buck, if approved by Blanco 
County Commissioners, the river will be closed to sw im m ing from the northwest corner of the park for three miles downriver. 
“ Investigation of drow nings r e ­ vealed the strong river currents and undertow were partial causes in the deaths.” said Buck, “ along with each individual's physical condition, age and swimming experience.” 
Buck said an alternate swimming area will be designated in a safer portion of the river downstream. 
“ Parks and Wildlife Commissioners also approved construction of addi­ tional parking at the designated area with river access trail and restroom facilities,” said Buck. 
However, the entire six miles of the 
Pedernales River within the park will remain open for bank fishing, boating, kayaking, canoeing and rafting. 
Under the Texas Water Safety Act, respective county officials have auth­ ority to close waters deemed hazar­ dous to swimming. 
Good news for 
T exom a anglers 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 

AUSTIN — Texas fishermen on Lake 
Texoma soon will be able to triple their leeal hue limit of strinedJiass or their hybrids, following recent action by the 
Texas Parks and Wildlife Commission. 
Prior to commission action, the bag limit on Texoma stripers on the Texas side was one per day. Approval of the staff recommendation by the commis­ sion will bring the Texas bag and possession limits in line with Oklaho­ m a’s three daily and six in possession. 
The new bag limit will go into effect in Cooke County 2o days after filing of the change in the Texas Register. In 
Grayson County the law will take effect upon commissioner’s court ratification of the commission’s vote 

 but a goose on ground 

By DAN K L E P P E R 
OUTDOOR EDITOR 
In flight, a hawk is a magnificent aerialist. It is in complete control of its environment as it drifts along unseen rivers of air. 
But a hawk on the ground is as awkward as a square cue ball. 
The bird walks like a goose, wobbling from side to side, occasionally attempting a half-hearted hop. 
And a lawn full of wobbling, hopping hawks is a fascinating sight, especially when the hawks are joined by flocks of wild pigeons, doves, flickers* lapwings and the crested tinamou. 
I witnessed the avian spectacle on a ranch 8o kilometers inland from the 
Argentine seaport of Bahia Blanca. 
The ranch is owned by E rnesto 
Ohlsson of Buenos Aires. It isn ’t a large ranch by Argentine standards. It encom passes ap pro xim ately 7.5oo acres. 
A little more than half of the ranch is planted in wheat, oats, barley, corn, sorgum, rye. clover and alfalfa. The remaining acreage serves as pasture for around 2.ooo head of registered black Angus cattle. 
Bulls 
Ohlsson’s interest is neither birds nor the trout in the strea m which meanders through thick woods behind the main house. 
His interest is in bulls. Angus bulls for breeding. Each October the ranch. 
Cabana La Sopresa, holds an Angus sale. Around 3oo head of black cattle, most of them bulls, are put in the ring, and buyers from many parts of Ar­ gentina attend. 
Near the sale ring is a building where potential buyers are wined and dined, literally. An Argentine wine called Aberdeen Angus is served to up to 1.8oo persons at a sit-down dinner at each sale. 
Horses 
Ernesto and his wife, Jutta. do not live on the ranch. They reside in 
Buenos Aires, where Ohlsson is an importer of newsprint. They also own a small hotel. Ilosteria del Viejo Molino, and a home in the Andean resort town of Bariloche. 
Jutta’s interest is not birds, either. 
She is interested in raising and racing thoroughbred horses, and her stud farm is half an hour's drive from the breeding bull ranch. 
The Ohlsson’s were married in 1971. 
Jutta emigrated from Germany a few years ago and after exploring the pos­ sibility of buying land for her stud farm in Kentucky or Tennessee, finally settled in Argentina. 
Ernesto is a native Argentine. His grandfather moved from Sweden to 
Argentina in 1885. An expert on butter and cheese, he started a dairy farm, and by 1915 had five of the farms. He was the first Argentine to export butter to Europe. 
He sold his farms to a large dairy product company and served on the board of directors of the firm. But you couldn’t keep grandfather off the farm. 
By 1919, he was a landowner again, this time of 7oo acres with a trout stream running through it. The farm. 

J 
, . , 
A u 
ExpreNN-XewN raj MS IJJ jAi m o o r s 

Sunday February 27 1977 

JUAN ECHEVARRIA, forem an of the cattle operation on a ranch in A rgentina, w ears trad itio n al dress of A rgentine gaucho, including baggy trousers — called bombachas — stuffed into boots 

ARGENTINE gauchos carry knives In clip-on m etal sheaths a t small of back. This one has silver handle and sheath. 

Ernesto explains, was only a front for the old man’s first love, trout fishing. 
The farm passed to Ernesto’s par­ ents. More land was bought, and in 

 tina offers some of the finest waterfowl shooting in the world. Two kinds of geese and several species of ducks nest in Tierra del Fuego near the antarctic

1948 the Ohlssons decided they needed and m igrate northward to the lakes some cows. The choice of breed was based solely on color, Ernesto says, because his father remarked, “ Well, I sort of like the black ones." 
After they bought the cows, they had to have a bull. They bought a regis- 
— - — — — 
-...vt. tered one, and the Angus bull breeding cons,dercd a pest, is abundant in some farm was burn 
"areas, rhis nnnmir»r;ifnrv ic al­ 

 and m arshes of central and western 
Argentina. 
The geese concentrate in grain fields and damage some crops. There is no bag limit on the birds. 
The Andean eared dove, which is 

Argentines are big beef eaters. They consume 8o per cent of the beef pro­ duced in tile country, and it is grass fed and good. According to Ohlsson, there isn t a feed lot in the country. 
Grain is grown to feed people, not cat­ tle. 
But the grain also feeds the birds. 
Because of the political situation in wi, ww„.„ 
Argentina today, little hunting is done. American birds and cannot properly 
Firearms must be registered, and it is identify all of the birds which gather difficult to obtain permits for guns. on the large, mowed lawn at the Olhs* 
This is unfortunate, because Argen- son Estancia each da 

 areas. This nonmigratory dove is al­ most indistinguishable from the North 
American mourning dove, and is com­ mon in the grain fields west of Bahia 
Blanca. This same bird ranges through the Andes into western Colombia. Out­ fitters in Cali. Colombia, do a brisk business guiding bird shooters from 
North America. do not have a good book on South 

The large, pheasant-like tinamous, a game bird, are the most wary. They don’t venture far from the tall grass of the high-fenced pasture where Ernesto keeps a herd of fallow deer. When ap­ proached, the tinamou will hide in the grass and explode beneath your feet like a five-pound quail. 
The lapwings with their spiky head plumes and spurred wings, act like killdeer. They run at your approach, finally taking to air with raucous cries. 
Some of the birds frequenting the lawn. such as the wild pigeons, ob­ viously seek seeds, others seem to be after insects. But the hawks apparent­ ly attempt to make meals of a very small mouse or shrew which lives un­ derground. 
The lawn is littered by tiny mounds of black earth resembling miniature fire ant nests. Beside each mound is a hole similar to that a tarantula makes. 
Small rodents, Ernesto said, inhabit the holes. 
I was told that the woods along the 

 trout stream were inhabited by a wild pigeon even larger than those which fed on the lawn and that the pigeons nest in holes in the bank along the creek. 
I observed the pigeons one afternoon. 
They the largest wild pigeons I have ever seen, appearing to be half again as large as the blue rock. 
I did not see one go into a hole in the bank, but my companion, Glenn Titus, outdoor writer from Oklahoma City, maintains that as he fished the stream next morning he saw one of the big pigeons dive into the w ater like a kingfisher, come up swimming like a duck and then d isap p ear beneath overhanging limbs along the bank. 

In addition to being a writer, Glenn has a degree in wildlife biology and is a trained observer of wildlife. But I’ve been writing outdoors longer than he has, and I know from experience that in this business your lies can play tricks on you.

DREW PEARSON 

Cowboys in cage gam e here 

The Dallas Cowboys will challenge the KSAQ radio personalities in the second annual charity basketball game March 18 at Alamo Stadium Gym. 
All proceeds from the game will go to the Boys’ Clubs of San Antonio. 

Drew Pearson, Ed .Jones, Kobert Newhouse and Billy Joe DuPree are among the Cowboy participants. 

Tickets are on sale at all Sears stores. Ducats are $2.5o apiece. 

Pony to Lion v 
DETROIT (AP) — Detroit Lions 
Coach Tommy Hudspeth said Saturday he has added Burnie Miller to his staff as defensive backs coach for the Na­ tional Football League club's 1977 season. 
Last season, Miller was defensive backfield coach at Southern Methodist 
University.

Clemens paces All-City girls’ cage team

CRH offer you hew CULTURES, fi FASCINATING LIFESTYLE, AHD 
UNLIMITED CAREER OPPORTUNITY. 

The Lockheed Aircraft Service Peace Log Program will bring you in contact with fascinating people, new cultures, and a totally different lifestyle. Benefits include overseas bonus, TAX PROTECTION, free housing, education allowance, plus yearly flights to the U.S.A. 

MAINTENANCE SPECIALISTS 
A variety of openings here, involving the planning and scheduling of maintenance on aircraft, A G E, vehicle and electronic equipment. Duties will include inspection, repair, servicing and related activities. A familiarity with AEM 66 1 is required. 

MATERIEL SPECIALISTS 
In this position you will perform materiel control duties in support of engine, vehicle, aircraft and communication maintenance activities. Working completely with data, you will be involved with inventory management, property disposal, storage analysis, and production & resources management. 
Requires a knowledge of AFM 67 1. 

LOGISTICS SYSTEMS PLANNING SPECIALIST 
An opportunity for you to develop logistics plans in support of supply operations, traffic transportation, packaging, POL 
(fuels) management, materiel handling, and maintenance modification planning. Requires a detailed knowledge of 
AFM 67-1. 

SUPPLY COORDINATOR 
In this position, you will act as a problem solver in the operation of shipment and storage sections, container assembly and reclamation sections, and distribution & materiel facilities branches. A knowledge of AFM 67-1 is a must. 

TECHNICAL ANALYSTS lf successful, you will provide technical services and advice on the maintenance of aircraft and AG E equipment. Desired experience includes corrosion control, propeller overhaul, aircraft engine overhaul and aircraft airconditioning systems. 
Additional personnel are needed with experience in aircraft equipment commodity management and aircraft maintenance production control. A familiarity with AFM 66-1 is required. 

LOGISTICS SYSTEMS SPECIALIST lf successful, you will develop materiel supply procedures in support of aircraft, engine, missile, fuel and radar/ communications systems. Materiel supply procedures will cover distribution, requirements, identification, cataloging and technical publications. To qualify, you must have related experience, plus a knowledge of AFM 67-1. 

TRANSPORTATION SPECIALIST 
Your responsibility will be to provide technical expertise in the areas of air and surface transportation traffic management, passenger and household goods transportation, shipment planning, and freight rate analysis. Related experience will give you the edge. 

CONTRACTS 
Interesting opportunities where you will negotiate with customers on prices, delivery dates and work statements, and will monitor contract performance to insure compliance with event milestones and work statements. Your background should include work in all aspects of the contractual cycle, including experience in evaluating proposals. 

PROGRAMMERS 
To qualify for an opening in programming, you should have experience in preparing programs in support of logistics operations, plus some exposure to the preparation of fiscal and personnel management programs. A knowledge of 
COBOL is a must, and Honeywell Series 6ooo experience is desirable. 

SYSTEMS ANALYSTS 
You'll be called upon to design advanced data automation systems, and to develop, test and evaluate systems for maintenance analysis, materiel management, manpower forecasting and other areas. Desirable qualifications include 
Honeywell 6ooo system experience, plus a background in aerospace, logistics, electronics or transportation. 

Th* Lo ckh art A ircraft S*rvic* P*«c« Log Program 

 ii an I qual O pportunity im p io yar M /F . 

AIRCRAFT ELECTRONIC MAINTENANCE 
Requires experience in avionics, aircraft gun and weapons control systems, electronic flight controls, autopilots, compass systems, airborne communications and electronic countermeasures. 

AERONAUTICAL ENGINEER 
An interesting opportunity where you will prepare, review and revise technical instructions and design specifications as they apply to aircraft and A G E equipment. Your experience should include aircraft maintenance analysis, engine propulsion analysis, and analysis of aircraft associated ground equipment. 

QUALITY CONTROL ANALYST 
In this position you'll be responsible for non-destructive inspection, QC lab and data analysis, and materiel equipment inspection. To qualify, you should have a knowledge of magnetic particle testers, weighing devices, x ray equipment, and test equipment for fluorescent and visible penetrants and eddy currents. A familiarity with AFM 66-1, the U SAF 
Technical Order System, and OC programs relating to POL storage and aerospace maintenance or supply storage facilities is also required. 

PRODUCTION CONTROL 
In this position you'll evaluate work methods, allocate workloads, establish schedules and evaluate the effectiveness of personnel. Requires production control experience in vehicle, electronic or aircraft maintenance. 

MATERIEL ANALYST 
In this "hands on" position, you'll be involved in materiel shipping, receiving, warehousing and crating, as well as various activities related to inventory management, in addition to a background in a similar area, you should also be familiar with 
AFM 67-1. 

GENERAL ELECTRONICS 
Requires experience on fixed and mobile electronic systems used for defensive, tactical, strategic and administrative purposes. 

QUALITY CONTROL ENGINEERS 
We're looking for personnel with a knowledge of portable & fixed magnetic particle testers, mechanical & electronic weighing devices, x ray equipment, or test equipment for fluorescent and visible penetrants and eddy currents. You should be familiar with AFM 66-1, the U SAF Technical Order 
System, and must be experienced with OC programs relating to POL storage, and aerospace maintenance or supply storage facilities. 

DATA AUTOMATION EQUIPMENT ANALYSTS 
One position is available for an experienced PCAM 
Maintenance Technician who can work on key punches, verifiers, sorters, reproducers and collators. Two positions are open for experienced G1o5 keypunchers. 

For information concerning any of tho p o sitio n s listed, please call the LA S Peace Log Employment Office at 
(714) 988-2117, or send your resume to: 
Lockheed Aircraft Service 
Peace Log Program c/o Lockheed Aircraft Service Company 
Department 9 143, P.O. Box 33 
Ontario, California 91761

By HARRY PAGE 
OF THE EXPRESS NEW S STAFF 

MARSHA WEICHOLD 
. . . Judson 

Clemens, led by guard Sylvia Godfrey, dominates the 1976-77 
Express-News All-City Girls’ basketball team. 

Four Buffettes are on the nine-player first team. which was selected by the 
Express-News Sports Department from the nominations of 29 schoolgirl coaches. 
Godfrey is the second athlete in city history to be named to an all-city team for three consecutive years in the same sport. Robert Rodriguez of South San 
Antonio was named to the all-city baseball team from 1974 to 1976. 
In addition to Godfrey, the Buffettes have forwards Susan Rouse and Rose 
Penkunis and guard Leslie Branham on the squad. 
Cheryl Ashley of Houston and Marsha Weichold of Judson complete the forward selections. 
- 
. . . . . . . f 
Yvette Douglas of Jay, Betsy Echols of Holmes and Tern Mollett of Houston loin Godfrey and Branham at the guard spots. 
Weichold. Penkunis, Douglas, Echols and Branham are juniors, while Monett is a sophomore. The rest are seniors. 
Douglas, Godfrey and Echols received four votes each from the nine-member selection staff, while Branham and Mollett got three votes each. 
The forwards all received four votes. 
Weichold was the city scoring champion, averaging 29.9 points per game. 
Penkunis scored 21.3 points per game and averaged seven rebounds and five steals a game. Rouse averaged 13.4 points, five rebounds and five steals per game. Ashley averaged 25.3 points per outing. 
The second team is made up of fowards Angela Carrington and Eleanor Bilotta of Jay. Carol Muerer of Ursuline, Darcy Paxton of Clemens and Denise Hall of lx*e; the guards are Kathy Guzman of Burbank. Anita Jerrell of Houston, Beverly 
Brock of Jay and Saundra Ingamells of Marshall. 
All players on the second team missed the elite squad by either one or two votes.

SALINAS blocks Bean shot 

PHOTO BY STEVE CAMPBELL 
Burbank wins title 

Continued from Page IS their season at 28-8. 
Bulldog star Gilbert Salinas, who didn’t play in those three the three losses because of a hand injury, scored 13 points and had live blocked shots before fouling out with nine seconds left in the game. 
Abraham Davis scored 23 points. Bean had 14, and 
Handy Reed IO for Sam Houston. 
Burbank hit 2H of 31 free throws while Houston mustered only nine of 17 before o,4oo (4,oo7 paid) fans. The game featured nine ties and eight lead changes. 
* “ I just had to make ‘em.” said Gamboa after the 

 game. 
Mr. Clutch 
“ Mr. Clutch,” Salinas said of Gamboa. “ He has got ice in his veins. It was a helluva game. No, I didn’t think about my injured hand, I just wanted to play.” 
Houston led at halftime 32-3o. Burbank’s biggest leads were five points ■— throe times — and the last one was at 56-51 with 1:34 left in the game. Houston’s biggest advantage was at 3o-32 and 38*32 early in the third period. 
“ It was our game, but we made too many mis­ takes,” Davis said after the game. “ When we got that lead in the third quarter. I think we relaxed too 
'much. We should have won, it’s our fault we didn’t. 
*\Ve missed too many shots also.” 
Opportunity 
J Houston could have taken the lead with 42 seconds remaining in the game but Bean missed a layup 
.trailing 36-55. After Gamboa missed his only free 
•throw in the period, guard Darrell Lynch overthrew 
‘ Fred Miehaux down court with the ero ee*> trailing by the same score. Next time, Gamboa did not give 
Sam Houston a break.

Bulldogs fell, 64-54 

SPfCIAl TO THI (KWK SS NIWS 
COMMERC E — Larry McGhee and Nato Granger combined for 52 points Saturday night to lead East 
Texas State to a 64-54 victory Over Texas Lutheran iii the first round of the NAJA District 4 playoff's. 

The victory puts East Texas in the finals against 
St. Mary’s, which trounced Howard Payne. 76-59, 
The game w ill be played Tuesday night in Com­ merce beginning at 7.3o p.m. 
The winner of that game w ill advance to the na­ tional tournament in Kansas City. 
McGhee scored 27 points and Granger 25 for the 
Lions, now 21-7. 
TLO, playing in postseason competition for the first tune since 1965. finished with a 21-1o record. 
“ We didn’t contain Granger and McGhee the way we wanted to, said Jim Shuler, the TIX couch. “ It was not so much the fault of our defense as it was their outstanding play.” 
But for TIX. the turning point cann* late in the second half when the Bulldogs went five minutes without a point.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS- 

 m 

 state 

 cage 

 finals 

Continued from Page IS 

Clemens shots. 
“ They had too much height, they were too tall for us and we could not stop their rebounding.” said “ 
Clemens’ Coach James Leonard. 
Oak Cliff mentor Gary Blair echoed, 
“ They didn’t have the size on the guards’ end to stop us.” 
Leonard had hoped to contain the 
Oak Cliff forwards. 
“ They play a double low post and our plan beforehand was to front them with one guard, sag with another and put the third guard on their outside for­ ward, take her tough aud intercept the ball if they tried to lob it. 
“ But they were just too big and it didn't work.” 
The difference, he pointed out,.came in the second quarter when South Oak 
Cliff outscored Clemens, 26-7, to take an insurmountable 48-23 load into the dressing rooms. 
Clemens hail its best quarter in the third round round, outscoring the 
Bears, 24-13, and closing tin1 gap to 
61-47 going into the fourth period. 
No changes 

Leonard said, “ We didn’t change anything, we just came out playing. 
“ We just came out hustling, which I 

 thought we did the whole game. Our players never quit. They played an excellent game. 
“ We just ran into a bigger, and I guess a better, club.” 

Tho Buffettes twice came within 12 points in the third quarter before dig­ ging as deeply as they could into Oak 
C liff’s lead when reserve Chris Cal­ deras, hit a bucket to make it 75-65 a minute from the end. 

Susan Rouse, who set a Class A AAA tournament single-game record of 16 free throws Friday, led Clemens with 
27 points, including IO in the third 

 period. 

Excellent 

Rose Penkunis, called by Blair, “ An excellent ballplayer,” tallied 26 points following her 32-point performance 
Friday. 
The 5-11 junior shot 23 of 45 from the floor in two games here. 
Penkunis hit three straight baskets in the early going for a 1o-9 Clemens lead, the only time the Buffettes were on top all day. 

Sandra Lee led the Bears with 3o points and Lorretta Lister added 25. 

The winners hit 3o of 6o afield and 19 of 32 at the line. 
Clemens went 24 for 61 from the floor and 17 of 29 at the line. although their two for seven performance there hurt them in the first quarter when it was still close. 
Prospects look good for Clemens next season, as only Rouse and guard 
Sylvia 
Godfrey graduate of the 
12-girl state tournament roster. 

Spearman won the first of four Sa­ turday title games with a 61-58 victory over Waco Robinson in Class AA. 

Canyon, appearing at state for the ninth consecutive year, reversed losses in the two previous AAA finals by stopping Waco Midway, 58-54 
Cooper won the Class A honors by trouncing Deweyville, - . 

Dallas South Oak Cliff w inds up 38-2, losing only to defending state champion Duncanville and new Class 
B Champion Nazareth. The la tte r handed Canyon its only loss.

Lam tough 

AUSTIN (AP) 
— Olym pic Gold 
Medalist Johnny (Lam) Jones crossed the finish line first four times Saturday to lead the Texas Longhorns past North 
Texas and TCU in track and field competition here. 
Texas notched the victory with a total of 1o2'2 points. North Texas finished a distant second with 47,2 and 
TCU had 16, 
Jones won the KH) yard dash in 9 21, the 22o in 21.6 and anchored the win­ ning 44o and mile relay teams. 
In addition to Jones’ crowd-pleasing performance, Longhorn high jumper 
Terry Davenport sailed over the bar at 
8 foot-IO. his personal best, to win the event 
Teammate Bob Keith took second, clearing the same height but w itll more misses. 
Owls tough 

HOUSTON (AP) - The Rice Owls, sparked b> Curtis Isaiah, defeated 
Texas AAM. 89-87, i i i a dual track meet 
Saturday. 
Isaiah won the long jump with a 22-11 effort to nip tin' Aggies’ Shifton BakAr, 
11-1o, for high point honors.

Cross-country skiing 

People who love m ountains usually also love snowy winters. 
People who love both usually also love cross-country skiing. 
And people who love all three love 
Montana. It’s a natural love affair. 
The Bi}? Sky State has mountains a- plenty — the whole, heady, vast stretch of the northern Rocky Mountains, as a mat­ ter ol fact. ranging from south to north across the western side of the state. 
And winters drop enough splendid snow to satisfy the most hopeless cross-country addict. The result is more superb cross­ country than you can shake a ski pole at. 
All of Montana’s line downhill resorts also offer fine cross-country. Headliner 
Biti Sky of Montana, near Bozeman in southwestern Montana, has some 35 miles of groomed cross-country trails — good enough to have made Big Sky the choice for North American cross-country cham­ pionship skiing 
And just a little further south at the 
Montana larder town (*f West Yellowstone an operation called Yellowstone Nordic 

Downhill run 

 p e o p l e ii h o e i r e »«>,i a m i m o u n t a i n s a l s a l i k e c r o s s - 
It t a a t r y s k i i n g 
— a n t i / n 'o p l c a i n t lik e a l l th re e seem to ( in t l 
M tn ilttn ti lilt• hast o f till / lossilile 
H in t e r n o rlils . 

 has created an assortment of choices that include package tours, back country trips, lessons and wavand-ski clinics — all reasonably priced in varying combin­ ations of attractions. 
People who like to pile superlatives on top of superlatives also ski into Yellow­ stone National Park — or ride a snow- coach in heated comfort —■ to ski-tour the famed geyser basin of Old Faithful, where sights of wintering w ildlife compete for attention with the magic of ice and steam and the genial com fort of accommoda­ tions in Yellowstone's Snow Lodge. 
Montana’s fine B ridger Bowl, which some people feel has skiing among the world’s best, also has fine cross-country 
— as does small but growing Discovery 
Basin, inst out of Anaconda, which is just out of Butte. 
In Helena. Montana’s irrepressible ca­ pital city, a young entrepreneur named 
Danny W illiam s at Nordic Experience offers rustic tours in the Elkhorn moun­ tains that end with a sauna and a plunge into an icy stream — and overnight ac­ commodations i i i a log cabin. 
Prices are so reasonable they’re stag­ gering, and he rents equipm ent and teaches cross-country as well. 
One of M ontana’s cross-country de­ lights is the Izaak Walton Inn at Essex, some 3o miles from West Glacier on the southern border of Glacier National Park 
If the views and the delightful atmos­ phere are not enough, the quality of the skiing experience w ill be — and the low prices are the frosting on the cake. The lodge is a converted railroad hotel with more charm per square inch than it has 

 any right to and with ski trails that start at the front door. 
There are also guided tours into Gla­ cier National Park, which have to be among lite s more m em orable exper­ iences, 
On G la c ie r’s west side is The B ig 
Mountain, one of Montana's oldest and most popular ski areas. There, downhill is superb and cross country means fine tra ils through forests of snow-ghosted trees with sudden views of the m agnifi­ cence of the Rocky Mountains i i i winter. 
There are a number of cross-country specialty operations em erging on 
Montana’s w inter scene — all of them worthy of attentions as well as a winter vacation 

Disco dancing for you? 

T h ere's a p lace in to w n th a t will teach you th e la te st disco dances. It's a m ove th a t m ay g e t you off th e w all an d on th e floor. See Try It! P ag e 3. 

Ski-touring with High Country Adven­ tures in Helena, including winter camp­ ing complete with snow caves, has been popular for a num ber of years w hile program s w ith A lpine E xperience in 
Missoula and Savage O utfitters i i i West 
Yellowstone are brand new aud lu ll ol verve and enthusiasm. 
The mountains are reads and waiting and >ou can depend on the snow The only thing that’s missing is you Put yourself

Neil Diamond: 
Marco Polo Chicken? 
Back stage view 

Television used to be the hist refuge for people who were under the im­ pression that Torn Or­ lando was w hat’s liap- 
,petting, baby, in ntusie today. 
Then Bob Dylan a s­ tounded television viewers by going on tin* air and presenting an en tire hour of m usic without a special guest appearance by ('ham. 
Now Neil Diamond has brought what he does in concert to television. The next thing you know. The 
Tubes will go on “ Hol­ lywood Squares’’ and get 
Suzanne Pleshette cor­ nered in the secret square. 
The two m edia con­ tinue to feed on one another with the release of Diamond’s “ Love at the dreck’’ (Columbia), a live album drawn from the sam e concert e n ­ gagem ent as the tele­ vision show. 

THE PROBLEM with concerts on television is that the sound system of the average television set is more suited to merry little jingles than rock music. 
Live albums sound a lot better but the picture is really lousy. 
This particular concert was a retu rn to the dreck Theatre, the out­ door theatre in b is 
Angeles which was the scene of Diamond's "Hot 
August Night.” 
That earlier live a l­ burn was classic Neil 
Diamond as much for its cover as its contents. It featured Neil proposing to his microphone. 
Sensuality has always been part of Diamond's act. Ile was still into black leat lier and Bryl- crcem all through the 
WK when those British bands were modeling the cutest little m atching outfits. 

I NI.IKE many other live albums, the new one 
Is at least som ething other than a collection of so-called greatest hits. 
There are times, though, when you still may wish for something other than what you get. 
Out of four sides, two are sort of Header's Di­ gest condensations of prev ious albums. One of those ts the highlights of his most recent album. 
"Beautiful Noise." lf you liked the album, you’ll love the commercial. 
The other is "Jonathan 
Livingston Seagull” re­ visited. Now that makes more sense. Most people 
Who saw the mov ie dozed fit hallway through the credits and didn t realize there were songs in it, too. i 
I ^fortunately, I did it 

THE OTI! EK two sides are really more interesting. Even if they are, well, greatest hits kind of. 
But "B rother Love’s 
T raveling 
S alvation 
Show” is a genuine show stopper. Its gospel fervor hits a crescendo at about the sam e tim e 
D ia­ m ond’s gravelly voice reaches train crash in­ tensity. 
And "Glory Road," the only new song on the album, is a good low-key ballad. 
Then there is "Song 
Sung Blue," which fea­ tures m ercifully brief guest shots by Helen 
Reddy and Henry (Arth­ ur Fonzarclli) Winkler. 
('ham must have had a chest cold. 
Arid what the heck, there is always "K en­ tucky 
W om an” and 
"Holly Holy.” Diamond has gone on to reach the heights of television, the greatest honor his coun-’ try men can bestow upon him Gene Pitney should have been so lucky. 

SPEAKING of throw­ backs naturally brings us to John T ravolta, famed punk sex symbol 
V mine 
Varbarino of 
‘ Welcome Back Hotter.” 
Or. as he is sometimes known, Ba-ba-ba Bu-ha- 

 barino. 
Through some wicked twist of fate. I missed his recording debut and I started cold with his se­ cond album, "( an't Let 
You Go" (M idland). I almost said cold turkey. 
Actually, the surpris­ ing thing is that the al­ bum is not totally offen­ sive. How is that for a nice positive review for a change? 
The music is in the genre known as easy lis­ tening. which somehow is riot what you expect from a sw aggering 
Sweating. It is the kind of soft pop m usical wallpaper that is consi­ dered good mood music 
Especially if you are gi­ ven to ra th e r bland moods. 
Some of the songs that are not the worst that have ever been done in­ clude "Slow Dancing,” 
"S e ttle 
Down” and 
"W hat 
Would 
They 
Say?” The latter was the them e from the te le ­ vision show "The Boy in the Plastic Bubble.” 

HEARTSFIELD is a high energy Southern rock baud from the hills of Chicago. They are an opening act that fre ­ quently deserves to Im1 the closing act. 
T heir new album , 
"Collectors’ Item ” (Co­ lum bia), dem onstrates that they are not stuck in som e holding p attern over Macon. 
It includes a great go spcl rock song, "W ith 
'ni»‘se Tools," a touch of 
Western swing, "All for 
Nothing." and a quieter ballad, "Southern Girl 
And a lot of good time music like "I Like It A lad’’ and "Let the Music 
Play.” 
An early Heartsfield album, "The Wonder of 
It All,” is on** of those obscure album s worth having 
So is this one though it would he nice if it weren’t so obscure. 

.I cann ie dabs on some more perfume and checks her prominent cleavage before tfoing in the concert. She knows there’s no way she can miss meeting a rock star tonight. 
After determ ining everything is in place, ap­ pearance wise, she slips into the backstage area at 
M unicipal A uditorium with three long-haired workers carrying musical equipment. 

Once back stage, the 
19-year-old blonde joins seven other women. They are standing a few feet away from the area illu­ minated by the spot lights which bathe the warm-up group iii a rainbow of lights. 
To everyone else back­ stage at the recent co n­ ce rt, Je an n ie and her friends are known as groupies. 
But refer to the women by that term and they’ll give you a defiant stare, suggest y ou do an anato­ m ically im possible act and stalk away to another part of the backstage ar­ ea to resum e their con­ versation. 
R egardless of what they’re called, rock pro­ m oter 
Joe 
Anthony agrees the young women arc an important part of the backstage color at a rock concert. 
“ You can’t write alinit what goes on back here without m entioning all tho beautiful la d ie s ." says Anthony. 
He then glances at the women who have quit talk in g and arc now focusing their attention on the musicians. 
P atro lm an 
Jim iny 
Johnson, who’s become a concert expert during his years as a back stag e gu ard , says every groupie seem s to have lier own method for get­ ting into a concert. 
Some of the women that walk by the patrol­ m an sport b ack stag e passes on their blouses, but most just wear very large smiles. 
One girl who doesn't look m ore than 
16-years-old sm iles at 
Johnson and introduces her friend Rose. 
The officer la te r ex ­ plains the girl is a regu- 

N ill DIAMOND: Live love

R unaw ays and th e ir m anager com e in through the stage din ti*. 
The m an ag er, who looks like he’s iii his late

‘odd couples’ but every­ one gets along well." 
Pointing to a long­ haired m an working a sound board with a man who looks to Im* in his BIK.

M eanwhile, the first rock group has ended its act.
