Classical record review 

Stunning abilities of Aldo Ciccolini 

By DAVID ANTHONY RICHELIEU 

Aldo Ciccolini smiles impishly us a Gene Wilder look-alike on the cover of his latest record album — but there the similarity ends. 
Ciccolini is a perfectly serious virtuoso, as evi­ denced In his dazzling performances of D 'Indy’s 
Symphony on a French Mountain Air and Franck’s 
Symphonic Variations and Les Djinns. 
Ciccolini is almost unknown to American concert artists because of a personal dislike for airplanes, hotels and other facilities related to travel. 
But he has a wide library of records which are on the American market and the latest (Angel S-37247) aptly displays his stunning abilities and artistry. 
There is at least one other recording which fea­ tures the same pieces on opposite sides. It features 
Casadesus and Ormandy — a formidable team for comparison. 
But Ciccolini more than holds his own. as do the 
Orchestra of Paris and Serge Bando on the D im ly and the Orchestra de Liege and Paul Strauss on the 
Franck. 

But the sound of this new Angel is better than the old Columbia/Odyssey and there is ample engineer­ ing to handle all the moments of solitude and the spectacular fortes dished up in this melodic feast. 
This is one of Angel s Stereo/Quad recordings and it is balanced, warm and brilliant. 
The performance is top-notch, with both orches­ tras and Ciccolini giving these showpieces the flair they need to send listeners soaring to the musical heights doubtless envisioned by the composers. 
Ciccolini is best known for his recordings of Erie 
Satie which have caught on with the “ pop” music crowd. 
This latest release, however, makes is abundantly clear that Ciccolini is no Salle cultist. Ile is a concert 
(icrformer of first rank — Gene Wilder look and all. 

ALDO CICCOLINI: No W ilder

ANTONIO AND OUR ARCA. 
Wall-eyed 

Posters are a good compromise between expensive art and cheap prints. But original posters are hard to find in San Antonio. 
NoWyou can get original posters without leaving your house with a catalog of antique American and European posters from 
189o to 193o. 
The catalog, ‘‘Off the W a ll," is pub­ lished by The Exhu­ mation, a Princetonn, 
N. J., art gallery. It includes a range of posters from an I 897 theater poster by Al- 
$«f| phonse Mucha that retails for $23oo to a 
4§j 
> 
Maxfield Parrish ma- gazine cover for a 
19o5 issue of Col- liers selling for $15. 
Each item in the 
^ f s* 
I catalog is illustrated 
* v* and many are availa- j* ble in only one exam- llP T flM pie. A highlight oHhe 
^^ 
^ 

 ed during the political upheaval of post- 
World W ar I. 
Even if you don't order anything from the catalog, it makes an interesting addition to an art libarary in itself.

Try Try It! 

Doubtless if you are looking at this item, you are aware of 
SUNDAY Magazine s Try It! page. Ifs a place where the unusual is the ordinary and the off-the-wall is standard fare. 
And what if you know of something unusual and off-the-wall? 
W e can spread the word, or whatever, for you, maybe. lf its of local interest, highly intellectual, amazingly important and/or written in English, it probably qualifies. 
Just send it along to the following address: 
RON WHITE’S Try It! Page, Box 2 171, San An­ tonio, Texas 7 8 2 9 7 . 

Soup’s On 

 lf you want to turn that hamburger helper into a gourmet’s delight, Craig 
Claiborne will tell you how. 
Claiborne is the food editor of the 
New York Times and author of the 
' New York Times Cook Book.” 
H e ll be here 
Tuesday and 
W ednesday with 
Pierre 
Franey, former chef at the White House and at New York’s Le Pavilion restaurant. 
Both chefs will be conducting a cook­ ing school for the Junior Women's 
Committee of the San Antonio Sym­ phony. 
They will both demonstrate gour­ met cooking recipes and techniques and show you how to spice up your own cooking. Day and night sessions are available for persons working during the day.

Shake Your Bootie 

Feel like a wall flower at your local discoteque? Do you sit on the sidelines while all the chicks and studs are out doing the boogie, the hustle, the bangle? 
Well, you don’t have to, you know. 
You can learn all you need to know to disco with the best of them at a disco dance course beginning Tuesday at the 
San Antonio Fine Arts Center. 
The six-week course is taught by 
Kathy Martin, an experienced dancer in classical, modern, jazz and disco. 
Class members don't even have to know how to do the fox-trot to join up. 
And for graduation, students will visit a disco to try out their new found skill.

Danes

EXPRESS NEWS SUNDAY MAGAZINE-—fob. 27, 1977 
PAGE 3 

V | 

C O Q R D S O C O Q R D 

DANA D. LUTZ 
14o2 Viewridge 
LEE HIGH SCHOOL 
Dana Lutz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlyle Lutz, is an outstanding member of the Robert E. Lee High School Class of 1977. Versatile and gifted, Dana ranked third in her junior class of r>6c> students. 
One of the leaders in her class, Dana has varied interests and en­ thusiasms. She is an accomplished musician, active for 3Vfc years in the 
Volunteer Band. She plays oboe in the San Antonio Youth Symphony, 
San Antonio Community Orchestra, the San Antonio Choral Society 
Orchestra, the Bicentennial Band and the newly formed Civic Chamber 
Orchestra at Incarnate Word College. 
She actively participates in the National Honor Society, Mu Alpha 
Theta, the National Spanish Honor Society, Opti-Misses and the Science 
Club. She is a member of Who’s Who Among American High School Stu­ dents and the Society of Distinguished American High School Students and was named a National Merit Scholarship semifinalist. 
Dana is one of those rare individuals who is equally as comfortable in the arts as she is in the sciences. Her fine analytical mind and her in- tellectural curiosity make her a delight to her teachers and win respect from her (leers. 
Dana plans to attend Northwestern University and major in music. 
Somewhere down the line she feels she might want to earn a degree in biology, pursuing an interest she found in a summer ecology course at 
Lee. 
Her friendly, cheerful manner has brought Dana many friends. Always loyal, appreciative and cooperative, Dana is a personality at Lee High 
School worthy of commendation. She will soon lie honored by the Optimist Club of 
San Antonio for her accomplishments. 

CO N G RATU LATIO N S.. 
M T H * ! 

Saving the whale m arks new topic 
Stamps 

 fACi 4 fxnrtss laws s u n d a y m a g a i i m - m 
. 27,197? 

It is incredible to learn that the mighty whale is becoming systematically destroyed by man All of this has i*onie about in less than 5o years. 
As conservation groups and governments all over the world fight to save the whale, the British 
Antarctic Territory has issued a new set of four stamps dedicated to the 
“ C o n serv atio n of 
Whales.” 
Each new stam p fea­ tures an illustration of a different type of whale which has been on the official U.S. endangered species list since 1971. 
A number of nations, including the U.S., Can­ ada and (Ileat Britain, h ave b a n n e d w h alin g from th e ir p o rts and have forbidden the im ­ portation of whale pro­ ducts. 
Yet many nations still hunt these highly intelli­ gent creatures for their oil. m eat and b y -p ro ­ ducts. 
The 2-pence depicts the 
Sperm Whale, one of the largest of the toothed variety 
Their large foreheads are storage tanks for the colorless oil. 
The intestines contain am bergris which is an expensive ingredient of fine perfume. 
The H-lienee shows the 
Kin Whale, recognized by the large dorsal fin on its back 
The 11-pence pictures the H um pback Whale, named for its habit of bending its back as it dives, 
T he 
H u m p b ac k is known to leap completely out of the water at times. 
Th*' 25-pence has the 
Blue Whale, largest of all the whale family, and considered by some ex­ torts to Im* the largest creature ever to live on earth. 
Unfortunately, this is the most endangered of the species and could become extinct in a few years 
The Republic of China 
(Taiwan) has issued a trio of stamps featuring ancie nt C hinese p a in t­ ings — pine, bamboo, plum, the three friends of winter. 
According to the World 
Wide Philatelic Agency, the three paintings were bv artists of the Yuan 
< 1277-13ttH) and Ming 
(I.IHM -1H44) d y n a s tie s , and were selected from the National Palace Mu­ seum 
The pine, bamboo and the plum are considered bv the Chinese people to be the “ three friends of w in te r” because they survive severe cold yet are lofty and noble. 
Th** pine, bamboo and the plum are considered by the Chinese people to tx- the “ three friends of w in te r” becau se they survive severe cold yet are lofty and noble. 
The subjects of the new stam ps are also symbols of traditional Chinese art and culture 
The stam ps are avai­ lable at your local stamp dealer or store.

Governor Ariyoshi has asked the 
F e d e ra l government to stop im­ m igration from the mainland. The Supreme

And 
H aw aiian s say mainlanders come here to live on Hawaiian wel­ fare and the easy life on golden beaches.

Paradise of the Pacific?

Wailea is the biggest — 

Around the World 

By STAN DELAPLANE 

 and most talked alnrnt — resort project in Hawaii. 
Three times the size of 
Waikiki. Five white sand beaches. A million dol­ lars worth of tennis courts. Three million of golf course. 
There’s an Inter-Con- tinental Maili hotel of 6oo rooms that cost $27 mil­ lion. And so far, 35o condom iniu m s — the medium priced ones go for $94,(HIO. 
When it ’s finished there's to be three hotels. 
A 
.shopping center planned around a village green. And 36oo living units: Condom inium s. 
Duplexes. Cottages. 
It's built on marginal 

 farm in g land — (but ideal resort living) — owned by Alexander & 
Baldwin, sugar growers of Hawaii’s Big Five. 
The final cost will be 
$1oo million. You can bet i f s being planned so every dollar buys a dol­ lar’s worth. 
“ No high rise . 
No house closer than a long sto n e ’s throw lo the beach. All building to be screened by our own En­ v iron m ental 
C om ­ mittee.”

3.2 m illion to u rists.

C anada CBers on rise 

( anuria is experiencing a ( I i explosion. It's not as large as tho one that hit tho I ’ .S. within tho last IS months, but it's still s ik h ilioant. 

Tho country’s Depart­ ment oi Communications 
(counterpart to tho U.S. 
Federal Communications 
Commission) estimates that thoro will soon ho I 2 

 m illion Canadians li­ censed to operate C li transceivers. 
Right now there are just over 2o(1.(MIO legal Cli sets in Canada and an 

 unknown quantity of people operating without licenses. 
The latest FCC report shows that more than eight million persons of 

 businesses hold U.S. li­ censes, and it's probably safe to assume that se­ veral million more oper­ ate on the citizens band without a license.

Larger amounts are available at higher repayment rates. Financial Services. Travel agents can approve immediately many credit applications up to $75o.

T O H A W A II W IT H FLY IN G C O L O R S 

CB Convac 

By INK DIPPER 

Editor of I hr CW Units-Journal 

Keep in mind, though, that Canada’s population is about one-tenth that of the U.S., so the per ca­ pita use of ( Bs in Canada might one day surpass the U.S. mark. 
What’s causing tin' in­ creasing popularity ? 
A lot of the same things that have sparked the growth here. 
Canadians want to keep up with radar and speed traps, they like the instant convenience of 
(B in g for obtaining highway inform ation, and the ( Bs have proven them selves tim e and again during em er­ gencies. 
But Canada is also, for the most part. a rural country. 
People in far-flung ar­ eas use their radios as a way to keep in touch wit Ii neighbors. 
The CB becomes a party line for Canadians in isolated areas who, even though they might have telephones, still en­ joy the companionship of a dozen or more other 
CBers who ratchet-jaw into the night 
The growth iii Canada has given the Doe some of the same growing pains encountered bv the 
FCC. 
In some urban areas. 

 the original 23 channels have become congested. 
And the flood of license applications has been al­ most overwhelming. 
To cope with conges­ tion, the DOC has allo­ cated 17 new channels — the same new fre ­ quencies allotted for U.S. 
( Bing — and set April I as the day the new chan­ nels can in* opened. 
The lag, DOC officials explain, is because the 
DOC fiscal year runs from April I to Marc h 31. and the channel expan­ sion will coincide with the new year. 
.lust as in the U.S.. the channel expansion in 
Canada has prompted CB retailers to offer price cuts on 23-c hannel stock. 
The glut of license ap­ plications has put a strain on the DOC, offi­ cials say, hut they’ve been able so far to cope with it and not fall far behind like the FCC, which at times took up to tm davs to process an application. 
Ail example of the DOC service1 is temporary li­ censing of A m erican 
( liers traveling in Cana­ da with their radio gear. 
Most applications from 
I S. ( liers lur the tem­ porary permits are ans­ wered bv return mail 

A m e ric a n E x p re ss t o m p u n y . 1 9 7 6 rRKteanfEurope. 
American Express brings it to life.

NASHVILLE. Tenn. - 
Production of the four- p art 
“ N ashville 99“ series here has been com pleted and is scheduled to a ir Sun­ days, March 27 and April 
3-1o-17 on CBS-TV. (It replaces “ Delvecchio.” ) 
The police-adventure show co -stars Claude 
Akins and Jerry Reed and features numerous country m usic e n te r­ tainers — Tammy Wyn­ cote, Charley Pride. Mel 
Ti 11 is, 
Ray 
Stevens, 
Jacky Ward and Chet 
Atkins as g u e s t s ; some in non-singer roles. 
Yes. Chet Atkins as a dramatic “ actor!” 
Akins and Reed por­ tray officers on the Me­ tro 
N ashville 
Police 
Dept. (Pride has a con­ tinuing role as a detec­ tive called “ K B .” ). 
One of the segments, filmed at Opryland, has 
A tkins 
(M r. 
G u itar) playing himself. 
“ It’s just a bit part.” insists Atkins. “ A cameo role, they call it. Yet. it is the first time I ve ever done any acting.” 
Chet, w ithout his guitar, is cast as a guide at Roy Aeuff’s Museum 
(an O pryland a ttr a c ­ tion). 
“ In the scene I am guiding some children through the M useum , describing the old in ­ stru m e n ts and th eir back g ro u n d ,” he ex ­ plained. 
“ During our tour we meet 
‘Officer’ 
Reed. who asks me to listen to some of his guitar licks. 
Jerry, according to the script, has been taking some picking lessons. 
“ I listen and then tell him he needs more les­ sons. It’s tragic-comedy, as 
Shakespeare would say.’* 
Somebody asked the internationally - known picker if his future plans included acting. 
“ I d on’t know if I would want to be an ac­ tor — say, like Burt 
Reynolds or Robert Red­ ford, although having pretty girls go ape over you might Ik* nice. 
“ lf, after the show is televised, any Hollywood agents call, I II certainly talk to them .”

Stoney Cooper, veteran 
Grand Ole Oprv regular, is recovering from a heart attack. Stoney, who performs with his wife 
W ilm a Lee and The 
Clinch Mountain Gang, actually was temporarily 
“dead” after suffering the attack. 
“ Only the quick and professional action of a doctor — who beat on 
Stoney’s chest — brought him back to life,” says 
Mrs. Cooper. 
Music City Vignette — 
Singer Mary McGregor of Steam boat Springs, 
Colo, was in Nashville in 
1974 begging record producers and agents for a break. 
She stayed around for a week or ten days and then, like hundreds do and have done, drifted 

 new 

 away. Back then the only way she could have got­ ten into the Grand Ole 
Opry House was to buy a ticket. 
Mary M cGregor now' has a big, big hit re ­ cording iii 
“ Torn 
Between Two Lovers." 
She was in Nashville last weekend, promoting her record and an album, and being interviewed all over the place by practi­ cally everybody with a pencil and pad and/or a microphone. 
One of the stops on her 
“tight" schedule was at the Opry House — where she did what amounted to a “ command perfor­ mance." 
Happy ending to vig­ nette!

 fXPtfSS-MfWS SUNDAY MAGAZINE— Feb. 17, l f 77 
PAGE 7 

‘Faster, faster, 9 he told his lens 

Photo Tips 

With Ron 
Jones 

Vyintf with “ Which obscure, off brand lens is best?” for unanswerable question of the month, is “Should I spend two hundred dollars more for an f/1.4 lens as opposed to an f/2?” 
Really! 
Is this som ething a professional should know? 
Am ateurs, with more money than they can spend at one place, are better equiped to answer these questions. 

Professionals usually work too tight of a budget to buy a lens they don’t absolutely have to have. 
The idea of picking up a selection of off-brand lenses — keeping tin* best and junking the rest — sends sw arm s of red craw ly th in g s up my 
I spine. 

When I need a new lens 
I get the one made for my cam era by the cam era m anufacturer. This lens usually costs from two to j four tim es as much as even the best brand-X. 

IF 
TMK 
LENS 
DOESN’T work just right, back it goes to the distributor for replace­ ment or adjustment. 

In the long run (three years and half a million exposures later) I II save money because this lens is built to last. The major 
. cam era m anufacturer's 
M rep u tatio n depends on 
I quality — particularly in 
'rn the focusing mount. No 
® one expects more than a 
* couple of easy years ser­ vice from Brand-X. 

The sticky question in­ volves lens speed or 
"how much is a quarter f-stop worth?” 

We have entered the age of fast lenses. 

WITH I M H K disre­ spect for such speed freak s as the Canon range!linier 5omm/o.95, until about five years or so ago a lens faster than f/2 was considered fast. 
Outside of normal (5o or 
55mm), and, with very few and generally una­ vailable exceptions, lenses were by today's standards slow. 

HUL 
99 

CM m n . JU S T IS if) in sharp focus. In bright daylight, a la-1 lew* in a want# of npccd. The older, anti -dower, lenten definatelv have a place photography. Thin -hot wan taken with l’ri-\ film, at F-l. in open nhadc at 
1-25o of a neeoud. 

Photography is closely tied to the science of optics. 
With most scientific instruments, price and quality are closely related. You get what you pay for. 

But what you need may not lie the most expensive lens available iii given focal length. 

If von are a stamp collector and wish to study a stamp s watermark, what you need is a good look­ ing-glass not a two million dollar microscope. 

(iood quality, fast lenses are available at relatively reasonable prices but do you need the speed? 
Probably not. 

Fast lenses used to be notoriously fuzzy. The 
Canon glass beast is a good example. Today's fast lenses are almost as sharp as their slower brothers. 

I’ve seen some very convincing tests that show the t8ommF/2.8 Nikkor lens to bi* almost as sharp as the utminr/i 

Almost I said. But not better. 

For only $4oo more you can have a lens almost as sharp as the inexpensive but incredibly sharp one f-stop slower standard for medium telephotography. 

PACI I ItftfSWtfWS SUNDAY MAGAZJMI-ftb. 17. lf77 

Phuff! 

Would anyone expect a new $2oo Sigma to tx* as sharp as a 195o model $1oo llektor 135ininf/4.5? They shouldn't. 

While Sigma is a leader in superfast lenses, they must sacrifice something for high speed. That so mottling is resolution and corner to corner sharp ness. 

How do you know if you need high speed lenses? 

If you must generally push your film two or more f-stops and always shoot your pictures with the lens at maximum aperture, then consider buying faster lenses. 

As a general rule (with some exceptions) the best or sharpest lens in the slowest usuable lens. Wide open, a fast lens will have little depth-of-field with only a shallow plane in sharp focus. This luck of depth in sharp focus will add to the impression of overall fuzziness. 

Most photographers tend to stop a lens down to increase the depth-of-field or overall sharpness 
This does away with the one advantage of fast lenses, lf you are going to shoot all of your pictures at f/5.8 or f/8 why pay $2oo extra for a fast lens? 

W atercolor scene 

Guest column 

This week I'm turning this space m er to Hill Bristow, choirman o f 
Trinity I niversity's art department. 
Bristow takes an enthusiastic look at what's happening to watercolors to­ day. 

By BILL BRISTOW 

In an age when artists are questioning the very validity of painting itself, it is interesting to witness the persistence of the traditional practice of a particular kind of paint­ ing: the medium of tran­ sparent w atercolor, or aquarelle, is enjoying a w idespread festival of celebration by serious artists and collectors that is unprecedented. 
A case in point is the focus of a grand exhibit in 
T rin ity 
U n iv ersity ’s 
Ureal Hall of the Chap­ man G raduate C enter, 
March 1-15, when 5o wa­ tercolors selected for the 
American Watercolor So­ ciety’s national competi­ tion will be on view. 
Sponsored by a dynamic local organization, the 
San Antonio Watercolor 
Group, and Trinity's Art 
Department, a few notes on the medium may whet the appetites of local gal­ lery goers. 
Dragonfly 
The delicate glazes of aqueous p ig m en ts on handsom e tex tu red papers has been likened to the gossamer quality of a dragonfly’s wings — a rather accurate descrip­ tion of the medium in the hands of an artist. Light penetrates the thin sheets of color, strikes the white substance of the paper and bounces back to the eye, illu m in a tin g the entire surface of the painting in the process; and the brilliance, spar­ kle and clarity associated with the medium are ac­ cum pl ished. 
The thin washes of co­ lor can be the palest bloom of hue or can build into the deepest pools of inky wetness. A barely dam p brush can drag across the dry textured paper 
(th e d ry b ru sh tech n iq u e) w ith the bleached quality of a hornet’o nest; or a fully loaded brush charged with color can spill wash onto a previously wet ar- ea with curdles of pig. 

 m ent (the wet-in-vvet technique) that bleed into marbled rivuleta. 
This rep e rto ire of b rushstroke and the range of possibilities in the m aterial are pure poetry, dem anding the skillful control of a disci­ plined artist. But part of the sense of discipline is the ability to recognize the fortuitous accident and the ability to turn oneself over to the me­ dium. 
Watercolor teaches the a rtist economy of lan­ guage and directness, and these very qualities are its special appeal to its audience: an intimate view of the a rtis t's thought processes and perceptions. On the one hand, it is an ideal study medium, it is simple and mobile; and yet it is po­ tentially heroic, and its only limits are the limi­ tations of the artist, what the artist can wring from white paper, the spec­ trum of pigments, clean water and a brush. 
Understatement 
In traditional aquarelle usage, the artist's light­ est tints are the white of the paper; arid these m ust be preserved throughout the painting process from the earliest broad and pale washes, through the gradual buildup of rich middle values, until the last crisp dark accents are added. 
The m edium lends itself to un d er­ statement; and once the artist has gone too far, the only recourse is to s ta rt again on fresh paper! 
Because of its inherent w etness, aquarelle is perfect for capturing a sense of atmosphere and spaciousness, the pene­ trability of skies, and the depth and reflectiveness of water. Because the ex­ posed paper serves as the lightest values, the crus­ ty opaqueness of solid form s bounding total sunlight to our eye is ea­ sily accomplished in the medium. 

F or all th e ir a tm o s­ phere, aquarelles are al­ so inherently ab stract. 
The m asters of aquarelle have explored the range of p o ssib ilities and opened the door for new expression. In the finest of both extremes we find 
[he w atercolors of the 
E nglishm an, W illiam 
I tim er, swollen with a mist and fog that swallow and dissolve objects like a Zen landscape; and the sp a rk lin g -c risp n ess of the work of the A m eri­ can, W inslow H om er w^itIi dappled light and shade and sharp-edged shape reductions of con­ trasting earth, water and sky. 
Tempera 
The purity of aquarelle fs often modified by the introduction of opaque tem p era 
(called gouache) in usually white tinted colors that partial­ ly obscure (he paper and even block out e a rlie r painting. The range of opaque watercolor, sim ­ ple gouache, casein, egg tem pera or a c ry lic, brings a m at textured sheen to the medium that has its own delicacy, but in no way dem ands the skilled choreography of aquarelle. 
M odern a rtis ts have very naturally combined paper collage with the various w ater pain ts which still maintains the delicate "w eight” of the m edium W ithin the li­ m its of w ater soluble media, unvarnished and applied to p ap e r, the present interest and ex­ citement is a touchstone with a rich and venerable tradition in art. 
The A m erican W ater- color Society exhibit al trin ity U niversity pro- 
XliEfkt offor vi*ual dt lights for the appre­ ciator of fine watercolor by some of the country's outstan d in g a rtis ts 
Some exam ples will be 
'Mild and daring, but the contact with a valuable tradition in art will be inherent in the demands of the medium.

REAL LIFE MELODRAMA: The plot of M elo­ dram a T h eater's new show opening Friday may sound strangely fam iliar. 
The original play w ritten by director B urdette 
Parks details the plight of the frozen citizens of San 
Antonio during the fuel crunch of 1876. 
The black-hearted villain, O scar DeLavaca, tri­ ples the price of firewood and kidnaps Mayor Lela 
Crockweli when she tries to close down DeLavaca s dance halls. 
M eanwhile City Councilm an Uncle Sam Woody keeps trying to get everyone involved in his Cen­ tennial Parade. 
Finally DeLavaca is outw itted by snow cone ven­ dor Harold Baskin and Robbin M ichaels, cub re­ porter of the E xpress and News. 

Look to Slope for detoils. 

MARVELOUS MARVELEE: A m em ber of the San 
Diego Opera since 197o, M arvelee C ariaga cam e to national prom inence in 1972 when she stepped in for the ailing Irene Dalis in the world prem iere of 
“ M edea” with only 24 hours notice. 
The m ezzo-soprano has since had several suc­ cessful engagem ents throughout the United States. 
This Tuesday she will be perform ing for the 
Tuesday M usical Club at San Antonio College's 
McAllister A uditorium . Local audiences w ill have a chance to decide if she m easures up to her press notices that her “ voice is im pressive for its natural beauty and wide, dynam ic range." 
Cheek out Music for outre info. 

DANCE, DANCE: 
San Antonians will have op­ portunities Sunday to see two dance com panies. 
The Luis R ivera Dance Company will present a free perform ance at 7:3o p.m. with the San Antonio 
S\ m phony at the T heater for the Perform ing Arts. 
E arlier, at 3 p.m ., the San Antonio Ballet Com­ pany will present "G iselle" at Incarnate Word 
College. 
“G iselle" will feature the com pany's principal m ale d an cer, R ichard P rew itt, in the lead of 
Albrecht. The com pany’s T erri Hayes and Joshua 
Thompson will also be featured. 
See Donee for detoils.

1 3 1 8 1 . G ra yso n St. 

{ B o o k s a t r o c e g r e a t T e x a s h e r i t a g e 

Bv CLARENCE J. 
LaROCHE 

Tho people and the land are the basic stuff three recent books of quality— in content and in production—deal with. 
And the settings are as diverse as Texas geo­ graphy: the Northeast, 
(beat Plains and Hill 
Country. 
Volumes are 
OLD r a n c h e s o f t h e 
TEXAS PLAINS (Texas 
AOI University Press; 
$27.5o), THE TEXAS 
HEARTLAND (Also the 
A O I Press; $21.5o). and 
BETWEEN 
THE 
CREEKS (Encina Press; 
$12.5o). 
The golden age of Tex­ as ranching, some say, began about 187o, during tin1 height of trail driving days and lasted into the first decade of this centry. Vividly, Mendel 
Rogers has captured this area with his paintings of rude abodes, homes and buildings of these Great 
Plains ranches. 
Growth of the ranching business from its begin­ nings is recorded by 
Rogers in 85 superb paintings. These paint­ ings start with the first rude dwellings—shacks, huts, dugouts. adobes—and range ti]) to the splendid Victorian mansions of later years. 

A fascinating introduc­ tion by the artist, a na­ tive West Texan, further enhances the superlative art work and reaffirms the book's authentic his­ torical value. 
"Texas Heartland" is subtitled "A Hill Country 
Year” and combines the outstanding camera ar­ tistry of Jim Bones Jr. and the text of John 
Graves. The latter brings the same keen feeling he senses for places in our state that he showed in 
"Goodbye to a River" a few years ago. His dis­ section and analysis of our Hill Country is one of the most expert and var­ ied this reviewer has read in a long, long time. 
Bones says the photo collection in the book is the culmination of over a decade id- work. How­ ever. most of the plates in the book were taken while he was in resi­ dence as a scholar at the late J. Frank Dobie’s place, ‘ P aisa n o ” on 
Barton Creek near Aus­ tin. 
These color photos gives us some of the most startling, stark and 

 beautiful photos—some minute closeups—made in the Hill Country. 
Again photos and text blend to bring us the passing, .just 3o years ago, of the last really 
"free range" in Texas, 
"Between the ( reeks.” 
Katharine Gust han­ dled the black-and-white photography and Debor­ ah Brown did the text. 
Only in blaek-and -white photos could the sadness and 
‘‘gone fo rev er” feeling and mood be conveyed. 
Ms. Brown, in the brief text passages, captures the sim ple, direct, earthy but eloquent talk of the “ between the creek" East Texans. 
This ‘‘between the creek" area is up near the Arkansas and Okla­ homa borders, between the Sulphur River and 
White Oak Creek. Time did little to alter life here until, first, the great De­ pression, then, by 1942, when the land came in­ 

 creasingly under control of a ranch development. 
The development ac­ quired more and more of the land and, gradually. 

"I don't want to< hear a song and dance about your attic full of old stuff!"

MGH SOCK TY 

At noon on October 25th, the Transcontinental Express left Geneva Station with almost one thousand people on board. 
Their destination: 
Basel, Paris, Brussels, Amsterdam, 
Copenhagen and Stockholm.

Soft cowl neck blouses are the latest for spring mixing 

To go with just about anything, these textured polyester blouses are the best when you want a little different look in your spring wardrobe. Cowl neck, cap sleeve tops for slacks, skirts or jumpers mix and match in your choice of solids or polka dots. Choose solids in white, brown, black, red, or navy, and dots in red, navy, brown, or black on white. Sizes 8-16. By Ioanna for Plaza Sportswear, 
Downtown, North Star, Windsor Park, and Austin Highland Mall.

SAYING 
OF THI 
WEEK . . . 
• RONALD REAGAN, for­ mer Governor of California, discussing the 
TV smash 
Roots: ‘‘Very frankly I thought the bias of all the good people md ail the bad n le being a astructive 

 being one color ai ople being another was rath- 

• GEORGE MASTERS Hol­ lywood hairdresser discussing his former client Doris Day: 
“I never saw anyone so bull­ headedly bent on being happy all the time, lier singing really drove me bats. She was always singing and humming to her­ self. Her joy of life drove me quietly berserk.” 
• GINGER ROGERS, ac- tress-dancer bemoaning the lack of movie roles for women: 
‘‘There are no women writers. 
And men don't know the first thing about women. Even men who make automobiles don’t think about women. Every­ thing is made for a man’s big foot, a man’s big hand.” 
• BARBRA STREISAND, a star of A Star Is Bom discuss­ ing her next role: “Give me a screen play with some (exple­ tive deleted) tenderness.” 
• O.J. SIMPSON, football star and entertainer, on his ca­ reer: “ I know I’m near the end in football. When you love something and have to give it up it s very tough Bid I do love acting. I know I can do it and I’m looking forward to doing a lot more of it.” 
• JODY POWELL, Presi­ dent Carter’s press secretary, on breaking his word that he wouldn't return to 
Plains. 
Georgia, for three months: “It may be that sometimes two weeks seems like three months.” 
• THEODORE SORENSEN on being thwarted from taking the top job in the CIA: “Some say that Jimmy Carter helped 
K l the noose around my neck 
I that is not true He helped kick the chair out from under­ neath ’ 

Marlene Dietrich, hip healed, steps out for expensive oysters with steady date 

SOMETHING about the photo above struck Chicago collector Hy 
Roth Ile paid $25 for it. then took it to an expert 
Roth’s keen eye served him well. The prissy gentleman is 
John Wilkes Booth, President Lin­ coln's assassin. As an authentic photo of Booth, the picture’s value shot up 8,ooo per cent to a cool 
$2,ooo 
"I just liked the picture,” Roth said “ It was well posed and well taken and so I bought it.” 
Big sundae for future big star 

QUINN Cummings. 9, receive the World’s Biggest Sundae after nabbing the starring role in Neil 
Simon's film. The Goodbye Girl 
“ It is wonderful.” she said 
“I ve done some television and 
I ve always wanted to do a proper film ” 

Couple$ to get divored after wedding crui$e 
FIRST, he tried to bring New 
Yorkers a flying nightclub It nev­ er got off the ground. 
Then it was a bullfight aboard a string of barges out at sea in the middle of winter. The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Ani­ mals stopped that. 
Now promoter John Hoffman is offering a “giant wedding cruise” for the first 1.ooo persons interest­ ed in paying $5,ooo to be married at sea and then divorced on the return trip by the captain. 

\ 

 v r 
Redford flees film for skis 
ROBERT Redford recently left his latest film, Ordinary People, to catch some Utah skiing “You are truly alone coming down a slope,” the 39-year-old actor said. 
“It is you against the mountain. 
Skiing is one of the most exciting sports in the world.” 
Caroline Kennedy follows in Jackie’s footsteps 

 f arolia* Kennedy with tool of 

CAMERAS have changed and liairstyles are different, but the ambition is just the same 
Caroline Kennedy is following in the footsteps of her mom, Jack­ ie, as a photographer. 
The 19-year-old daughter of the late President John Kennedy has just slimed a contract with a Ger­ man fashion magazine, 
Mode 
International, to provide photo­ graphs and articles for a year. 
In 1963, Jackie Kennedy Onassis signed to work as a photographer for the Washington Times Herald. 

Jackie Kennedy OoassU, 26 years ago. her trade. 

During Jackie’s stint at the pa­ per she met her first husband, 
John Kennedy 
Caroline became interested in photography in the summer of 
1971 when her mother asked pho­ tographer Peter Beard to join her family on the yacht Christina for a cruise. 
Beard loaned Caroline his Le lea camera, gave her a little advice, and she snapped away all sum­ mer. 
Beard said of her work: “ It be­ came a strong interest of hers. 

She has a keen seeing eye and is growing Her photographs show a lot of reeling. 
In the soring of 1975, Caroline held an exhibition of her work in 
London and was beseiged by of­ fers from papers and magazines ail over the world. 
For the oast two years, Caro­ line has talked about turning pro­ fessional. 
Caroline is currently at school at Radcliffe College, Cambridge, 
Mass , and will be there until the beginning of the summer 

# MARLENE Dietrich (left) is alive and well and eating oysters in Paris 
* with her long-time friend, actor Jean 
Pierre Aumont. 
The 
75-year-oid singer actress had been in seclusion since breaking her hip a year ago. When spotted at the exclusive Marius And Jeanette restau­ rant, she told reporters she is busy finishing her memoirs, for which she has already been paid a $2oo,ooo advance.

THE SAN ANTONIO STAB— february 27, 1977 
PAGE 3 

Nude tenants are the answer ta a landlord's money prayer 

EX-JEHOVAH witness 
Terry 
Parker solved the problem of empty apartments when he took over the job of managing a com­ plex. 

He allowed the tenants to walk around the building—without any clothes on. 

When Terry took over the build­ ing last year many of the apart­ ments were vacant. Now there s a 
12-month wait to rent one. 

“I just abolished rules that said oeople had to be dressed—now they walk around nude.” 

Terry. 32. of Austin, Tex., now hopes to turn 7o other complexes into all year round nudist colo­ nies. 

“We started off small with a 
14-apartment complex offering total freedom to the residents,” he said. “Now we are renovating a 78-unit complex in East Austin. 
“After that we intend to take the freedom of dress code into 7o other complexes. They will be all over Austin, Texas—and it’s about time." 
Tile experiment has been profit­ able. From the original concept started in June of last year, ne has been able to raise the rents 2o percent for those lucky enough to get an apartment. 
“As soon as I altered the dress code. I suddenly had a waiting list,” he said. “We will have no trouble filling as many complexes as we like 
People want free­ dom." 
All the apartments that are tak­ ing on the new rules are having big walls built around them with 
IV monitors to guard against peeping toms. 
Tile complexes have swimming pools where residents swim in the altogether. 
“There has been a lot of opposi­ tion,” he said. "But the people who call us weird are the real weird ones 
They are the ones with the twisted minds 
“People don’t value their liber­ ty enough We are giving people liberty. In our complexes people can do exactly as tney please so long as they are not physically ag­ gressive to anyone." 
Parker's nude apartments have a wide range of people living in them. 
“We have laborers to profes­ sional people," he* said “The age group runs from 18 to the middle forties.”

COMPARE the photos above and at right. 
When the photo above was tak­ en nine years ago, the busty blonde was fresh off the Uni­ versity of Texas campus and just another pretty face struggling to be noticed amid the glitter and flim-flam of Hollywood. 
Today (photo at right) she is 
Farrah Faweett-Majors, 29, a TV star in Charlie’s Angels, and in constant demand for commer­ cials, magazine covers, and pos­ ters. 
Her husband. Lee Majors, The 
Six Million Dollar Man. says she is the natural successor to Mari­ lyn Monroe as America's sex symbol. Millions of males agree. 
Maturity, not the surgeon, turned Farrah from good looker to Super Face. 
"She was always beautiful,” said her personal agent, but the first pictures of her always made 
Farrah look older and bigger." 
Farrah Faweett-Majors

A small advertisement in Maine makes American legal history 

Lawyer David Kee 

THE small ad in four recent 
Maine newspapers was a “first” in America — an advertisement by lawyers listing their rates and noting they accepted Bank Ameri­ ca rd and Master Charge. 
The ad appears while the U.S. 
Justice Department is suing the 
American Bar Association over its ban on lawyers advertising their services. Said David Kee. managing partner of the Maine firm: 
“The little feedback we have had so far has been very favorable " 
The Maine Bar dropped its ad ban when sued by the Maine at­ torney general over the issue.

 by Warren Beatty 

GRETA GARBO, once the most beau­ tiful of all actresses who preferred se­ clusion to stardom , is to make a film comeback I m told—and her persuad­ ers are none other than WARREN 
BEATTY and JACK NICHOLSON 
Since the failure of The Fortune, the tal­ ented pair has wanted to do another film together to show they can really pull off a good one. 
They found a script and in it discovered the role of a once-famed actress who goes into hiding. Who better for the part than 
Garbo? 
Nicholson apparently pursued the myste­ rious Swede, who faded away from Holly­ 

 wood three decades ago, before catching up with her' in N&w York. Eventually he got a yes out of her. 
She told him she would do it because he reminded her so much of her leading men of the thirties and forties. 
Meanwhile, Academy officials have in­ vited her to the Oscar ceremony and for the first time since she was Hollywood’s hottest movie property she has hinted she may turn up. 
With girl friend KATE JACKSON filming in Utah for a few months, Beatty has been seen around Hollywood with ex-lover JU­ 
LIE CHRISTIE. 
Close friends say now that MICHELLE 
PHILLIPS is also’out of the picture, the 
Christy-Beatty couple are trying to make a go of it again. 
It seems that Warren has never really given up on the vivacious, if somewhat eccentric, English actress—and neither has she on him 

Dressed like Russian royalty, 
Lucy Arnaz and date Sandy 
Gallin showed up for fash­ ionable film capital ball.

This huge model of the mighty gorilla was being prepared for shipment at Paris airport for a promotional tour of European cities, where the film King Kong is already a Kong-sized hit. 

HOW TO TURN A m m 
A’S BOY' 
INTO A MAN: DOCTOR 

MOMMA S boys are not bom, they’re made — often by well­ meaning mothers who don't know any better, according to a leading psychiatrist. 
A ‘Momma s Boy’—a man, sin­ gle or married, who hasn t broken 
His emotional ties to his mother — is often the product of a home where the father had too little say in his son s life leaving mom as the heavy, says Dr. Jack Chemus, 
Acting Chief of Psychiatry at 
Gouverneur 
Hospital in 
New 
York. 
He told THE STAR: “This man 
Is a ‘boy’ in terms of his emotion­ al development. But he could be of any age. from puberty to a man in his sixties. 
“The influence of a mother on a son bears a heavy imprint for his entire life A father might op­ pose a mother who is making her son into a ‘Momma s Boy , but odds are she will continue to raise her son that way.” 
Some mothers refuse to let their sons become truly masculine. It starts in boyhood, says Dr. Cher- 
HUS. 
* The mother won t let her son ride a bike, play football, climb a fence, or rough play' with the other boys And when it comes time to date, she usually discour­ 

 ages his positive feelings toward women. 
“Two out of a hundred mothers raise their sons to be * Momma's 
Boys’, lf you think you are one — or you love someone that is — there are things you can do to break away. Dr. Chemus’ advice is: 
• Try to break away. It isnt easy. lf you’re too old to live with 
Momma’ but still do, make plans to move. Realize that you will be 
•panicky’ at first. There are many new adjustments. 
Prepare for the transition. 
• Break the news to your moth­ er without anger. You may be very angry at her for having kept you tied to her apron strings But anger does no good. Tell her calmly you’re moving and that you want to live your own life. 
• Be prepared for her nicely couched phrases that will encour­ age you at first, but discourage you after 
For example, your mother might say: 
‘Well, Its right for you to want to be on your own, but, whoa going to cook for you?1 Respond to her objections by saying that you know what you 

 will be losing out on, but that you feel you will gain by making the move. 
• lf necessary, think about moving to another city But make sure you have a job and an apart­ ment before doing it. 
• If you have been neglecting 
‘women’, or avoiding them, begin a campaign to start going out more on dates. Ask your men friends to arrange a blind date’. 
Overcome your suspicions that women are 
‘after something’. 
Avoid the type of man who puts down women or is always belit­ tling them. 

• Consider your concept of masculinity. It does not mean the false ‘male macho’ thing Rather, it means a man who is independ­ ent of his mother, who makes a warm and tender relationship with a woman, who has a family. 

• lf you have broken away from your mother, you may still keep up a relationship with her by mail, or phone, and visits. 
But be aware that she will still try to run your life. Talk this over with your wife, and enlist her aid. 

The TV divorce of the year is about to take place—and it s not between BARBARA WALTERS and the ABC network. 
Rhoda Morgenstem and her long-suffering screen husband Joe are actually going through with it after months of bickering and sep­ aration on their hard-hitting Sun­ day night CBS comedy Rhoda. 
VALERIE HARPER, who plays the title role, will once again be living as a single woman when the show restarts in September. 
The producers say there won’t be a specific episode about the di­ vorce, but they will convery one is in the offing in the last few epi­ sodes of this season's shows in 
March. 
Joe? You won t be seeing him again except in re-runs. 
All is not well behind the scenes of the new TV show Mrs. Blan- sky’s Beauties featuring NANCY 
WALKER. 
Some network officials now be­ lieve it was a mistake bringing the middle ager into the show and feel it would have appealed more to teenagers if ROZ KELLY, now playing second fiddle, had been given the starring role. 
RED SKELTON is about to con­ clude a multi million dollar deal bv selling 2o years of his TV shows to a syndicate that would re-distribute them. 
The canny comedian owns ev­ ery one of the programs he mack. 
JOHN TRAVOLTA refuses to be photographed unless he knows the cameraman personally. 
The Welcome Back Rotter star wants to be absolutely certain thai the pictures are flattering 

Fancily-attired Olivia Newton. 
John shows up by herself for a Hollywood awards party.

BURNETT and is ready to put millions of dollars on the line if she will sign up with them for the next IO years. 
The comedienne has already been on the network since 1967.

O.J. SIMPSON is rumored to be leaving football again. The rea­ son? After seeing the rushes of 
Capricorn One, Universal wants to sign him to a long term con­ tract that would earn him more than football. 
A fight is now going on between the Buffalo Bills ana the studio. 
Crooner EDDIE FISHER, who has had to devote more time to his marriages than his career during the last decade or so is going to make a comeback.

STAR LETTERS • STAR LETTERS • STAR LETTERS • STAR LETTERS 

AFTER being married only a short while, I found one fault with my husband—he never woke up in a good mood. 
Recently a friend gave me a beautiful little mutt. On the first morning at home, he ran into our bedroom and proceeded to pull off our blankets, one by one. 
I was sure this would create grumbles from my husband, but when he woke up and looked down at the little doe-eyed pup, practi­ cally hidden in blankets, he had to laugh. 
This is a daily habit for both my husband and our pup. Now I hate to change old sayings, but 
‘A dog is a woman's best friend,” at least, in my opinion Theresa 
McDonald, Portland. Me. 
Aciv mate mtnlel

TV’s sit coms who is a breath of fresh air amid a bunch of stereo­ types 
He is Adam Ark in, son of actor 
Alan Arkin, who is the comic hero in the new TV series, Busting 
Ixiose. Unlike other male stars, he's not a finger-snapping 
Mr. 
Cool’ like the Eon/, or a macho womanizer like 
Barbarmo in 
‘Welcome Back Hotter.’ 
Young Arkin portrays a sensi­ tive, often vulnerable, human being— a fine model for some he man types I know. Ya listenin’ fellas?— 
Melissa 
Feeze, 
New 
York, WY.

Hell system 

WE had just had the phone con­ nected and our teenage son and his friend devised a communica­ tion system of ringing each other. 
Three rings meant one thing, four another, etc. 
The first time they tried it, it 

 rang three times, then stopped. 
About five minutes later, the phone rang and I answered, ll was my son s friend ringing to see if my son got his message — 
Nada Armstrong, Hartford, Conn. 

Smell of home 

MY husband had been away on a construction job for about six months and when he got home he exclaimed: 
‘ Boy, that smells good!” 
"What does?” I asked. He re­ plied as he hugged me: “ Home!” 
— Jean Interlandi, Chicago, 111.

ANOTHER PULLOUT 
BOOK BONUS 

The Star concludes the story that TV left unfinished 

ABC-TV’s dramatic serialization of Roots, seen by 13o million viewers, told the story of the Afri­ can slave boy Kunta Kinte, his daughter Kiziry. her son Chicken George, and Chicken George's son Tom. THE STAR took up Alex Haley’s book where TV left off, telling of Tom’s daughter Cyn­ thia, her daughter Bertha, and Bertha's son Al­ ex — the author himself. Alex took up writing to kill boredom during his 2o years with the U.S. 
Coast Guard. One day, recalling the tale of Kun­ ta Kinte that had been passed on from genera­ tion to generation, he thought what a good idea it would be to trace his family roots back to Afri- 
By Alex Holey 

On the site of the Waller plantation today: Judge Waller, descendant of Kunta Kinte’s first owner, reads from the family Bible to Benjamin Cole and Annie Thompson, descendants of slaves who worked for the Judge. Also in this exclusive Star photo — the Judge's wife. 
Blocks still work for the Wallers on 

By GEORGE GORDON 
IN Spotsylvania County, Va., where Kunta Kinte was first brought in chains to start life as a slave, the old plantation is still there. 
Blackened timbers and a line of stones mark the original site of the master’s house. 
But just two miles away on the fringe of John Waller’s grounds is the home of his great, great grandson. Judge Absalom Waller. 
Working in his house and in the 
I SO-acres that is left of the estate, are two descendants of the origin­ al slaves. 
Judge Waller. 7H, is proud of his ancestors. He can trace them back to Europe and the battle of 
Agineourt. 
The family settled in Virginia in 
1635. A few generations later we come to John Waller, who ordered 
Kinte to be whipped for his first escape attempt. 
When Kinte made his second escape bid. the whites who caught him chopped up halt his foot, and it was then that Waller’s more humane brother 
Dr. 
William 
Waller bought him and nursed him back to health. 
The Judge savs ol Hoots: “ It was interesting, but I objected to the historical inaccuracies. 

Kunta Kinte’s old plantation 

I LL never quite get over Cousin Georgia s re­ sponse when I told her I was going to trace the family story Wrinkled and ailing, she jerked upright in her bed. her excitement like bovhood front-porch echoes 
“ Yeah. boy. dat African say his name was Kin- tay ! . . . He say de guitar a ‘ko,’ de river Kamby 
Bolongo,' an he was choppin wood to make hisself a drum when dey cotched im ’ ’’ 
Cousin Georgia became so emotionally full of it that I had a time trying to calm her down I ex­ plained to her that I wanted to try to see if there was any way that I could possibly find where our 
“ Kin-tay’ had come from . . which could reveal our ancestral tribe 
“ You go 
'head, boy!” exclaimed 
Cousin 
Georgia. “ Yo’ sweet grandma an' all of ’em— dey up dere watchin’ you'" 
Soon after. 
I was at the National 
Archives in 
Washington, D C . going through microfilm of Alam­ ance County. North Carolina, cen­ sus records just after the Civil 
War. wearily viewing an endless parade of names recorded in that old-fashioned penmanship of dif­ ferent 18oos census takers. 

“ This area is very flat, and the series was filmed in hilly country. 
“ They showed wagons being pulled by one horse when there should have been two. 
“ I can recall conversations with my father, and I know that we never called the negroes slaves. We always called them servants.” 
The judge expressed no regrets over the conduct of his ancestors. 
Ile simply accepts that it was a way of life at the time. “ I am very proud of my family history.” 
Im* said. 
• Benjamin Cole. 73. is a direct descendant of one of the Waller slaves. Today he does part ti*»M* work for the judge in the grounds of the old plantation. 
He cuts the lawns, plants flow­ ers and looks out over the fields where his ancestors once worked under the brutal lash of an over­ seer picking cotton. 
Today, much of the land is rent­ ed out to farm ers for grain crops. 
Benjamin didn't bother to watch Roots. But he and the judge are close friends. Ile joked: 
“ Me and the judge base dis cussed finding a few old graves 

 lorne Green I left) and Robert 
Reed portray Kunta Kinte’s owners John and I>r. William 
Waller in the ABC TV series 

 and charging admission.” 
Ile holds no resentment against the 
Waller family. “ We have come a long way together.” he said. "All those things happened a long time ago.” 
Benjamin remembers stories told to him by his father of condi­ tions on the old plantations. 
“They had leather straps made special to tie people to fences where they would be beat for mis­ behaving. You also got beat if you were caught praying. 
“ You also had to go to bed when the sun went down so that you got a good night's sleep and could get up earlv to work.” 

• Mrs. Julia Thompson is 84. 
She remembers stories from her grandmother, who was auctioned off a block in Charlestown. W. 
Va., before being brought to Spot­ sylvania as a Waller slave. 
Today, her daughter-in-law Meg does housework for the judge. 
Dr. William Waller’s mansion and his original plantation have disappeared. 
The fine old house, where Bell cooked and Kinte wailed outside with a buggy to take the doctor out on house calls, is now barely marked by stones that trace part of the foundation. 
Over the years, the land was sold off in lots to pay debts. Since then some of the lots have changed hands half a dozen times. 
When the slaves were treed, hundreds moved to find work and land outside of 
Virginia. 
But many stayed to continue working on the plantation for a wage 
Their descendants are still in the area, and when Roots was tel­ evised it received a mixed reac­ tion. Many didn't want to be re­ minded of their background. 

Suddenly, in utter astonishment, 
I found myself looking down theres on: “Tom Murray, black, black­ smith—,” “ Irene Murray, black, housewife-—" . . . followed by the names of G randm a's older sisters 
-m ost of whom I d listened to countless times on G randm a's front porch. 

 ll wasn't that I hadn’t believed the* stories of Grandma and the rest (rf them. You just didn t not believe my grandma. It was sim­ ply so uncanny sitting staring at those names right there in official 
U. S. Government records. 

Then living in New York, I re­ turned to Washington as often as 
I could, searching in the National 
Archives, the Library of Con­ gress, and the Daughters of the 
American Revolution Library 

Wherever 
I was. whenever black library attendants per­ ceived the nature of my search, documents I d requested would reach me with a miraculous speed 

Krum one or another source during 1866, I was able to docu­ ment at least the highlights of the cherished family story. I would 

Continued on next page 

\ 

THE STORY OF YOUR FAMILY TI 
How Haley’s trail led b 

From preceding page 

 have given anything to be able to tell Grandma—then I would re­ member what Cousin Georgia had said, that she, all of them, were 
‘ up there w atching’ 
Now the thing was where, what, how could I pursue those strange phonetic sounds that it was al­ ways said our African ancestor had spoken. 
It seemed obvious that I had to reach as wide a range of actual 
Africans as I possibly could, sim­ ply because so many different tribal tongues are spoken in Afri­ ca. 
There in New York City, I be­ gan doing what seemed logical: I began arriving at the United Na­ tions around quitting time. 
It wasn't hard to spot the Africans. 
And every one I was able to stop, 
I d tell my sounds to. 
Within a couple of weeks, I guess I had stopped about two dozen Africans, each of whom had given me a quick look, a quick lis­ ten, and then took off. 
I can't say I blame them—me trying to communicate some Afri­ can sounds in a Tennessee accent. 
Increasingly frustrated, I had a long talk with George Sims, with whom I d grown up in Henning, and who is a m aster researcher. 
After a few days. George brought me rn a list of about a dozen peo­ ple academically renowned for their knowledge of African lin­ guistics. 
One whose background in­ trigued me quickly was a Belgian, 
Dr. Jan Vansina, at the Univer­ sity of Wisconsin. I phoned him and flew out to see him 
That even ag in the Vansinas' living room, I told him every syl­ lable I could remember of the family narrative heard since little boyhood—recently buttressed by 
Cousin Georgia in Kansas City. 
We talked so late that he invited me to spend the night, and the next morning Dr Vansina, with a very serious expression on his face, said, "I wanted to sleep on it The* ramifications of phonetic sounds preserved down across your family’s generations can bt' immense.” 
He said that he had been on the 
(hone with a colleague Africanist, 
’fillip Curtin; they both felt certain that the sounds I'd con­ veyed to him were from the 
"Mandinka" tongue: the language spoken by the Mandingo people. 
The word ko, he said, could re­ fer to the kora, one of the Mandin­ go people's oldest stringed instru ments, made of a halved large dried gourd covered with goat skin, with a long neck, and twen­ ty-one strings with a bridge. 
Hie most involved sound I had heard and brought was Kamby 
Bolongo. my ancestor's sound to his daughter Kizzy as he had pointed to the Mattaponi River in 
Spotsylvania County, Virginia 
Dr Vansina said that, without question, bolongo meant, in the 
Mandinka tongue, a moving wa­ ter, as a river, preceded by 
Kamby.” it could indicate the 
Gambia River. 
I d never heard of the Mandingo tribe' or the Gambia River 
Not long after that, I flew to Af­ rica; Dakar, Senegal, and then

‘‘Our country's oldest villages tend to be mimed for the families that settled those villages centu­ ries ago,” they said 
Sending for a map. pointing, they said, “ Look, here is the vil­ lage of Kinte-Kundah And not too far from it, the village of Kinte- 
Kundah Janneh-Ya 
Then they told me something of which I d never have dreamed of very old men. called griots, still to be found in the older back­ country villages, men who were in effect living, walking archives of oral history 
A senior griot would be a man usually in his late sixties or early seventies; below him would be

D.yO: In the village of Juffure, in Africa,

 on, by light plane, to small Yun- dum Airport in The Gambia. 
I was met in Banjul, the Gambi­ an capital, by a group of men knowledgeable in their small country's history. 
I told these men the family nar­ rative that had come down across the generations. I told them in a reverse progression, backward from 
Grandma through 
Tom, 
Chicken George, then Kizzy, say­ ing how her African lather insist­ ed to other slaves that his name was “ Kin-tay,” and repetitively told her phonetic sounds identify­ ing various things, along with sto­ ries such as that he had been at­ tacked and seized while not far from his village, chopping wood. 
When I had finished, they said almost with wry amusement: 
“ Well, of course Kamby Bolongo’ would mean Gambia River, any­ one would know that.” 
I told them hotly that no, a great many people wouldn't know it! 
Then they showed a much greater interest that my 176os 

*1 w as bawling as I hadn’t since I 

1767: 
Kunia, 
17, is snatched by America’s slave traders. 

 progressively younger griots—and apprenticing boys. 
Senior griots could tell the cen­ turies-old histories of villages, of clans, of families, of great heroes 
I was informed, and there were certain legendary griots who could narrate facets of African history literally for as long as three days without repeating themselves. 
Since my forefather had said his name was “ Kin-tay”—proper­ ly spelled “ Kinte,” they said—and since the Kinte clan was old and well known in The Gambia, they promised to do what they could to find a griot who might be able to assist my search. 
Back in the United States, I be­ gan devouring books on African history. It grew quickly into some kind of obsession to correct my ignorance concerning the earth’s second-largest continent. 
It em barrasses me to this day that up to then my images about 
Africa had been largely derived or inferred from Tarzan movies, and my very little authentic knowledge had come from only occasional leafings through the 
National Geographic. 
After some weeks, a registered letter came from The Gambia; it suggested that when possible, I should come back. But by now I was stone broke—-especially be­ cause I'd been investing very lit­ tle of my time in writing. 
I wrote to a contact at Reader's 
Digest about the compulsive quest 
I d gotten myself into. She invited me to lunch with some editors, and I talked nonstop for nearly three hours. 
Shortly afterward, a letter told me that the 
Reader’s 
Digest would provide me with a three- hundred-dollar monthly check for one year and “ reasonable neces­ sary travel expenses ” 
I again visited Cousin Georgia in Kansas City, and found her quite ill But she was thrilled She wished me Godspeed, and I flew back to Africa 
The men with whom I had pre­ viously talked told me that a griot very knowledgeable of the Kinte clan had indeed been found His name, they said, was “ Kebba 
Kanji Fofana." 
I was ready to have a fit. 
Where is he''” 
They looked at me oddly: “ He's in his village." 
It took me three days of nego­ tiating through unaccustomed endless African palaver finally to lure a launch to get upriver; to rent a lorn, and a Land Rover to take supplies by a roundabout

 land route; to hire finally a total of fourteen people, including three interpreters and four musicians, who had told me that the old griots in the back country wouldn’t talk without music in the background. 
In the launch Baddibu. vibrat­ ing up the wide, swift "Kamby 
Bolongo,” I felt queasily, uncom­ fortably alien. Did they all have me appraised as merely another pith helmet? 
Finally ahead was Jam es Is­ land, for two centuries the site of a fort over which England and 
France waged war bark and forth for the ideal vantage point to trade in slaves. 
Asking if we might land there a while, I trudged amid the crum­ bling ruins yet guarded by ghostly cannon. Picturing in my mind the kinds of atrocities that would have happened there, I felt as if 
I would like to go flailing an ax back through that fact of black 
Africa’s history. 
Without luck I tried to find for myself some symbol remnant of an ancient chain, but I took a chunk of mortar and a brick 
In the next minutes before we returned to the Baddibu, I just gazed up and down that river that my ancestor had named for his daughter far across the Atlantic 
Ocean in Spotsylvania County, 
Virginia. 

Then we went on, and upon ar­ riving at a little village called Ai- breda, we put ashore, our destina­ tion now on foot the yet smaller village of Juffure. where the men had been told that this griot lived, 
There is an expression called 

“the peak experience”—that which emotionally nothing in your life ever transcends. I’ve had mine, that first day in the back country of black West Afri­ ca. 
When we got within sight of Juf­ fure. the children who were play­ ing outside gave the alert, and the people came flocking from their huts It s a village of only about seventy people. 
Like most back-country vil­ lages, it was still very much as it was two hundred years ago, with its circular mud houses and their conical thatched roofs. 
Among the people as they gath­ ered was a small man wearing an off-white robe, a pillbox hat over an aquiline-featured black face, and about him was an aura of 
* somebodiness.” I knew he was the man we had come to see and hear. 
As the three interpreters left our party to converge upon him, the seventy-odd other villagers gathered closely around me, in a kind of horseshoe pattern, three or four deep all around, had I stuck out my arms, my fingers would have touched the nearest ones on either side 
They were all staring at me. 
The eyes just raked me. Their foreheads were furrowed with their very intensity of staring. 
One of my interpreters cam e up quickly and whispered in my ears, “They stare at you so much because they have never here seen a black American.” 
After a while, the old man turned, walked briskly through the people, past my three inter-

Angie Dickinson: Success ruined her love m atch. 

By ADAM EDWARDS 
L IFE at the top is lonely — achingly lonely — for beautiful Angie Dickin­ son. 
Her success as TV's Police Woman has given her all the fame, wealth and independence she’s always longed for. 
But it s cost her the man she loved — her husband of ll years, composer. Burt 
Bacharach. 
And, she told THE STAR in an exclu­ sive interview, she hasn’t found anyone to replace him. 
“ I can’t have an affair with a man un­ less I love him,” said Angie, Holly­ wood’s most dazzling 45-year-old. 
‘‘I haven’t found anyone else to love yet.” 
Angie also disclosed that her success coming as Bacharach^ career declined, was the cause of their shock break-up six months ago. 
She said Bacharach, 47, found it in­ creasingly tough playing number two as she became more famous. 
“I suppose Burt and I knew what we were getting into when I took over Po­ lice Woman,” she said. 
“It meant long hours, late dinners and eight hours sleep-a-night for me to get the engine working properly for the next day. 
“But it was worse than either of us thought.” Now Angie lives a solitary life. 
She goes home after working on Police 
Woman and spends the evenings alone with her 1o-year-old daughter Nikki. 
Her greatest sadness is the slump in 
Bacharach^ career since he was writing such best selling tunes as Raindrops 

•I haven't found anyone else to love yet" 
Burt and Angie in happier days 

Success is poison for Hollywood marriages 

ANGIE Dickinson and Burt Bach­ arach are not the first superstar couple to have their romance de­ stroyed by success. 
The Hollywood landscape is lit­ tered with examples of famous people who have discovered two stars in the family is one too many. 
Some of the victims include: 
• Frank Sinatra, who admitted at the time of his 1967 split with his young actress wife, Mia Far­ row! "Mia and I have problems over the different directions our careers are going to take." 
• Comedian Peter Sellers, who said after ending his marriage to actress Britt Ekland “ I tried to tell her that instant success was impossible but she did not, or could not understand, britt tried to make a sudden rush to stardom through me " 
• Man* Hartman star Louise 
Passer. Married for three years to comic Woody Allen, she explained after their break-up: “At first we honestly thought there was noth­ ing we couldn’t do. that, we were 
(Hie of America s couples But we couldn’t take the pressure " 
• Richard Burton and Eliza­ beth Taylor, the classic couple whose marriage could not with­ stand the pressure of fame and success "It was like living on the edge of a volcano," said Burton. 
"An exciting volcano But with us, it was either all or nothing." 
• Burt 
Reynolds, who said 
' fame broke up his four-year rela 

 tionship with entertainer Dinah 
Shore: "She was apple pie and 
American flag and I wasn’t good for that image. For four years we were the butt of a lot of jokes, a lot of one-liners, a lot of April-De- cember, whatever the hell that means.’’ 

• Barbra Streisand and ex-hus- band Elliott Gould. "Barbra was 

 the biggest thing in the business," 
Gould said. "I lacked confidence and subordinated myself to her. 
My self-respect got all used up." 

• Sonny 
Bono and former spouse Cher. He said: "When we got successful. Cher decided she wanted to drop me and go off and do her own thing. Somehow she got it into her head she was carry­ ing 7o percent of the load. And when a person in a partnership makes an evaluation like that, it's finished.” 

Keep Falling On My Head. "I am having the success and he hasn t had a hit for two years,” said Angie, discussing how they drifted apart. 
Angie and Bacharach had separated before their current split. But they al­ ways got back together. 
They once had a perfect marriage. 
Angie said. "And the only way to work out our problems, we thought, was to miss each other a little bit. 
"But we didn t sepal ate because we are both sex symbols. That wasn’t diffi­ cult to live with It didn't cause jealousy. 
“ It was gratifying to come home at night to a man a Tot of other women would like to be with. 
"Most women would like to go home and find Robert Redford waiting for them. I had my own Redford and Burt had me. 
“It was fun. After all, I don’t think two sex symbols have lived together as a married couple for quite a while, 
Frank Sinatra and Ava Gardner were the last. Or John Kennedy and Jackie." 
Before her Police Woman success. An­ gie was quoted as saying: 
"I am a woman. 
Bacharach is my man. 
I'd hate it if I were to become a bigger star than him." 
At the time, her career was in mothballs after a string of so-so films 
"I wanted to devote my time to my daughter," she told THE 
STAR "I refused to take any long movies, go on location or consider a TV series. During those years 

 my career shout.” was a whisper, not a 

Bacharach, meanwhile, was riding a wave of hit songs, gold records and highly-rated TV spe­ cials. Then it all ended for him 
He decided to stop his 'IV ap­ pearances and concert tours and get down to writing more songs 
He also encouraged his wife to pick up the pieces of her career. 
"Nikki was seven when 
I agreed to do Police Woman,” An­ gie said. "The break was good for her. It was time for me to cut her umbilical cord And Burt encour­ aged me not to miss such a golden opportunity.” 
But the "golden opportunity” ended a match that began in the early 6os, when Angie met Bach­ arach after dating some of Ameri­ ca’s most attractive men, includ­ ing John F. Kennedy and Frank 
Sinatra. 
Bacharach, currently touring the country1 promoting his new songs, refuses to discuss his split with Angie. 
He still telephones her regular­ ly, although Angie says she no longer sits by the phone waiting. 
The couple are frequently seen at the same Hollywood parties, but seldom together. 
Angie has no special date. 
When she needs an escort she usually chooses someone from the 
Police Woman cast . 
Bank chief doubles as a priest WF 

MAN MAULED IN SHARK ATTACK 
VOWSTO GET REVENGE 
SURFER Alan Brenneka, 19, who lost an arm to a shark last year, is going back into the sea 
— for revenge. 
"One of them got me, now I want to get one of them,” says Alan, who is planning to kill a shark. 
Alan lost his arm while paddling his surf­ board off Boynton Beach. Fla. The shark mauled him so badly, he lost all but two pints of his blood. 
Doctors fought for a week to save his right arm. eventually having to* amputate above the elbow. 
Alan spent another three weeks in the hospi­ tal and is now waiting for his doctor's permis­ sion to enter the water for his shark hunt. 
Alan's parents agree with his shark hunt project, and his father Charles, an experi­ enced diver, will dive with his son 

 a i u n o t, 
^ mot*ier Beverley said: "We know he 
Aum Brenneka: 
^ \\ never feel completely right again until he 
Revenge dive. has his chance at a shark.” 

LIFE is more than dollars and cents to banker Arthur H. Tildesley. For he spends his lunch hour and every spare minute away from his desk being Rev. 
Tildesley. 
"I have the best of both worlds,” he told THE STAR this week. “An extreme­ ly stimulating job in business, and also a rewarding occupation in the ministry 
Mr Tildesley, a 45-year-old fa­ ther of four, and a banker for more than 2o years, was recently ordained an Episcopal priest at 
St. Mary’s By-the-Sea Episc 
Church, in Point Pleasant, N 
"It was the realization of a dream I have had for years," he said 
Mr. Tildesley, a vice president of the Ocean County National 
Bank in Point Pleasant, said that being a priest enabled him to help customers and to do some work for good in the community. 

 my role as a them in other 

Arthur Tildesley 
I can help 
Pf tin nest ngs.’ 

"I deal with people throughout the day who have all manner of fi­ nancial problems," he said. "In 

Mr Tildesley doesn’t wear his clerical collar to the office, but he is able to get away from his desk at lunch time to do ministerial work at a nearby hospital 
The banker-minister started his studies for the priesthood over six years ago 
"It is a life I always wanted," he said. "But I had been im­ mersed in banking, arui in raising and bringing up a family 
"Then a program was intro­ duced in the church to let people like myself become priests I en­ tered it immediately. It was one of the happiest days of my life when I was ordained ”
