ON THE STREET WHERE CHICO LIVED, THEY 

THE SU IC ID E of 22-year-old TV star Freddie Prinze stunned the folks on New York City's 
West 157th Street, where he grew up. Last week THE STAR asked two writers who knew the area to go back there and talk to people who remem­ bered Freddie before he was 
TV’s much-loved Chico. Here is the report — from JOSE 
TO RRES, former world light heavyweight champ and later 
New York Post columnist on 
Hispanic affairs; and 
STAN 
M IE SES, former Star staffer and jazz and rock critic. 
FELICIANO DIAZ, the build­ ing superintendent 
Freddie 
Prinze made famous for say­ ing “ Ees not my job, man,” never laughed at Freddies jokes on television 
It was not that Diaz minded that the jokes were about Puerto 
Ricans or that the most memora­ ble of them poked gentle fun at him personally. 
It was just that Diaz, like oth­ ers in the New York neighborhood where Freddie grew up. watched turn in a different way than the rest of his fans did 
They watched with reverence. 
For them, Freddie Prinze was not merely a comedian 
He was a god 
These were the people who knew Freddie from the beginning when he was a fat. pesky little boy They watched him go from nowhere to somewhere. 
They appreciated the enormity of the leap he made and they loved him for it because it gave them hope They shared in his triumph by putting up pictures of him — like shrines — in their liv­ ing rooms, their bars, their clubs. 
“ We made* a collection among all the tenants to send flowers for his funeral." Feliciano Diaz told 
THE STAR. “ Everyone donated money. He was loved by all in this building ” 
Diaz does not remember Prinze as a complaining tenant to whom it was ever necessary to say “ Ees not my job. man." He remembers him as a friend 
“ Freddie helped me a lot," 
Diaz said “ I had lots of trouble understanding tile American ten­ ants and Freddie was the transla­ tor. And he also taught me to speak English." 
There are other memories. 
“ When Freddie was about 13 or 
14. he became interested in mu­ sic. He asked me to teach him to play the clarinet On the first les­ son he learned as much as I did in a whole year He really had natural talent for music: piano, maracas, the clarinet and drums." 
Al one point, Freddie formed a combo He rehearsed all day long. 
Diaz's voice brok** as he re­ membered something else. “ As he grew and his clothes became too small for him, lie would give them to my kids. Because he liked my children 
“ The day he went to Hollywood he left all of his belongings to my children.” Diaz has six children. 
Proudly, Diaz escorts visitors to the apartment where Freddie grew up It is Apt 64 on the sixth floor — seven and a half rooms with a 7o-fool hall A Dominican family lives there now 
In the room that was Freddie’s, 
Diaz says, “ Freddie liad a psy­ chedelic room 
The roof was painted red and Ute walls were 
Black and white” 
Ile shakes his fiend There is 

STILL SHAKE THEIR! 
HEADS HI DISBEllEI 

Feliciano Diaz: “Ees not my job.” 

Sergio Pena: Local storekeeper. 
Building on West 157th Street, New York, where Freddie Prinze grew up. 
4 He came v/ith his wife but she was not nice. She was too experienced * 

 castorial joint of marijuana But no hard stuff — in those days, never any hard stuff. 
Some people take drugs for a feeling of fitting in. The feeling led Fr 

 one more thing to recall — Fred­ die’s triumphant returns from 
Hollywood. He always came to see his old friend Feliciano Diaz. 
“ He came with his beautiful wife.” Diaz said “ But she was iv it nice like him She was too ex­ perienced for him." 
Diaz puts all his feelings about 
Freddie into one final, eloquent sentence; “He was still a boy." 

DOWN the street, in his bar at 
Broadway and 157th, Jaunt* Vic­ tor Peralta stands next to a pic­ ture of Freddie and also talks about Biose great homecomings, especially the first one. 
“ He sat right where you are sit­ ting now and his wife sat two chairs away," Peralta says. 
‘ What a nice kid. He had not changed. And he came back to see his old. childhood friends His old neighborhood 
“ ! just can't believe it I read it in th* newspapers. I hear it on ev­ ery radio stamen. I see it in every 
TV channel. But I cannot accept it. 
Freddie 
Prinze cannot be dead” Peralta's bar was a fang 

 out for teenage Freddie Prinze. 
It wasn’t because of the booze 
Freddie just liked the place 

“ lie came in almost every night and he didn t touch a drop of alcohol," Peralta said. 

“He drank two or three Coca- 
Colas and then he would go to the public phone in the back and talk to a girl for hours. He was always sober, straight” 
Peralta emphasizes what every­ one else says. It wasn't there in the neighborhood, among his old friends, that Freddie started the drugs and drinking that surround cd his death. Those happened lat­ er 
He did smoke a lot for a kid his age 
“ Freddie used to come here al­ most every night with two black schoolmates to get his usual two packs of Marlboros” said Sergio 
Pena at the El Tope Market. 
“ I used to tell him smoking would stunt his growth. He just got taller and taller." 

And, friends say. he tried an oc­ 

 cluded Freddie Prinze, even as a neighborhood kid. 

"He was just a little chubby kid a lot of the guys used to beat up on." said Freddie Solar, 22. who grew up in the same building as 
Prinze and was his same age. 

"He wasn't into sports too much, and the guy couldn't throw a football. He never got into fights, because he really didn’t know how to fight. 

“ I know he didn't hang out with the Spanish guys. I don’t even re­ member him speaking Spanish. It was pretty funny to us. seeing him as the big Puerto Rican on 
TV” 

Pnnze’s father was Hungarian- 
Jewish His mother was Puerto 
Rican. In a neighborhood where 
Puerto Ricans predominated, he stuck out. 
Manuel Taveras, who also lived 

Bartender Jaime Peralta: 
“He cannot be dead.” 

 in Freddie’s building, told THE 
STAR. “ I used to see this fat kid with swollen cheeks jumping up and down in the elevator trying to touch its roof, and I used to insult him in Spanish, thinking he was an American. 
“ I did it three or four times. 
Then one day, I was coming up with groceries and the fat kid asked me in clear Spanish. ‘Which floor are you going to so I can press the button for you?’ And I was so embarrassed " 
Since “he really didn t know how to fight,” Freddie Prinze learned to defend himself the only way that came naturally — with words. And especially with funny, biting words. 
Freddie Prinze learned to like the laughs he got with his words, and before long getting laughs be­ came his passion. He practiced putting together words so they got laughs as intensely as he had once practiced his music. 
By the age of 16, he was getting laughs as a performer in such competitive New York showcases for young talent as The Improvis­ ation and Catch A Rising Star. 
While his neighborhood friends attended George Washington High 
School, he crossed the city each day to attend the High School of 
Performing Arts, where he stud­ ied the business of getting laughs. 
And after high school, he didn’t go back to the neighborhood and try to fit in. Instead he went to 
Hollywood, where he made a for­ tune telling vast audiences what a funny place the neighborhood had been 

“His background was a con­ stant source of inspiration for him,'' said one of his teachers at the High School For Performing 
Arts 
“ But it also gave him a sense of desperation, a sense that if he failed, he was doomed to be an­ other character in the gallery he created — only not a funny one.” 
NBC is searching for a Freddie Prinze replacement 

CHICO And The Man will go on without its tragic young star. 
Freddie Prinze, who committed suicide in January. 
Producer Jimmy Komack is re portedly convinced that tile show can continue to be successful if the right replacement for Prinze is found Komack is believed to be 

 searching for an actor of Puerto 
Rican or Mexican ancestry, pre­ ferably an-f known. 
The last four completed shows involving 
Prinze are being screened now. 
The final show with Prinze was televised Feb. 25. 
NBC would also like four addi­ 

 tional shows to go on before the reruns begin in April. Nobody knows at this point whether 
Prinze’s replacement will be found in time for the new seg­ ments. but the prospects aren t bright. 
Undoubtedly, the Chico And 
Tile Man reruns will garner tre­ 

 mendous interest as viewers expected to flock to their set glimpse a bubbling, happy, k making 
Freddie 
Prinze c again. 
All of the reruns will be sen lously edited to make certain reminders of Prinze’s death deleted.

 most incredible family group photo: Alex Haley discovers Juffure, the village where his great- 
Kunta Kinte was born (and taken from by slave traders) ana is greeted by his kinfolk after a 2oo-year “separation.’’ up to me. His mine, seeming understand his what they felt con- millions of 
J ilaces that est mat ions translation came: 
I been told by the fore- there are many of us dace Who are iii exile e called America—and aces." man sat down, facing people hurriedly gath­ er him. Then he began 
»r me the ancestral his-

; for th# still, silent vil- 

Ptctures of early ancestors, as portrayed in

Portraits of Cynthia and Bertha courtesy of Alex Haley. 

 lagers, it was clearly a formal occasion. 
The griot would speak, bending forward from the waist, his body rigid, his neck cords standing out, his words seeming almost physi­ cal objects. 
After a sentence or two, seem­ ing to go limp, he would lean back, listening to an interpreter’s translation. 
Spilling from the griot s head came an incredibly complex 
Kinte clan lineage tnat reached back across many generations: who m arried whom; who had what children; what children then married whom; then their off­ spring. 

It was all just unbelievable. I was struck not only by the profu­ sion of details, but also by the narrative’s biblical style, some­ thing like: “—and so-and so took as a wife so-and-so, and begat . . and begat . . . and begat . . 
He would next name each be­ g ats eventual spouse, or spouses, and their averagely numerous offspring, and so on. To date things, the griot linked them to events, such as “ —in the year of the big water”—a flood—“ he slew a water buffalo.” To determine the calendar date, you’d have to find out when that particular flood occurred. 
Simplifying the encyclopedic sa­ ga, the griot said that the Kinte clan had begun in the country called Old Mali. Then the Kinte men traditionally were black­ smiths, 
“ who had conquered fire,” and the women mostly were 

The youngest son, 
Omoro, stayed in Juffure village until he had thirty rains—years—of age, then took as his wife a Mandinka maiden named Binta Kebba. By 
Binta Kebba, roughly between the years 175o and 176o, Omoro Kinte begat four sons—Kunta, Lamin, 
Suwadu, and Madi. 

The old griot had talked for nearly two hours up to then, and perhaps fifty times had included some detail about someone whom he had named. Now, after he had just named those four sons, again he appended a detail, and the in­ terpreter translated— 
“About the tim e the King’s sol­ diers came, the eldest of these four sons, Kunta, went away from his village to chop wood . . . and he was never seen again. . . . ” 
I sat as if I were carved of stone. My blood seemed to have congealed. This man whose life­ time had been in this back-coun­ try African village had no way in the world to know that he had just echoed what 
I had heard all through my boyhood years on my grandm as front porch in Hen­ ning, Tennessee . . . of an African who always had insisted that his name was “ Kin-tay” ; who had called a guitar a “ ko,” and a riv­ er within the state of Virginia, 
“ Kamby Bolongo” ; and who had been kidnaped into slavery while not far from his village, chopping wood, to make himself a drum. 
I managed to fumble from my dufflebag my basic notebook, whose first pages contained grandm as story. 
After briefly reading, the interpreter clearly astounded, spoke rapidly while showing it to the old griot, who became agitated. 
He got up, exclaiming to the people, gesturing at my notebook in the interpreter’s hands, and they all got agitated. 
I don’t remember hearing any­ one giving an order, I only recall becoming aware that those seven­ ty-odd people had formed a wide human ring around me, moving counterclockwise, chanting softly, loudly, softly; their bodies close together, they were lifting their knees high, stamping up reddish puffs of the dust. . . . 

The woman who broke from the moving circle was one of about a dozen whose infant children were within cloth slings across their backs. 

Her jet-black face deeply con­ torting, the woman came charg­ ing toward me, her bare feet slap­ ping the earth, and snatching her 
Baby free, she thrust it at me almost roughly, the gesture say­ ing “Take it!” . . . and I did, clasping the bilby to me. 
Then she snatched away her ba- 

Continued on next page 

SSO each 

T H E 
S T A R this week launches a nationwide search for the great sto­ ries hidden in the history of almost every American family. 

Hie story of one such family, 
Roots, has made its author Alex 
Haley a millionaire overnight and has fired everybody’s imagination. 

Now we want to hear about the thousands of other great family stories that must abound. We want to hear of the colorful, exciting, perhaps fright­ ening — even unbelievable — tales that you have been told about your ancestors. 

Perhaps they go back to the old country — wherever in the world that might be. Perhaps there are others there descended from Kunta Kinte — great grandchildren oi Torn Murray, the blacksmith in Hoots. Or others who have heard stories passed down through the years <n their slave ori­ gins. 

There must be many too. whose ancestors were here long before the 
Mack OR white men came — descen­ dants ut the proud 
Indian races, maybe even kin of great chiefs like 
Sitting Bull. 

• For the best story received, 
THE STAR will pay $5oo. 

• Ten other prizes of $5o each will also be awarded. 

• And every letter published will earn its writer $1o. 

You do not have to br a writer to participate in this great quest. Just get the person in your family best able to express himself lur herself) to write down the story as you know it. 

Remember, we are looking for ex­ citing, colorful, dramatic, touching, romantic, even terrifying stories. We do not mind if they seem unbelievable, so long as you recount the story as told to you. DO NOT embelish the sto­ ry yourself with fanciful conjecture.

THE STORY OF YOUR FAMILY TREE COULD WIN YOU $5oo 

From preceding page 

 have given anything to be able to tell Grandma—then I would re­ member what Cousin Georgia had said, that she, all of them, were 
•'up there watchin’.” 
Now the thing was where, what, how could I pursue those strange phonetic sounds that it was al­ ways said our African ancestor had spoken. 
It seemed obvious that I had to reach as wide a range of actual 
Africans as I possibly could, sim­ ply because so many different tribal tongues are spoken in Afri­ ca. 
There in New York City, I be­ gan doing what seemed logical: I began arriving at the United Na­ tions around quitting time. 
It wasn’t hard to spot the Africans. 
And every one I was able to stop, 
I d tell my sounds to. 
Within a couple of weeks, I guess I had stopped about two dozen Africans, each of whom had given me a quick look, a quick lis­ ten, and then took off. 
I can’t say I blame them—me trying to communicate some Afri­ can sounds in a Tennessee accent. 
Increasingly frustrated, I had a long talk with George Sims, with whom I d grown up in Henning, and who is a m aster researcher. 
After a few days, George brought me in a list of about a dozen peo­ ple academically renowned for their knowledge of African lin­ guistics. 
One whose background in­ trigued me quickly was a Belgian, 
Dr. Jan Vansina, at the Univer­ sity of Wisconsin 
I phoned him and flew out to see him. 
That even ag in the Vansinas’ living room, I told him every syl­ lable I could remember of the family narrative heard since little boyhood—recently buttressed by 
Cousin Georgia in Kansas City. 
We talked so late that he invited me to spend the night, and the next morning Dr. Vansina, with a very serious expression on his face, said, “ I wanted to sleep on it The ramifications of phonetic sounds preserved down across your family’s generations can be immense ” 
He said that he had been on the phone with a colleague Africanist. 
Dr Philip Curtin, they both felt certain that the sounds I’d con- 

How Haley’s trail led back to Africa 

•'V t- 

'* W t 

 veyed to him were from the 
“ Mandinka" tongue: the language spoken by the Mandingo people. 
The* word ko, he said, could re­ fer to the kora, one of the Mandin­ go people’s oldest stringed instru ments, made of a halved large drit*d gourd covered with goat­ skin, with a long neck, and twen­ ty-one* strings with a bridge*. 
Hie most involved sound I had heard and brought was Ka rn by 
Holongo, my ancestor’s sound to his daughter Kizzy as he had pointed to the Mattaponi River in 
Spotsylvania County, Virginia 
Dr Vansina said that, without question, bolongo meant, in the* 
Mandinka tongue, a moving wa- ter, as a river; pre*ce*ded by 
“ Kamby,” it could indicate the 
Gambia River. 
I d never heard of the Mandingo tribe* or the* Gambia River. 
Not long after that, I flew to Af­ rica: Dakar, Senegal, and then

Binta Kinte gives birth to a boy she names Kunia. 

 on, by light plane, to small Yun- dum Airport in The Gambia. 
I was met in Banjul, the Gambi­ an capital, by a group of men knowledgeable in their small country’s history. 
I told these men the family nar­ rative that had come down across the generations I told them in a reverse progression, backward from 
Grandma through 
Tom, 
Chicken George, then Kizzy, say­ ing how her African father -insist­ ed to other slaves that his name was “ Kin-tay,” and repetitively told her phonetic sounds identify­ ing various things, along with sto­ ries such as that he had been at­ tacked and seized while not far from his village, chopping wood. 
When I had finished, they said almost with wry amusement: 
‘Well, of course Kamby Bolongo’ would mean Gambia River; any­ one would know that.” 
I told them hotly that no, a great many people wouldn’t know it! 
Then they showed a much greater interest that my 176os 
*1 was bawling as I hadn’t since I was a baby* 

 ancestor had insisted his name was •Kin-tay.” 
“Our country's oldest villages tend to be named for the families that settled those villages centu­ ries ago.” they said 
Sending for a map. pointing, they said, “ Look. here is the vil­ lage of Kinte-Kundah And not too far from it, the village of Kinte- 
Kundah Janneh-Ya.” 
Then they told me something of which I d never have dreamed of very old men, called griots, still to bo found in the older back­ country villages, men who were in effect living, walking archives of oral history 
A senior griot would be a man usually in his late sixties or early seventies; below him would be 

 snatched by America’s slave traders. progressively younger griots—and apprenticing boys. 
Senior griots could tell the cen­ turies-old histories of villages, of clans, of families, of great heroes 
I was informed, and there were certain legendary griots who could narrate facets of African history literally for as long as three days without repeating themselves. 
Since my forefather had said his name was “ Kin-tay”—proper­ ly spelled “ Kinte,” they said—and since the Kinte clan was old and well known in The Gambia, they promised to do what they could to find a griot who might be able to assist my search. 
Back in the United States, I be­ gan devouring books on African history. It grew quickly into some kind of obsession to correct my ignorance concerning the earth’s second-largest continent. 
It em barrasses me to this day that up to then my images about 
Africa had been largely derived or inferred from Tarzan movies, and my very little authentic knowledge had come from only occasional leafings through the 
National Geographic. 
After some weeks, a registered letter came from The Gambia; it suggested that when possible. I should come back. But by now I was stone broke—especially be­ cause I d been investing very lit­ tle of my time in writing. 
I wrote to a contact at Reader's 
Digest about the compulsive quest 
I’d gotten myself into. She invited me to lunch with some editors, and I talked nonstop for nearly three hours. 
Siortly afterward, a letter told me that the 
Reader's 
Digest would provide me with a three- hundred-dollar monthly check for one year and “ reasonable neces­ sary travel expenses ” 
I again visited Cousin Georgia in Kansas City, and found her quite ill. But she was thrilled. She wished me Godspeed, and I flew back to Africa. 
Hie men with whom I had pre­ viously talked told me that a griot very knowledgeable of the Kinte clan had indeed been found His name, they said, was “ Kebba 
Kanji Fofana.” 
I was ready to have a fit. 
"Where is he? 
They looked at me oddly: “ He’s in his village." 
It took me three days of nego­ tiating through unaccustomed endless African palaver finally to hire a launch to get upriver; to rent a lorry and a Dana Rover to take supplies by a roundabout

K 

 land route; to hire finally a total of fourteen people, including three interpreters and four musicians, who had told me that the old griots in the back country wouldn’t talk without music in the background. 
In the launch Baddibu, vibrat­ ing up the wide, swift “ Kamby 
Bolongo,” I felt queasily, uncom­ fortably alien Did they all have me appraised as merely another pith helmet? 
Finally ahead was Jam es Is­ land, for two centuries the site of a fort over which England and 
France waged war back and forth for the ideal vantage point to trade in slaves. 
Asking if we might land there a while, I trudged amid the crum­ bling ruins yet guarded by ghostly cannon. Picturing in my mind the kinds of atrocities that would have happened there, I felt as if 
I would like to go flailing an ax back through that fact of black 
Africa’s history. 
Without luck I tried to find for myself some symbol remnant of an ancient chain, but I took a chunk of m ortar and a brick. 
In the next minutes before we returned to the Baddibu. I just gazed up and down that river that my ancestor had named for his daughter far across the Atlantic 
Ocean in Spotsylvania County, 
Virginia. 
Then we went on. and upon ar­ riving at a little village called Ai- breda, we put ashore, our destina­ tion now on foot the yet smaller village of Juffure, where the men had been told that this griot lived. 
There is an expression called 

“the peak experience”—that which emotionally nothing in your life ever transcends. I’ve had mine, that first day in the 
We: back country of black West Afri­ ca. 
When we got within sight of Juf­ fure, the children who were play­ ing outside gave the alert, and the people came flocking from their huts. It’s a village of only about seventy people. 
Like most back-country vil­ lages, it was still very much as it was two hundred years ago, with its circular mud houses and their conical thatched roofs. 
Among the people as they gath­ ered was a small man wearing an off-white robe, a pillbox hat over an aquiline-featured black face, and about him was an aura of 
“ somebodiness.” I knew he was the man we had come to see and hear. 
As the three interpreters left our party to converge upon him, the seventy-odd other villagers gathered closely around me, in a kind of horseshoe pattern, three or four deep all around; had I stuck out my arm s, my fingers would have touched the nearest ones on either side. 
They were all staring at me. 
The eyes just raked me. Their foreheads were furrowed with their very intensity of staring. 
One (rf my interpreters cam e up quickly and whispered in my ears, “They stare at you so much because they have never here seen a black American.” 
After a while, the old man turned, walked briskly through the people, past my three inter-

1967: The world's most incredible family group photo: Alex Haley discovers Juffure, the village where his great- great great-great-grandfather Kunta Kinte was born land taken from by slave traders! and is greeted by his kinfolk after a 2oo-year “ separation.” s, and right up to me. His piercing into mine, seeming to feel I should understand his 
Mandinka. he expressed what they had all decided they felt con­ cerning those unseen millions of us who lived in those places that had been slave ships’ destinations 
— and the translation came: 
“We have been told by the fore­ fathers that there are many of us from this place who are in exile in that place called America—and in other places.” 
The old man sat down, facing

Portraits of Cynthia and Bertha courtesy of Alex H aley. 

 me, as the people hurriedly gath- ia him. Then he began to recite for me the ancestral nis- ered behinc 

 tory of the Kinte clan, as it had been passed along orally down across centuries from the fore­ fathers’ time. 
It was not merely’ conversation­ al, but more as if a scroll were being read; for the still, silent vil­ 

 lagers, it was clearly a formal occasion. 
The griot would speak, bending forward from the waist, his body rigid, his neck cords standing out, his words seeming almost physi­ cal objects. 
After a sentence or two, seem­ ing to go limp, he would lean back, listening to an interpreter’s translation. 
Spilling from the griot*s head came an incredibly complex 
Kinte clan lineage that reached back across many generations, who m arried whom; who had what children; what children then married whom; then their off­ spring. 

 itters and weavers. In time, one ranch of the clan moved into the country called Mauretania; and it was from M auretania that one son of this clan, whose name was 
Kairaba Kunta Kinte — a m ara­ bout, or holy man of the Moslem faith — journeyed down into the country called The Gambia. 

In Juffure, Kairaba Kunta Kinte took his first wife, a Mandinka maiden named Sireng, and by her begot two sons, Janneh and Sal- oum. 
Then he took a second wife, 
Yaisa, and begot a son named 
Omoro. 
The youngest son, 
Omoro, stayed in Juffure village until he had thirty rains—years—of age, then took as his wife a Mandinka 

It was all just unbelievable. I was struck not only by the profu­ sion of details, but also by the narrative’s biblical style, some­ thing like: “—and so-and-so took as a wife so-and-so, and begat . . . and begat . . . and begat . . .” 
He would next name each be­ g ats eventual spouse, or spouses, and their averagely numerous offspring, and so on 
To date things, the griot bnked them to events, such as “—in the year of the big w ater”—a flood—“ he slew a water buffalo." To determine the calendar date, you’d have to find out when that particular flood occurred. 
Amplifying the encyclopedic sa­ ga, the griot said that the Kinte clan had begun in the country called Old Mali. Then the Kinte men traditionally were black smiths, 
“ who had conquered fire," and the women mostly were 

 maiden named Binta Kebba. By 
Binta Kebba, roughly between the 
S ears 175o and 176o, Omoro Kinte egat four sons—Kunta, Lamin, 
Suwadu, and Madi. 

The old griot had talked for nearly two hours up to then, and perhaps fifty tim es had included some detail about someone whom he had named. Now, after he had just named those four sons, again he appended a detail, and the in­ terpreter translated— 
“About the tim e the King’s sol­ diers came, the eldest of these four sons, Kunta, went away from his village to chop wood . . . and he was never seen again. . . .” 
I sat as if I were carved of stone. My blood seemed to have congealed. This man whose life­ time had been in this back-coun­ try’ African village had no way in the world to know that he had just echoed what I had heard all through my boyhood years on my grandma's front porch in Hen­ ning, Tennessee . . . of an African who always had insisted that his name was “ Kin-tay"; who had called a guitar a “ ko," and a riv­ er within the state of Virginia, 
"Kamby Bolongo"; and who had been kidnaped into slavery while not far from his village, chopping wood, to make himself a drum. 
I managed to fumble from my dufflebag my basic notebook, whose first pages contained grandma's story. 
After briefly reading, the interpreter clearly astounded, spoke rapidly while showing it to the old griot, who became agitated. 
He got up, exclaiming to the people, gesturing at my notebook in the interpreter’s hands, and they all got agitated. 
I don’t rem ember hearing any­ one giving an order, I only recall becoming aware that those seven­ ty-odd people tiad formed a wide human ring around me, moving counterclockwise, chanting softly, loudly, softly; their bodies close together, they were lifting their knees high, stamping up reddish puffs of the dust. . . . 

The woman who broke from the moving circle was one of about a dozen whose infant children were within cloth slings across their backs 

Her jet-black face deeply con­ torting, the woman came charg­ ing toward me, her bare feet slap­ ping the earth, and snatching her baby free, she thrust it at me almost roughly, the gesture say­ ing “Take it!" . . . and I did, clasping the baby to me. 
Then she snatched away her ba-

$5o each 

THE 
STAR this week launches a nationwide search for the great sto­ ries hidden in the history of almost every American family. 

Hie story of one such family. 
Roots, has made its author Alex 
Haley a millionaire overnight and has fired everybody's imagination. 

Now we want to hear about the thousands of other great family stories that must abound. We want to hear of the colorful, exciting, perhaps fright­ ening — even unbelievable — tales that you have been told about your ancestors. 

Perhaps they go back to the old country — wherever in the world that might be. Perhaps there are others there descended I rum Kunta Kinte — great grandchildren ut Tom Murray, the blacksmith in Hoots. Or others who have heard stories passed down through the years or their slave ori­ gins. 

There must be many too. whose ancestors were here long before the black OR white men came — descen­ dants of the proud Indian races, maybe even kin of great chiefs like 
Sitting Bull. 

• For the best story received, 
THE STAR will pay $5oo. 

• Ten other prizes of $5o each will also be awarded. 
• And every letter published will earn its writer $1o. 

You do not have to he a writer to participate in this great quest. Just get the person in your family best able to express himself tor Herself I to write down the story as you know It. 

Remember, we are looking for ex­ citing, colorful, dramatic, touching, romantic, even terrifying stories. We do not mind if they seem unbelievable, so long as you recount the story as told to you. DO NOT embellsh the sto­ ry yourself with fanciful conjecture. 

Letters will become the property of 
The Star and will not be returned un­ less the writer encloses a stamped, self-addressed envelope. Closing date for letters: Monday, March ti. 

TIIK STAR will look into the best stories, and interview the w riters of them, lf ci.cam stances perm it, we will help the writer of the best letter lo dirt lurcher into his family’s roots. Letters should be addressed to; Family Tree, 
The Star, San Antonio Express, IME

 by; and another woman was thrusting her baby, then another, and another . . . until I had em ­ braced probably a dozen babies. 
I wouldn’t learn until m aybe a year later, from a H arvard Uni­ versity professor, 
Dr 
Jerom e 
Bruner, a scholar of such m at­ ters: “ You didn’t know you were participating in one of the oldest cerem onies of humankind, called 
‘The laying on of hands’! 
“ In their way, they were telling you ‘Through this flesh, which is us, we are you, ann you are us!’ ’’ 
Irater, the men of Juffure took me into their mosque built of bamboo and thatch, and they prayed around me in Arabic I re­ m em ber thinking, down on my knees, 
“ After 
Iv e found out where I cam e from . I can’t under­ stand a word they're saying." 
As we drove back to Banjul, in my mind’s eye, rather as if it were mistily being projected on a screen, I began envisioning de­ scriptions I had read of how col­ lectively, millions of our ancestors had been enslaved. 
Many thousands were individu­ ally kidnaped, as my own fore­ bear Kunta had been, but into the millions had com e awake scream ­ ing in the night, dashing out into the bedlam of raided villages, which were often in flames. 
The captured, able survivors were linked neck by-neck with thongs into processions called 
“ coffles," which were som etim es as much as a m ile in length I en visioned the m any dying, or left to die when tliey were too weak to

 continue the torturous m arch to­ ward the coast. And those who made it to the beach were greased, shaved, probed in every orifice, often branded. 
I envisioned them being lashed and dragged toward the long­ boats; their spasm s of scream ing and clawing with their hands into the beach; their desperate efforts for one last hold on the Africa that was home. 
My mind reeled with it all as we approached another, much larger village. Staring ahead. I realized that word of what had happened in Juffure m ust have left there well before I did. 
Tile driver slowing down, 
I could see this village’s people thronging the road ahead; they were waving, am id their caco­ phony of crying out som ething 
I guess we had moved a third of the way through the village when it suddenly registered in my brain what they w ere all crying out 
. the wizened, robed elders and younger men. the m others and the naked tar-black children, they were all waving up at m e; their expressions buoyant, beam ing, all were crying out together, 
“ Meester Kinte! M eester Kinte!" liet m e tell you som ething: I am a man. A sob hit me som e­ where around my ankles, it cam e surging upward, and flinging my 

 hands over my face, I was just bawling, as I hadn’t since I was a baby. 
“ M eester K inte!” I just felt like 
I was weeping for all of history’s incredible atrocities against fel­ lowmen, which seem s to be m an­ kind’s greatest flaw. . . . 
Flying hom ew ard from Dakar, 
I decided to write my book. 
In New York, m y waiting tele­ phone m essages included that in a 
Kansas City Hospital, our eighty- three-year-old Cousin Georgia had died Later, making a time-zone adjustm ent. 
I discovered that she passed aw ay within the very hour

GIRL LOSES 2oo ROUNDS TO 
JOIN THE ARMY 

BOBBI WEISS lost nearly 2oo pounds so she could join the Army. 
At enlistm ent, she weighed 131, just three pounds under the Arm y’s m axim um for her 
4-feet-114 height. 
Bobbi, 27, of Van Nuys, Calif., weighed 325 and wore a size 56 dress only two years ago. Now she 

 w ears a size 8 
Her weight girt her dis­ charged from nursing school. 
Then she began studying to be a teacher but the I>os An­ geles school system said it wouldn't hire her because she was too heavy. 
“ I joined Weight W atchers that night," she said. 

Bobbi Weiss 

End the Tragedy of a 

Bobbi’s am bition to join the 
Army actually goes back IO years. But every tim e she visited the recruiting

 center, she was told to com e back when she' lost weight 
“ I always knew she could do it. I adm ire her tenacity and her courage,” said Sgt. Jake Hay­ ward, the Van Nuys recruiter. 
“ My father was in the Army during World War 
II and I have a very patriotic feeling for my country," Bobbi said in explaining her determ i­ nation to be a soldier.

 where called ’Naplis.” I knew they had to have been referring to 
Annapolis, Maryland. 
So I felt now that I had to ti7 to see if I could find what ship had sailed to Annapolis from the 
G ambia River, with her hum an cargo including “ the A frican," who would later insist that “ Kin- tay" was his nam e, after his m as­ sa John Waller had given him the nam e "Toby." 
I needed to determ ine a tim e around which to focus search for this ship. Months earlier, in the village of Juffure, the griot had timed Kunta Kinte’s capture with 
“ about the tim e the King’s sol­ diers cam e." 
Returning to London, midway during a second week of search­ ing in records of m ovem ent as­ signm ents for 
British m ilitary units during the 176os, I finally found that "K ing’s soldiers" had to refer to a unit called “ Colonel 
O’H are’s forces." 
The unit was sent from London in 1767 to guard the then British operated Fort Ja m es Slave Fort in the G am bia River. The griot had been so correct that I felt em ­ barrassed that, in effect, I had been checking behind him. 
At Lloyds of London I went through weeks of seemingly end­ less searching in an effort to iso­ late and then pin down a specific slave ship on a specific voyage, from within cartons upon cartons of slave-ship triangular voyages among 
England. 
Africa, and 
America. 
Along with m y frustration, the more a rage grew within me the more I perceived to what degree the slave trade, in its tim e, was regarded by m ost of its partici­ pants simply as another m ajor in­ dustry. 
Many records seemed never to have been opened after their original storage; apparently no one had felt occasion to go through them. 
In the seventh week, one after­ noon about two-thirty, 
I was studying the 
1,o23rd sheet of slave-ship records. A wide rectan­ gular sheet, it recorded the G am ­ bia River entrances and exits of some thirty ships during the years 
1766 and 1767. Moving down the list, my eyes reached ship No 18. and autom atically scanned across its various data heading entries. 
On July 5. 1767—the year “ the 
King’s soldiers cam e"—a ship nam ed lA>rd Ligonier, her captain a Thomas E. Davies, had sailed from the G am bia River, her des­ tination Annapolis. . . . 
I flew back to Washington with­ out ever returning to my hotel. I taxied to the Library of Congress, ordered a book and there it was. confirmation! 
The I^ord Ligonier had cleared Annapolis’ customs on Septem ber 29, 1767 

Renting a car, napolis. I went to the 

 published around the first week of 
October 
1767. 
I was halfway through the October I issue of the 
M aryland G azette when I saw the advertisem ent: 
“JUST IMPORTED, In the ship 
Lord Ligonier, Capt. Davies, from the River G am bia, in Africa, and to be sold by the subscribers, in 
Annapolis, for cash, or good bills of exchange on Wednesday the 7th of October next, 
A Cargo of 
CHOICE 
HEALTHY 
SLAVES. 
The said ship will take tobacco to 
London on liberty at 6s. Sterling per ton." The advertisem ent was signed by John Ridout and Daniel of St. Thos. Jenifer. 
The 1766-67 docum ent compiled at Jam es Fort in the G am bia Riv­ er had included that the Lord Li­ gonier had sailed with 14o slaves in her hold 

I searched to find a record of the ship’s cargo listed upon her arrival in Annapolis—and found it, the following inventory, in old­ fashioned script: 
“ 3,265 
‘ele­ phants teeth,’ as ivory tusks were called; 3,7oo pounds of beeswax; 
8oo pounds of raw cotton; 32 ounces of Gam bian gold; and 98 
‘Negroes.’ Her loss of 42 Africans en route, was average for slaving voyages." 
I realized by this tim e that 
G randm a, Aunt Liz, Aunt Plus, and Cousin G eorgia also had been griots in their own ways. My note­ books contained their centuries- old story that our African had been sold to “ M assa John Wall­ er,” who had given him the nam e 
"Toby.” 
During his fourth escape effort, when cornered he had wounded with a rock one of the pair of pro­ fessional slave-catchers who caught him, and they had cut his foot off. "M assa John’s brother. 
Dr William W aller,” had saved the slave’s life, then indignant at the m aim ing, had bought him from his brother. 
I dared to hope there might ac­ tually exist some kind of record. 

 to An­ a r) land 

*1 know they’re all watching* 

I went to Richmond, Virginia, whereafter poring through m icro­ filmed legal deeds, I found a leng­ thy deed dated Septem ber 5, 1763, in which John W aller and his wife 
Ann traasferred to William W aller land and goods, including 24o acres of farm land . . and then on the second page, “ and also one 
Negro man slave nam ed Toby." 
My God! The old stories were right I had traced my roots. 
I think now that not only are 
G randm a. Cousin G eorgia, and those other ladies 
“ up there watchin ," but so are all of the others: Kunta, and Bell; Kizzy; 
Chicken 
George and 
M atilda, 
Tom and Irene; G randpa Will 
Palm er, 
Bertha, 
Mama, and 
Dad . . .

TOP PSYCHICS LIFESAVING DIET 
BECOMES A 
COOKBOOK 

By,CHRISTINA KIRK 

AN AMAZING diet prescribed more than 5o years ago by psychic Edgar Cayce can save your life, a dietary expert once near death has told THE STAR. 
Inspired by her recovery, Marceline A. Newton has written The 
New Life Cookbook (Donning F>ress, $6 95). It contains recipes and menus based on Cayce s nutrition­ al philosophy. 
Cayce, who died in 1945, diag­ nosed illnesses and prescribed cures for people whose names were given to him while he was in a self induced hypnotic state. 
All the “ Sleeping Prophet’’ said in this state was recorded and preserved. Mrs. 
Newton based her book on nutrition sections of these Cayce “ readings” now on file at the Association for Re­ search and Enlightment (ARE) in 
Virginia Beach, Va. 
She has served her culinary creations to thousands as food service manager of the hotel owned by ARE, a foundation de­ voted to Cayce’s teachings and headed by his son Hugh Lynn 
| Cayce. 
At 26, Mrs. Newton was hospi­ talized for treatm ent of blood clots and high cholesterol which threatened her life. 
“They took blood clots the size of an egg from my lungs,” she 

Marceline A. Newton, above, has written a cookbook based on teachings of psychic Edgar Cayce, left, whose dietary rules she credits with saving her life. 
The Sleeping Prophet and his redpes 

 told THE STAR. “ One passed through my heart. I headed for 
ARE as soon as I was released.” 
. 
She followed the Cayce diet to 
■the letter—natural foods only, no 
( 

^alcohol, no cigarettes, no sugar or white bread. And she not only re­ covered but was able to stop tak­ ing an anti coagulant medication doctors had said she would need for the rest of her life. 
Mrs. Newton explained the life­ saving Cayce dietary laws. 
“ Basically, he recommended a balance of 8o per cent alkahne- forrning to 2o pier cent acid-form- ing foods,” she said. 
"For example, this would mean four vegetables to one protein and one starch. Of the vegetable ypes, one below-ground to two ibove-ground and one leafy to one 
|x>d variety are suggested. 
“Citrus fruits combined with grains, coffee with milk and neavy starch-protem combina­ tions cause over-acidity. Sweet or tined fruits are better combined with starches than with proteins.” 
The adjacent box includes a omplete list of acid and alkaline oods. 
“ In general, you need propor- ionately more alkaline foods be­ cause your body uses more of 
IM-se foods. You also need the roughage in high-fiber alkaline vegetables,” Mrs. Newton said. 
Acid forming foods have an equally valuable role in mainlam- ng good health, Mrs. 
Newton 
(aid. 
They give you your protein id vitamin A and several other ypes of vitamins and m inerals.” 
“Animal fat, for lastance, is the inly source of vitamin B-12 which everyone must have. A lack of B 
2 in the diet can cause brain iamage that cannot be reversed 
[hat s why vegetarians take B-12 upplements or force themselves o eat a little seafood.” 

HERE is a selection of recipes, based on Edgar Cayce’s nutri­ tion teachings, from Marceline 
A. Newton’s new cookbook: 

SWEET POTATO PUDDING 

SIX cups fresh mashed sweet potatoes, 2 tsp. cinnamon, I tsp powdered mace, 2 tsp. nutmeg, 
I Vi cups shredded coconut, I cup clover honey, 6 eggs, Mb cups peanut oil. 
Mix all ingredients and bake 
35o degrees, about 4o minutes, in a greased pan.

THE FORMULA 

ALKALINE MAKERS: 8o% 

FRUITS: Apples, apricots, berries, dates, figs (unsulphured),grape fruit, honey, lemons, limes, oranges, peaches, pears, pineapples, raisins, small pumes. Avoid plums, cranberries and large prunes 
VEGETABLES: Asparagus, beets, cabbage, carob, carrots, cauli­ flower, celery, eggplant, green peas, kohlrabi, lettuce, mushrooms, olives (ripe), onions, oyster plant, parsnips, radishes, rutabaga, spinach, sprouts, string beans, sweet potatoes, tomatoes, turnips. 
Avoid dried peas, beans and lentils; also rhubarb. 
MILK: All forms; buttermilk, clabber, sour milk, cottage cheese, cheese 
ACID MAKERS: 2o% 

ANIMAL FATS AND VEGETABLE OILS: Large prunes, plums, cranberries, rhubarb. 
ALL CEREAL GRAINS and other such products, as, bread, break­ fast foods, etc., rolled oats, corn flakes, corn meal mush, polished rice, etc. Brown rice is less acid forming. 
ALL HIGH STARCH AND PROTEIN FOODS: White sugar, syrups made from white sugar. Starchy foods in combination with fruits or proteins are acid combinations and should be avoided. 
NUTS: Peanuts, English walnuts, pecans, filberts, coconut 
LEGUMES: Dried beans, dried peas, lentils. 
MEATS: Beef, pork, lamb, veal. 
POULTRY: Chicken, turkey, duck, goose, guinea hen, game. 
VISCERAL MEATS. Heart, brains, kidney, liver, sweetbreads, thy­ mus. 
EGG WHITES. Yolks are not acid forming. 

ZABAGLIONE 
SIX egg yolks, 6 tbsp, brown sugar or honey. 4 cup Marsala wine, 4 tsp. salt, Va tsp. ground mace or nutmeg. 
Arrange double boiler so wa­ ter in bottom does not touch top section. Combine ingredients in top section. Cook over simmer­ ing water, beating constantly with a portable beater until mix­ ture is thick and light. It will swell to about 3 or 4 times its or­ iginal volume. Avoid overcook­ ing, or the mixture may curdle. 
Serve warm- 

CHESTNUT SOUP 
TWO lb. chestnuts, 3 tbsp, but­ ter, I large sliced onion, 2 small sliced carrots, I stalk sliced cel­ ery, 4 to 5 cups chicken stock, I tbsp, chopped parsley, a pinch thyme, I bay leaf, a pinch nut­ meg, I cup cream. 
Make small slit in top of each nut and place in a well greased pan in a 375 degree oven 12 to 15 minutes to loosen both outer and inner skin. Remove both skins and reserve nutmeat. Melt but­ ter and add onion, carrots, and celery. Mix well over gentle heat before adding chestnuts. 
Cover pan, and cook 3 to 4 min­ utes, snaking pan occasionally. 
Add stock, herbs, and seasoning, and simmer for 2o to 3o minutes, or until the chestnuts and vege­ tables are tender. 
/ Remove bay leaf; put soup in­ to electric blender and blend un­ til smooth, or put through a fine food mill. Return to pan and re­ heat soup. Season to taste Add the cream just before serving. 
CREOLE FILLETS 
ONE cup chopped onion, I cup chopped green pepper, 4 cups canned tomatoes, 3 tbsp, oil, I or 
2 bay leaves, 14 tsp salt, dash of cayenne, 2 lb. halibut fillets, 
I tsp. pepper. 
Saute onion, green pepper, and garlic in hot oil until tender. 
Add tomatoes, bay leaf, salt, and dash cayenne; simmer 15 minutes. Place fish in baking dish. Sprinkle with I tsp pepper. er fish. 
Pour tomato mixture over 
Bake at 35o degrees about minutes or until tender.

Cayce’s Menu 

Herb tea or Sanka with 2 meals each day.

BREAKFAST: 
Fresh yogurt 
2 blueberries, shirred eggs with cheese, whole wheat toast, orange juice with little lemon juice. 
LUNCH: Egg Foo Young, brown rice, sauted Chinese 
Vegetables, ginger bread, orange peel tea. 
DINNER: Tomato juice, broiled salm­ on steaks, sauteed cabbage, lima bean casserole, whole wheat bread, sweet potato pudding.

BREAKFAST: Fresh yogurt, granola with dried fruit, non-fat milk, pineap­ ple juice with a little lime juice. 
LUNCH: len til Soup ll, dandelion sal­ ad with garlic dressing, summer squash pie, whole wheat bread, peach cream. 
DINNER: Chestnut soup, cucumber mousse, roast goose, cauliflower, corn on the cob, applesauce bread, sour cream ginger bread.

Fresh yogurt with fresh strawberries, hot buckwheat pancakes with honey or natural maple syrup, baked apples, crisp bacon. 
LUNCH: Cream salmon soup, spinach with cottage cheese dressing, golden broiled chicken, baked carrots, sau­ teed zucchini, soybean bread, carob cake. 
DINNER: 
Vegetable cream soup, chicroy crown salad with bleu cheese dressing, soybean patties. Scripture 
Bread, strawberry natural ice cream.

DINNER: 
Artichoke soup, peaches and cream salad. Creole Fillets, baked brown rice or 
Bulgur, brussels sprouts, chopped fresh spinach, poppy seed bread or whole wheat bread, 
Scripture Cake. 
FRIDAY 
BREAKFAST: Fresh yogurt, poached eggs on whole wheat English muffins, bacon slices, stewed prunes or figs. 
LUNCH: Carrot soup, avocado salad with avocado dressing, lamb casser­ ole, baked beets, apricot nut bread, honey nut ice cream . 
DINNER: Onion soup, roast turkey with herb dressing, stewed tomatoes, fresh collard greens or summer squash, rice muffins, blackberry pie. 
SATURDAY 
BREAKFAST: Fresh yogurt, oatmeal made with steel-cut oats, non-fat milk with honey, orange juice with a little lemon juice. 
LUNCH: Puree of turnip soup, cran­ berry-orange molded salad, turkey, asparagus, lemon-bread, apple dum­ plings. 
DINNER: Potato Peel Soup, cucum- ber-vogurt salad, chicken or veal mousse, fresh vegetables, whole wheat bread, granola cookies.

SEI SOLUTION PAGE 19 

FOR A working stiff who pays an obscene chunk of his paycheck to support the welfare system, the following story is hard to believe. 

It deals with Mrs. Linda Henderson, an attractive young mother of two children in Stoughton. Wis. In 1973, she was involved in a car accident that resulted in her getting, two years later, $3o,9oo in damages. 
She spent the year previous to her award on welfare. After lawyers fees and expenses were paid, Mrs. Henderson cleared almost $15,ooo from her settlement. 
She told the Dane County Social Services Department of her windfall, and because sin* was no longer destitute, she was declared ineligible for welfare. Fair enough. 
But then the great bureaucratic minds told her not to worry. All she would have to do to get back on welfare was spend all her money. 
So in six weeks. Mrs. Henderson told Dane County Judge Archie 
Simonson, she went on a spending spree and bought a car. a stereo, furniture and a $259 grandfather clock. This bill came to $14,5oo. 
Broke again, she went back on welfare. 
Judge Simonson is one of those oldtimers who believes not only in the law but in justice. When Mrs. H enderson cam e before him in an abandomnment hearing and he heard her story of being TOLI) to go on her spending spree, the old judge gasped. 
“ Here is a case,” the judge told me on the telephone, “ where an agency actually encourages a woman to beat the system. 
“There was no attem pt to preserve Mrs. Henderson’s assets. They did nothing to supervise this windfall. They told her to go out and squander the money in a frivolous spending spree.” 
Now there is no cause to criticize Mrs. Henderson. She has a rough time looking after two children with no support. 
And ifs obvious that $15,ooo would not keep her and her two children more than one year. 
But for an agency to actually ENCOURAGE her to go broke to get back on welfare should be a hanging offense. 
When Judge Simonson critized the Dane County Welfare Board, you would have thought he was using obscene language by the response he got. 
Jerry McCartney of the Dane County Social Services Department attacked Simonson in a letter charging the judge had “ misplaced the responsibility for the laws which you as a judge must enfor ce." 
McCartney countered that his mob did not encourage Mrs. Henderson to spend the money. 
“ In this case.” said McCartney, “ when asked if the accident settle­ ment money could be used for the purchase of household goods, the answer was yes. To state otherwise would have been incorrect.” 
Come now Mr. McCartney, don't give us this “ rules and rules" stuff. 
Nobody argues with the hardship of Mrs. Henderson but to make no attempt to preserve that loot is doggone irresponsible. 
Other m em bers of McCartney’s departm ent claimed the judge was just looking for publicity. 
‘I don’t choose to publicize the case, it s just that I don’t want to sweep it under the rug." the judge replied. 
You’re damn right, judge! 

Ifs worth the money just to stay warm 

FEDERAL Energy Administrator John F. O’Learv puts shivers up my spine. 

Realistically, he says, this country, particularly the freezing North­ east. must lace the fact of using less heat. “ A 65-degree heating high will become a fact in tile future," he savs. 
I just do not believe that will all the billions we are wasting in useless programs, we can’t keep ourselves comfortable. 
How much is the government spending to research good. reliable and cheap solar heating? 
How much is being spent to convert to atomic power** lf we have to bite the bullet, so bt* it. But if we are just saying “ Freeze your tail oft and hope for a warm er winter next year" — without really looking hard at what we can do about the problem - then I wish the good Mr. O'U'ary would go jump in the lake 

 and only 2oo living 
EUREKA, Nev., has nine cemeteries residents. 
The cemeteries are left over from the days when Eureka was a silver mining center and had more than 1o,ooo people. Those were the 187os and 188os and people flocked to Eureka seeking 
Al J I |/ a_a fortunes. There are a Jewish 
(JIO WW&ST t o w n cemetery, a Catholic eeme- 
WW WI w w ww mw tory, a Chinese cemetery, an 
Indian cemetery, the Odd Fel­ lows Cemetery, the City and 
County 
Cemetery, and the 
Masonic 
Cemetery, 
Theres even a cemetery exclusively for the rich and one for those who were plagued with contagious diseases while living. 

“It’s weird." said Marcia Elliott, head of Eureka s historical society. “ It was almost as if they were afraid the contagious dis ease would spread from grave to grave after death."

Reward your kids with love, not lollipops 
Diet #4: 
For special situations 

MORE OF DR. ATKINS’ SUPERENERGY DIET PLAN 

Dr. Robert Atkins 
USE this diet when you want to incre&tt the quality of your met but cannot make drastic changes in your physiolo­ gy and metabolism. 
Dr. Atkins’ Diet #4 is four simple rules 
• Avoid sugar 

• Avoid starch and all refined (tour. 
• Avoid caffeine. alcohol and 

• Take your vitamins and minerals as outlined in tile find part of this 
STAR series 

I STRONGLY suggest that anybody who is raising children begin as early as possible to get them on a diet that can promote their future health. 
When a tiny infant is bom, its first food if it is lucky will be the nourishing milk from its mother’s warm, comfort­ ing breasts. 
But if it’s like most newborns in the United States, its first meal will be water with—of all things—sugar in it! 
Right from the first day the infant is conditioned to de­ velop a taste for sugar. 
Then, to continue to imprint his brain with the desire for sugar, as a toddler he is rewarded with lollipops at the barbershop or doctor’s office (of all places), is given cook­ ies or candy for being good, and is brought sweets as a symbol of love from grandma and grandpa. 
Claudine longer to be 
» 
• ^1 
M 
. a 
. .. boom is answer shuttled out of hate to fl *** town for her jail term 

BY BOB BOYD 
CLAUDINE Longet will never serve a day of her jail term in the town that hates her. 
THE STAR has learned that plans are almost complete to make Miss Longet serve her time in a jail which offers her more protection than the tiny Pitkin Coun­ ty Jail in Aspen. 
It is the Garfield County Jail in Glen­ wood Springs, just 4o miles from the ski and sin capital of the nation's jet set. 
Sources in Colorado say an agreement has already been worked out between Pit­ kin County Sheriff Dick Kienast and Gar­ field County Sheriff Edward E. Hogue. 
Miss l/Miget would normally have had to serve her month-long sentence in the re­ cently-remodeled Pitkin County Jail be­ cause the crime and trial took place in 
Aspen 
Sheriff Kienast told THE STAR: “ My jail simply is not equipped to handle a woman pre-oner of this type. 
“ I have contacted other, larger jails in the same Colorado judicial district to see if orb’ of them will take Miss Longet and all the problems which po with her off my hands ” 
Sheriff Hogue acknowledged he has been in contact with Sheriff Kienast regarding the much-celebrated offender. 
“We have a larger, much more modem jail than Dick Kienast does," he said. “ We are willing to take tier in. I expect she will be doing her tune with us It would be more difficult for anyone to break in here than at Pitkin It is bigger and more secure ” 
Aspen residents made their feelings about Miss lx>nget clear before, during and 

 the Aspen jail and no back-up is imme­ diately available. The Garfield County 
Jail, meanwhile, has a resident jailer, his wife and an assistant jailer. 
It also has c'osed-circuit television moni­ tors and sheriff’s deputies who provide round-the-clock surveillance. Sheriff Kien­ ast had already macle tentative plans to house Miss Longet in his jail before he went looking for a different facility. He ar­ ranged for her meals to be catered by Hol­ iday Inn and had contracted for renovation of the cell she would be held in. 
But some people say he feared a group of Sabich’s friends, enraged by what they felt was a light sentence Miss Longet re­ ceived, might break into the Aspen jail and harm her. One source in Aspen explained to THE STAR that the town could not take another scandal such as might be created by any violent action. 
A break-in at Garfield County Jail is highly unlikely, though. 
Sheriff Hogue said the cell Miss Longet will probably occupy has no windows 
The jail normally houses five to 2o pris­ oners, the sheriff added, about three of them women. It has two cells used specifi­ cally to house women prisoners—one for adults and the other for juvenile offenders. 

Miss Longet will probably share her cell with one or two other women prisoners. 
Sheriff Hogue said. 
• Claudine’s ex-husband, 
Andy 
Wil­ liams, is planning soon to announce his en­ gagement to 21-year-old Laurie Wright, 
THE STAR learned this week. 

TWO housewives have had their business prayers answered — thanks to a boom in second-hand church furniture. 

Doris Cecil and Regina Finnen- ger of Richardson. Tex., went into the antique business a year ago to break the dull routine of house­ work. They began buying up pews, hymn racks and other church items, and quickly discov­ ered they were in big demand from homeowners, posh restau­ rants . . . and even saloons. 

The pews sell for around $35. 
The two women go on antique- hunting expeditions every week­ end in a red pick-up truck, touring churches in rural communities. 

“ We both wanted to break the middle-age hum-drums,” said 
Mrs. Finnenger. “ I can’t type and 
I can’t take shorthand, but I can haul pews.” 

They say their biggest selling items are hymn racks, which fit onto the back of pews to hold hymnals and prayer books. Now they are finding their ways into homes as spice racks, towel hold­ ers and tissue dispensers. 

 after the trial for the shooting death of Spi­ der Sabich, the ski star and her lover. 

The vast majority of the town s residents expressed haired for die French-bom ex­ wife of singer Andy Williams. 
Sabtch was a folk hero in Aspen and had many friend., 
Following Miss longers conviction, she was sentenced to 3o days jail and two years probation 
She was instructed lo pick any time be­ tween now and September to serve the term 
Pitkin Jail recently underwent a $1o ooo renovation but many feel it still lacks the kind of protection Miss Longet might need in a town filled with her avowed enemies.

WIFE THANKS 
COPS FOR TE S T 

WHEN Nita Jean Hayden, a 28-year-old 
California housewife, was arrested for suspicion of driving under the influence of alcohol, it was the best thing that could have happened 
A chemical test al the San Diego 
County Jail. Calif., stiowed no trace of alcohol—but it did reveal porphyry, a rare blood disease that can be fatal if untreated 
A sheriff’s department spokesman said Mrs. Hayden, who was released without being charged, never knew she had porphyria 

Pot solesmon aims to sit on city council 

CRAZY Carl the flower peddler lists some unique qualifications in his bid for public office in Austin, 
Tex. 
He has served four days in the city jail, five in the county jail and ten semesters at the Univer­ sity of Texas, nine of them on scholastic probation. 
Crazy Carl — real name Carl 
Hickerson — is running for city council. He says his previous jobs included artist’s model, gogo dancer and a marijuana salesman in Holland 
Carl, 32. balances carnations in tin? palms of his hands at his streetcomer sales stand 
His platform for the campaign includes stopping city growth, arming policemen with tranquiliz­ er dart guns and creating nude swimming areas 

By the time he is a teenager, he has such a taste for sweets that his diet may largely made made up of soda pop, cakes, candy bars, and pizza with a little milk thrown in. 
If you want to do your child a big favor, keep him off sugar. 
Reward him with something else, such as love to sustain him, a steak and fresh salad to nourish him. or a baseball or tennis racket to exercise him. 
Until recently severe malnutrition in children was thought to exist only beyond the borders of the United 
States. Now we know differently. 
A huge number of our children have deficiences in vi­ tamins and minerals, even protein. 
The deficiencies often cause apathy in school, growth re­ tardation and vulnerability to illness. 
Hundreds of thousands of children make their way listlessly, or perhaps belligerently, through school, failing to reach their inherent potential be­ cause teachers, physicians and parents do not rec­ ognize the nutritional cause of their lack of energy. 
Even starting with the prenatal diet we fail them. 
In the United States, an estimated 35,ooo newborn babies die every year because their mothers are un­ dernourished during pregnancy. 
And about 12o,ooo babies are bom malnourished every year. 
What can you do as a parent? 
You should start before the child is even bom. 
Before you get pregnant, get to your ideal weight. If you are more than IO pounds overweight, go on Diet 
#1 described in the first part of this STAR series. 
Pre-pregnancy fatness definitely means a greater chance of complications during pregnancy. 
If you are reducing on Diet #1 and become preg­ nant, stop trying to lose, and adjust your diet to al­ low you to achieve close to the ideal weight gain of 
24 pounds total during pregnancy. 
Even more important, get enough vitamins and minerals. Vitamins E, C, folic acid, pyridoxin, and the mineral zinc are most important 
The single moot important thing you can do after the baby is bom is to breast feed your baby. 
Babies who feed on breast milk, rather than for­ mula, have been shown to have fewer allergies, fewer colds and other l'lnesses, miss fewer days in school, and have fewc* doctor visits. 
Also, be sure to give him vitamin and mineral supplements that contain adequate amounts of all nutrients. 
When your child is ready to start on solids, for heaven’s sake don’t add sugar. 
Even later, do not overstuff your children. Help stamp out the clean-the-plate club. 
Just be sure that when your child is hungry you have plenty of nourishing food for him to eat, so he doesn’t fill up on junk. 
If your child has attacks of paleness, limpness, inattention, staring into space, listlessness, head­ aches. lack of coordination, stupor, convulsions, rapid heartbeats, or sweating, the chances are very great he may have low blood sugar (hypogly­ cemia). 
Those of us who have seen hypoglycemia in chil­ dren know what deep disturbances low blood sugar can cause. 
A child may be subject to anxiety attacks, may run away, may be aggressive and destructive, or he may go to the other direction and be lethargic, apathetic, unable to become interested in anything, with few friends and a poor school record. 
How many times have you seen a mother stand­ ing in the check-out line with a shopping cart piled high with soft drinks, cookies, candies, donuts, and sugar-coated cereal, and right behind her is a screaming, uncontrollable child 
Is it only coincidence? Or is it really a graphic example of what we are doing to our children with the foods we are giving them'’

BOOZE STUDY IS MAKING 
THE SWINE 

A TEAM of hard drinkers are making pigs of themselves over booze — all in the name of science. 
They're going the whole hog in a study of alcoholism by slurping their way through a quart of vod­ ka a day. 
The dedicated drunks are all . pigs. 

Scientists at the University of 
Missouri hooe that the four-footed tipplers will help them discover more about the effect of alcohol on humans. 
Said one researcher: “ Drunk or sober, pigs are a lot like people in

PIGS OUT OF 

 ways that are social as well as physical.’' 
The animals prefer screwdriv­ ers — and there are signs that their heavy drinking is already creating problems apart from hangovers. 
In the test, each pig is given all the alcohol it wants three tim es a day By measuring a pig’s drink mg, its feed and behavior, scien­ tists detect changes in its social altitudes. 
The report said pigs are ideal for human alcohol tests. They have sim ilar cardiovascular and respiratory systems, about the same nutritional needs and show similar social behavior. 

A FAULTY HEART IS 
FOUND IN DUMMY’ 

WHEN a California fire fighter. 
Cain* Steven Lujan, volunteered to be a ' dummy’’ he had no idea it might save his life. 
IaiJan, of Stockton, calif , at­ tended a rescue training equip­ ment session at his fire depart­ ment and allowed paramedics to use him to demonstrate an elec­ trocardiograph machine. 
When Lujan was hooked up to the machine, it detected an irreg­ ularity in his heartbeat. He was rushed to a hospital and under­ went treatment for an unsuspect­ ed heart ailment.

BEST FOOD BUYS 
FOR MARCH 

By CATHY ROUNDS 
HOT meals are still in order this month and pork promises to be one of the best buys. 
Shop around for bargains. 
Here are the other best buys for 
March: 
I: Broccoli is still economical at 69 to 79 cents a bunch. 
2: Carrots go a long way at 25 to 35 cents a bunch. 
3: Cucumbers are a steal at 15 cents each 
I: Iceberg lettuce ranges from 
59 to 79 cents a head. 
5: Yellow onions are a hot item between 29 and 39 cents a pound 
6: Eggplant should be about 39 cents a pound 
7: Potatoes from the Eastern 
Shore range from IO to 15 cents a pound. 
8: Sweet potatoes will sell for about 29 cents a pound. 
9: Butternut squash will go for 
19 cents a pound. 
IO: Vineripe tomatoes will sell for about 59 cents a pound. ll: lied Delicious Apples are a best buy at 39 cents a pound.

2o centi. 
13: Grapefruit, like all citrus fruit, was affected by the Florida freeze. They’ll sell for about 15 to 
3o cents, depending on size. 

14: Oranges out of California will go for 5 to 15 cents each. 
15: Pears will be retailing for about 35 cents a pound. 
16: Pick up a dozen large eggs for anywhere from 79 to 89 cents. 
17: Whole leg of lamb will re­ tail for about $1 59 a pound.

Campbell's vote 

HOW does singer Glenn Campbell feel about Jimmy Carter as Presi­ dent? He’s a southerner, too.— 

I HEAR that singer Tom Jones is so homesick for his native Wales that he has installed a British- style pub in his new Beverly Hills mansion and has English beer specially shipped over. If this is true, why doesn't he just live in 
Wales?—Augusto Rodriguez, Al- burquerque, N.M. 

THE reason is taxes. Back in the green, green grass of home, Tom was shelling out an incredible 96 
B 
?r cent of his earnings to the ritish taxman. Despite the fabu­ lous money he makes, that didn’t leave much for an occasional glass (rf his favorite ale. 

Mickey 
Kentrotti, 
Knoxville, 
Tenn. 

GLENN doesn’t like Carter and didn t vote for him. He doesn’t fee! Carter is enough of a realist to tackle the nation’s pressing problems. But for the most part, 
Glenn says he's not very political­ ly-minded. 

Roots reruns 

I 
SO much enjoyed watching 
Roots on TV, but a couple of nights I had to work late and missed the show. Are there any plans to rerun the series so I can catch up on what I missed?—San­ dra Messinger, Watertown, N.Y. 
YES hut not for at least a year. 
ABC television, which screened 
Roots, says1 that so many people watched the series that it would bt' pointless lo rerun it any soon­ er. However, there is enough un­ used material from Alex Haley’s blockbuster book to make another series. And network chiefs are se­ riously considering this possibili­ ty.

BATTLE REPORT 

Bulletin: Wild Turkey, 
Kentucky’s finest 
Bourbon, is winning with Bourbon drinkers— even invading the home of the Tennessee whiskies. 

This is tile latest report from the front in the war between Kentucky and Tennessee. 
It all began with the introduction of a new 
86.8-Proof Wild Turkey Bourbon—at a price and prexif comparable to 
Tennessee’s leading sour mash whiskies. (Good whiskies, of course, but not quite Wild Turkey.) 
This means that you no longer have to settle for anvilling less than Wild 
I in key.acknow ledged to be the King of all Ken­ tucky Bourbons. 

New Wild Turkey victorious! 

Since the start of this new "War Between the States!’Wild Turkey, at both 1o1 and 86.8 
Proof, has Iven winning over thousands of 
Bourbon drinkers. Our correspondents have even reported a daring invasion of enemy territory: some distinguished citizens of Tennessee have quietly switched to Wild Turkey Bourbon. 
I he new 86.8-Proof Wild Turkey, priced only slightly higher than the leading Tennessee whiskies, stands right next to 1o1-Proof Wild Turkey in your liquor store. Its the only Bourbon that deserves to Iv on the same shelf. 

Bourbon drinkers are the winners. 

We invite you to take sides in the battle. 
Make a comparison between Wild Turkey from Kentucky (in the proof of your choice) 

 and the leading whiskies from Tennessee. 
You'll find this is a "War Between the States" in w hich you, the Bourbon drinker, come out the w inner. All you need to join the invading forces is an appreciation of great Bourbon. 
And a Kiltie of Wild Turkey.
